DOC.HEAD: Rebels Begin Major Offensive in Section of Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with seven grafs to UPDATE with appeal in Wahington for temporary peacekeeping force, details, edits thereafter to conform. Picks up graf 4 pvs, `Earlier Thursday...'
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following is partly based on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia, among them Associated Press correspondent Michael Goldsmith.

Rebels on Thursday launched what appeared to be a major offensive about three miles from the center of the capital, witnesses said. Travelers from the Loganville section of Monrovia reported large numbers of government casualties lying around the railway terminal. One witness reported a truck loaded with government wounded rushing toward the city's only working hospital. The fighting was near the Bong iron ore mines' railway and the terminal itself, witnesses said. The railroad station, three miles from downtown Monrovia, was the closest the rebels have yet come to the city center after a 10-day lull in the 7-month-old civil war. In Washington, meanwhile, the foreign minister of Liberia and other prominent Liberians appealed Thursday to the United States for a temporary U.S. peacekeeping force to help prevent further bloodshed. Foreign Minister J. Rudolph Johnson, Washington Ambassador Eugenia Wordsworth-Stevenson and eight other Liberians wrote President Bush that they expect the ``resignation and departure from Liberia'' of President Samuel Doe ``and the establishment of an interim government.'' The letter proposed ``a limited U.S. force be provided, on the invitation of that interim government, to play an initial peacekeeping role'' in the vicinity of Monrovia. The appeal did not explain how the resignation and departure of Doe would be carried out. Earlier Thursday, rebels ambushed government troops trying to take a key intersection on the road to the country's international airport, forcing them to retreat, military sources said. Sixty government troops were sent to recapture Red Light Junction, six miles from downtown, the military sources said. Forces of the rebel National Patriotic Front of Liberia ambushed the troops, killing three. The junction is on the main road to the international airport at Robertsfield, held by the rebels for several weeks. Journalists who tried to visit the area were turned back by government troops one mile from the fighting. The rebels have brought heavy artillery to the north of Monrovia, Liberian security sources said. Armored cars and artillery have been seen moving south from Kakata toward Monrovia in the past two days, the sources said. Rebel control of parts of Lofa County, north of Monrovia, has led government troops to turn back refugees fleeing the capital, witnesses said. In the capital, food shortages and the fear of a rebel attack increased. Up to 1,300 Lebanese living in Liberia, primarily small businessmen and their families, have registered with the Lebanese Embassy to leave aboard a ship en route from Tunisia. ``We don't feel any direct threat but there's a great deal of looting taking place, not only businesses but houses as well,'' Lebanese Ambassador Michel Bitard said. The ship has been chartered by the Arab League. In neighboring Sierra Leone, a rebel leader, Thomas Woewiyu, said late Thursday that no progress was made in talks between intermediaries of the two sides. He said the rebels would not compromise on their demand that Doe resign before a formal cease-fire can be reached. The rebels, led by former Doe aide Charles Taylor, advanced to the fringes of Monrovia before their advance was halted. Taylor accuses Doe's government of corruption, inefficiency and human rights abuses. Doe has agreed not to seek re-election but has so far refused to leave the country. He has a force of 500 Israeli-trained troops defending his heavily fortified residence in Monrovia. Random killings have been reported on both sides as the insurgency has degenerated into tribal warfare. Most rebels come from the Gio and Mano tribes, while government supporters are mostly Krahns and Mandingos. Doe is a Krahn. Hundreds of people are streaming out of the city in the direction of Sierra Leone. Taylor's forces have opened the highway from the surrounded capital to the Sierra Leone border to allow refugees to flee, military sources reported. Most of Monrovia has been without power for two weeks, and water supplies have been cut. Residents have been forced to collect rain water and forage for food as supplies dwindle and soldiers loot what is left. Doe took power in a violent 1980 coup that ousted the incumbents, descendants of American immigrants who historically monopolized power and discriminated against indigenous Liberians. Liberia was founded in the 19th century by freed slaves from the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Menninger's Thoughts on Mental Illness, Freud, War
With PM-Obit-Menninger
DOC.TEXT: Here are selected quotations from the books and speeches of Dr. Karl Menninger, the psychiatrist who died Wednesday:

``Gone forever is the notion that the mentally ill person is an exception. It is now accepted that most people have some degree of mental illness at some time, and many of them have a degree of mental illness most of the time. This should not surprise anyone, for do not most of us have some physical illness some of the time and some of us much of the time?'' _ from his book, ``The Vital Balance.''

``We all look for miracles in the relief of our distress, but psychotherapy lays no claim to miracle performings. All it can do is to present certain aspects of the truth and by this, as we are often reminded, some are set free. Loneliness may disappear as you know yourself better and become aware of conflicts within that prevent you from getting close to others.'' _ from the book ``Man Against Himself.''

``(Sigmund) Freud's great courage led him to look honestly at the evil in man's nature. Freud persisted in his researches to the bottom of the jar, and there he found hope. He discerned that love is stronger than hate, that, hence, for all its core of malignancy the nature of man can be transformed through the nurture and dispersion of love. In this way, the destructiveness can be transcended.'' _ from the book, ``The Vital Balance.''

``The vast majority of ailing minds never see psychiatrists and never will, and many of them never should. But the principles of psychiatry should be applied all the same. Sometimes they can be self-administered; sometimes, a friend will turn the trick. The family doctor or clergyman often does it. And, sometimes a book will do it.'' _ from the book, ``The Human Mind.''

``Most people never see the awfulness of war; they only read about it or hear about it from reporters or survivors. War continues to be a deputized human activity, some citizens are sent out to do what the total citizenry couldn't and wouldn't do. The rest of us stand, or sit, a long way off, and watch or listen occasionally.'' _ from the book ``Whatever Became of Sin?''

``To many of us, the war in Vietnam seems a prime example of self-destructiveness, one more likely to spread communism and other evils than to control them. Youths are being sacrificed. Money, materials, the country, our own national image and, in many places, our goodwill are being destroyed in a continuing, pointless and _ as it seems to many of us _ futile military bonfire.'' _ Testimony before the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee, June 19, 1969.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Catches Government Flat-Footed, Slow To Respond
DOC.TEXT: The earthquake that struck the main Philippines island of Luzon caught President Corazon Aquino's government ill-prepared for disaster and dramatized her administration's organizational shortcomings. Three days after the quake, which measured 7.7 on the Richter scale, the government has no comprehensive picture of the extent of damage and casualties. Relief operations appear centered in areas such as Baguio, where media focused its attention. ``The immediate task is the rescue and feeding of survivors,'' said the newspaper Malaya. ``Three days after the earthquake, the abject failure of the government on this score is appalling.'' Even in Baguio, a lack of coordination among government agencies was clear. The Office of Civil Defense counted 82 people dead in Baguio, 110 miles to the north. Chief of Staff Gen. Renato de Villa said 91 were killed, and the Red Cross estimated 118 dead. Poor communications forced local officials to use private radio and television stations to alert Manila of the devastation and appeal for help. Today, Rep. Simeon Garcia told radio station DZMM that about 100 motorists stranded by the quake were at his home in Nueva Ecija province waiting for help promised by the army days ago but as yet unreceived. ``Clearly, if we hope to reduce the number of deaths and the extent of the damage wrought by natural calamities, we as a nation must give priority to disaster monitoring, prediction and preparedness,'' the Philippine Daily Inquirer said today. Problems of communication and coordination emerged within moments of the Monday's quake, when Mrs. Aquino dispatched officials to survey the damage in Manila and ordered the military to ferry stranded commuters. Few military trucks appeared on the streets, and tens of thousands of commuters wound up walking home. That typified the government's reaction to the crisis: good intentions but neither the resources nor the organization to implement them. The temblor struck about a half hour before government offices normally close for the day. Most state employees simply went home early, fearing another quake. Soon afterward, the presidential press office announced that the government was studying the extent of damage. It was only after commercial radio stations broadcast damage reports from their provincial affiliates that the government began to respond. First reports focused on Cabanatuan City, 60 miles north of Manila, where a six-story school collapsed, trapping hundreds of students and teachers. On Tuesday, Mrs. Aquino flew to the city for her first view of the relief operations. Reporters who traveled with her said she was angry over what she saw. ``Who's in charge?'' aides quoted her as asking local officials. ``The rescue operation is so slow. Why?'' Only after returning from Cabanatuan did she declare a ``state of calamity'' in affected provinces. On Wednesday, she hurredly added La Union province to the list after radio and television stations broadcast first reports of massive destruction there. The government maintains a system of regional disaster coordinating councils which are supposed to marshal the nation's resources to cope with calamities. But the regional committees lack money, equipment, communications and trained rescue personnel. Cabanatuan Mayor Honorato Perez used commercial radio stations to beg Manila for cranes, jackhammers and trained rescuers. The government sent troops to Cabanatuan, but they were no better trained in rescue operations than the civilian volunteers. In Baguio, where the temblor damaged the airport runway and cut land routes into the city, stocks of emergency supplies and equipment were insufficient to mount an effective relief operation. Even if local authorities were better equipped, the highly centralized government structure tends to inhibit grass-roots initiatives. The simplest request often turns into a bureaucratic nightmare. For example, as the Philippines appealed to the world for help, the Office of the President produced ``implementing guidelines'' for receiving foreign donations: ``Interested overseas donors or their local representatives are to submit written offers to the presidential management staff. Once notified of the government's acceptance, the donors are to submit a bill of lading or airway bill for clearance by the presidential management staff, which in turn transmits all necessary documents to the Bureau of Customs. The Bureau of Customs, initiates the processing of import documents and releases the donation to the Office of the President. Finally, the Office of the President turns over the donations to the designated recipient agency or organization.'' Such disorderly responses are sadly routine nearly every time disaster strikes. During typhoons, comprehensive reports of damage and casualties often take days _ or even weeks _ to reach Manila, delaying the shipment of food, medicine and supplies to the victims. The lack of coordination seems all the more surprising because an average of 20 typhoons strike the Philippines annually. Some routinely kill hundreds. ``From the moment the ... quake ... struck until this very moment, we have had to play it by ear and improvise,'' said The Manila Times. ``Many of the hundreds of people killed in this latest disaster could have been spared if only we had all taken to heart the deadly serious business of disaster preparedness.''

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Throws Out Bologna Bombing Convictions
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court has thrown out the convictions of four people sentenced to life in prison two years ago for a 1980 bombing that killed 85 people at Bologna's train station. It said after 15 days of deliberation that defendants Valerio Fioravanti; his wife, Francesca Mambro; Massimiliano Fachini; and Sergio Picciafuoco had not committed the crime. State-run RAI-TV described Wednesday's verdict as a ``shock.'' The Aug. 2, 1980, bombing was one of the worst terrorist actions in Europe. The court also reversed the convictions for slander of Licio Gelli, former grandmaster of the secret Propaganda Due (P-2) Masonic lodge, and financier Francesco Pazienza, sentenced to 10 years in prison in the first trial. Prosecutors described the Bologna attack as a neo-Fascist plot to undermine Italy's democracy, and the four convicted of planting the bomb as right-wing terrorists. P-2 allegedly backed right-wing terrorism as a means of throwing the country into confusion to pave the way for an eventual rightist dictatorship. The slander charges were based on a 1981 incident when explosives similar to those kind used at Bologna were found on a train at Bologna's station. Prosecutors claimed Gelli and Pazienza misled investigators by claiming the explosives were linked to other people.

DOC.HEAD: Argentina Gets First British Ambassador in Eight Years
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Menem has accepted the credentials of the first British ambassador to Argentina since the two countries went to war over the Falklands in 1982. The war ``is an issue of the past,'' the new ambassador, Humphrey Maud, told reporters covering the ceremony Wednesday at the president's official residence in the suburban town of Olivos. ``Now we can think of the future.'' Ownership of the Falklands ``is not an issue for discussion at this moment,'' said the 56-year-old career diplomat. Britains rules the islands off Argentina's southern coast, but Argentina claims them. Relations with Britain were cut after Argentina invaded the islands in April 1982. Argentina surrendered after 74 days of fighting that killed about 1,200 people. Relations thawed only after Menem's inauguration in July 1989. He proposed that the question of who rules the islands be set aside for the immediate future.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Hero Removed From Bulgarian Mausoleum, Cremated
DOC.TEXT: The remains of former Bulgarian leader Georgi Dimitrov, revered as national hero during Communist rule, have been removed from a downtown mausoleum and cremated, the state news agency BTA reported. It said Wednesday that the cremation took place in the presence of relatives, suggesting the procedure took place overnight to avoid publicity. Despite longtime official veneration, Dimitrov has become increasingly unpopular, particularly in Sofia, where the non-communist opposition Union of Democratic Forces emerged as clear winner in last month's multiparty elections. The mausoleum that had held Dimitrov's remains has been guarded around the clock by two soldiers in traditional Balkan-style dress uniform, equipped with bayonet-topped rifles. A leading figure in the international Communist movement, Dimitrov was acquitted in a trial in late 1933 in which he was charged with complicity in the fire that destroyed the German Reichstag (Parliament) building. Historians say the arson was a Nazi provocation. In 1946, Dimitrov became leader of the Bulgarian Communist Party and also headed the government until his death in 1949. Under Dimitrov, non-Communist opposition parties were either disbanded or merged in a Communist-dominated mass organization.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Decision on Germany Will Boost Arms Control Talks: Experts
DOC.TEXT: Moscow's decision to drop its objection to NATO membership for a reunited Germany likely will put East-West arms control negotiations back on track, administration officials and private arms control experts say. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told reporters Wednesday that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's concession on German participation in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization ``removed the last roadblock'' to clinching two landmark arms control agreements. Cheney referred to 23-nation negotiations to sharply reduce the number of conventional arms _ tanks, troops and aircraft _ in Europe, and to U.S.-Soviet talks on slashing strategic, or long-range, nuclear missiles by one-third. The conventional arms negotiations have been bogged down for months by several key disputes, including NATO resistance to a Soviet demand that the West German government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl accept a numerical limit on its armed forces. Kohl had said his country must not be singled out for such limits. But at his summit with Gorbachev on Monday, Kohl agreed that a united Germany would have no more than 370,000 troops in its army, 45 percent fewer than the present combined strength of the East and West Germany's armed forces. In return, Gorbachev withdrew his objections to permitting a united Germany in NATO, whose leaders pledged at a meeting in London on July 6 to relax their military readiness and reduce their reliance on nuclear arms. Settlement of the German troop strength question is likely to give new life to the East-West conventional arms negotiations under way in Vienna, arms control analysts said Wednesday. ``It definitely helps,'' said David Shorr, associate director of the British American Security Information Council, a research group based in Washington and London. Shorr said the Kohl-Gorbachev deal made it increasingly likely that the Vienna negotiators will meet their unofficial deadline of completing a treaty in time for a 35-nation summit to be held in Paris on Nov. 19 to ratify a new political relationship among the United States, the Soviet Union, Canada and all of Europe. Some obstacles to a conventional forces agreement are yet to be worked out. They include: _Whether a limit should be placed on individual nations' shares of the total number of troops allowed in Europe. _Which kinds of aircraft should be counted in the military equipment limits. _Under what circumstances a country would be allowed to convert military equipment to civilian use. _How often each country would have to permit inspections of conventional arms on its soil. The Kohl-Gorbachev agreement appeared to have little direct application to the U.S.-Soviet Strategic Arms Reduction Talks to reduce long-range nuclear missile arsenals, although Cheney mentioned START in saying arms agreements were now more likely. Cheney did not elaborate on this point, but analysts said they believed resolution of the last remaining major political obstacle to German reunification would make it easier for Washington and Moscow to resolve their START disagreements. ``The national security bureaucracies in both countries ... have been preoccupied with these questions of German reunification,'' said Dunbar Lockwood, who studies START issues for the private Arms Control Association. ``Now they can start thinking about arms control again.'' Three major issues remain unresolved in the START talks, which Gorbachev and President Bush have said they hope to complete by the end of this year. The stickiest issue is how far the Soviets will be allowed to go in modernizing their SS-18 intercontinental ballistic missiles, which form the backbone of the Soviet nuclear arsenal. The two other unresolved matters are limits on the Soviet Backfire bomber and Soviet efforts to restrict U.S. sales of strategic nuclear systems to Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Spy Jonathan Pollard Serves Wife With Divorce Papers
DOC.TEXT: Convicted spy Jonathan Pollard served his wife with divorce papers Wednesday at the hospital where she is being treated for a gastrointestinal disorder, Mrs. Pollard's attorney said. In seeking the divorce, Jonathan Pollard cited ``irreconcilable differences'' and the fact that he has not lived with his wife since his arrest in November 1985, said Mark Baker, attorney for Anne Henderson Pollard. Pollard, a 36-year old former Navy analyst, was sentenced to life in prison in June 1987 after he pleaded guilty to providing Israel with documents about the military strengths of countries in the Middle East. Mrs. Pollard, 30, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to receive embezzled government property and being an accessory to possession of national defense documents. She was sentenced to five years in prison and was released this year after serving 40 months. Pollard is serving time in a maximum security federal prison in Marion, Ill. He is in solitary confinement and knows only what his father and sister tell him about his wife's actions, Baker said. Mrs. Pollard has worked to secure her husband's freedom since her release, including trying to get the Israeli prime minister to intervene on Pollard's behalf. In a news release, Mrs. Pollard said she believed her husband's action Wednesday was the result of five years of solitary confinement, manipulation by his parents, his sister and political forces. ``I am deeply grieved by this action as I had hoped to have children,'' she said. Her husband's Washington lawyer, Judith Barnett, denied that relatives influenced his decision. ``This 100 percent Jonathan's action,'' she told The Washington Post. The couple lived together for ``several years'' before being married in August 1985, said Baker. They were together as a married couple for just three months before they were arrested in November, and haven't seen each other since they were sentenced more than four years ago, Baker said. Mrs. Pollard spent a good portion of her jail term in prison hospitals undergoing treatment for the gastrointestinal ailment. She is currently being treated at Mount Sinai Hospital but hopes to leave for an Israeli hospital where she can receive treatment at no cost, her attorney said. The attorney said the divorce papers were served on Mrs. Pollard by a process server disguised as a hospital employee.

DOC.HEAD: Impossible for Gorbachev to Block NATO Membership For Germany ^AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The collapse of pro-Soviet regimes in Eastern Europe and the impending union of the two Germanys gave President Mikhail S. Gorbachev little choice but to abandon his opposition to the new Germany's membership in NATO. ``I don't think he had any bargaining chips left, once East Germany collapsed,'' said Adam Ulam, a professor at Harvard University. ``It was obvious that he would have to accept anything that was offered. What West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl offered was $3 billion in credits to ease an increasingly desperate Soviet debt problem, plus continued German support for Western aid to the Soviet Union. Gorbachev's about-face on the issue of German membership in NATO also came after he won promises that Germany would cut its armed forces and that the Atlantic alliance would adjust its policies to the shrinking Soviet threat. ``We got what we wanted, too. It was a step-by-step process, with concessions on both sides,'' a senior Soviet diplomat said. A senior Western diplomat, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said ``Gorbachev got what he needed in London, and from Kohl.'' Both diplomats were referring to statement issued after a recent North Atlantic Treaty Organization meeting in London that the Western alliance was shifting from a military to a political alliance, as requested by the Kremlin, and to an agreement by Kohl to reduce the German armed forces. Soviet media, however, still have not reported in detail Gorbachev's meeting with Kohl on Monday, when the Soviet leader dropped months of ardent opposition to German membership in NATO. The Soviet Union lost 20 million people during World War II, and memories of the Nazi invasion still are bitter. In his meeting with Gorbachev, Kohl agreed that in the next three or four years the united German army will be cut to 370,000 troops. The two Germanys now have about 600,000 men under arms, 480,000 of them in the West. Kohl and Gorbachev also agreed: _ To begin negotiations on the complete withdrawal of Soviet soldiers from what is now East Germany. The approximately 380,000 soldiers should be withdrawn in three to four years, they said. _ That no NATO forces will be stationed in what is now East Germany as long as Soviet forces are there. German soldiers not integrated into the NATO command may be stationed there as soon as unification is completed. _ The rights of the four victorious World War II powers _ France, the United States, Britain, and the Soviet Union _ will cease immediately upon unification. But Western forces may remain in Berlin as long as Soviet soldiers stay in any part of the country. Poland, which had sought guarantees that Germany would not seek to regain land that once was German but has been Polish since the war, this week said it was satisified with the arrangement. Ulam, reached by telephone in Cambridge, Mass., said he would ``be surprised if the Soviets did not have their forces out of Germany within a year,'' shortly after the expected unification of Germany. Most Soviet troops in Eastern Europe are stationed in East Germany and have been in a precarious position since the Communist government in Poland fell and the hard-line East German regime collapsed last year. The Soviet Union, where people can wait a decade or more for housing, will have a difficult time absorbing the returning soldiers and their families. Kohl has agreed to foot part of the bill for keeping Soviet troops in East Germany, Moscow-based diplomats said, but pressure is expected to mount to use the money for the civilian economy. Kohl, along with President Francois Mitterrand of France, also has been pushing for Western aid to support Gorbachev's reform efforts. President Bush has balked at the French and German proposal, urging the allies to wait until the Soviets move more decisively from a planned to a market economy. Western diplomats in Moscow say Bush wants the International Monetary Fund to impose on the Soviets the same type of stringent economic conditions it would on needy developing nations. ``That way, it would be an economic condition, and not a political condition,'' said a Western diplomat. Gorbachev might find that formula convenient, as well. ``He has given in on almost everything,'' said Ulam. ``His political skills are great, but they consist largely of being able to swim with the current.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Bryan Brumley has been covering Soviet affairs for The Associated Press since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Panel Calls on Senator to be Denounced, Pay Restitution
LaserPhotos WX6-7
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Ethics Committee is calling on the full Senate to denounce Sen. Dave Durenberger, who is agreeing to pay up to $124,000 in restitution for his financial misconduct. The Minnesota Republican said he would repay the money as a ``tangible sign of my regret.'' The committee unanimously approved a resolution Wednesday saying that Durenberger ``knowingly and willingly'' violated Senate rules through financial dealings that were ``unequivocally unethical.'' Leaders of the Senate say they hope to put the recommendations to a vote by the time Congress leaves for its August recess. Senate historians say that denouncing or censuring a colleague is the most serious disciplinary action senators can take short of expulsion. The committee said Durenberger should reimburse the Senate $29,050 plus interest for improper payments on his Minneapolis condominium and give to charity about $95,000 that he collected in excess speaking fees. That amount would be reduced by whatever taxes he has already paid on the income. Durenberger has incurred more than $500,000 in legal fees. The panel referred its findings, without making any recommendations, to Senate Republicans, who could strip Durenberger of any positions of party responsibility. The findings also will go to federal agencies, including the Justice Department and Federal Election Commission. ``Of all the thousands of words that have been written or spoken during 23 months of investigation, news coverage and commentary, only three are appropriate today: I am sorry,'' Durenberger said in a brief statement after committee leaders announced their recommendation. ``I accept the committee's direction to make restitution as a tangible sign of my regret and continuing commitment to the people of Minnesota,'' he said. Durenberger's popularity has plummeted in Minnesota, according to opinion polls, but he has said he will not resign. He does not face re-election until 1994. State Democratic Chairman Todd Otis called on Durenberger to resign, saying he had ``brought a black cloud to Minnesota politics.'' The Ethics Committee found the following violations, which it said ``brought the Senate into dishonor and disrepute'': _A book contract with Piranha Press that Durenberger used to collect $100,000 in speaking fees over the Senate's limits on honoraria. _Real estate transactions involving his Minneapolis condominium so he could obtain reimbursement from the Senate for staying there. _His failure to report the receipt of travel expenses in connection with his book-promotion appearances and trips to the Boston area, where he made speeches to coincide with visits to his marriage counselor. _His discussions about the condominium with the trustee of his blind trust. _Acceptance of free limousine service in violation of Senate gift limits. _Conversion of a $5,000 campaign contribution to personal use. The committee's vice chairman, Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., told reporters that the panel found a pattern of misconduct in his book and condominium deals. ``Taken in their totality, the committee decided unanimously that they merited, regretfully, this severe punishment,'' Rudman said. Although the matters were referred to the FEC and Justice Department, Rudman said there was ``no finding of criminality anywhere in the report.'' Rudman and committee Chairman Howell Heflin, D-Ala., said they intentionally did not recommend any specific action to Republican senators. ``That is not a proper matter for the Ethics Committee. That is a Republican Party matter,'' Rudman said. ``They can read. They can look at the sanction.'' The committee's report should go to the Senate in seven to 10 days. The panel still has before it a series of loans that Durenberger received from a St. Paul, Minn., bank at favorable terms during the 1980s, but Rudman said he did not expect the panel to pursue the matter. The committee has been embroiled in a dispute with the Minnesota Commerce Department over records of an investigation of the Commercial State Bank. Durenberger and bank officials have denied he received special treatment.

DOC.HEAD: Vitamin A Effective Treatment for Severe Measles
With PM-Sex Trigger, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: All children with severe measles should take vitamin A supplements to sharply reduce the risk of complications and death, a study published today concludes. Measles kills about 2 million children worldwide each year and leaves many more blind or afflicted with lung disease. The research conducted in South Africa found that the vitamin reduced the death rate by more than half and the duration of pneumonia, diarrhea and hospitalization by about one-third. The results ``indicate a remarkable protective effect of vitamin A in severe measles,'' the doctors wrote. Earlier research has turned up circumstantial evidence that the vitamin helps. As a result, the World Health Organization three years ago recommended that young measles victims take vitamin supplements anywhere that vitamin A deficiency is common or that more than 1 percent of measles cases are fatal. The study published in today's New England Journal of Medicine was conducted by Drs. Gregory D. Hussey and Max Klein of the University of Cape Town. The study randomly assigned 120 milligrams of vitamin A or identical-looking placeboes to 189 children who were hospitalized because of measles complicated by pneumonia, diarrhea or croup. Of the 12 children who died, 10 were taking placeboes. ``All children with severe measles should be given vitamin A supplements, whether or not they are thought to have a nutritional deficiency,'' the doctors wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Man Says AWOL Soldiers Trying to Go to Heaven
DOC.TEXT: Six soldiers who left their Army intelligence post in West Germany told a man who sold them a van that they were Christian fundamentalists who believed their road to heaven led through a Florida beach. ``They believed the Rapture was going to happen in Pensacola Beach in October,'' William Grant of Morristown, Tenn., told the Pensacola News Journal in an interview published Wednesday. Many fundamentalist Christians predicte believers will be swept to heaven seven years before the end of the world in the Rapture. The five men and a woman, members of the 701st Military Intelligence Brigade at Augsburg, West Germany, were arrested in this Pensacola suburb over the weekend. They are being held at Fort Benning, Ga., pending a counterintelligence investigation. All six held top-secret security clearances and were intelligence analysts assigned to intercepting, identifying and exploiting foreign communications, Padilla said. Maj. Joe Padilla, an Army spokesman at the Pentagon, Wednesday retracted an earlier statement that the six were members of a group known as ``The End of the World.'' ``There is no group as far as we can tell,'' Padilla said. The term ``End of the World'' was written on doodles found in the room of one of the soldiers in Germany, Padilla said. He said he didn't know why they left Germany or anything about their religious beliefs. Said Grant: ``I don't want to talk down to anyone about anyone else's religious beliefs, but they said if they weren't on the beach in Pensacola they wouldn't go to heaven.'' He said he sold the them a van July 7 in Morristown, near Jefferson City, the hometown of one of the soldiers, Specialist Kenneth Beason, 26. Gulf Breeze police stopped the van and its driver, Pfc. Michael Huckstaedt, 19 of Farson, Wyo., because the taillights weren't working. A computer records checked showed that he and the other five were wanted by military authorities. Gulf Breeze police identified the others as Pfc. Kris Perlock, 20, of Osceola, Wis.; Pfc. William Setterberg, 20, of Pittsburgh; Specialist Vance Davis, 25, of Valley Center, Kan., and Sgt. Annette Eccleston, 22, whose hometown was unknown. The Army has yet to file any charges against the six, but Padilla said he doubted they would be going back to their unit in Germany. He said they are accused of being absent without authorization which could lead to formal charges of being absent without leave or desertion. All six held top-secret security clearances and were intelligence analysts assigned to intercepting, identifying and exploiting foreign communications, Padilla said.

DOC.HEAD: Magnetic Levitating Trains Possible in U.S. by End of Decade
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Non-polluting, 300-mile-an-hour magnetic levitating trains could be whisking passengers between some U.S. cities before the end of the 1990s, the federal railroad administrator predicts. The country may be entering a new era in ground transportation, with projects already beginning in California, Nevada and Florida, said Gilbert E. Carmichael, who heads the Federal Railroad Administration. Several other areas also are looking into magnetic levitation or high-speed rail, he said. Carmichael, in an interview Wednesday, discussed an FRA report completed this week that said magnetically levitated trains are feasible for the United States, even without significant federal funding. No magnetic train yet carries paying passengers anywhere in the world, but Carmichael said he recently rode on a 19-mile test system in West Germany. ``You feel it levitate, and then you feel it swoosh you along without any vibration,'' Carmichael said. ``Cows were grazing underneath when we passed over, and they didn't even look up.'' Because the trains float on a powerful magnetic field, there is no friction or wear and far less energy is consumed. It takes about as much electricity to run the German system as to air-condition it, Carmichael said. Fares would be about 20 percent below air fares and, on some shorter routes, 40 percent lower, the administrator said. The report said the United States _ which started and then abandoned the ``maglev'' technology two decades ago _ still could create a better system than those being tested in West Germany and Japan. The system is intended as an alternative to short-distance air travel. Carmichael said he expects at least two maglev routes to be in operation before the end of the decade, along with two or three high-speed rail systems. But he said the decision must be made whether to invest $1 billion to develop a new U.S. system, to get into a joint venture with a foreign system that already is well along or simply to buy either the German or Japanese products. Maglev technologies are in competition with high-speed rail, which is a fast steel-on-steel system, and with Swedish tilting trains that allow faster service on existing tracks without passengers feeling the curves. Carmichael said all of the systems can be used, along with tilt-rotor aircraft, in a multi-modal approach to preventing transportation gridlock next century. The FRA study said any heavily traveled route of 100 to 500 miles holds potential for the magnetic system. A system of up to 2,600 miles could be built for about $55 billion with tax-free bonds and no public financing, assuming rights-of-way are available at little or no cost, the report said. An advisory panel to the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works recommended a year ago that the government allocate $750 million over six years to develop, test and demonstrate several maglev routes. The federal budget so far calls for only $12 million to further study the potential for high-speed trains. But there are signs of growing support from industry. On Monday, a partnership headed by Bechtel International Inc. of San Francisco put up $500,000 for the right to bid on a $5 billion maglev train between Southern California and Las Vegas. Planners hope to have the train running in seven years. Business and government leaders in Pittsburgh are moving to make the city a technological and manufacturing base for the German-developed maglev system, while developing a 19-mile demonstration run between downtown Pittsburgh and the city's international airport. Another privately funded project in Florida is planning to build a 14-mile German system by 1994 to link Orlando Airport to Disney World and other nearby resorts. Carmichael said at least two companies are bidding to develop a high-speed rail system in Texas to link Houston and Dallas. The FRA's report envisions five maglev systems that eventually could be tied together. They include a giant web in the Northeast running from Boston to Richmond, Va., and going as far west as Minneapolis and St. Louis. In the South, the floating trains would zip from Nashville down to Miami and from Charlotte across to Birmingham. The California-Nevada system eventually would link Reno, Sacramento, San Francisco and San Diego to the already planned Los Angeles-Las Vegas line. A Northwest system would tie Portland to Seattle, and the Dallas-Houston line would connect to San Antonio and Austin.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Should Go Further on Cambodia, Some in Congress Say
With PM-Cambodia Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's decision to end recognition of rebels battling Cambodia's Vietnamese-backed government _ and open talks with Vietnam instead _ is being welcomed in Congress, but some lawmakers say it doesn't go far enough. ``U.S. policy requires overhaul and intensive effort, not tinkering and fleeting attention,'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said Wednesday. He called past policy ``a dismal failure.'' Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, called for an end to covert U.S. aid to Cambodia's rebel coalition. Secretary of State James A. Baker III announced Wednesday in Paris that the United States would withdraw its support for the three-party coalition that is fighting the Vietnamese-installed Phnom Penh government. That coalition includes the Khmer Rouge, which was responsible for more than 1 million deaths during its reign in Cambodia in the 1970s. Baker also said the United States would begin a dialogue with Vietnam about the need for a political solution to Cambodia's civil war, and would allow U.S.-sponsored humanitarian programs _ including $5 million in aid for children _ to go forward inside Cambodia. The moves were seen as adjustments to a new reality in Cambodia, where a potential takeover by the brutal Khmer Rouge has become a larger worry than fears of encroachment by neighboring communist Vietnam. But in a letter to Mitchell, Baker also said ``it is more important than ever to provide U.S. materiel support for the non-communist resistance, who should not be undercut just as they seek to provide the only non-communist alternative in free elections.'' The United States now provides $7 million openly to the resistance for non-lethal supplies and an additional $13 million a year in covert military aid for the coalition, according to intelligence sources. Both payments are under attack in Congress, because while the aid ostensibly supports the coalition faction of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, critics say it at least indirectly helps the Khmer Rouge, which is the country's strongest military force. Several opponents of U.S. policy said continuing the aid was inconsistent with other moves by the administration. ``The administration has eliminated the rationale for their policy of support for the non-communist resistance, but on the other hand has increased its resolve to provide assistance. That's a contradiction,'' said Rep. Chester Atkins, D-Mass. Citing reports that the Khmer Rouge is gaining ground on the battlefield, Mitchell said: ``There is simply no excuse to delay additional action'' that would go beyond Baker's announcement. Among actions Mitchell sought was direct U.S. talks with the Phnom Penh government of Hun Sen, rather than his Vietnamese sponsors in Hanoi, who are in turn supported by the Soviet Union. And he said Bush should be more willing to apply pressure to China, the chief supporter of the Khmer Rouge, and to do so publicly. ``The Chinese leadership must be made to understand that it stands entirely alone in support of genocidal forces,'' he said. Boren did not directly refer to the covert military aid program that goes through his Intelligence Committee, but he said that all U.S. support for the resistance should be handled openly. ``Any future debate on our policy toward Cambodia should be in the Foreign Relations Committee, not in the Intelligence Committee,'' which meets behind closed doors, Boren said. The intelligence panel voted June 28 to cut off the covert aid program beginning Oct. 1. Boren said he assumed the policy shift is ``a signal that the administration would no longer be seeking any aid that could be even indirectly helpful to the Khmer Rouge.'' That will require the administration to shift its budget request to support humanitarian programs and democracy-building moves, he said. Under U.S. pressure, the United Nations has awarded a seat to the Cambodian resistance coalition and denied formal recognition to Hun Sen. Baker said the United States also was changing its policy toward the Cambodian U.N. seat.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Concerned, But Not Well Informed, About Children's Issues
DOC.NOTE: For release 10 a.m. EDT; time set by source
DOC.TEXT: American voters are concerned about children's issues and would be willing to support candidates and increased funding of programs to help them, according to a survey released today. However, the study said that translating voter concern into action has been lacking because ``public knowledge has yet to catch up to the reality of children's lives.'' A better-informed public ``may provide greater political momentum for enhanced public programs for children,'' said the study titled, ``Kids' Clout: Americans' Attitudes on Children's Issues.'' The study, published by the National Association of Children's Hospitals and Related Institutions, discusses how concern for children can influence voting behavior. The association found 60 percent of Americans believe the quality of children's lives ``has become worse over the past five years _ and more than one American in four believes that it has become much worse.'' Sixty-nine percent or two-thirds recognized that 20 percent or more children have no health insurance. But only 11 percent could differentiate Medicaid from Medicare as the government health program that serves poor children. However, when the confusion was cleared up, ``support for this program (Medicaid) ranks near the top of many Americans' spending priorities'' with 58 percent ranking it at 6 or higher on a scale of one to 10, with 10 being the highest priority. The study showed Americans also would be willing to pay increased taxes to pay for health insurance for poor children. ``A majority, 59 percent, would be willing to have their taxes raised the $100 per year it is estimated to cost to give all poor children health insurance,'' said the study. Further, 67 percent said they ``would be more likely to vote for a candidate who supported increased spending for children's programs, even if it meant an increase in their taxes.'' Both men and women favored more overall spending on children's programs but parents are more likely than non-parents to support increased spending on children's health. The study was the result of a June 9-17 telephone survey of 1,000 adults commissioned by the association. The margin of error was plus or minus 3.1 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: German Unification Will Affect U.S. Farm Exports
DOC.TEXT: The rejoining of East and West Germany will mean some changes for U.S. agricultural exporters, an Agriculture Department trade expert says. East Germany has imported up to one-fourth of its annual grain needs, said Steven Yoder of the department's Foreign Agricultural Service. Part of that has been U.S. corn and durum wheat for pasta, and sometimes some oilseeds. But when East Germany is united with West Germany and becomes a part of the European Economic Community, ``we're likely to lose those grain markets _ regardless of what happens to East German grain production,'' Yoder said. Yoder recently visited both East and West Germany for a firsthand look at farm production and markets. He was U.S. agricultural attache in East Germany during 1980-84. ``The other thing we've got to do is establish a strong presence for U.S. farm and food products in the East German marketplace before our competitors get it all sewn up,'' he said. Yoder said traders from West Germany and other Western European countries ``are moving into the market in a big way with consumer food products.'' The West Germans, or course, have a language bond with the East, Yoder noted. Some have lived in East Germany and can go back to renew contacts. ``Sure, the market is not without risk,'' Yoder said. ``There are no guarantees in such an unsettled situation. However, there are a lot of opportunities up for grabs, too.'' The main thing, he added, is that U.S. traders ``can't sit back and wait for everything relating to new-to-market food products to jell.'' Yoder's remarks were in the forthcoming August issue of AgExporter magazine published by the USDA agency. According to department export records, about $74.5 million worth of U.S. agricultural commodities, mostly grain, were exported to East Germany in calendar 1989. Sales to West Germany, by comparison, were about $1 billion. Yoder noted that East Germany is a small country with about 16 million people, but ``has many needs.'' West Germany's population is around 61 million. ``For example,'' he said, ``the East German diet has always been largely a meat-and-potatoes-and-bread affair. Milk and milk products, including cheese, also are available, although not up to the quality expected in the West. ``But supplies of fruits and vegetables are much less than desired. And there's a wide-open market for high-value processed products ranging from ketchup to ice cream.''

Exports of U.S. farm products declined seasonally in May to an estimated $3.26 billion but were still running ahead of a year earlier, according to Agriculture Department analysts. The May export estimate, which was down $145 million from April, dropped as the result of lower values for dairy products, wheat, rice, grain sorghum, animal feeds, soybeans and cotton. A monthly report by the department's Economic Research Service said Wednesday that those declines more than offset increases in May for corn, barley, live animals, meat, vegetable oils and horticultural products. For the first eight months of the fiscal year that began last Oct. 1, however, export values totaled about $28.5 billion, up 2 percent from the comparable period in 1988-89. Corn exports in May rose to 5.4 million metric tons valued at $667 million. The Soviet Union was the largest market, taking almost 1.5 million tons, with Japan second at 1.2 million tons. Other major corn markets in May included Mexico, South Korea and Taiwan. Wheat exports dropped for the second consecutive month to 1.9 million tons valued at about $294 million. Shipments to the Soviet Union declined sharply to 288,000 tons, ranking third behind China and Japan. Soybean exports in May plummeted 48 percent in volume from April to 621,000 tons valued at $148 million. That was the lowest monthly volume since last September, but officials said soybean shipments ``generally drop off in the second half of the fiscal year.'' Cotton shipments fell 20 percent in May to 128,000 tons, following a 26 percent drop in April, the report said. However, the export value increased to $1,628 per ton from $1,573 in April. The increase in the average cotton price was attributed to increased exports of higher-priced long-staple Pima cotton. ``Declining shipments to China, Taiwan, Thailand, Indonesia and the (European Economic Community) more than offset increases to Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Egypt,'' the report said.

Vegetable farmers are boosting production this summer, including both fresh market and processing crops, the Agriculture Department reports. The prospective acreage for seven selected fresh market vegetables in the summer season was estimated at 271,000 acres, up 4 percent from a year ago. Increases were reported Wednesday for carrots, celery, sweet corn, head lettuce and tomatoes. Decreases from a year ago were indicated for cauliflower, while broccoli was about the same. Plantings for the major vegetable crops for processing were estimated at 1.63 million acres, up 8 percent from last summer. Increases were indicated for sweet corn, cucumbers for pickles, green peas and tomatoes. The acreage for snap beans was reported down from a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: INS Changing System for Granting Asylum to Foreigners
DOC.TEXT: The United States is changing the system for granting asylum to foreigners, a move that might increase the number of requests it approves and remove political bias from the procedure. ``The regulations ... will ensure that those who seek the protection of this country encounter a fair and sensitive legal process,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in announcing the reform on Wednesday. Foreigners seeking asylum in the United States must be able to prove that, if they are returned to their homeland, they are likely to face persecution based on their political views, their race or religion. Asylum requests currently are handled at Immigration and Naturalization Service district offices by examiners who handle many kinds of immigration and visa applications. Under the new policy, effective Oct. 1, asylum requests will be handled by specialists in Washington. The INS will designate 70 to 90 examiners who will be trained in international law and in conditions existing around the world so they may better decide upon asylum requests, Commissioner Gene McNary said at a news conference. He said the INS also will open a documentation center that will have updated reports on conditions in various countries for examiners to use as reference. Supporters of the change say that by having its own documentation center, the INS will rely less on the State Department and thus may increase the number of asylum requests it approves. ``The State Department has infused the asylum process with foreign policy considerations, and the INS has been unable to rise above its law enforcement ethos in order to examine the claims fairly,'' said Arthur C. Helton, head of the refugee project of the Lawyers' Committee for Human Rights. The documentation center will draw on information about political conditions in foreign countries from a variety of sources, including Amnesty International and other human rights groups, Helton said. The new procedures probably will mean more asylum applications will be approved, he predicted. McNary said the number of asylum requests had increased from 19,000 in 1986 to a projected 65,000 for 1990. Of those requests, 28 percent are approved on the average every year, he said. About 85 percent of those seeking asylum in the United States are from Latin America. Most of the remainder are from Asia and Ireland. McNary said the INS did not know if the new system would increase or lower the approval rate. ``It will be a more accurate adjudication,'' he said. The system will cost between $7 million and $9 million a year and will be paid for mostly from fees the INS collects on various applications.

DOC.HEAD: Brando's Daughter Accused in Murder
DOC.TEXT: Marlon Brando's daughter, who fled to the South Pacific after refusing to testify against her brother in the murder of her 26-year-old boyfriend, has been charged with conspiracy in the killing. The victim, Dag Drollet, was shot to death May 16 at the actor's estate in the Santa Monica mountains near Los Angeles. The actor's son, 32-year-old Christian, is charged with the murder. Brando's 20-year-old daughter, Tarita Cheyenne, went to French Polynesia after refusing to testify against her brother, according to Deputy District Attorney Steven Barshop of Los Angeles. It was not immediately clear whether she would be extradited to the United States. Tarita Cheyenne Brando, a native of these South Pacific islands, is the daughter of Brando and his current wife, Tarita Teriipia, the Tahitian actress who played his love interest in the 1962 remake of ``Mutiny on the Bounty.'' Judge Max Catti on Tuesday accepted the charge of conspiracy against Brando's daughter, acting at the request of a lawyer for the victim's family. She was ordered not to leave French Polynesia. Barshop, who is prosecuting the case against Christian Brando, told a California judge on June 25 that he would attempt to introduce statements by Miss Brando as evidence against her half-brother in a hearing later this month. He said the statements were made in a June 12 interview with police. Miss Brando returned to French Polynesia eight months pregnant with the child of her slain boyfriend. She was in a Papeete hospital undergoing treatment for nervous exhaustion. Her father maintains a home in Tahiti. The actor was home at the time of the slaying, but he was elsewhere in the house and did not see it. His son reportedly told police that Drollet died during a struggle over a gun. Christian is the son of the actor and his first wife, Anna Kashfi. The couple was divorced in 1960. Their son was the subject of a bitter custody battle.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Seek to Bar S&L Figures From Hiding Gains
DOC.TEXT: Savings and loan defaulters could no longer protect their assets from government seizure by transferring them to a spouse or filing for bankruptcy, under a proposal by House Democrats. Unveiling the latest package in a flurry of proposals to answer mounting public discontent over the need for new taxes to address S&L losses, Democratic leaders said Wednesday they also want a bipartisan commission to search out the root causes of the crisis. They said their legislation would target people like Bill L. Walters, a former business associate of President Bush's son, Neil. Walters defaulted on $106 million in S&L loans and then purchased a $1.9 million home in Newport Bay, Calif., through a trust in his wife's name. ``There are no laws on the books that prevent that son of a gun from leading a fat life while the taxpayers are spending hundreds and hundreds of thousands of dollars because he got the money,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., the author of the new proposal. Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said Schumer's package would be included in an anti-crime bill he plans to bring to the House floor next week. Meanwhile, the Resolution Trust Corp. established by Congress last year to manage the thrift bailout, said it has referred about half of the 454 S&Ls seized by the government to the Justice Department for suspected criminal misconduct. James Dudine, the RTC's chief investigator, said Wednesday his agency estimates that 80 percent of those cases involve fraud and insider dealing and warrant ``major criminal investigations.'' Walters, according to government records, defaulted on a total of $106 million in six loans from the collapsed Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver. As a director of Silverado, Neil Bush voted to approve all of the loans to Walters after Walters invested $150,000 in Bush's oil exploration company and extended a $1.75 million line of credit to the president's son. Bush has denied any impropriety. The 12-member bipartisan study commission proposed by House Democrats would be structured along the lines of the Kerner Commission established after inner city riots in Detroit, Los Angeles, Washington, New York and other cities in 1968. While the Justice Department has opposed an independent commission, Schumer voiced optimism that the administration might go along with the idea to defuse the current wave of election-year sniping by Democrats and Republicans blaming each other for the S&L crisis. ``People want answers and the atmosphere in Congress has gotten kind of rancorous,'' he said. ``A commission could look into it and really get the answers to what happened. This is a big enough crisis _ like civil rights and the problems of the inner cities were _ to deserve that kind of thing.'' The Democratic bill also would make the concealment of an S&L's assets a federal offense and rewrite tax laws so that a defendant in a civil suit could not write off court-ordered restitutions as an income tax deduction. And it would prohibit banking executives from giving themselves so-called ``golden parachutes'' when they leave or change their jobs. The Senate toughened S&L sanctions as part of a crime bill it passed last week. It voted to establish lifetime sentences for ``S&L kingpins'' convicted of fraud in cases where the government is left covering millions of dollars in losses of federally insured deposits. The House bill creates new criminal offenses for concealing assets from government regulators or obstructing their investigations but leaves untouched the current maximum sentence of 30 years for S&L fraud. ``We tried to be as tough as possible without going off the deep end just for show,'' said Schumer, predicting the package will win strong bipartisan support.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Tracking Down Gene That Determines People's Sex
DOC.TEXT: Scientists are closing in on the tiny bit of genetic code that makes a man a man and a woman a woman. In a report published today, a British team announced the discovery of a gene they call ``sex-determining region Y'' and said it may be the long-sought sex trigger. If biology works the way many scientists believe, a single gene rules sexual development in the womb. When an embryo inherits this gene from its parents, it grows to be a boy. When it doesn't, it becomes a girl. The search for this gene has been the subject of intense international competition between scientists. A team from the Imperial Cancer Research Fund in London took the latest step. But their chief rival, a group from the Whitehead Institute in Cambridge, Mass., speculates that two or more genes lie at the heart of the differences between the sexes. In 1987, Whitehead's Dr. David Page announced the discovery of a gene he called ZFY. He and many others believed it probably was the sex trigger. But last December, the London group proved that ZFY was not the crucial gene _ at least not by itself. In the British journal Nature, the London team said today their gene, which they call SRY for short, is ``proposed to be a candidate for the elusive testis-determining gene.'' ``The evidence is good so far, but I wouldn't stick my neck out until we have the rest of the data in,'' said Dr. Andrew Sinclair, the lead author of the report. If Page's scenario is correct, his gene and the London group's discovery could turn out to be partners in triggering sexual differences. Like Page, the London group pinpointed its gene by a process of elimination. Everyone is born with 46 strings of genes called chromosomes. Two of these, called X and Y, are the sex chromosomes. Women have two X's, while men have an X and a Y. Scientists reason that the gene that makes men different from women must be located someplace on the Y. Scientists have concentrated on apparent exceptions to the rule, so-called XX males. To all outward appearances, these people usually are physically normal men. But their cells contain the double X's of women. Through a genetic mix-up, one of their X's contains a tiny fragment of Y, enough to make them men. The London group narrowed the search to a narrow stretch of the Y chromosome in which they have located one gene. They cite several reasons to think that this is, indeed, the long-sought sex gene: _While men have the gene, women do not possess anything like it. _The gene actively makes a protein in men's sex organs but not in other parts of the body. _Other kinds of male mammals have similar genes. _In mice, the gene is turned on at precisely the moment in development when sexual differences appear. Critics of this work point out that some of the XX males who carry just the newly discovered gene have some, but not all, male sexual features. To be completely male, they argue that people need at least one more gene, perhaps Page's ZFY. ``This is a very important piece of work. There is no doubt about that,'' Page said. ``It's just a question of whether we really know the number of genes on the Y that are involved in sex determination.'' Adds Dr. Robert Erickson of the University of Michigan, ``My hunch is that it takes ZFY to finish the job off.'' Dr. Peter Goodfellow, senior scientist of the London group, said he is open-minded about this genetics puzzle. While the critics may be right, he said another possible explanation is that his SRY gene is the true sex trigger, but it didn't work properly in the partially masculinized people he studied. To settle the question, the London team says two more pieces of research will be necessary. One will be to check XY females _ women who appear genetically to be men _ to see if they are missing SRY. The other will be to implant the gene into female mouse embryos to see if this makes them become males.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Find Haven at Voice of America Station
DOC.TEXT: About 11,000 refugees have found a haven at the Voice of America radio station in Liberia, but despite fighting in the area the transmitter still relays the U.S. government's programs to Africa. Should the facility be damaged by fighting, VOA will lose about 40 percent of its broadcasts to Africa, especially to the eastern and southern parts of the continent, VOA Deputy Director Robert Coonrod said Wednesday. The area around the facility near the town of Careysburg, about 20 miles from the capital Monrovia, fell to the rebels last month in fighting against the troops of President Samuel Doe. The station relays 20 hours of VOA programs in Swahili, English, French and Portuguese each day. The programs are usually transmitted by satellite to Monrovia and then by cable to Careysburg. But with the recent failure of the earth station in Monrovia, Coonrod said, the broadcasts are now sent to Careysburg by shortwave radio from the United States. In recent weeks, fighting has broken out around the station between the forces of Charles Taylor, a former government official seeking to topple Doe, and renegades who broke away from Taylor's army. Coonrod said the station has been run by 100 Liberians since the last of the American staff was evacuated about four weeks ago. ``They're doing a remarkable job, keeping it going under incredible circumstances,'' said Coonrod. ``We're amazed.'' He said the technicians are performing basic maintenance jobs on the transmitter, getting instructions by shortwave radio from their boss in Monrovia, which is still under government control. Taylor has been sending refugees to the VOA facility because he considers it a neutral site, and also because the station has its own water sources that the refugees are using, Coonrod said. The refugees are camping out on the grounds of the station, which is located on a 2,000-acre jungle clearing, and two Liberian doctors are treating the ill and injured, he said. The VOA buildings have been secured with metal bars on the windows, but the staff has instructions to abandon the facility and save themselves if fighting spreads to the grounds of the facility, Coonrod said. The VOA station, which started operating in 1954, is one of several U.S. government facilities in Liberia, a country founded by freed American slaves in the 1820s. Most official Americans have been evacuated from Liberia since Taylor's insurgency began last December. It has since escalated into a tribal conflict, pitting members of the Gio and Mano tribes against government supporters who are mostly Krahns and Mandingos. Doe took power in a violent 1980 coup that ousted the American descendants, who historically monopolized power and discriminated against indigenous Liberians.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Links Trade Benefits to Human Rights Gains
DOC.TEXT: The House Ways and Means Committee is demanding that the Beijing government improve its human rights policies before the United States renews special trade privileges for another year. However, the committee, which originates all trade legislation in Congress, rejected an effort to withdraw the most-favored-nation trade benefits that President Bush extended to China last month. Those benefits guarantee the lowest tariffs available on goods imported into the United States. ``Our object ought to be to improve human rights in China, not to cut off trade,'' Rep. Donald Pease, D-Ohio, said Wednesday in arguing successfully for his bill, which the committee approved by voice vote. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the committee, supported Pease's bill. ``We are all outraged by human rights atrocities taking place in China,'' but revoking trade benefits would be counterproductive, he said. Rep. Richard Schulze, R-Pa., made several unsuccessful attempts to toughen the bill. Despite the massacre of protesters in Beijing's Tianamen Square in June 1989 and other human rights violations, ``the resolution says `you get one more year to do a little better,''' Schulze said. ``We have said we are going to turn our backs on it, that the almighty dollar ... is much more important.'' Rep. Sander Levin, D-Mich., described Pease's bill as ``an attempt to create enough common ground that the president and Congress can stand on it together.'' Anything tougher almost certainly would be vetoed, he said. In granting the trade benefit this year, Bush had to consider only China's emigration policy and was allowed by law to waive any concerns about it in the national interest. The bill would not affect the designation for the next 12 months. Before renewing most-favored-nation status next year, the bill would require the president to consider whether the Beijing government has made significant progress in several areas. They include: _Terminating martial law. _Accounting for citizens who were arrested as a result of nonviolent expression of political beliefs during the uprising that led to the Tianamen Square massacre. _Easing restrictions on freedom of the press. _Ceasing harassment of Chinese citizens in the United States. The president also would have to consider how denial of the trade benefit would affect Hong Kong, the British crown colony that borders China. Some members quarreled with the ``significant progress'' phrase in the bill. ``If you shoot 1,000 people instead of 5,000, have you made progress?'' asked Rep. Marty Russo, D-Ill. Bipartisan legislation in the Senate would withdraw most-favored-nation status outright on grounds the Beijing government continues to engage in torture, use of forced labor, denial of emigration and suppression of domestic dissent, as well as support of Khmer Rouge forces in Cambodia. Almost all nations, except developing countries, whose exports are allowed tariff-free treatment, have been given most-favored-nation status. Exceptions include Cuba and Vietnam.

DOC.HEAD: Fujimori Names Former Center-Right Minister As His Prime Minister
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Alberto Fujimori has named as his prime minister a former center-right Cabinet minister, the strongest signal yet that he is indeed embracing the tough market-oriented reforms he once eschewed. Fujimori on Wednesday night named ex-agriculture minister Juan Carlos Hurtado Miller to be his prime minister and economics minister. The president-elect, who takes over from center-left President Alan Garcia on July 28, said Hurtado Miller would announce the rest of the Cabinet this afternoon. The appointment came two days after two of Fujimori's top economic advisers resigned. The two had supported a gradual economic adjustment program. Before the June 10 election, Fujimori sharply criticized the type of market-oriented ``economic shock therapy'' advocated by his opponent, novelist Mario Vargas Llosa. But on subsequent visits to the United States and Japan to seek loans, Fujimori was told drastic reform _ such as ending price subsidies and selling off unprofitable state-owned industry _ was needed in order to qualify for international credit. Fujimori has said one of his top priorities is to mend relations with international lenders. The announcement came in a hastily called press conference held at a Lima military base where Fujimori has been meeting with advisers for the last week to choose a Cabinet. They've been meeting at the base for security reasons. A decade-old insurgency by Maoist-inspired Shining Path rebels has plagued a series of Peruvian administrations. Though mostly centered in the countryside, the rebels have in the past year or so tried to move their struggle into the capital. Hurtado Miller, who resigned Wednesday from the center-right Popular Action party, is a former bank president and served as agriculture minister under former President Fernando Belaunde Terry from 1983 to 1985. Hurtado Miller, like Fujimori, is an agricultural engineer who also holds a master's degree in economics from Iowa State University and masters in public policy and management from Harvard. Fujimori said the priorities of his Cabinet ``will be centered in the pacifying Peru, ending bureaucratic corruption, cleaning up the economy, promoting a fair policy of economic stabilization, and the reinsertion of Peru in the international financial community.'' Following meetings last month with heads of the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank, he promised to dismantle populist price subsidy programs and exchange rate controls imposed by Presdident Garcia. Those lending agencies cut off credit to Peru after Garcia stopped payments on the country's $20 billion foreign debt. Fujimori said his Cabinet would be made of leaders representing a broad spectrum of political parties, but he gave no indication Wednesday night who his ministers would be.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Says 1993 Deployment of Star Wars Would be Premature, Risky
DOC.TEXT: A presidential decision to deploy the first phase of the Strategic Defense Initiative in 1993 would be ``premature and fraught with high risk,'' congressional investigators say. Citing design problems caused by the introduction of the ``Brilliant Pebbles'' concept of orbiting interceptors and detailed tests that won't be completed in time, the General Accounting Office on Wednesday recommended a delay in deployment of the antimissile system. The report by Congress' watchdog agency is certain to affect debate over the level of spending on SDI, commonly known as Star Wars. The Senate Armed Services Committee, in approving a $289 billion fiscal 1991 defense bill, cut $1 billion from President Bush's $4.7 billion budget request for the program. The House Armed Services Committee, which will craft its version of the bill later this month, must slash a total of $24 billion from Bush's overall budget of $307 billion to conform to House instructions. A deep cut in SDI is expected. In the report, the GAO said ``Brilliant Pebbles'' had drastically changed the system's design, leaving it in a state of flux. In January, the Pentagon incorporated the ``Brilliant Pebbles'' concept into Phase 1. The technology involves several thousand interceptors that would orbit the Earth to seek and destroy a target by smashing into it at high speeds. The GAO also said that detailed tests planned by the Strategic Defense Initiative Organization, a Defense Department agency that oversees Star Wars, won't be completed before the scheduled executive decision on deployment. Based on those problems, the GAO said it doesn't believe the SDI organization ``will be able to give the president enough information to support a 1993 decision to deploy Phase 1.'' The Pentagon plans to spend between $69 billion and $87 billion to develop and deploy the first phase of SDI, designed to protect the United States from a Soviet nuclear ballistic missile attack. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has said the goal of Phase 1 was to destroy half the Soviet Union's SS-18 nuclear warheads _ 1,540 of the 3,080 currently deployed _ and 40 percent of its other warheads launched in an initial strike against the United States. The first phase involves seven highly integrated elements: two space-based sensors, a space-based weapon, two ground-based sensors, a ground-based weapon and a command and control system that would manage the other elements. SDI officials believe they can support a decision to deploy Phase 1 with less information but say it will be done at increased risk, the GAO said. In a statement, the SDI Organization said its goals are to conduct ``a vigorous research and technology program'' that would be the basis for an informed decision by the president. The agency said it would have no official comment on the report until the GAO formally released it in early August. Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., chairman of the House Government Operations Committee, said successful deployment depends on a ``sound, stable design plan.'' ``GAO's report shows that no such plan exists because of the radical changes made recently by the inclusion of Brilliant Pebbles into the design. Caution and skepticism are appropriate when Congress looks toward funding the completion of Phase 1,'' said Conyers, who requested the report. The GAO noted the absence of scrutiny the Pentagon envisioned for the program. The Defense Acquisition Board didn't conduct its scheduled 1989 review and has not assessed the affect of Brilliant Pebbles on the design and tests. ``The lack of effective agency oversight has contributed to the failure of other automated weapons systems, none of which matches the scale and technological complexity of Phase 1,'' the GAO said. ``Consequently, any executive decision in 1993 to deploy Phase 1 would be premature and fraught with high risk.'' The GAO recommended that Cheney advise President Bush to defer a decision to deploy any element of the Phase 1 system until the SDI Organization has stabilized the design and shown the system's effectiveness through testing.

DOC.HEAD: Study: U.S. Policy on Nuclear Waste `Bound to Fail'
DOC.TEXT: A National Research Council report says a plan for an underground dump for high-level nuclear waste is ``bound to fail'' because it requires an assurance of safety that science can't guarantee. The report said a U.S. policy requiring the Department of Energy to build a deep underground nuclear dump that is absolutely assured of being safe for 10,000 years is a scientific and engineering impossibility. ``A policy that promises to anticipate every conceivable problem, or assumes that science will shortly provide all the answers, is bound to fail,'' the study said. It notes that the 10,000-year requirement covers a period that is as long as all of recorded human history. The study said federal law should give DOE more flexibility to allow for uncertainties found while building such a large project that has never before been attempted. However, Melinda Kassen, a lawyer for the Environmental Defense Fund, said her organization and other environmental groups believe the standards now in place should be enforced and that a policy demanding firm evidence of safety is the correct approach. ``There is wisdom, we believe, in trying to assure up front that you're not going to have contamination or catastrophe down the road,'' Ms. Kassen said in a telephone interview. ``Before putting nuclear waste in the ground, you ought to show that the system is going to work.'' The National Research Council study said the effect of current laws is that DOE managers feel required to do things ``perfectly the first time.'' While preparing an underground depository for high-level radioactive wastes, the report said, federal experts are not given the flexibility to find ways to cope with unexpected geological features or to incorporate new scientific knowledge.
