This rigid approach, the study said, creates a ``scientific trap'' by ``encouraging the public to expect absolute certainty about the safety of the repository for 10,000 years and encouraging DOE program managers to pretend that they can provide it.'' ``Engineers are unable to anticipate all of the potential problems that might arise in trying to site, build and operate a repository,'' the report said. ``Nor can science prove that a repository will be absolutely safe.'' The DOE has studied a number of candidate sites for underground nuclear waste storage. In 1987, Congress designated a site at Yucca Mountain in Nevada for detailed study. If the site meets standards established by the law, it could be licensed as the first underground repository for thousands of tons of high-level radioactive waste created annually by nuclear power plants. Congress in 1982 assigned DOE to design and operate an underground depository. The law says the site must licensed by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and meet Environmental Protection Agency standards that limit release of radiation to levels that would cause fewer than 1,000 deaths over 10,000 years. ``This perfect knowledge approach is unrealistic, given the inherent uncertainties of this unprecedented undertaking, and it runs the risk of encountering show-stopping problems and delays that could lead to further deterioration of public and scientific trust,'' the National Research Council said in its report. Requiring predictions of safety so far into the future, the study said, ``stretches the limits'' of geology, groundwater chemistry and other sciences. ``As a consequence, the resulting estimates are uncertain to some degree and they will remain uncertain no matter how much additional information is gathered,'' the report said. The American people, the study said, should understand such uncertainties. ``The public has been told too often that absolute guarantees can be provided, but most citizens watching the human frailties of their governments and technologists know better,'' the report said. ``A realistic, and attainable, goal is to assure the public that the likelihood of serious unforeseen events ... is minimal and that the consequences of such events will be limited.'' The National Research Council is an agency of the National Academy of Sciences, a private organization chartered by Congress to advise the federal government on scientific matters.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Department to Share Technology with Business
DOC.TEXT: U.S. industry will be allowed to share technology developed in nuclear weapons laboratories as part of a growing government-private sector partnership, Energy Secretary James Watkins says. ``Without the ability to manufacture high-quality goods, America is out of the competition,'' Watkins said as he signed two technology-transfer agreements with business consortia on Wednesday. The initiatives follow enactment last year of legislation encouraging such exchanges. ``Japan and a number of European countries are way ahead of us in government encouragement of private industry,'' said Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich. ``These agreements will unlock technology now in the hands of the government and ... make this country more competitive.'' The Energy Department's weapons program consists of 17 laboratories, production facilities and test sites in 12 states. It has over $100 billion in assets and a yearly research and development budget of about $3 billion. The program is one of a handful in government that advance technology from the basic research stage all the way to product application. It has generated some of the world's most sophisticated manufacturing equipment, machine tools, control and measurement systems and quality assurance methods, Watkins said. One agreement commits the Energy Department to share information with the National Center for Manufacturing Sciences, a non-profit consortium based in Ann Arbor, Mich. It represents more than 100 companies. ``Taxpayers have invested $100 billion in America's national labs and production complexes over the years, and they represent one of the world's great treasure houses of technology and manufacturing know-how,'' said Ed Miller, president of the center. Under the second agreement, a consortium of 10 companies plus universities and the Energy Department will conduct research on specialty metals at the Sandia National Laboratories of Albuquerque, N.M. Specialty metals are combinations of metals and alloys or other materials, such as ceramics, that are designed to meet strict quality-control standards for highly complex products. They are used in aircraft, satellites, nuclear-power reactors and high-speed drills. The Sandia lab will give industry and university researchers access to the only 310-kilowatt electron-beam melting furnace of its size in the nation available for pure research. The agreement with the center in Ann Arbor will boost research into advanced robotics techniques for manufacturing, pollution cleanup technology and high-speed machine technology, Miller said. Some of the center's member companies already are working with the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California to develop a grade of aluminum that could ``revolutionize'' automobile production through more precise engineering, Miller said. ``You're talking about multi-billion-dollar impacts to the productivity and quality of products,'' he said. ``People with the biggest companies in the United States _ General Motors, Ford _ have already visited the laboratories and have said they'll use this technology if they can get access to it.''

DOC.HEAD: One Fugitive Pro-Democracy Leader Arrested; Another Placed In Solitary
DOC.TEXT: Authorities have arrested a fugitive student leader of last year's crushed pro-democracy movement later set up an underground organization to agitate for reforms, the student's university confirmed today. A student source, meanwhile, said a second protest leader had been placed in solitary confinement for trying to organize a hunger strike among prisoners. An official at the Student Affairs Office of the Beijing Economics Institute, contacted by telephone, confirmed unofficial reports that fugitive student Zhai Weimin had been arrested and jailed, but said she had no details. She did not give her name. Zhai is the fourth Beijing student known to have been arrested without publicity in the past three months, even as the government tries to ease foreign criticism by announcing large prisoner releases. The other three were students at Beijing University suspected of involvement in underground activities. The student source, who spoke on condition of anonymity for fear of official punishment, said Zhai was placed in Beijing's Qincheng Prison for political prisoners in May. That was just three months after Zhai held a secret conference in Beijing of his underground Democratic Front for the Salvation of China. Participants in the conference told foreign journalists at the time that more than 60 people took part. The front was one of several small underground groups established across China to agitate for reform after Communist authorities ordered an army attack on student-led demonstrators in Beijing on June 3-4, 1989, ending seven weeks of massive pro-democracy protests. Hundreds of unarmed civilians were killed. Zhai, 22, from central China's Henan province, was a student at the Beijing Economics Institute when the student protest movement began in April 1989. He quickly became one of its leaders. After the army attack, the government issued a list of 21 most-wanted student protest leaders. Zhai, No. 6 on the list, already was in hiding. Another protester on that list, Liu Gang, who has been jailed since June 1989, was moved to solitary confinement at Qincheng Prison in May, the student source said. He said Liu had tried to organize fellow prisoners in a hunger strike on June 4 to commemorate the slain protesters. Liu, 29, had been working at a research institute when the protests began but quickly joined the students. The student source also said two more fugitives on the list of 21, Wang Zhixin of the China University of Political Science and Law, and Wang Youcai of Beijing University, were in prison. He did not know when they were arrested. Both universities said they had no information on the two students. Police have refused to comment on arrests. Eight students from the list of 21 were previously known to be arrested. The arrests of Zhai and the two Wangs would bring that to 11. Two students on the list who were arrested last summer have since been released. Five on the list have fled abroad, and the whereabouts of five are not known. The government has said that 355 people who are still being investigated remain jailed in Beijing in connection with the pro-democracy movement. It has not released figures for people charged and awaiting trial, or already tried and sentenced. Chinese sources say several intellectuals have received sentences of eight to 10 years in prison. Shanghai Mayor Zhu Rongji, visiting the United States to drum up foreign investments, said last week in Washington that fewer than 10 people are still being detained in his city in connection with the protests. No figures have been issued for the rest of the country, but thousands are known to have been arrested nationwide. The government has announced the release of a total of 881 prisoners in Beijing and Shanghai. China's policy since the winter has been to try to wrap up as many cases as possible, releasing those it considers lesser offenders, beginning prosecution of alleged ringleaders and sending abroad some of the most famous dissidents _ astrophysicist Fang Lizhi and folk singer Hou Dejian.

DOC.HEAD: Bulldozer Operator Flattens His Car
DOC.TEXT: What do you do after accidentally flattening your own car with a bulldozer? In the case of Mike O'Neil, an equipment operator for the Port of Kalama, you unplug your home telephone so you don't hear people who laugh at you or ask whether the rumors are true. O'Neil said he couldn't see where he was going when the accident happened Tuesday. ``I was dragging a large log out of the way and I had to go up an incline in the roadway bank,'' O'Neil said Wednesday. ``I had the blade raised up high.'' Then he noticed pieces of his Datsun emerging from under the 12-by 5-foot blade and tracks. ``Not a good feeling,'' O'Neil said. ``I backed up a bit hoping it wasn't as bad as I thought it was.'' O'Neil said his next car would have a large flag waving over it when he is at work.

DOC.HEAD: Deposed Hard-liner Asks To Speak Before Parliament, Aims To Head Off Trial
DOC.TEXT: Ousted hard-line Communist leader Todor Zhivkov, seeking to head off a possible trial on charges he abused power, has asked to speak before Parliament about his rule. Lawmakers agreed Wednesday to allow the 78-year-old Zhivkov to address a session but did not set a date. Zhivkov is ``ready to stand before the Grand National Assembly and tell the Bulgarian people the truth'' about his 35 years in power, Rumen Vodenicharov, head of the Association for the Defense of Human Rights, told Parliament. Zhivkov, in the message read by Vodenicharov, also appealed to the assembly to stop the official probe into his past. He has been under investigation for alleged abuses of power and misappropriation of state property. He has also been accused of fomenting ethnic unrest. Zhivkov was ousted in November by reform Communists. He has since been under virtual house arrest or in the hospital. Along with Erich Honecker of East Germany, Zhivkov is the only surviving ousted Eastern European hard-line leader to face possible prosecution. It is doubtful that the ailing 77-year-old Honecker would ever be brought to trial. Earlier this month, the chief prosecutor's office announced that it expected to complete its preliminary investigation of Zhivkov this week. The prosecutor would then have a month to decide whether to put Zhivkov on trial, and if so, set a date for the proceedings. Zhivkov was the author of so-called ``Bulgarization,'' or persecution and forced assimilation of the nation's 1.5 million ethnic Turks and other native Bulgarian Muslims. After his ouster, he was accused of corruption when it was revealed he had maintained at least 30 holiday and hunting retreats throughout this poor Balkan nation of 9 million people. Zhivkov's often-violent forced assimilation policy banned Moslem religious practices and required ethnic Turks and Moslems to forsake their own names and take Bulgarian ones. It was overturned by the reformed Communists who deposed him. At Wednesday's session, the assembly's newly elected chairman Nikolai Todorov proposed appointing a commission to investigate allegations of irregularities in last month's multiparty elections _ the first free elections in Bulgaria in 58 years. He also proposed establishing a commission to work out new rules of parliamentary procedure and making personnel changes in the Supreme Court and other courts. In last month's elections, the ruling Socialist Party, formerly the Communists, won 211 seats for a majority in the 400-member Parliament. The main opposition coalition, the Union of Democratic Forces, took 144 seats. While foreign observers could not confirm initial allegations of widespread manipulations, the Central Electoral Commission received a list of complaints about local irregularities in the balloting. The Parliament must also choose a new national president to replace Petar Mladenov, a Socialist, who resigned earlier this month under public pressure after a videotape was released in which he was heard to call for the use of tanks against anti-government demonstrators in December. Tanks were not used. It was not clear when the Parliament would vote for a new president.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 33,055.62, up 7.51 points, or 0.02 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Reebok has dropped Madonna as spokeswoman for the athletic shoe company before she filmed a single commercial. The company and the pop singer had agreed to, but not signed, a contract that would have paid her nearly $6 million, The Los Angeles Times reported. But Bernadette Mansur, Reebok's vice president of marketing communications, said, ``Madonna's availability and our need to get her weren't a mesh.'' Maddona is xurrently on a world tour and publicists at Creative Artists Agency had no immediate comment Wednesday. Last year, Pepsi signed a $5 million contract with Madonna. But the soft-drink maker took her commercial off the air because some people confused it with her ``Like a Prayer'' music video, which contained religious imagery some found offensive. Lawsuits and counter-claims also have been filed between Nike and Madonna over an alleged $4.25 million endorsement agreement.

``King of Las Vegas'' Wayne Newton says he isn't offended that a hotel celebrated his 30th anniversary on stage 14 months late. Newton, 46, first appeared at the Fremont Hotel on May 16, 1959. In those 31 years and two months since, he's played to 15 million people. He was toasted in the Elvis Presley Suite at the Las Vegas Hilton on Tuesday night as he began a new show there. He also appears in a new movie, ``The Adventures of Ford Fairlane,'' and has a new record, ``At This Moment.'' This week also is the first time the Wayne Newton International Fan Club Inc., based in Grand Rapids, Mich., has brought together all its chapters for an annual convention. About 150 members plan to be in the audience for Newton's shows this week. Carole Stewart, a spokeswoman for the Hilton, said Tuesday was the first chance the hotel had to celebrate Newton's three decades in show business. Newton didn't complain. ``I don't live in a chronological world. So many people do,'' he said.

At 22, with Olympic gold behind her, gymnastics has finally become fun for Mary Lou Retton. ``Now I perform, I don't compete and that makes a real difference,'' Retton said. Retton was the sensation of the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles. Her gold medal, in the all-around competition, was the first ever for an American woman gymnast. ``When we were practicing for the Olympics, we spent eight hours a day in the gym,'' she said Monday. ``The time in between practice, we were too tired to do anything else.'' ``If you want to be successful you give up your social life. You give up everything except gymnastics,'' she said. Now, Retton performs six to eight times a year, travels as a motivational speaker and does charity work. She also is engaged to be married in December.

Personal possessions of former billionaire Nelson Bunker Hunt _ from art to a popcorn popper _ will be auctioned off Saturday. Hunt and brother William Herbert Hunt, who sought bankruptcy protection when their silver fortune collapsed a decade ago, were ordered to sell possessions to pay their creditors. The Internal Revenue Service is owed the most. ``The public will really have a rare inside look into the lives of one of America's most interesting families,'' said trustee Carter Pate. He called the auction ``distasteful for all parties involved.'' Pate expects to take in $200,000 from the sale at Bunker Hunt's Circle T Ranch, one of his favorite retreats. The premier piece of the auction may prove to be Hunt's gigantic rocking chair, with a cowhide seat and his name burned into the back. Antiques dealers said they are excited by the collection of porcelain birds by Edward Marshall Boehm. Items with the Circle T emblem, including drapes and linens, and more mundane furnishings, like tissue dispensers and the Hunts' hot-air electric popcorn popper, will be for sale.

Nelson Mandela, celebrating his 72nd birthday upon his return home from a triumphant international tour, says he feels half his age. ``I feel like a boy of 36, and the present I would like to have is votes for all,'' said Mandela, who looked tired after his six-week tour of 14 nations, including the United States. Mandela was greeted by about 200 supporters and relatives on Wednesday, his first birthday in freedom after 27 years in a South African prison for fighting the country's white-minority government. The African National Congress leader said he hoped to see President F.W. de Klerk in the next few days to set up talks leading to full-scale negotiations on ending apartheid. ``There is no doubt that apartheid is crumbling,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Father to Appeal Judge's Refusal to Order Bone-Marrow Transplant Tests
DOC.TEXT: The father of a leukemia-stricken boy says he'll appeal a judge's refusal to force the child's twin half-siblings to be tested as possible bone-marrow donors. Tamas Bosze says a bone-marrow transplant is the only hope for saving the life of his 12-year-old son, Jean-Pierre. Bosze sought a court order after the 3-year-old twins' mother, Nancy Curran _ his former girlfriend _ objected to the blood tests tests. Doctors say family members have a better chance of being compatible donors than strangers. The predicament of Jean-Pierre, Bosze's son by another woman, ``evokes sympathy from all who've heard the story,'' Cook County Circuit Judge Monica Reynolds said in a written ruling. But, the judge said, ``An order forcing the twins to submit to a blood test and possibly to a bone marrow harvesting at a later date would be an invasion of their constitutional rights of privacy.'' ``To subject a healthy child to bodily intrusions, against the will of the custodial parent in order to attempt to save a diseased child ... is not a duty the courts can impose upon a child or anyone else,'' the judge wrote. Bosze said he was disappointed but would appeal. ``This is not over,'' he said. Ms. Curran's attorney, Beverly Pekala, said her client felt vindicated by the judge's decision but remains fearful that the tests would endanger her twins' lives. Ms. Curran was not in court. Dr. Jong J. Kwon, Jean-Pierre's physician, argued that the potential to save the boy's life outweighs the slight risks _ including pain, possible anemia or infection _ involved in testing and then extracting bone marrow. Jean-Pierre's parents and other family members were found to be incompatible donors. Kwon said the boy, diagnosed with leukemia in 1989, is not improving and he must undergo several doses of chemotherapy a week. Kwon said he is trying to keep the boy's spirits up. ``I told him that transplantation has the best chance, but even if the twins are not the donor we can still look for some other volunteer donor,'' Kwon said. ``We cannot say there is no hope.''

DOC.HEAD: Rare Cancer in Three Children Stirs Fear in Small Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS in 13 grafs to UPDATE with town meeting; Picks up 11th graf pvs, `Thomas Hornshaw ...'.
DOC.TEXT: A rare cancer usually found in just nine of every million children struck three babies in this small central Illinois town. Residents suspect an abandoned coal factory is to blame. But state health officials told residents Wednesday night that it's premature to assess responsibility for the cancer cluster. The children, ranging in age from 6 months to 22 months, have been diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a cancer of the adrenal glands and sympathetic nervous system that occurs primarily in children under age 10. The sympathetic nervous system controls some automatic body functions. State health experts are studying medical records and the incidence of cancer in Taylorville, a city of 11,000 people about 210 miles southwest of Chicago. The childrens' parents and others in the community suspect the cancer cluster is linked to an abandoned factory site that was contaminated with coal tar. The affected children all live within three miles of the site. ``It's too much to be a coincidence,'' said Brenda May, whose 7-month-old daughter, Erika, was diagnosed with neuroblastoma soon after birth and underwent successful surgery to remove a tumor. A second child, 22-month-old Zachary Donaldson, has been declared cured; 6-month-old Chad Hryhorysak is undergoing chemotherapy. Symptoms include weight loss, body aches, paleness and irritability. In some cases, tumors cause diarrhea and high blood pressure. The condition can be fatal if left untreated, but is usually caught in time. Residents have formed the Taylorville Awareness Group to press for government investigation of the cancer cluster. At a town meeting on the issue Wednesday night, state toxicologist Tom Long told residents they shouldn't blame the abandoned factory yet. ``It is right and good for you to be concerned about the cancer and your environment,'' Long said. ``However, at this stage of the game, it's not right or productive to link the two.'' About half of the 50 residents at the meeting signed a petition asking the federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta to investigate. State health officials said their own investigation would suffice. Before the meeting, Mrs. May said that while she was pregnant with Erika, she often took her two older daughters to play in a park next to the former site of a Central Illinois Public Service Co. plant that made coal gas for street lights. The plant shut down in 1932. Thomas Hornshaw, who assesses toxic-chemical sites for the state Environmental Protection Agency, said 9,000 cubic yards of coal tar and contaminated soil were removed from the site in 1988. Although the site is no longer contaminated, residents could have been exposed before and during the cleanup, he said. Studies have linked coal tar to lung and skin cancer, but not specifically to neuroblastoma, health officials said. Mrs. May said she and other parents of cancer-stricken children are resented by some residents who fear their town will be labeled a cancer hazard. ``But they haven't stayed up all night and watched a heart monitor to make sure their baby is still alive,'' she said. In the United States, neuroblastoma occurs in about nine of every million live births every year, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control. Fewer than 500 babies are born here every year. About 500 cases are reported each year across the country and the prognosis is good if the cancer is diagnosed before age 2. Researchers don't know exactly what causes neuroblastoma, but heredity plays a role and a virus or environmental factors might be involved, said Dr. Holly Howe, chief epidemiologist for the Illinois Department of Public Health.

DOC.HEAD: Toymaker Recalls `Bead Coasters'
DOC.TEXT: A New York toymaker is recalling 7,600 ``Bead Coaster'' toys because the wooden beads may become detached and pose a fatal choking hazard to young children. The three metal blue, yellow and red wires of the toys form a hill and valley roller-coaster shaped vertical field attached to a wooden base to create what a spokeswoman for the Consumer Product Safety Commission called ``an activity toy.'' Wooden beads of various shapes and colors are threaded through and move easily about the wires. It is these beads that may become detached and pose a potentially fatal choking hazard, the commission said Wednesday. The toy was imported from Taiwan by Associated Merchandising Corp. of New York and sold nationwide from September 1989 to March 1990 under the trade name ``Creative Years,'' which appears on the wooden base. Consumers are advised to take the toys from children immediately and return them the store where purchased for a refund.
DOC.HEAD: Army Reaffirms Plan to use Pacific Atoll Site to Destroy Chemical
DOC.TEXT: Arms

The Army is reaffirming plans to ship several hundred tons of chemical weapons from storage sites in West Germany to a Pacific atoll for destruction in incinerators now being tested. To meet federal environmental requirements the Army had considered several alternatives, including leaving the chemical weapons in Germany or moving them to the United States for destruction at incinerators now on the drawing boards. In announcing its decision Wednesday to stick to its original plan for destroying the chemical agents on Johnston Island, the Army said the operation ``is expected to have minimal public health, safety and environmental effects'' on Johnson Island and the Pacific area. The island is about 700 miles southwest of Hawaii. The Army began testing the $240 million Johnston Atoll Chemical Agent Disposal System on June 30. It halted the tests on the same day after encountering what Army officials called minor problems; testing resumed last weekend. The plant is expected to start full-scale operations in 1992. Congress ordered the Army in 1985 to destroy its arsenal of older chemical weapons, including those in West Germany, by 1997. The size of the stockpile is classified but is believed to be about 30,000 tons. President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev agreed at their meeting in Washington in early June to reduce their nation's stockpiles of chemical weapons by 80 percent over the next decade.
DOC.HEAD: Labor Department Examining Possible Leak Of Unemployment Figure
DOC.TEXT: The Labor Department is looking into the possibility that its June unemployment report was leaked to traders in financial markets by a news service. Spokesman Bob Zachariasiewicz said Wednesday that the matter involves a monthly report released July 6 on unemployment in June. He said the department's action was not a formal investigation, but a study of a report that the information had been leaked early and caused a fluctuation in market activity. ``We had no way of telling that the market fluctuation was caused by a premature release of the information,'' Zachariasiewicz said. Just before the figure's release, one trader on the Chicago Board of Trade began selling bond futures heavily, according to a report Wednesday by Dow Jones. The selling spree could have been the result of a lucky guess or could indicate a premature leak, the service said. When the report is released each month, news organizations are given copies at 8 a.m. on the condition that they not be released until 8:30 a.m. Markets can rise or fall based on this information, and its release even a minute prematurely has drawn the department's ire in the past. Zachariasiewicz declined to say which news organization was being reviewed but another Labor Department source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said it was a Japanese service.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Post Reporter Dies of Cancer
DOC.TEXT: William R. Peterson, a reporter for The Washington Post who also worked for the Louisville (Ky.) Courier-Journal, is dead of cancer at age 47. Peterson had been the Post's correspondent in Chicago since 1987. He was diagnosed with lung cancer in the autumn of 1988 and underwent surgery earlier this year. He died Wednesday at Georgetown University Hospital. He had flown to Washington on Monday to see friends and colleagues. Born in San Luis Obispo, Calif., Peterson attended Hamline University in St. Paul, Minn., and also studied at American University and received a masters' degree from Northwestern University. Survivors include his wife, Linda Peterson of Chicago, and two sons.

DOC.HEAD: Army Officer Arraigned In Cover-Up of Jesuit Killings Claims Innocence
DOC.TEXT: An army officer charged with a coverup in the slayings of six jesuit educators, their housekeeper and her daughter denies he ordered the burning of documents in the case. ``I'm innocent,'' Lt. Col. Carlos Camilio Hernandez told reporters Wednesday after asking a judge to postpone his hearing until a new defense lawyer is named. ``I trust in God, justice and my innocence, since I didn't order the burning of any books,'' he said. Hernandez is charged with destroying logs that may have contained evidence implicating nine army men, including the former Military School director Col. Guillermo Benavides, in the November massacre. The brutal slayings and sluggish investigation have prompted lawmakers in Washington, which backs the right-wing government of President Alfredo Cristiani with millions of dollars in aid, to call for a funding cut. Hernandez' lawyer Carlos Castellon resigned from the case Wednesday, claiming he had been threatened. A prosecution lawyer said the log books ``are key evidence'' in the investigation because they show departures of army officers charged with leaving the military academy to kill the Jesuits on Nov. 16. The killings took place on the Catholic University campus on the fifth day of the biggest guerrilla offensive in 10 years of Salvadoran civil war. Cristiani and the army high command immediately blamed the killings on the guerrilla Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. But U.S. Army Maj. Erick Buckland told superiors that Salvadoran Col. Carlos Armando Aviles told him Col. Benavides ordered the massacre. Aviles later denied saying he knew who took part in the killings. Judge Ricardo Zamora has told the Salvadoran Foreign Ministry to ask the U.S. Embassy's permission for Buckland to provide further testimony. The investigations have led to the arrest of Benavides, Hernandez, two colonels, two lieutenants and four enlisted men. Benavides is the highest ranking official of the Salvadoran army ever accused of human rights violations in the history of the civil war. No officer has been convicted on that charge. The evidence against Benavides to date consists of testimony by other army men charged in the case. Under Salvadoran law, such testimony cannot be admitted as legal proof.

DOC.HEAD: Karl Menninger, Dean of American Psychiatry, Dead at 96
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Karl Menninger, who pushed psychiatry into the American mainstream and for more than six decades strove for the compassionate treatment of the mentally ill, has died at age 96. The pioneer died of abdominal cancer at Stormont-Vail Regional Medical Center on Wednesday, just four days before his birthday. If psychoanalysis was born in Vienna, the child of Sigmund Freud, it grew strong on the Kansas prairie under the guidance of Menninger. Friends and associates said he nurtured psychiatry into a medical speciality. ``He was one of the first American psychiatrists to integrate psychoanalytic theory into his practice,'' said Dr. Elissa Benedek, president of the American Psychiatric Association. Menninger was once hailed by the association as the nation's ``greatest living psychiatrist.'' A hot-tempered, excitable maverick, he jolted popular thought with his theories on crime, prisons and child abuse. Menninger grew up in Topeka and attended Harvard Medical School. He interned at Boston Psychopathic Hospital, returning to Topeka in 1919. In 1925, he and his father, Charles, and brother, William, converted a 13-room farmhouse into a clinic, which later became the renowned Menninger with the largest training program in the world for psychiatrists. ``My chief purpose in the beginning was to show you could treat `insane' people,'' Menninger once recalled. ``Everybody thought they were untreatable. But I said they were being treated every day. We demonstrated you could treat people in a better way.'' Menninger applied Freudian principles to people who were mentally ill but not psychotic, said Philip Holzman, professor of psychology at Harvard University. Before that, such people were not considered worthy of treatment, he said. ``He entered psychiatry at a time when psychiatry was defining itself,'' Holzman said. Dr. Gertrude Ticho, who worked at the Menninger for 18 years and is now in private practice in Washington, said Menninger was one of the first psychiatrists to create an environment for psychiatric patients based on compassion and treatment. Menninger's once-revolutionary approaches to mental illness became standard as psychiatrists trained at Menninger established their own practices, Ticho said. ``In a sense, he was a victim of his own success,'' she said. ``He trained at Menninger so many people who went out and set up comparable clinics.'' In 1930, Menninger published ``The Human Mind,'' which still is used as a textbook. In 1938, he came out with ``Man Against Himself,'' a seminal volume that examines patterns of self-destructive behavior. Menninger's other books, including ``Love Against Hate,'' ``The Crime of Punishment'' and ``What Ever Became of Sin?'' also drew a wide readership outside of psychiatry. ``Dr. Menninger brought psychiatry to the average person, widening public understanding and acceptance of psychiatry as an agent of healing and help,'' Benedek said. ``He wrote and spoke in the language of the average American, making mental illnesses more understandable and less feared.'' Menninger also explored the relationship between the mind and the body, between mental health and physical well-being. ``Menninger was perhaps the foremost pioneer in refuting the notion of two separate systems, one body, the other mind, in human beings,'' said longtime friend Norman Cousins, who has written about on health for the layman. ``He advanced the concept of a singular system in which both mind and body were constituent parts,'' said Cousins, who teaches at the University of California Medical School. Crime and reform dominated Menninger's thinking in later years. He moved to Chicago in 1966, serving as a consultant on prison affairs and helping set up a mental health center in downtown Chicago. He moved back to Topeka in 1974. Psychiatrists attribute reforms in mental hospitals to Menninger. Under his guidance, Topeka State Hospital became a national model for state hospitals across the country, Holzman said. ``Compassionate care of the mentally ill is the thing that stands out with Menninger,'' said Cousins, who first met Menninger in the late 1930s. ``All you have to do is visit a lot of mental hospitals to realize we have not arrived at that form of treatment.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar inched up against the Japanese yen in Tokyo today, and share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rose marginally. The dollar closed at 147.60 yen, up 0.35 yen from Wednesday's close. It opened at 148.05 yen and ranged between 147.40 yen and 148.18 yen. Spot transactions totaled $10.501 billion, down from Wednesday's $11.740 billion. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues rose 7.51 points, or 0.02 percent, to 33,055.62. The index had shed 124.17 points on Wednesday. Volume on the first section was estimated at 600 million shares, unchanged from Wednesday. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond stood at 86.52 points as of 4:00 p.m. (3 a.m. EDT), down from Wednesday's close of 86.70. The yield was 7.300 percent, up from 7.260. The dollar gained ground after a round of buy-backs in early trading in which traders tried to cover short, or oversold positions, dealers said. Akihiko Kagawa, a dealer with Bank of Tokyo, reasoned that Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's testimony before the U.S. Congress on Wednesday did little to clarify the outlook for U.S. interest rates. Many traders had oversold the dollars, anticipating Greenspan would indicate easier credit is ahead, he said. Lower interest rates tend to drop a currency's value. On the stock market, share prices remained slightly lower during most of the day's mild trading until a last-minute round of index-linked buying lifted the benchmark Nikkei index, said Yoshiro Inoue of Nomura Securities.

DOC.HEAD: National Implications Seen in Electrician's Manslaughter Conviction
DOC.TEXT: An electrician's manslaughter conviction for work that caused a fire and killed a 12-year-old has implications for other electricians nationwide, industry officials say. Richard E. Salz faced sentencing Friday after a jury last month found him guilty of improperly installing a baseboard heating unit in the East Haven, Conn., home where the boy died. ``I think the individual (Salz) deserves what happens. But to put the rest of my trade in jeopardy of manslaughter is asking a lot,'' Lou Acampora, president of the Connecticut Electrical Contractors Association, said Wednesday. ``This sets a bad precedent. It puts a lot of good electricians in jeopardy for making a mistake,'' he said. Phil Simmons, executive director of the Park Ridge, Ill.-based International Association of Electrical Contractors, said, ``I hope it has a sobering effect and that people realize they will be held responsible for their actions.'' Simmons said he knows of no other case in which an electrician was charged with manslaughter for a death resulting from electrical work he has done. Lawrence Acquarulo, an assistant state building inspector who testified at Salz's trial, said the electrician should have known his work was a fire hazard. ``This was not just John Q. Public making an honest mistake,'' he said. Salz, 49, from East Haven, faces a maximum prison term of 10 years. The boy, Burton Gorman III, died of smoke inhalation in the fire Dec. 26, 1988, at his grandparents' home. Salz failed to get a permit for the work, ignored the manufacturer's instructions for installing the heater in the home's basement and committed more than a dozen electrical code violations, Acquarulo said. Salz connected the 120-volt unit to a 240-volt circuit box, doubling the amount of heat that was supposed to come from the heater, Acquarulo said. The unit overheated and ignited wall paneling, investigators said. Salz's license as a contractor was revoked in July 1989, but the state Electrical Work Examining Board gave him a journeyman's license allowing him to work under supervision.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Signs Big Tax Increase
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, who bragged about the ``Massachusetts Miracle'' during his failed presidential bid, has signed a bill taxing myriad services to infuse the state with needed cash. Dukakis signed the bill Wednesday behind closed doors. ``This is not something to celebrate,'' he said later. ``Taxes are like medicine,'' he said. ``Nobody likes to prescribe them. Nobody likes to take them. But taxes are part of what will be required to regain fiscal health in the state.'' The measure raises state income and gasoline taxes and extends the 5 percent sales tax to hundreds of business services that are now exempt. The new law is expected to generate $1.2 billion this fiscal year and an additional $1.8 billion next fiscal year. State officials said residents will start feeling the effects of the law at the gasoline pump within 10 days and will start seeing a bigger bite out of their paychecks as early as three weeks. Opponents argued the state constitution forbids some of the sales taxes on services, but the state Supreme Judicial Court supported the concept in an advisory opinion Tuesday. The huge tax boost marks another chapter in the up-and-down fortunes of Dukakis and Massachusetts. Two years ago, Dukakis was preparing to accept the Democratic nomination for the presidency as he bragged about the ``Massachusetts Miracle.'' But since then, the economy has soured, revenue has shrunk, and state government has run up a deficit of more than $1 billion for last fiscal year. Massachusetts' bond ratings have plummeted to the lowest in the country. ``The only miracle that I can see is that working men and women up to this time have been able to keep their heads above water,'' said House Minority Leader Steven Pierce, the Republican candidate for governor. He said he will file legislation to repeal the tax package. Dukakis is not running for re-election.

DOC.HEAD: A Description of the Major Parties in Cambodia's War
With PM-Cambodia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief description of the leading participants in Cambodia's 11-year-old civil war: _The Vietnamese-installed government of Premier Hun Sen, comprised largely of Khmer Rouge defectors, is fighting a coalition of three Cambodian resistance groups. _The communist Khmer Rouge, armed by China, is the strongest of the three. Its political leader is Khieu Samphan. The Khmer Rouge ruled Cambodia in 1975-1978. During that time, hundreds of thousands of its 8 million people died from Khmer Rouge executions, famine and civil unrest. Knowledgeable sources say the Khmer Rouge has about 30,000 troops. _The Khmer People's National Liberation Front is one of two non-communist guerrilla groups. It is led by former Cambodian Prime Minister Son Sann. It was formed from a number of non-communist groups that had fought the Khmer Rouge since 1975. _Non-communist followers of former Cambodian leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk have formed their own force, the National Sihanouk Army. Sihanouk is the also leader of the resistance coalition. Non-communist resistance forces number an estimated 20,000. The resistance is based along the Thai border, armed principally by China. It holds Cambodia's U.N. seat. _The Soviet-backed Vietnamese invaded Cambodia in late 1978, ousting the Khmer Rouge government. Vietnam announced it had removed all its troops from Cambodia in September. Since then, the resistance has made its biggest gains of the war.

DOC.HEAD: Greta Garbo's Art Collection to be Auctioned
DOC.TEXT: Art and antiques that decorated Greta Garbo's apartment will be auctioned at Sotheby's in November for a targeted $20 million, the auction house says. The 250 items are not personal effects but a collection purchased by the reclusive film legend, Sotheby's President Diana D. Brooks said Wednesday. Garbo died April 15 at age 84. ``What's exciting for us is that it is a serious art collection that was acquired and lived with by one of the legendary figures of the 20th century,'' she said. Garbo's estate, executed by her niece, Gray Reisfield, authorized the Nov. 13-15 sale. The art collection includes three Renoirs, 18th-century French furniture, decorative rugs, rare books, and Continental, English and Chinese ceramics. All were kept in her seven-room Manhattan co-op. The Swedish-born actress performed in 27 movies, including ``Anna Christie,'' ``Mata Hari,'' ``Grand Hotel,'' ``Queen Christina,'' ``Anna Karenina,'' ``Camille'' and ``Ninotchka.'' But she retired in 1941, favoring her privacy to Hollywood stardom.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Of all the thousands of words that have been written or spoken during 23 months of investigation, news coverage and commentary, only three are appropriate today: I am sorry.'' _ Sen. Dave Durenberger, R-Minn., after he was denounced by the Senate Ethics Committee for financial misconduct.

``You feel it levitate, and then you feel it swoosh you along without any vibration. Cows were grazing underneath when we passed over, and they didn't even look up.'' _ Gilbert E. Carmichael, head of the Federal Railroad Administration, who rode on a magnetically levitated train in West Germany and said the same kind of transportation may be soon used in the United States.

``We return home full of hope for the future of our country. ... The world is with us in wishing for the speediest resolution to the country's problems.'' _ African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, greeting supporters in Johannesburg, South Africa, after returning from a tour of 14 nations.

DOC.HEAD: Key Events in the Cambodian Conflict
With PM-Cambodia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronological look at the Cambodian conflict: _On Christmas Day 1978, tanks rolled from Ban Me Thuot in the central highlands to start Vietnam's invasion of Cambodia and war with its former Communist ally, the Khmer Rouge. _On Jan. 7, 1979, the Vietnamese marched into Phnom Penh. So unexpectedly swift was the strike that the Khmer Rouge left behind half-eaten meals and tons of arms as they fled. _On Jan. 10, a new Communist government was proclaimed. It was led by Heng Samrin and other Khmer Rouge defectors who had fled to Vietnam, fearing the previous government's bloody purges. But sanctuary from Thailand and arms from China soon raised the Khmer Rouge from its knees into a potent guerrilla insurgency. _In January-February 1979, China wages a border war against Vietnam to ``punish'' it for the invasion of Cambodia. _In June 1982, the Khmer Rouge, the forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and of former Premier Son Sann form a resistance coalition. The United Nations recognizes it as Cambodia's government. _In March 1985, Vietnamese forces, allied to the government in Phnom Penh, overrun every major border camp in its greatest victory of the war against the resistance coalition. _In December 1986, Nguyen Van Linh, head of Vietnam's Communist Party, focuses on economic reform and breaking the international isolation that the Cambodian war has caused. _In July 1987, Sihanouk holds peace talks in France with Phnom Penh's Prime Minister Hun Sen. _On Dec. 19, 1988, Premier Li Peng says China will decrease its aid to the resistance as Vietnam withdraws from Cambodia. He said China will halt all aid when the troops are gone. _In December 1988, Vietnam begins its pullout of 50,000 troops. _In January 1989, Vietnam sends a senior official to Beijing to discuss the conflict. The two sides agree that Vietnam will withdraw its troops by September in exchange for an end to Chinese aid to the guerrillas. _In July 1989, a 19-nation conference on Cambodia opens in Paris. Sihanouk calls for interim government with Khmer Rouge participation. Hun Sen strongly opposes the idea. _In September 1989, Vietnam says it has withdrawn its last troops. Guerrillas call it a sham and begin a general offensive. China calls the pullout a fraud and indicates it will continue arming the guerrillas until there is a political settlement. _On Sept. 30, 1989, non-communist guerrillas seize the district seat of Thmar Puok near Thai border. They make their greatest gains in the war in the coming months. _On Feb. 11-13, 1990, the U.N. Security Council permanent members, meeting in New York, say regrouping the Cambodian armies into designated areas is essential to the peace process. But they fail to agree on proposals to disarm the factions. _In February, Sihanouk and Hun Sen hold talks in Bangkok, Thailand. They agree on the need for a U.N. presence in Cambodia and a ``supreme national body.'' _In April, Sihanouk urges an immediate cease-fire in his country. He says the U.N. Security Council should deploy peacekeeping troops to enforce it. _In June, Cambodian guerrillas launch major attacks and seize areas of several provinces as Cambodia's warring factions prepare to meet to discuss a cease-fire. Chinese, Thai and U.S. officials join attempts to foster progress in peace talks stalled by the Khmer Rouge refusal to attend.

DOC.HEAD: Paul McCartney: `Pro-Corn' and Anti-Meat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: k.d. lang in 5th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Paul McCartney proclaimed himself ``pro-corn'' and stuck to his anti-meat stance before he got down to rock 'n' roll during his first concert in the nation's top pork and corn state. The former Beatle is a vegetarian, which angered some livestock producers and prompted radio stations to hire airplanes towing banners that read: ``Paul Moo-Cartney'' and ``Paul Don't Have a Cow Man.'' McCartney told reporters before Wednesday night's concert that he was more interested in promoting environmental awareness than vegetarianism on his first world tour in 13 years. He said he and his wife, Linda, a keyboard player in his band, have been vegetarians for 20 years. ``So we're used to the meat-versus-vegetables argument,'' he said. McCartney's anti-meat sentiments bubbled to the surface this month in livestock country when he decided to support People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals after country singer k.d. lang's ``Meat Stinks'' commercials for the group got her banned from some Midwest radio stations, including at least one in Iowa. ``We haven't come out on this tour to preach against meat. We're pro-corn, very pro-corn,'' McCartney said. Iowa is the nation's leading corn- and pork-producing state and ranks fourth in beef that is fattened for market. The Maryland-based animal rights group set up an informational booth at the concert, offering up tofu ``not dogs'' as an alternative to meat-based hot dogs. A concert crowd of 54,000 jammed traffic in this central Iowa city, which has a population of 45,600.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Firms, Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was higher in European trading this morning, after gaining in Tokyo trading. Gold also rose. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 147.60 yen, up 0.35 yen from Wednesday. Later in London, the dollar was unchanged at 147.60 yen. The British pound traded at $1.8155, down from $1.8205 late Wednesday. Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday: _1.6445 West German marks, up from 1.6440 _1.4130 Swiss francs, up from 1.4085 _5.5175 French francs, up from 5.5160 _1,204.40 Italian lire, up from 1,203.75 _1.1530 Canadian dollars, unchanged. The morning rate for the Dutch guilder was unavailable. The dollar gained ground in Tokyo after a round of buy-backs in early trading in which traders tried to cover short, or oversold positions, dealers said. Akihiko Kagawa, a dealer with Bank of Tokyo, said U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's testimony before Congress on Wednesday did little to clarify the outlook for interest rates. Many traders had oversold the dollars, anticipating Greenspan would indicate easier credit is ahead, he said. Brian Green, Treasury manager at the London branch of First City Texas-Houston, said this left the dollar ``not knowing whether to go up or down.'' ``Over time, I see the dollar going lower,'' added Mark Austin, currency analyst at Hong Kong & Shanghai Banking Corp. in London. Gold was quoted at $361.55 per troy ounce at the morning fixing in London, up from $360.25 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, the price was $361.40 per ounce, from $359.85 bid late Wednesday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $2.14 an ounce today, to close at $362.29. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid price of $4.89 a troy ounce, from $4.84 bid late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Rises, Evacuation Readied, Hopes Fade For Survivors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with nearly 500 dead and 1,000 injured. 30,000 fleeing Baguio. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Philippines-Unready, Bjt
LaserPhoto NY11
DOC.TEXT: Hopes faded today for hundreds of people missing and believed trapped under rubble three days after a devastating earthquake on the main Philippines island of Luzon. The official death toll neared 500. Monday's quake, which registered 7.7 on the Richter scale, toppled buildings and triggered landslides across a wide area north of the capital. Rescuers said there could be 250 more dead in the ruins of a school in Cabanatuan City, two flattened hotels in Baguio and in this city's factory district, where search operations have not begun. That does not include others who may be in cars, buses and trucks reported buried in landslides or hurled into ravines elsewhere on Luzon in the temblor. As many as 30,000 people fled on foot from this mountain resort north of Manila, heading for the lowlands along a highway blocked by landslides, an official said. All roads to the city had been cut off iin the quake and authorities hoped to blast through remaining mudslides and open one today. Figures compiled by the Office of Civil Defense and the Red Cross showed at least 490 people were killed and 1,000 injured in the quake. Officials said two Americans were among the dead and five were missing. Manila television stations reported that hundreds of thousands of people in central Luzon lacked electricity, drinking water and food and many were camped along highways for fear of aftershocks. President Corazon Aquino ordered price controls on rice, pork and other commodities in short supply throughout the affected area. But survivors complained of price-gouging and food shortages. Especially hard-hit was Baguio, 110 miles north of Manila, where 1,500 Americans live. Officials said scores of people were believed trapped in eight hotels that were severely damaged. American rescuers today said they halted search operations at the Nevada Hotel in Baguio after recovering the bodies of Richard Finley, an official of the U.S. Agency for International Development, and the wife of former Education Minister Jaime Laya. Both had been attending a USAID conference. Officials said about 20 Filipinos working for USAID were missing and feared dead in the hotel. U.S. officials said an American woman was killed but her name was withheld pending notification of kin. ``The rescue effort (at the Nevada) is over,'' said John Mitchell, a fireman from Miami, Fla., who was among Americans sent by the U.S. government for the rescue effort. ``Nobody's alive in there.'' Mario Say-Ocha, a miner who volunteered to search through the Hyatt, said he was not optimistic. ``The stench is terrible inside,'' he said. ``It can turn your stomach.'' In Manila, Highway Secretary Fiorello Estuar said clearing operations along the road to Baguio were hampered because 20,000 to 30,000 people were using the highway to walk to the lowlands of La Union province. There were no estimates of the economic impact of the quake on the country's struggling economy. Preliminary estimates ran more than $1 billion because many buildings, hotels, bridges and highways were destroyed. In Manila, Rep. Rolando Andaya, chairman of the House appropriations committee, said he would propose a two-year suspension of payments on the country's $26 billion foreign debt to free funds for reconstruction. The House resumes sessions Monday after the summer recess, and Andaya said he expected the resolution to pass easily. Scores of workers were believed missing in factories of the Baguio Export Processing Zone, where a building caught fire during the quake. Search efforts have not begun there because the plant was still smoldering. In Cabanatuan, 60 miles north of Manila, British technicians using sensor devices found no signs of life today in the rubble of the six-story Philippine Christian College. Hundreds of students and teachers were trapped when the building collapsed. Rescuers found 137 survivors and 60 dead in Cabanatuan. British rescuers said sensors indicated about 25 bodies remained buried there. Local officials told Manila radio stations that numerous other victims were probably buried in landslides near Baguio and elsewhere in the northern mountains. In La Union and Tarlac provinces, thousands of people slept in cars and in their yards because of damage to their homes and fears of another quake. Huge fissures of up to a half-mile cut highways throughout the area. Thousands remained camped in Baguio city parks, many with only umbrellas for shelter in the frequent thunderstorms. ``We will just walk,'' one woman said. ``It's dangerous on the road because of the landslides. But it would be much safer than staying indoors.''

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Absolves Exxon in Waterway Spill
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard absolved Exxon Corp. of major blame in an oil spill in a New York Harbor waterway last January, but said workers who ignored an alarm added to the extent of the spill. According to a report released Wednesday a crack in an underwater pipeline caused the Jan. 1 leak of 567,000 gallons of heating oil into the busy ship channel between Staten Island and New Jersey. The leak was not discovered immediately because a computerized leak detection system failed to shut off the oil flow, and workers at the refinery disregarded alarms that oil was leaking, the report said. The report also concluded that dredging equipment probably dented the 12-inch underwater pipeline, which runs about 6.7 miles from a refinery to a terminal on the New Jersey side of the Arthur Kill waterway. Exxon spokesmen did not immediately return calls. Federal and state grand juries in New Jersey are still investigating the spill. It was the first in a series of mishaps that have plagued the Arthur Kill and the adjacent Kill Van Kull this year, polluting the waters and shorelines, endangering wildlife and disrupting ship traffic. The Exxon refinery was the scene of another spill Wednesday. A barge leaving the refinery at Linden, N.J., struck a docked barge and spilled about 37,000 gallons of home heating oil into the Arthur Kill. Coast Guard officials said the spill posed little risk to the environment. They said hot weather would speed evaporation and the cleanup.

DOC.HEAD: State Employees Frown on Happy Face Pins
DOC.TEXT: A state campaign featuring those perky, yellow happy faces on lapel pins has some state workers frowning. The workers are complaining they're being forced to wear the pins with the message ``YES WE CAN!'' over Gov. William Donald Schaefer's name. William H. Bolander, director of Council 92 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said workers dislike the buttons because they think ``it's a subtle way to endorse the governor in an election year.'' Some, he said, claim they were threatened with discipline, including suspension, if they refused to wear them. State officials have denied that. Robert B. Sivert, director of facilities management for the Department of General Services, said Wednesday that his July 6 memorandum telling workers to wear the pins was a request _ not an order. ``If they choose not to wear the buttons, there is no disciplinary action that's going to be taken,'' Sivert said. The campaign is aimed at encouraging all 70,000 state employees to treat the public with kindness, courtesy and concern. ``We're just talking about reminding employees that they're important in the lives of others and that they make a difference. ... I resent even the implication that there's any kind of relationship between a political campaign and this promotion,'' said Samantha K. Weiner, a public relations consultant to the state Department of Personnel and the creator of the campaign. Asked why the governor's name is on all the promotion's materials, Weiner said, ``Because he is a Maryland state employee and is representative of the promotional campaign.''

DOC.HEAD: Philip Leacock, Director Known for Work with Child Actors, Dead at 72
DOC.TEXT: Philip Leacock, a film and TV director who was noted for his work with child actors and directed episodes of popular U.S. television TV series, has died aged 72. Leacock, who lived in Pacific Palisades, outside Los Angeles, died suddenly on July 14 in London while on holiday with his family, a death notice said. It gave no cause of death. Born Oct. 8, 1917, Leacock made artistic documentaries before taking on feature-length movies. His 1950s work with child actors was most notable in ``The Kidnappers,'' a hit family movie set in Nova Scotia; ``The Spanish Gardener'' starring Dirk Bogarde; ``Innocent Sinners'' with Flora Robson; and ``The Rabbit Trap'' with Ernest Borgnine. He moved to Hollywood in the early 1960s, where he made ``The War Lover.'' Based on John Hersey's novel about a World War II pilot, it starred Steve McQueen. Other Leacock films were ``Take a Giant Step,'' about a black youth's encounter with racism, and ``Let No Man Write My Epitaph,'' about juvenile drug addiction. He also directed episodes of ``Gunsmoke,'' ``Route 66,'' ``The Waltons'' and ``The Defenders.'' He retired in 1987, after directing an acclaimed three-part TV drama about the Salem witchhunts, ``Three Sovereigns for Sister Sarah,'' starring Vanessa Redgrave. Leacock's first marriage ended in divorce and in 1959 and he married Carolyn Slater. Each marriage produced two children. He is to be cremated in London on July 23.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Agreement Clearing Way For Constitutional Talks is Near
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with report saying ANC, government close to agreement on talks. Pickup 5th graf pvs, `Government officials...'
DOC.TEXT: The South African government and the African National Congress are close to an agreement that would pave the way for constitutional talks on ending white-minority rule, a report said today. The Star newspaper, citing government officials, said the two sides appeared to be on the verge of resolving problems that had been blocking talks, including an ANC demand for release of political prisoners. The report, which came a day after ANC leader Nelson Mandela returned from a triumphant 14-nation tour, said Mandela and President F.W. de Klerk were ``likely to meet within days.'' The Star, an English-language newspaper, has been supportive of de Klerk's reform efforts. On his arrival at Johannesburg's international airport on Wednesday, Mandela said the world was behind the fight to end apartheid in South Africa and that white-minority government could not last much longer. ``We return home full of hope for the future of our country...,'' Mandela told cheering supporters. ``The world is with us in wishing for the speediest resolution to the country's problems.'' Government officials said today no date had been set for a meeting between Mandela and de Klerk, but they expected contacts fairly soon. Mandela said he was optimistic the ANC and the government were moving toward an agreement to end apartheid and give blacks political rights. Having held their first-ever meeting in May, the government and ANC are trying to clear the way for full-scale talks. ``They are one with us in demanding the end of apartheid now,'' Mandela said. But he ruled out any concessions on the ANC's refusal to end its armed struggle and accept a cease-fire, for which the ANC has set various conditions. The conditions include the release of hundreds of prisoners the ANC says are political internees. ``The agreement between the government and ourselves is as soon as the government has removed the obstacles to negotiations. ... Then we would be prepared to consider the suspension of hostilities,'' he told an airport news conference. Mandela and his aides said the ANC had gained major political support on their six-week tour of North America, Europe and Africa, but they gave few details. Mandela was lauded and idolized in the United States, where vast crowds turned out to cheer him. The ANC said Mandela's return from neighboring Mozambique was delayed several hours after it received anonymous threats against its leaders and its offices. ANC officials said they received a message by facsimile mail saying: ``July 18, 1990 the last day of freedom for the ANC inside the Republic of South Africa.'' The message also claimed there were bombs on Mandela's flight and at the airport. Scores of heavily-armed police guarded the airport and searched for bombs, but reported finding nothing. Right-wing white extremists who oppose plans to end apartheid have claimed responsibility for a series of bombings in recent weeks. Mandela, looking tired, was greeted by about 200 supporters and relatives on his 72nd birthday. It was his first birthday in freedom after 27 years in prison for fighting the white-minority government. The supporters sang ``Happy Birthday Dear Leader!'' and chanted ``ANC!'' Asked how he was feeling on his birthday, Mandela, who came down with a mild case of pnuemonia last week, said: ``I feel like a boy of 36, and the present I would like to have is votes for all.'' Mandela said if the government embraces major reforms, the ANC might be willing to consider asking that international economic sanctions on South Africa be eased before a new constitution is negotiated. His statement was in contrast to his strong demands on his overseas tour for no relaxation in sanctions. Mandela appeared more authoritative and commanding after his tour. He was crisp with reporters and tartly declined to answer several questions, in contrast to his more easy-going style in the past. As part of reforms by de Klerk, Mandela was released from jail in February and the ANC and other anti-apartheid groups were legalized. De Klerk has promised to end apartheid and share political power with the black majority.

DOC.HEAD: Three Teens Drown in Drain as Storms Sweep Lower Michigan
LaserPhotosFTN2
DOC.TEXT: Three teen-agers wading through a storm drain drowned when a sudden storm flooded the culvert and pinned them inside. Fire officials said } inches of rain fell in less than 20 minutes when thunderstorms hit lower Michigan on Wednesday. ``We had three teens swimming in Gilkey Creek when the heavy rains came,'' Battalion Chief John Balser said. ``All the rain water in the area converges in the one culvert. The water pressure pinned them against a steel grate.'' Marvin Corbin, 17, and Patrick Hoye, 17, and his 13-year-old brother Michael, were killed, said Flint police Sgt. Ron Mossman. The band of storms stretched from Muskegon to Bay City. Heavy rains and gusty winds knocked over small trees in Fenton, while hail fell in Bay, Genesee, Midland and Saginaw counties. Elsewhere, thunderstorms broke out in Minnesota and Nebraska this morning while skies remained cloudy over much of the country after a night of heavy rain, the National Weather Service said.

DOC.HEAD: Shiites Clash And Kidnap Rival Members
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with ambulances bringing out wounded during lull in fighting. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `Police said...'
DOC.TEXT: Rival Shiite Moslem militias battled today with artillery and rockets around mountain villages of south Lebanon for a fourth day and kidnapped each other's members in Beirut. Fighting between the Iranian-backed fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the Syrian-backed Amal militia wounded at least two women and an Amal militiaman. That raised the casualty toll from four days of fighting to 64 Shiites killed and 221 wounded in the area southeast of Sidon, the provincial capital and port 25 miles south of Beirut. Both sides agreed to a midday ``mercy cease-fire'' so casualties could be evacuated, said the International Committee of the Red Cross. Clashes raged on for several hours after the cease-fire was to have taken effect, but finally a convoy of eight ambulances was able to enter the hilltop village of Jarjou, an Amal stronghold captured by Hezbollah late Monday, to take out the dead and wounded. Red Cross teams began bringing the wounded to hospitals in the provincial capital of Sidon, 10 miles to the northeast. Police said earlier that the village square, scene of savage close-quarter fighting Monday, was ``littered with bodies.'' In an attempt to separate the warring militias and stem the Hezbollah advance on Sidon, the PLO has moved into a string of villages including Sarba, which is 2 miles northwest of Jarjou. Amal and Hezbollah have been fighting on and off for three years for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. More than 1,100 people have been killed and nearly 3,400 wounded in the power struggle. Police said masked gunmen from the rival factions raided houses in west and south Beirut during the night in a chain of kidnappings in which at least 40 members of the two organizations were seized. Amal and Hezbollah gunmen fled Beirut's streets after daybreak when Syrian troops moved in to prevent shootouts. Beirut's independent an-Nahar daily reported that the Palestine Liberation Organization, which deployed a force of 600 guerrillas into the battle zone on Tuesday, withdrew an ultimatum to the fundamentalists to pull out of Jarjou. The PLO force, drawn mainly from PLO leader Yasser Arafat's Fatah faction, occupied Sarba and other villages Tuesday to form a 4-mile buffer zone to block Hezbollah's advance west toward the Mediterranean from its mountain strongold. The PLO guerrillas came under Hezbollah shellfire Wednesday and six guerrillas were wounded. The PLO has an estimated 5,000 hard-core fighters in their bases in refugee camps in Sidon. A Hezbollah-controlled region stretching to the coast would open a new supply outlet, cut off Amal's stronghold in the south from Beirut and threaten the Palestinian bases by linking up with anti-Arafat Palestinian radicals. Hezbollah's mountain enclave is bordered in the the east by Israel's self-proclaimed ``security zone'' in southern Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Death Toll in Kirghizia Rises to 212
DOC.TEXT: Fighting has continued along the border between the Soviet Central Asian republics of Kirghizia and Uzbekistan, driving the death toll to 212, the state news agency Tass reported today. ``Reports are still coming in of fights, arson and pogroms,'' Tass reported. ``Passing cars are being stoned. Barricades are being built.'' Fighting broke out June 4 in a land dispute between members of the Kirghiz and Uzbek ethnic groups. Both are largely Sunni Moslem and speak Turkish. The unrest has caused damage estimated at $68 million and left more than 400 people missing and possibly dead, the newspaper Rabochaya Tribuna reported. Earlier, Soviet media had reported 800 people were missing in the area. Soviet authorities have bolstered the contingent of Soviet troops in the region by sending Col. Gen. Yuri Shatalin, commander of Interior Ministry troops, to the region, Tass reported. A series of violent ethnic disputes have erupted intermittently in the Soviet Union since President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has come to power.

DOC.HEAD: Two Die in Crash Of Vintage World War II Plane
DOC.TEXT: A pilot and his stepson died when their World War II-era plane crashed in a grove of trees. The single-engine P-51 Mustang fighter crashed Wednesday, about 30 miles southwest of Minneapolis. Killed were pilot Kermit LaQuey, 58, of St. Michael and Christopher Barnes, 35, of suburban St. Louis. LaQuey was chief pilot for the Planes of Fame Air Museum, which displays 23 military airplanes, almost all from World War II, at Flying Cloud Airport in suburban Minneapolis. Dick Rutan, co-pilot of the first aircraft to fly non-stop around the world without refueling, was piloting a second plane, but did not witness Wednesday's accident, authorities said. Carver County sheriff's officials said LaQuey's plane hit a grove of trees. Federal officials will investigate the crash.

DOC.HEAD: Burmese Students Demand Release of Opposition Leader
DOC.TEXT: About 150 youths marched through the capital today in a protest demanding that the military government free an opposition leader whose party won a national election and allow her to take power. The protest came hours after a peaceful commemoration of Martyrs Day, which marks the the assassination 43 years ago of independence leaders. Those leaders include Gen. Aung San, the father of detained opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi. Her National League for Democracy easily won the May 27 election, but the government has given no indication that it will hand over power or free Ms. Suu Kyi from house arrest. Witnesses said the youths shouted anti-government slogans as they marched to the Martyrs Mausoleum hoisting the banner of Ms. Suu Kyi's party. The number of soldiers around her house has been increased in recent days, Western diplomats contacted in Rangoon from Thailand said. After she led pro-democracy demonstrations that were crushed in 1988, the military government accused Ms. Suu Kyi of subversion and put her under house arrest on July 20, 1989 for one year, saying the sentence could be renewed. Small groups of high school students had staged demonstrations in the city Tuesday and Wednesday calling for her release, a Western diplomat said. A diplomat described an increased presence in the city of troops armed with automatic rifles, particularly around the mausoleum. At the subdued government Martyrs Day ceremonies, the home and information minister, Lt. Gen. Phone Myint, laid a wreath at the mausoleum at the foot of the Shwedagon Pagoda. In the afternoon, members of Ms. Suu Kyi's political party also laid wreaths there. Ms. Suu Kyi held a private religious ceremony inside her house. Ms. Suu Kyi was a leader of the national pro-democracy uprisings that military officers crushed in September 1988 by killing hundreds of people. In May, the military rulers allowed the first multiparty elections in three decades and severely restricted campaigning by the opposition, but Ms. Suu Kyi's party still won 396 of the 485 seats in Parliament. On Friday, Maj. Gen. Khin Nyunt, the head of military intelligence, said the authorities would not yield to international pressure for Ms. Suu Kyi's release and a transfer of power to her party. ``We do not care at all about such threats,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Arabia Appears Poised to Recognize China
DOC.TEXT: China's foreign minister left today for Saudi Arabia, where diplomats said the two nations would announce the establishment of diplomatic relations over the weekend. Winning recognition from Saudi Arabia would be a diplomatic triumph for Beijing, which has seen a sharp drop in exchanges with Western nations since it used its army to crush pro-democracy demonstrations in June of 1989. China has diplomatic relations with most other Arab nations, including the conservative states of Oman, Kuwait and Qatar. It has been eager to establish formal ties with Saudi Arabia, with which it already has trade links. Trade between Saudi Arabia and China totaled $319 million in 1989. China exported $249 million in goods, mainly textiles, light industrial products and food, and imported $70 million worth of goods including chemical fertilizer, wheat and steel. The official Xinhua News Agency reported without explanation Foreign Minister Qian Qichen's departure for Saudi Arabia today. It said he would also visit Cyprus, Morocco and Algeria. Diplomats in the Saudi capital, Riyadh, said the establishing of ties would be announced at a ceremony on Saturday or Sunday. The diplomats spoke on condition of anonymity. There has been a flurry of recent contact between the two countries, including a visit to Beijing last week by Saudi Prince Bandar Bin Sultan. The first indication that a change in Sino-Saudi relations was in the works came in 1988, when it was disclosed that Beijing had sold intermediate-range ballistic missiles to Saudi Arabia. The granting of Saudi recognition to Beijing would be a blow to the rival Nationalist government in Taiwan. Saudi Arabia is one of only 28 nations that recognizes Taiwan. Most of the others are smaller nations in Africa and Latin America. Indonesia this month announced plans to normalize relations with China after a 23-year suspension. The Taiwan government has apparently been advised of Saudi intentions. A Nationalist official said Wednesday that Saudi Arabia's King Fahd had sent word of his plan to make ``certain adjustments'' in Riyadh's relations with Taiwan and the mainland. The Nationalist official, Vice Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen, refused to disclose the exact contents of the letter, but it was believed to express Saudi Arabia's plan to switch recognition. The Nationalists lost a civil war on the mainland in 1949 and fled to the island province of Taiwan, but continue to maintain that they are China's legitimate rulers.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Drops Federal Charges Against Woman in Drug Cult Slayings
DOC.TEXT: A judge has dismissed federal charges against a woman who investigators call the high priestess of a drug cult that sacrificed 15 people, but she remains in jail facing state charges, her lawyer says. Federal Criminal Court Judge Bernardo Tirado dismissed charges of homicide, resisting arrest and causing injuries to others that were filed against Sara Maria Aldrete Villareal, 25, a former honors student at Texas Southmost College in Brownsville, her attorney, Horacio Moyar Quintanilla, said Wednesday. She also had faced a fourth federal charge of criminal association. The judge ruled that Ms. Aldrete, who has been jailed since her arrest in May 1989, would not have to face any further penalties regarding that charge, which carries a sentence of six months to six years in prison, Moyar said. Court officials were not available for comment late Wednesday on the judge's ruling. On Tuesday, federal prosecutors had recommended dropping the charges of homicide, resisting arrest and causing injuries to others. The federal charges stem from the May 6 shootout in Mexico City in which Ms. Aldrete and four other cult members were arrested and the cult's alleged ringleader, Adolfo de Jesus Constanzo, and his bodyguard were shot to death. Prosecutors said Ms. Aldrete and Constanzo and other cult members had made a pact to kill each other rather than face arrest. They said she encouraged a fellow cult member to shoot Constanzo and his bodyguard as police closed in on their hideout. The judge's ruling clears the way for Ms. Aldrete to be transferred from a federal prison in Mexico City to a state prison in Matamoros, Moyar said in a telephone interview with The Associated Press. She is expected to go on trial next week in Matamoros, where she faces Tamulipas state charges including homicide, drug trafficking and secretly burying people, Moyar said. Mexico does not have the death penalty. She faces a maximum penalty of 40 years in prison. Moyar said he would fight transfering Ms. Aldrete to the Matamoros prison because he feared for his client's safety. ``She doesn't want to go,'' he said. ``It's dangerous there. There are problems with the families of victims.'' He also said he would seek to get the state charges dropped. Ms. Aldrete has maintained her innocence and denied that she had anything to do with the ritual slayings of 15 people, including Mark Kilroy, a 21-year-old University of Texas student whose mutilated body was found buried at a ranch near Matamoros across the border from Brownsville, Texas, in April 1989. Mexican investigators have described Ms. Aldrete as a ``witch'' involved in a Mexican drug cult that made human sacrifices. Authorities say Constanzo had overseen the ritual killings of the 15 men and boys at the ranch near Matamoros in April, telling members of his drug trafficking ring the deaths would give them spiritual protection from police.
