Police say Ms. Aldrete took part in at least one of the ritual killings, selecting the victim and supervising his murder.

DOC.HEAD: Tour Operators Accuse U.S. Of Pressuring Kenya
DOC.TEXT: Tour operators, smarting from a drop in business, have accused the United States of discouraging tourism in an effort to pressure Kenya's one-party government to adopt political reforms. A U.S. official denied the allegation, which stems from State Department's advice to Americans on July 10 to postpone all non-essential travel to the East African nation following riots that left at least 28 people dead. Sam Mwaura, chairman of the Kenya Tour Operators Association, told the government in a letter that ``it is our considered opinion that tourism is now being used to put pressure to bear on the government to achieve certain political objectives.'' Kenyan politicians have accused the United States and embassy officials in Nairobi of backing advocates of multiparty politics in the one-party state. Tourism is Kenya's top foreign currency earner, bringing the country $240 million in 1989. Last year, 713,800 tourists, mainly from Europe, visited Kenya. Many of the tourists visit the nation's game preserves. In his letter, Mwaura urged the Ministry of Tourism and Wildlife to seek ways of persuading the State Department to withdraw its travel advisory. Mwaura wrote the letter Tuesday, a day after association executives met U.S. Embassy officials on the issue. An embassy spokesman denied the United States was pressuring the Kenya government. ``The State Department issues travel advisories to help American citizens make intelligent decisions. They are not a political weapon.'' The State Department revised the advisory today but advised Americans to excercise caution when visiting Kenya. Mwaura said the State Department's warning also had led to cancellations of bookings from several European countries and Australia. He said a similar but ``fairly mild'' warning by the British government had also contributed to those cancellations. Mwaura said one local company, which he did not identify, was losing $100,000 daily in canceled bookings from the United States. The U.S. criticism of Kenya's government was stepped up ealier this month when Kenya detained without trial or charge seven advocates of multipary politics. Those detained indefinitely include two former Cabinet ministers and the son of a former vice president. The four days of riots began July 7 after police wielding wooden clubs and firing tear gas dispersed a crowd attemping to hold a pro-democracy rally a few blocks from downtown Nairobi. The violence spread into Nairobi suburbs, four other major towns and several rural communities where rioters burned vehicles, battled police with rocks and looted stores.

DOC.HEAD: Rev. Al Sharpton Behind Bars for 15-Day Sentence
LaserPhotoNY24 of July 18
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Al Sharpton was behind bars today as part of his 15-day disorderly conduct sentence for a 1988 ``Day of Outrage'' protest. Sharpton and the Rev. Timothy Mitchell were convicted at a non-jury trial before state Supreme Court Justice Phyllis Flug. Charges against 11 others were dismissed. They surrendered to authorities Wednesday afternoon and were taken to jail where they were placed in maximum security, protective custody, said Corrections spokeswoman Ruby Ryles. The protective status isolates them from the general prison population. Ryles said they were given that status because of their notoriety. Sharpton's 15-day sentence stems from a Jan. 27, 1988 ``Day of Outrage'' rally during the Howard Beach racial attack trial. Hundreds of protesters brought traffic around La Guardia Airport to a standstill. With good behavior, the pair could be out in 10 days, Ryles said.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Civil Rights Bill
With PM-Civil Rights, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are the major provisions of the civil rights bill passed by the Senate Wednesday night. The bill: _Prohibits harassing, firing or otherwise discriminating against employees because of their race. _Requires employers to justify employment practices whose negative impact falls disproportionately on minority groups by proving in court that they are based on business necessity. _Bars lawsuits challenging court-approved, fair-employment agreements except in a few unusual instances. _Makes illegal any reliance on prejudice in making employment decisions. _Grants all victims of intentional discrimination the right to sue for compensatory damages and, in the most serious cases, punitive damages. _Eases the way for court challenges to discriminatory seniority plans.

DOC.HEAD: 911 Operator Ignores Frantic Call; Victim Found Dead
DOC.TEXT: An emergency operator ignored a witness's frantic call about an abduction that left a 19-year-old woman dead, police said. Police were trying to determine whether the 911 operator's failure to dispatch officers to the scene cost the victim her life, said Police Chief Drew Diamond. A woman telephoned police Friday night about an accident she witnessed in southeast Tulsa, Diamond said. A motorist left the road, drove onto a sidewalk and struck a woman, identified as Tammy Garret, authorities said. The witness told the 911 operator that the driver stopped and put the woman inside the car. Ms. Garrett's body was found the next morning in a nearby field along the Arkansas River. She was stabbed several times and her throat slashed. Police believe she was killed in the field. Jack G. Lynch, 33, was arrested Tuesday and was held on a murder charge, court records show. ``It should have gone out as a Priority One call,'' Diamond said Wednesday at a news conference. ``This call was not, regrettably, put into the system.'' Diamond said the operator also failed to record the name of the caller, who police believe may be the only witness to the abduction. The caller volunteered her name but the operator said it wasn't needed. Diamond would not speculate whether police dispatched to the scene could have prevented Ms. Garrett's death, even though the caller was able to provide the location, description of the suspect's car and the vehicle's tag number. The information led to Lynch's arrest on Tuesday, said Lt. Jack Putnam. ``There's just no way to tell,'' Diamond said. ``We've been struggling with that question. We want to sleep, also.'' The 911 operator, who Diamond refused to identify, resigned Wednesday after being on the job for only 30 days.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher of Tintin Magazine and Asterix Comics Dies
DOC.TEXT: Publisher Georges Dargaud, who launched the wildly popular Tintin magazine and Asterix comic-book series, died after a long illness, his publishing house announced today. He was 79. The spokeswoman for the publisher, Dargaud Editeur, did not disclose the cause of Dargaud's death on Wednesday. Dargaud founded the publishing house in 1936 and took an active role in its operation until selling it to the Media Participation group in January 1989. In 1948, Dargaud began a 27-year relationship with the Belgian artist Herge to publish Tintin magazine, in which the comic hero and his faithful dog Milou narrated news and feature articles written for young people. Dargaud launched Pilot magazine in 1960 and used it to introduce such characters as the Gaul warrior Asterix and the lonesome cowboy Lucky Luke, which were later spun off into films and hard-bound books. The adventures of Asterix and his fellow tribesmen battling Caesar's legions in Roman-era France are among the best-selling comic series in France today. The publishing house sells 2 million copies of the 30 original Asterix titles a year in 33 languages. A theme park based on Asterix's village opened in northern France last year. Dargaud was an officer of the Legion of Honor of Arts and Letters. He is survived by his wife, Irene, and daughter, Corinne. Funeral arrangements were pending.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Oilman Kills Daughter in Her Iron Lung, Then Himself
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Family caretaker ...' to CORRECT day to Tuesday, sted Wednesday. Picks up 4th graf, ```The (note)...'
DOC.TEXT: A retired oilman shot to death his 61-year-old daughter, a polio victim who used an iron lung, and then killed himself, officials said. Ammy Harlin Drake, 94, opened Alta Jeanne Drake's iron lung, shot her twice in the chest, returned to his lounge chair and shot himself with a .32-caliber revolver early Tuesday, police said. Family caretaker Helen Jackson found the bodies Tuesday and along with a note from Ammy Drake, detailing funeral arrangements. ``The (note) indicated he couldn't take care of her anymore and that there was no one around to take care of her,'' said police Capt. E.L. Holman. The Dallas County Medical Examiners Office ruled the death a homicide-suicide. Relatives said Ms. Drake's health was failing and her father had cancer. Those who knew Ms. Drake said her fear of being institutionlized may have led her to devise the shooting. ``Jeanne may have made the decision (to die),'' said Ms. Drake's cousin, Joeza Dailey. ``My cousin had a horror of being in an institution, and she had no faith in any sort of help from the state, or any sort of governmental help.'' Paralyzed by polio, Ms. Drake has used an iron lung since 1951, one year after she was graduated from Southern Methodist University. She had married six months earlier. Her husband left her in 1956; her mother died in 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Approves Universal Service Law
DOC.TEXT: The Lithuanian parliament has approved a compulsory service law for the Baltic republic's young men, a spokesman said today. The law may lead to increased tensions between the republic and the central Soviet government, which carries out a military draft. The Lithuanian law will require a year of mandatory service in civilian work units for young men between the ages of 19 and 26. They could also elect to undergo the military training that many high school and college students now receive as part of the standard Soviet education system. Simas Ardziunas, a representative of the parliament's information bureau, said in an interview that some deputies who voted against the law when it was approved Tuesday argued that it could lead to the creation of a Lithuanian army. The vote in the Supreme Council was 68-16 with 22 deputies abstaining. Ardziunas said the law does not go into effect until the government can issue a directive including all the details of service. No barracks or camps yet exist for the force, he said. ``The law says nothing about any weapons,'' Ardziunas added. Youths serving in the force would be available for service along the border and in case of natural disasters, he said. Lithuania declared its independence from the Soviet Union on March 11 and for months has been embroiled in a dispute with Mikhail S. Gorbachev about it. Gorbachev slapped a tough economic embargo on the republic. On June 29, the Supreme Council voted to place a moratorium on the declaration, to take effect when talks with Soviet officials begin on independence. Soviet officials immediately began lifting the embargo.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Says Financier Skewed Results of Telephone Poll on Trump
DOC.TEXT: Cincinnati financier Carl H. Lindner Jr. skewed results of a call-in telephone poll on Donald Trump conducted for USA Today, the newspaper said today. The newspaper said an independent analysis of the call-in results to a ``Trump hot line'' from June 8 through June 10 showed that 5,640 of 7,802 calls came from two phone numbers at Great American Insurance Co., a subsidiary of Lindner's American Financial Corp. Lindner would not comment, the newspaper said, but a spokeswoman for him said the calls were made because Lindner and others at the company admire Trump's ``entrepreneurial spirit.'' The newspaper said it studied phone records generated by Airdata Inc., a call-in service company, because of some apparent last-minute ballot-stuffing. From 5 p.m. to 6 p.m. EDT on June 10, the final hour of the three-day call-in period, more than 1,000 calls poured in. Ninety-three percent of those calls were pro-Trump, the newspaper said. Callers were asked to say which statement they agreed with: ``Donald Trump symbolizes what makes the USA a great country`` or ``Donald Trump symbolizes the things that are wrong with this country.'' Trump won in a ``landslide,'' the newspaper said, with 5,215, or 81 percent, agreeing with the first statement despite Trump's recent financial and marital problems. The second statement got 1,191 votes, or 19 percent of the 6,406 callers who cast votes, the newspapers said. The newspaper quoted a statement from the Lindner organization that said Trump was an example of the entrepreneurial spirit that builds businesses and creates jobs. ``We feel that the intent of this survey seemed to have been to have a good laugh at someone's misfortune,'' the statement said. The newspaper called such surveys ``strictly for fun'' and ``unscientific.'' It added that it would take steps to prevent such skewed results in the future, while guaranteeing callers' privacy.

DOC.HEAD: Strutton Named Publisher of Rocky Mountain News
DOC.TEXT: Larry Strutton, president of Baltimore Sunpapers, was named president, publisher and chief executive officer of the Rocky Mountain News, where he began his career 26 years ago as a linotype operator. He succeeds William Fletcher, who was elected chairman of the board. Strutton, 49, will assume his new positions at the News in six weeks, Fletcher said Wednesday. Strutton began his career in the News' composing room in 1964. He was named production director in 1972, and left in 1982 to become vice president of production at the Detroit Free Press. Strutton joined the Los Angeles Times as vice president of operations in 1983 and was promoted to executive vice president in 1986. In April 1989, Times-Mirror Corp. named him president of Baltimore Sunpapers.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Major Civil Rights Measure But Door Open to Deal
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS new 6th graf, In San Antonio... to UPDATE with Quayle reaction
DOC.TEXT: Sponsors of a bill to combat job bias, fresh from victory in the Senate, say they would welcome a compromise to ease White House concern that the plan could lead to hiring quotas. ``We'll continue to consider any proposals from the president,'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., the chief sponsor, said Wednesday night after the Senate approved the measure, 65-34. ``But we're not going to sacrifice the essential principles of this legislation.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, traveling with President Bush in Anaheim, Calif., said the administration was disappointed by the outcome of the Senate's vote. ``We'll work to change it in the House,'' Fitzwater said. ``We still want a bill we can sign.'' Fitzwater later issued a statement saying that the ``president wants a bill that ends discrimination, not one that starts a quota system.'' In San Antonio, Vice President Dan Quayle told reporters today, ``The administration is not going to have a quota bill crammed down its throat disguised as a civil rights bill. This is a quota bill, pure and simple.'' The bill is the top legislative priority of the civil rights movement. It would effectively overturn five Supreme Court decisions on job discrimination handed down last year. While Kennedy said he would ``welcome the president's support,'' he also said the margin of victory suggested that it would be possible to override a veto if Bush refused to sign. Ten Republicans joined 55 Democrats in propelling the measure through the Senate, while 34 GOP senators voted against the bill. The House Judiciary Committee is expected to start work within days on its version of the legislation, whose provisions range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to punitive damages for victims of the worst kinds of employment discrimination. The sharpest clashes, however, have come over a provision that would make it easier to challenge employment practices whose negative effects fall disproportionately on minority groups. The Supreme Court's decision last year in a case involving a salmon cannery in Alaska said such practices do not violate the law unless those filing suit can show they were not prompted by business necessity. The bill would require the companies challenged in such suits to prove that the practices in question were justified by business necessity. The provision is similar to the law as it was before the high court decision. The administration, some Republican senators and business groups contend that the bill's definition of business necessity, combined with possible punitive damages that would frighten lawyers, would lead to quotas. Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., told the Senate that corporate lawyers would look for ways to insulate their companies from the danger of such suits and tell executives: ``Better make certain that your percentage of the workforce matches the percentage of available applicants.'' Kennedy maintained throughout the debate that the bill would not lead to quotas. He said experience before the Supreme Court's decision proved it. ``The false hue and cry of quotas is a disservice to the president of the United States, a disreputable tactic by those who don't care about civil rights for women and minorities,'' Kennedy said. But he negotiated with White House chief of staff John Sununu for weeks in an effort to alleviate administration concerns. The last bargaining session broke up at midnight Tuesday. Even then, Bush sent three Republican senators from the White House to Capitol Hill on Wednesday morning with a fresh proposal. It failed to galvanize sufficient support. Sen. John C. Danforth, R-Mo., said the hangup remained the definition of ``business necessity.'' He said ``every combination of words has been tried.'' ``We are now proceeding on the road to a certain veto,'' Danforth said. ``This is a bill that can do a lot of good for a lot of people and it is going nowhere.'' Tempers frayed on the Senate floor Wednesday night. Republican leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said he had never before voted against civil rights legislation but that this measure was being ``rammed down my throat.'' He made it clear he was still upset that Democratic sponsors won a time limit on debate before it began, which gave Republicans little time to present amendments. In retaliation, Dole used a tactical move to bar moderate Democrats from attaching some politically sensitive amendments they had wanted, including a cap on punitive damages that had been sought as a way of easing concerns among small businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq's Parliament Proposes Presidency For Life for Saddam Hussein
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's parliament has approved a plan to make Saddam Hussein the president for life and scrap planned elections, Iraq's official news agency reported today. Saddam has been tightening his grip on power while establishing himself as one of the Arab world's most ruthless rulers. The 250-member assembly, dominated by Saddam's Baath Party, approved the president-for-life proposal at a three-day session on planned constitutional changes, according to the official Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Nicosia. The session ended Wednesday, but it was not clear from the report whether the measures were binding or the vote final. No details were provided about the proposals. Saddam, 54, had promised political reforms _ including a multiparty system and a free press _ following the August 1988 cease-fire in the eight-year war with Iran. But today's report said lawmakers had altered a proposal that would have provided for Iraq's first elections since it became a republic in 1958. Saddam had said he would run in the election _ whose date had never been set _ but no one had come forth to challenge him. Under the current constitution, the president is elected by the 10-member Revolutionary Command Council composed of senior officials of the Baath Party. The current constitution was drawn up in 1968 when the party seized power in a coup. Saddam has ruled with an iron fist since July 1979, when he took over as president from Gen. Ahmed al Bakr. A final draft of the new constitution is to be drawn up by the Baath Party and the 10-man Revolutionary Command Council headed by Saddam. Saddam exercises near-total rule over Iraq's 17 million people through his vast security apparatus. The inner circle of Iraq's leadership is packed with Saddam's relatives, by blood or marriage, from his extended clan from Takrit in northern Iraq. The Baath Party is ostensibly socialist and pan-Arab but is now virtually devoid of any ideology beyond Saddam's policies. Saddam has turned his reign into a personality cult that has reached the realms of near-mythology. Photos and posters of him are everywhere. It is a capital offense to insult him publicly. Iraqi dissident sources have claimed in recent weeks that as many as 40 senior military figures, including a cousin of Saddam, have been arrested and probably executed in Saddam's latest purge. There has been no independent confirmation of the reports. Since the cease-fire in the war with Iran, Saddam has revived his ambitions to become the paramount leader of the Arab world and has built up an arsenal of long-range missiles and chemical weapons that has drawn denunciations from the West and Israel. He has also taken a belligerent stand against violators of production quotas set by the Organization of Petroleu Exporting Nations. This week Saddam threatened to retaliate against Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates with force for violating production quotas, saying they were responsible for driving down prices and costing Iraq $14 billion in lost revenues in the last year. Saddam accused quota violators of stabbing Iraq in the back ``with a poisoned dagger.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Leaders Say U.S. Shift Might Push Khmer Rouge To Fight On
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to ADD Congressional reaction. Pickup 5th graf pvs, `But resistance...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY8
DOC.TEXT: Angry non-Communist Cambodian guerrillas say the withdrawal of U.S. recognition, though intended to spur a peaceful settlement, could force them closer to China and strengthen the Khmer Rouge. China indicated today that it had no intention of joining the United States in changing who it recognizes and would continue aiding the Khmer Rouge, the strongest fighting force in the three-party resistance coalition. Cambodia's government, along with its Vietnamese backers, welcomed the U.S. move, but Indonesia and Thailand said it would not weaken the Khmer Rouge. Cambodia described the U.S. action as ``paving the way for achievement of an early political settlement,'' the nation's official SPK news agency said. In Wasington, Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, called for an end to covert U.S. aid to Cambodia's rebel coalition. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said Wednesday that ``there is simply no excuse to delay additional action'' that would go beyond the Bush administration announcement. But resistance leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk called the U.S. move ``an act of very serious injustice'' and appealed to all governments to keep Washington from trying to strip the coalition of Cambodia's seat in the United Nations. The coalition will now be ``more firm and fierce in their determination to continue to resist,'' he said in a statement from North Korea's capital, Pyongyang, where he lives part of the year. Vietnam invaded Cambodia in 1978, ending a four-year reign of terror by a Khmer Rouge government that tried to force a radical agrarian commune on the population, killing hundreds of thousands of people. The government it installed has been battling insurgents for 11 years. The war has widened in recent months, with the Khmer Rouge scoring victories. Reflecting fears of a Khmer Rouge takeover, the Bush administration announced Wednesday that it was withdrawing recognition of the resistance coalition and opening a dialogue with Vietnam on resolving the war. Vietnam's foreign minister, Nguyen Co Thach, said his country was ready to negotiate ``with concerned countries'' on Cambodia, the official Vietnam News Agency reported today. The Cambodian government's SPK news agency reported the U.S. move without comment today. Cambodian peace talks have foundered, with the guerrilla coalition rejecting the wish of the Hanoi-backed government of Prime Minister Hun Sen to remain in power during a transitional period before elections. The guerrillas want to share power or have the United Nations assume authority _ and Sihanouk and the head of the third rebel faction, former Prime Minister Son Sann, have refused to abandon the Khmer Rouge. They say the Khmer Rouge would only fight on if left out of a settlement. Sihanouk said the U.S. move will only perpetuate the rule of a government that is ``a creature and creation'' of Vietnam. The Vietnamese claim they withdrew all their troops in September, but there is evidence Vietnamese soldiers remain and are supporting government forces against the rebels. In Beijing today, Foreign Ministry spokesman Jin Guihua said all Cambodian factions must be included in any politicial settlement. ``So long as Vietnam does not withdraw all its troops from Cambodia genuinely, China will continue to support the Cambodian people in their resistance against the foreign invaders,'' he told a news conference. Jin did not specificially mention Chinese aid to the communist Khmer Rouge, but China is known to be their main weapons supplier. He refused to answer questions about whether the U.S. change in policy would prompt Beijing to increase aid to the Khmer Rouge. There was no immediate indication of whether Washington intends to cut its non-lethal and covert military aid to the non-communist factions. A Thai analyst involved in the aid program said the U.S. decision will affect the Khmer Rouge politically but not militarily ``and might push them to concentrate on a military solution.'' The official spoke on condition of anonymity. Indonesia's foreign minister, Ali Alatas, said in Jakarta that the six Southeast Asian countries involved in the Cambodia peace process had been informed in advance of the U.S. move but were doubtful it would lead to peace. The Khmer Rouge's 30,000-member army is reported to have struck in virtually every province in Cambodia in an unprecedented escalation of the war, attacking five provincial capitals in the south, north and west in recent weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Government Wants To Question Security Guard About Alleged Drug Use
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; editing throughout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The government said today it has evidence about cocaine use by one of Marion Barry's security guards, a city police officer who was the leadoff witness for the defense in the mayor's drug and perjury trial. Assistant U.S. attorney Judith Retchin said she wants to question police Sgt. James Stays, a member of the mayor's security detail, ``about his involvement with cocaine and Mr. Barry.'' Her comments came in court with the jury out of the room. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson said legal counsel should be appointed for Stays and that prosecutors could question the security officer about the alleged drug use. Barry attorney R. Kenneth Mundy said prosecutors should not be allowed to question Stays about alleged drug use, but the judge overruled Mundy's objection. The defense had called Stays as its first witness. Before his testimony was interrupted, the 29-year police veteran contradicted minor points in the testimony of two government witnesses. ``The witness has used cocaine on an occasion within the statute of limitations,'' said Retchin after her cross-examination of Stays and after the jury had been sent out of the courtroom. The issue of Stays' alleged cocaine use came up after he testified that he knew Willie Davis. Government witnesses have testified that Davis used cocaine with the mayor. Davis, a former aide to Birmingham, Ala., mayor Richard Arrington, has not been called to testify in the case. After Stays told the court he knew Davis, Retchin asked him if he had told another security officer that Davis ``provides Mr. Barry with cocaine.'' ``Me?'' replied Stays. ``No.'' The jury was then sent out of the courtroom so that Retchin and Mundy could argue about further questioning of Stays. Earlier, the judge denied the last of the defense's motions for acquittal, including the one stemming from an FBI sting operation in which the mayor was videotaped smoking crack cocaine. In addition to the charge stemming from the sting, Jackson let stand a conspiracy charge and two cocaine possession charges. One Wednesday, he rejected motions for acquittal on the other 10 charges drug and perjury charges against the mayor. Barry's lawyers had said he was entrapped in the videotaped sting operation. They also said the government had failed to prove there was a single conspiracy involving the mayor and that witnesses had failed to substantiate the dates of the two cocaine possession charges. The judge said court rulings did not support Barry's position on the entrapment question. Jackson also said there were a series of interlocking conspiracies, with Barry at the hub. He said the courts give leeway to the government by not requiring it in all cases to prove precise dates on which crimes were committed. The prosecution ended its case Wednesday with testimony from a city police detective that Barry made more than 2,000 calls on his car phone to people who supplied him with drugs. The detective said the calls were made in a four-year span starting in 1986. In 4{ weeks of testimony, 10 prosecution witnesses testified that Barry snorted cocaine and smoked crack, opium and marijuana about 200 times from 1983 to this year. Barry has pleaded innocent to the single conspiracy charge, 10 counts of cocaine possession and three felony charges of lying to a federal grand jury.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Sentences Two in Phone-Tapping of NY Times Bureau
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court has upheld the conviction of the publisher and the former managing editor of a leading Greek daily in the phone-tapping of The New York Times' bureau in Athens, a court spokesman said today. The three-member court sentenced the two men to 20 days in jail, but they were permitted to avoid imprisonment by paying a fine, the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. The amount of the fine was not disclosed. Under Greek law, people convicted in cases not related to narcotics may pay to reduce or eliminate their prison terms if the terms are less than 18 months. The decision upheld the conviction of Ethnos publisher George Bobolas and former Managing Editor Alekos Filippopoulos in May 1985, the spokesman said. Bobolas, 63, and Filippopoulos, 60, were found guilty of providing the former socialist government of Premier Andreas Papandreou with tapes of conversations tapped at the home and office of a journalist working for the New York Times and Daily Telegraph of London in July 1983. Greek-Cypriot journalist Paul Anastasi took legal action when Ethnos published his conversations with a lawyer a week later. In a separate story, the paper alleged that the conversations were coded and actually referred to a plot designed to overthrow the socialist government. The appeals court convened last week to determine the final sentence but their decision was made known today, the court spokesman said. Anastasi and the Ethnos newspaper have been in court in a series of related trials since 1983, following the journalist's publication of his book called ``Take The Nation In Your Hands.'' The book alleged that Ethnos was launched to promote Soviet propaganda and disinformation in Greece. Anastasi was sentenced to one year in jail for libel and was allowed to buy off his prison sentence. But he never withdrew his allegations. Bobolas, Filippopoulos and three senior Ethnos editors are to stand trial on charges of defaming and libeling Anastasi and of perjury in connection with the phone-tapping case. If found guilty of perjury, the accused could be banned from journalism and publishing.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Holding Up Generic Drug Applications from Pittsburgh Lab
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration said today it is holding up applications for approval of generic drugs tested by a Pittsburgh lab whose work has been found by the agency to be flawed. Pending applications based on the testing of Biodecision Laboratories Inc. were put on hold while the FDA continues its review of the results of an inspection of the lab, said FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit. The FDA's inspection, in which 13 studies conducted by the lab on candidate generic drugs were reviewed, found that all but two violated FDA regulations or fell short of accepted laboratory practice. The findings of the inspection, conducted last October through January, were released earlier this week. Biodecision is one of the nation's largest independent testing labs. The studies were to determine whether the candidate generic drug worked the same as the patented drug for which it would be sold as a substitute. A generic drug must be shown to be ``bioequivalent'' to a name-brand drug before it can win FDA approval. Nesbit said seven of the 11 drugs in which Biodecision's studies were flawed are not currently being sold. The remaining four are antibiotics, for which a broad potency range is acceptable. Nesbit said he did not know how many generic drug applications were being held up. Biodecision President Robert Lecher was quoted in The Pittsburgh Press as saying the laboratory has confirmed the findings of the 11 tests questioned by the FDA. Lecher said the re-evaluations were part of the lab's efforts to work with the FDA to correct problems found in the inspection. The lab has corrected all but one of the deficiencies cited in the inspection, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rep. Boggs Reportedly Considering Retiring
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Lindy Boggs reportedly will not seek re-election to the congressional seat she and her late husband have held for 46 years. Mrs. Boggs, 74, was expected to announce her decision Friday. She has been under increasing emotional and physical strain because of the illness of her elder daughter, Barbara Sigmund, friends of the family say. The daughter, mayor of Princeton, N.J., is suffering from cancer. The Washington office of the Louisiana Democrat refused today to comment on the reports in the New Orleans media. Earlier this week, Mrs. Boggs said, ``When I make up my mind positively, I'll certainly let everyone know.'' She assumed the post in March 1973 after winning a special election to succeed her husband, the powerful House majority leader, whose plane disappeared during a flight over Alaska six months earlier. The primary election for the 2nd Congressional District _ which encompasses most of New Orleans, will be Oct. 6. A runoff, if needed, would be Nov. 6.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Gives First Go-Ahead to Women in Military
DOC.TEXT: Women could volunteer for service in the Italian military, one of the last all-male armed forces in Europe, under legislation approved by a parliamentary committee. The bill passed Wednesday by the Defense Committee of the Senate also would reduce the draft for men from 12 months to 10 months and offer alternative service in such fields as civil defense and environmental protection. Increasing numbers of Italian women have been joining the police forces in recent years, but the armed forces have remained closed to them. Elsewhere in Europe, women have joined the military in many countries. The bill would open up the Italian services to women as volunteers and offer careers to them as officers and non-commissioned officers but would exclude them from combat roles. The bill must go before the full Senate and then to the Chamber of Deputies.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Court: Cigarettes Are Not Drugs
DOC.TEXT: A chain smoker may be addicted, but cigarettes are not drugs, according to the Swiss Supreme Court. The Federal Tribunal's ruling upheld a lower court which ordered a health insurance company to pay $12,850 in sick benefits to a heavy smoker who had fallen ill. The insurers had refused payment, arguing that their contract did not provide for sick-benefit money for illnesses caused by abusive use of drugs or medicines. In the ruling published Thursday, the Federal Tribunal said while smoking may lead to addiction, cigarettes cannot be legally categorized as drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Warns Against Defacing Banknotes
DOC.TEXT: The Central Bank delivered a stiff public warning Thursday to stem the rising number of people defacing banknotes with what it termed ``indecent expressions.'' Notices appeared in English-language and Arabic newspapers cautioning that writing on a banknote could cancel its monetary value. The bank said Oman had introduced security measures in banknote printing technology to prevent what it called ``forgery and cheating.'' But it said: ``It has been observed for some time that there is an increasing trend among the public to write on banknotes _ telephone numbers, names, verses of poetry or even indecent expressions.'' The bank statement noted that the designs and words of the notes are also sometimes tampered with. ``Keeping our banknotes in a good condition is a national duty, observance of which indicates our civilized attitudes and behavior,'' the statement added. The Omani rial is currently worth about 38 cents.

DOC.HEAD: Baker, Shevardnadze to Meet in Siberia
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III will meet with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in the Siberian city of Irkutsk after touring Asia early next month, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said Thursday. Spokesman Vadim Perfiliev said he did have exact dates for the meeting or any other details. ``Such a meeting is under preparation right now,'' he told reporters. ``Irkutsk was chosen because of the fact that Mr. Baker will be touring Asian countries, and geographically that was the location that turned out to be very convenient for the meeting of the two sides.'' Irkutsk is located near Lake Baikal, north of Mongolia. Baker's visit would repay the visit Shevardnadze made to Jackson Hole, Wyo., last fall.

DOC.HEAD: Italians Decry Failure of Motorists to Help Desperate Child
DOC.TEXT: Six-year-old Vanessa Moretti left her dying father in the car along a busy highway and dashed away for help. She ran a mile along a guard rail, falling and scratching her arms on branches, desperately seeking aid from scores of vacation-bound travelers speeding past. No one stopped. The little girl's case has startled Italians and prompted some columnists to speculate about whether their country is losing its soul as it accumulates ever greater wealth. ``We have begun to show the cold, glacial face that even a few years ago we reproached other, richer countries for having,'' columnist Sabino Acquaviva said in the Milan-based daily Corriere della Sera. The incident last Saturday drew particular outrage because it occurred along the ``Sun Highway'' near the western coast that thousands of Italians were traveling for the start of their vacations. Several newspapers said vacationers were so intent on reaching the beach they ignored a desperate child on the side of the highway. ``The weekend of mass exodus, of the big departure of the army of vacationers, opened with a tragedy made even more bitter by an incredible cynicism,'' the Turin-based La Stampa said. The little girl finally succeeded in stopping a motorist, who alerted highway police. But it was too late to save her father, 34-year-old Marco Moretti, who had died of a heart attack while driving his daughter to the beach at Monte Argentario in central Italy. ``The `Beautiful Country' doesn't exist anymore: the days of spaghetti and guitars, of courtesy and sweetness, are over,'' Acquaviva wrote. ``Because we have inculcated in people the philosophy of well-being, we have created egoists, consumers, people who ultimately are alone and unhappy.'' The case reflected the unease felt by some Italians over the changes in their country as it has become wealthy during eight years of uninterrupted economic growth. Italians who lived in poverty just four decades ago have enjoyed a consumer boom, donning designer clothes, buying bigger cars and taking exotic vacations in places like Indonesia and Mauritius. In real terms, Italians spent three times as much in 1988 for television sets and other recreational equipment as they did in 1971, according to the government statistics institute ISTAT. Some people have expressed concern that Italians have become selfish and indifferent to others as they have grown wealthier. ``The average citizen ... ever more frequently lives involved in and absorbed by his own problems, interests and affairs, immersed almost exclusively in his own world,'' the respected Rome-based think-tank Censis said in a report released last December.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Grand Jury Subpoenas Financial Records of S.C. House Members
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with more on possible FBI sting. Picks up 4th graf, `U.S. Attorney ...' ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: A federal grand jury subpoenaed campaign records for all 124 state representatives in connection with an FBI sting in which lawmakers were allegedly offered cash for votes, according to legislators and media reports today. A lobbyist allegedly paid cash to about 30 lawmakers in exchange for votes on an unidentified issue, The Greenville News and WBTW-TV in Florence reported, citing unidentified sources. An attorney who said he was approached by several lawmakers because of the probe said, in the alleged sting operation, a fake lobbyist offered money to lawmakers in exchange for legislative favors. The attorney requested anonymity. The House Ethics Committee received the subpoena Wednesday for the financial disclosure forms for all House members going back to 1988, said the committee's chairman, Rep. Pat Harris. U.S. Attorney Bart Daniel refused to comment on the subpoenas. ``We can neither confirm nor deny the existence of any federal grand jury investigation,'' Daniel said Wednesday night. Several lawmakers, including one senator, said they were individually served subpoenas. Many said they were surprised and puzzled by the order. House Speaker Bob Sheheen said that two House members told him FBI agents that visited the lawmakers wanted to know if cash contributions were made to their campaigns. ``They wanted to know whether those contributions were deposited in their camapaign accounts,'' Sheheen said. The investigation apparently involves possible violations of the Hobbs Act, a federal anti-corruption law that prohibits legislators' acceptance of money or gifts in return for promised performance, said an attorney who spoke on conditin of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Future Flight: Three-Eighths Of An Inch Off The Ground
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Federal railroad officials are predicting a new era in ground transportation where trains that zip over a magnetic field at 300 mph can compete with air travel. At least two magnetic levitation trains, or ``maglevs,'' will be running in the United States before the end of the 1990s, Federal Railroad Administrator Gilbert E. Carmichael predicted. His agency this week released a report on the technology. In addition, Carmichael said, two or three high-speed rail, steel-on-steel systems could be built. The report said magnetically levitated trains that float along at three-eighths of an inch or more from a magnetized rail are feasible for the United States even without significant federal funding. With planning for such systems moving ahead in California, Nevada, Florida, Texas and Pennsylvania, Carmichael said it is still possible for the U.S. to take the lead in a technology on which the Germans and Japanese already have each spent $1 billion to develop. The German and Japanese systems operate differently than that proposed for the U.S., with the Japanese train riding several inches above a stronger magnetic field. The fiscal 1992 federal budget so far includes $12 million to study high-speed trains. Congress failed to act last year on a Senate committee study that recommended $750 million over six years to develop a U.S. maglev technology. But there are signs of growing private interest in magnetic trains: _ On Monday, a partnership headed by Bechtel International Inc. of San Francisco put up $500,000 for the right to bid on a $5 billion maglev train between Southern California and Las Vegas. Planners hope to have the train running in seven years. _ Business and government leaders in Pittsburgh are moving to make the city a technological and manufacturing base for the German-developed system, while developing a 19-mile demonstration run between downtown Pittsburgh and the city's airport. _ A privately funded project in Florida is planning to build a 14-mile German system by 1994 to link Orlando Airport to Disney World and other nearby resorts. _ At least two companies are bidding to develop a high-speed rail system in Texas to link Houston and Dallas. Magnetic trains do not yet carries paying passengers anywhere in the world, but the Carmichael described a recent ride on a 19-mile test system in West Germany. ``You feel it levitate, and then you feel it swoosh you along without any vibration,'' Carmichael said. ``Cows were grazing underneath when we passed over, and they didn't even look up.'' Because the trains float on a powerful magnetic field, there is no friction or wear and far less energy is consumed. It takes about as much electricity to run the German system as to aircondition it, Carmichael said, and the only pollution comes from producing the electricity. Usual fares would be about 20 percent below air fares and 40 percent lower on some shorter routes, Carmichael said. In some cases, trips between major city centers would be faster than by plane, since downtown stations would be used. The report said the United States started and then abandoned the ``maglev'' technology two decades ago and now faces the prospect of buying guideways and trains from West Germany or Japan. Maglev technologies are in competition with high-speed rail, which is a fast train that runs on special tracks, and with Swedish tilting trains that allow faster service on existing tracks without passengers feeling the curves. The maglev system is expensive _ about $30 million a mile on routes that could carry trains simultaneously in both directions. But the FRA report said costs could be offset by savings in highway and airport construction, pollution control, reduced travel delays and in the increased commerce the system would attract.

DOC.HEAD: Former Opera Singer Dies
DOC.TEXT: Robert L. Charlebois, who sang in major opera houses of Europe in the 1950s and early 1960s, has died after a long illness. He was 67. Charlebois, who grew up in Minneapolis, died Saturday at his home in St. Paul. He had suffered a stroke on Jan. 2. After serving in the Army during World War II, Charlebois stayed on as entertainment director for U.S. troops in Munich, West Germany. He studied with Fritz Wolff at the Munich School of Music. He was chosen by Wieland Wagner, grandson of the composer, to sing the title role of ``Parsifal'' at the Bayreuth Festival in 1951. Charlebois also sang in major opera houses in Austria, France, Belgium, Denmark, Sweden, Italy, Spain and Portugal. At a command performance for Queen Elizabeth II at the Royal Opera House in London, he sang Sigmund in Wagner's ``Die Walkure.'' In 1965, he ripped a vocal cord singing ``Tannhauser,'' ending his singing career. Survivors include two sons, a sister and four grandsons. Services will be Monday at Fort Snelling National Cemetery.

DOC.HEAD: Restaurateur Tommy Harris Dead at 78
DOC.TEXT: Tommy Harris, a restaurateur, city parks commissioner and former radio personality once known as the ``Little King of Song,'' died after a brief bout with leukemia. He was 78. Harris, who died Wednesday, was the founder and longtime owner of Tommy's Joynt, a landmark saloon known for gaudy murals covering its facade as well as its buffalo stew. Harris first became known in San Francisco as a radio entertainer; in the mid-1930s he was known as the ``Little King of Song'' on the NBC network. He started in vaudeville at 17, after dropping out of high school, and performed with his own dance band on a cruise vessel. Later, he ran night clubs before establishing Tommy's Joynt in 1951. In 1971, Harris was appointed to the city Recreation and Parks Commission by then-mayor Joseph L. Alioto. He remained in the post until his death. He is survived by his wife, two sons and a daughter.

DOC.HEAD: Survivors Gather on Crash Anniversary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with captain's remarks at news conference. Picks up 6th graf, `Several survivors...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos staffing
DOC.TEXT: The captain of United Flight 232 said today his reunion with the survivors of the cartwheeling crash has been very emotional and he reluctantly accepts being called a hero. More than 100 of the 184 survivors were attending a daylong reunion, one year after the July 19, 1989 crash that killed 112 people. Several relatives of the dead were expected at an afternoon prayer service. ``To be able to talk it out and to talk it through with them _ it's been very fulfilling,'' United Air Lines Capt. Al C. Haynes said at a news conference. Haynes said there were no heroes among the crew that guided the crippled DC-10 jetliner to the Sioux Gateway Airport. But he said some people needed to look up to the crew as part of their healing. ``If we are serving some kind of function by being called heroes, so be it,'' Haynes said. ``I'd like to think that any other well-trained crew would have responded as we did.'' Several passengers arriving late Wednesday sought out Haynes, who managed to fly the plane after its flight controls were severed by an engine explosion. The jumbo jet cartwheeled in flames on landing at Sioux Gateway Airport. Haynes said today he would not ever get over the crash, ``but I'm well through it. I'm well on to other things.'' ``I think about it every day, but I've never had nightmares,'' Haynes said. ``I don't dwell on it.'' Several survivors and relatives of the victims visited the airport Wednesday. Some left flowers at the perimeter. Some survivors attending the reunion flew for the first time since the tragedy. ``You could feel the plane heat up with emotion as we came in for a landing,'' said Becky Larson, who flew with crash survivors on a United Air Lines flight from Denver late Wednesday. ``A lot of people said they hadn't flown since the crash and some of them wouldn't look out the window. But I did. I wanted to see it from the air,'' said Ms. Larson, a United flight attendant who saw the crash from the ground and was among the first rescuers on the scene. Survivor Mark Michaelson of Cincinnati said flying isn't routine anymore. ``Takeoffs are difficult, landings are difficult, turbulence is especially difficult,'' he said. ``Every once in a while when you are in the clouds for an extended period of time and can't see where you are going you get anxiety attacks.'' Michaelson survived the crash with his wife, Lori, and their daughter, Sabrina. Mrs. Michaelson since has campaigned for mandatory child safety seats on commercial flights. Sabrina, then 1, was thrown from her mother's arms in the crash. Passengers and their families have been arriving all week for the anniversary, said Linda Phillips, who is coordinating the event for the local Chamber of Commerce. Phillips estimated 160 passengers and their families, and a few relatives of those killed, planned to join the reunion at their own expense. Phillips said Sioux City residents are proud of their rescue efforts but that the reunion was not designed as a pat on the back for the home crowd. ``We're doing it because we feel it needs to be done,'' she said. ``They were coming back here at the anniversary whether we did anything or not.'' Emergency personnel had practiced responding to a nearly identical calamity two years before the crash. After the crash, residents offered food, transportation and even their homes to the survivors, and hundreds lined up to give blood without anyone putting out a call to do so. ``There are no heroes,'' said Shirley Brown, assistant city manager. ``The people genuinely believe that they just did their jobs that day. They did them well, they were coordinated and they had rehearsed, but they simply did what they had practiced.''

DOC.HEAD: High School Handbook Details Sexual Harassment
DOC.TEXT: High schoolers who beam sexually charged stares at classmates or exchange snippets of intimate gossip could fall afoul of new guidelines to curb sexual harassment among students. The rules are designed to make school a more comfortable place, the principal said Thursday. ``We had an idea that we should have a clear statement in our student handbook about sexual harassment,'' said Ilene Levitt, principal of the Amherst-Pelham Regional High School. ``I think in 1970 people would have turned up their eyebrows. This is 1990 and I think students understand.'' Jason Bray, incoming senior class vice president, said some may laugh at the handbook's detailed offenses, but he thinks it was a good idea. Sexual harassment at the high school generally takes the form of ``little things,'' said Bray, 17. But hearty flirting by a ``macho man'' can be upsetting, he said, ``especially to girls that aren't popular and don't know these people. I'm sure it made them very uneasy.'' Another incoming senior, 17-year-old Jennifer Emery, said she was surprised about the policy because she had never considered sexual harassment a problem at the school. ``Plenty of people have given me strange looks and said strange things to me but it's all been a joke,'' she said. At the National Association of Secondary School Principals, spokeswoman Maryellen Parker said she had not heard of a high school having a similar policy, but it is an issue the association has promoted for some time. Sexual harassment ``is a widespread problem but it receives little attention from administrators or teachers so it's good to see that there are policies that are beginning to occur. It's long overdue,'' Parker said in a telephone interview from Reston, Va. The policy, which has been approved in principle by school officials, lists several behaviors that would qualify as sexual harassment. Among them: staring or leering with sexual overtones, spreading sexual gossip, making unwanted sexual comments, exerting pressure for sexual activity and making unwanted physical contact of a sexual nature. The guidelines will be printed in student handbooks this fall, pending a few changes in language that do not affect the substance of the draft, said School Committee Chairwoman Joan Hanson. ``It's something that several people have felt for a long time,'' Hanson said. ``Times have changed.'' While the focus is on students, the guidelines also point out that sexual advances from adults at the school are not appropriate. Possible punishment includes a parent conference, apology to the victim, detention, suspension, expulsion, and in cases of physical assault, referral to police, Levitt said. The school probably will rely most heavily on the first two avenues, she said. Levitt said it may be hard to make a determination on reports of leers and gossip, but at the very least there will have been discussion of the problem. ``We have a sense of humor, too,'' she said. ``There's certainly sexual behavior that's appropriate among adolescents. We certainly aren't Puritans.''

DOC.HEAD: Proposals Call For Cut In U.S. Aid To Kenya
DOC.TEXT: Two congressional proposals introduced Thursday call for the United States to stop all aid to Kenya until the African nation frees political prisoners and implements democratic freedoms. ``Americans should not send these tax dollars to a government that denies its citizens their basic rights,'' said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., who authored Senate legislation. A companion measure was introduced in the House of Representatives by Tom Lantos, a California Democrat. Neither chamber is expected to act before September, after a summer recess. Congressional Democrats have criticized Kenyan President Daniel Arap Moi. But the decision to propose the aid cut follows rioting that began July 7 after police using clubs and tear gas dispersed a crowd attempting to hold a pro-democracy rally in Nairobi. Twenty eight people were killed in the four days of disturbance and seven democracy advocates _ including two former government officials _ were detained without trial. Amnesty International said Thursday that it had learned of the arrest of eight additional government critics since then. The London-based human rights organization warned about the ``alarming deterioration of the rule of law in Kenya'' and ``the harsh conditions under which political prisoners are held.'' Kenya is the largest recipient of U.S. aid to sub-Saharan Africa. This year it was scheduled to receive $46 million, including $11 million in military assistance. For next year, the Bush administration has asked Congress to give Kenya $42 million, $16 million of which is for the military. But Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., chairman of the Senate subcommittee on Africa, said he had frozen some $13 million of this year's aid. He said Kenya's President Daniel Arap Moi was heavily dependent on foreign aid and loans, which comprise 27 percent of his government's annual budget. ``The only language he (Moi) understands is that of aid,'' said Gibson Kuria, a prominent dissident who sought refuge last month in the U.S. Embassy in Nairobi and was allowed to leave the country. Kuria said Moi was in a ``panic'' because of growing pressure to legalize political parties. A letter from Coretta Scott King, Jesse Jackson and other prominent blacks made public during the news conference calls on the administration to cut all aid to Moi's government. Kenya has been a U.S. favorite in Africa for many years, eschewing socialism even when its neighbors embraced it, and providing a stable buffer against Soviet influence in east Africa. Moi contends multi-party democracy is unsuitable for Kenya and other African countries because it could lead to tribal wars. Kenya did have opposition parties after it gained independence in 1963 and until Moi, who took power in 1978, amended the constitution in 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Khmer Rouge Control Large Areas of Cambodia
LaserPhoto BK3
DOC.TEXT: Khmer Rouge guerrillas have seized large areas deep inside Cambodia in recent months and say they will fight as long as needed if they are shut out of a political settlement. A recent five-week, 450-mile trip through the country's north by this reporter found the Khmer Rouge have strong Chinese support and have stockpiled caches of weapons, ammunition and funds in case foreign aid is cut. The United States announced Wednesday it was withdrawing recognition of the guerrilla coalition dominated by the Communist Khmer Rouge. The coalition also includes the non-Communist forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Son Sann. The U.S. move was prompted by fears of a return to power of the Khmer Rouge. The Communist group killed hundreds of thousands of people in forced agrarian reform in the 1970s until Vietnam invaded and installed a new government in early 1979. The 30,000-man Khmer Rouge army already controls hundreds of villages in the country's south, west and north, and it operates in virtually all parts of the country. In their jungle command posts, senior Khmer Rouge commanders said recently they were stepping up the fight to force the Vietnamese-backed government into political concessions. ``The Khmer Rouge have everything they want from China. They don't need any more guns or money,'' said Col. Khan Savoeun, a commander of Sihanouk's army. ``U.S. support for the non-Communists is very important psychologically for the non-Communist resistance. But it means nothing for the Khmer Rouge.'' Ta Pok, a Khmer Rouge brigade commander in this northwestern province, said he listened to the Voice of America and Radio Free Asia for news on peace and hoped for progress. But he said the guerrillas cannot wait around for documents to be signed. ``The Vietnamese will only listen to strength, and if they don't listen they will lose everything,'' Ta Pok said. ``Our strategy is to isolate Kompong Speu, Battambang and Kompong Thom. But we already have most of Kompong Speu and Kompong Thom. We are doing very, very well.'' The guerrillas have seized large quantities of weapons in recent fighting. Dozens of hidden jungle bases are full of ammunition and captured heavy weapons were seen in the north. The Chinese aid is channeled through the Thai border. But as the guerrillas push deeper into the country, they rely on the hidden caches and food from recently seized villages. Thousands of soldiers and civilian supporters were seen moving freely through newly seized areas. Heavy fighting between Khmer Rouge and government troops holed up at several key forward outposts defending Siem Riep city was heard every day. The guerrillas mined roads, attacked supply convoys and overran government artillery bases. ``We are winning more easily than we expected. There is nothing that can stop us,'' said Khmer Rouge division commander Mit Lot, in charge of areas around the ancient temples of Angkor Wat in Siem Reap province. ``If (Cambodian Prime Minister) Hun Sen is not flexible, we will fight and for sure we will win,'' he said. The guerrillas appear to have substantial popular support. Many villagers say the Khmer Rouge are not forcing them to fight, and pay those who help carry ammunition and supplies. The guerrillas also pay a high price for rice. However, some villagers said they were afraid to refuse guerrilla requests for help. As part of preparations in case foreign aid is cut, the Khmer Rouge have seized large gem-mining areas in the south and collect more than half a million dollars monthly in taxes from miners, said Western intelligence analysts in Bangkok. In the north, they have created a sophisticated logging operation and trucks full of teakwood head toward markets in Thailand daily from vast forests under their control. The guerrillas now have a network of thousands of miles of roads snaking from areas under their control to new front lines deep in the interior. Dozens of Chinese-supplied trucks and jeeps were seen ferrying ammunition to the guerrillas attacking positions around Siem Riep and Angkor Wat. Bulldozers were clearing new paths in the jungles. ``A year ago we used porters to take supplies to the frontlines,'' said Khmer Rouge commander Ta Pok. ``Now we have trucks which can go anywhere.'' Som Narin, a Sihanouk army commander, said the Khmer Rouge had such firm control over the area near Angkor Wat they didn't even need to carry guns. ``This is now Khmer Rouge Cambodia,'' he said. Tens of thousands of civilians who have lived in isolated jungle camps run by the Khmer Rouge along the Thai border since 1979 have moved to newly seized towns and villages in Cambodia. But while analysts agree the Khmer Rouge army is superior to the government and the other guerrilla groups, there are signs they have difficulties gaining wider support as they move from jungle outposts to more populated areas. In many areas, villagers did not readily offer food and information, although they did not do anything to oppose the Khmer Rouge.

DOC.HEAD: Broadcasters Provide Rescuers, Families With Lifeline After Quake
LaserPhoto MLA7
DOC.TEXT: When Karen Yee wanted to tell her uncles she was safe after a devastating earthquake, she turned to the local radio station in Baguio to get the message through. When Red Cross official Richard Gordon needed to confer with authorities in quake-damaged Cabanatuan, he did so in a telephone patch provided by another radio station, which aired the consultations live. In the aftermath of Monday's earthquake, which left about 500 people dead, radio and television stations not only reported the news. They helped rescuers and worried relatives circumvent poor communications, and served as a spur to a clumsy, unresponsive bureaucracy. Broadcasters directed rescuers to areas of destruction, relayed messages to family members separated by the disaster and solicited relief goods. ``It was the radio stations which were coordinating rescue efforts, broacasting the need for blood, blankets, medicines, earth-moving equipment,'' columnist Luis Beltran wrote in The Manila Standard. ``Government departments went to them for guidance on what to send, where to send.'' After the quake struck, provincial affiliates of the major networks broadcast the first reports of destruction. At that time, President Corazon Aquino's staff said only that it was ``studying the extent'' of the disaster. Provincial officials, unable to get through to Manila by telephone, broadcast appeals to the capital for assistance over private stations. Radio and television reporters traveled through the affected area and briefed government officials about which towns and cities were in urgent need of help. ``They served as effective alternatives to government agencies whose addiction to routine has robbed them of the power of initiative and the ability to respond quickly,'' former Labor Minister Blas Ople wrote in The Manila Bulletin. As the extent of the disaster became clearer, managements of stations DZRH, DZMM, DZBB, DZXL and others discontinued regular programming for round-the-clock quake coverage. ``We shifted to public-service priority programming because we feel that that is the need of the present time,'' said Maria Asuncion Lanuza, program coordinator of DZBB. ``I think we are complementing the government.'' Faced with severe communications problems, government officials turned to radio stations as an effective means of relaying instructions. Late Monday, Gordon, the Red Cross official who also serves as mayor of Olongapo, telephoned DZMM and asked the station to report that he and a U.S. rescue team were heading to Cabanatuan to help search for students trapped in a school building. While Gordon was on the telephone, the station patched his call through to the Cabanatuan mayor. In a conversation broadcast live, the two discussed what equipment and supplies were needed. The quake also isolated Baguio, a mountain resort 110 miles north of Manila, by cutting off telephone service, damaging the airport and triggering landslides that closed all roads. Ordinary people turned to the radio to relay messages to their loved ones. In Baguio, radio stations set up an outdoor ``office'' along the main street, where people could tape brief messages that were broadcast nationwide by affiliate stations. Relatives in Manila in turn aired appeals to family members in quake-affected areas. In one message, Miss Yee said from Baguio that she and her mother were safe but ``Daddy hasn't come yet.'' The message was directed primarily at her father's brothers in Pampanga province. In Manila, a weeping Linda Pineda made an appeal over DZRH to her three children studying in Baguio. ``If you are safe, my children, please go to reporters and tell them you are fine,'' she sobbed. ``I don't know where you are, children,'' she added. ``But it would reassure me if you send word through reporters.''

DOC.HEAD: B-2 Cost Control System Was `Essentially a Farce,' Memo Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf to simplify statement; DELETES redundant 4th graf, bgng, ``Accordingly...
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department was unable to pursue a fraud claim against the maker of the B-2 bomber because the government had known Northrop Corp.'s cost system was ``essentially a farce,'' according to a document. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., on Wednesday disclosed portions of a September 1988 Justice Department memorandum that found Northrop submitted false cost and scheduling data to the Air Force on the B-2 program. The disclosure came in a letter to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. ``While certain of the allegations concerning program deficiencies are essentially accurate, the Air Force has known of these facts for some time but has chosen to take no remedial action,'' the memo said, so there is no fraud case to be made. Officials of the Air Force, Defense Department and Northrop Corp., said they were aware of Dingell's letter but had no immediate comment. The government has invested more than $25 billion to build the radar-evading aircraft. Scrutiny of aircraft production, however, has been limited because the program was classified until last year. The Justice Department said in the memo that the Defense Contract Audit Agency had only two auditors assigned to Northrop to oversee the operation. During that time, it said, the company's cost schedule control system, which measures potential cost overruns and schedule delays, produced false information. ``Northrop's cost schedule control system is essentially a farce,'' the memo said. Dingell, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on oversight and investigations, asked Cheney to assemble an independent ``court of inquiry'' that would report to Congress by Aug. 24. ``It is clear that in the Air Force's zeal to protect the funding for the B-2 program, they have ignored or tolerated major infractions by Northrop to the detriment of the taxpayers,'' Dingell said in the letter to Cheney. Faced with a diminished Soviet threat and an increasing budget deficit, Cheney in April cut the production number of the bat-winged aircraft from 132 to 75. But congressional opposition to the plane remains, with lawmakers highly critical of the cost of $860 million per plane. The Senate Armed Services Committee, approving a $289 billion defense bill last week, agreed to Cheney's request for two planes in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 at a cost of nearly $5 billion for the aircraft and other expenses. Amendments to kill the program are expected when the full Senate takes up the bill. The House Armed Services Committee begins crafting its version of the defense bill later this month and attempts to terminate the B-2 program in the full House remain strong.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Jurist Angry Over Short Sentences; Returns Dealers to Pen
DOC.TEXT: Calling parole and prison officials ``bleeding hearts,'' a judge has thrown the book at a drug trafficker caught dealing in cocaine after serving only a portion of a previous sentence. ``Some idiot in the prison system thought you were rehabilitated after three years,'' U.S. District Judge G. Kendall Sharp declared in ordering Robert Zingarell back to prison. Zingarell, 49, had appeared before the judge in 1984 after being convicted of selling 400 pounds of marijuana and 2.2 pounds of cocaine. Sharp imposed what he thought was a harsh sentence: 10 years. Zingarell was back in court Wednesday, and the judge took the occasion to blast the U.S. Parole Commission and the U.S. Bureau of Prisons on the way they choose to release drug dealers. He then lambasted Zingarell, who served 3{ years in prison before being paroled. He gave Zingarell another 10 years in prison, despite a guilty plea and his cooperation with prosecutors. ``If they had put him away like I did the first time, he wouldn't have been out dealing cocaine again,'' Sharp told a reporter later. ``They are a bunch of bleeding hearts making room (for new inmates) by cutting other people loose. I understand their problem, but it undermines my ability to give what is an appropriate sentence. ``They ought to ship them to an isolated island in the Pacific and if they want to escape, let them try.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Cynthia Hawkins told Sharp of Zingarell's cooperation in an investigation against some co-defendants. Federal guidelines called for Zingarell to face up to eight years in prison. Ms. Hawkins recommended he receive no more than 6{ years. But Sharp departed from the guidelines and recommendation in his 10-year sentence. Zingarell's attorney, Mark O'Mara, said Sharp improperly enhanced both the seriousness of his client's crime and the range of the sentence. ``I don't think he did it right and I know Mr. Zingarell will appeal,'' O'Mara said.

DOC.HEAD: Pete Rose Sentenced to Five Months in Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `His voice,' to CORRECT quote and that it was made by Rose's son sted wife.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY19, LaserColor CS2
DOC.TEXT: Fallen baseball hero Pete Rose was sentenced today to five months in prison and fined $50,000 for cheating on his taxes. ``I have no excuses because it's all my fault,'' the former manager of the Cincinnati Reds baseball team said. ``I lost my dignity, I lost my self respect ... and I almost lost a lot of dear friends.'' Rose was sentenced for failing to report more than $354,000 in income from baseball memorabilia sales, autograph appearances and the gambling for which he was banned from professional baseball. U.S. District Judge S. Arthur Spiegel also ordered Rose to spend three months in a halfway house after the prison term and perform 1,000 hours of community service with inner-city youths. He could have sentenced Rose to six years in prison and a $500,000 fine. Spiegel repeatedly referred to Rose's standing as a baseball hero, but said he had to ignore Rose's fame in considering punishment. ``Today we are not dealing with the legend,'' he said. The 49-year-old Rose blames his troubles on a gambling disorder, for which he's getting treatment. He first denied having a gambling problem when friends told investigators he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team. He still denies betting on baseball, but accepted a lifetime ban from the sport last August. He is eligible next month to apply for reinstatement to baseball, but has indicated he will not do so. Rose, limping from a knee injury, showed no visible reaction when he was sentenced. But earlier, Rose's voice broke as he told the judge he was sorry. ``Your honor, I'd like to say I'm very sorry, very shameful to be here today in front of you,'' Rose said. His voice faltered again when he told the judge how his 5-year-old son had told his wife that ``his daddy is a jailbird.'' Spiegel allowed Rose to remain free until Aug. 10, so that he may have surgery on his injured knee. Then he is expected to report to a federal prison in Ashland, Ky. Spiegel praised Rose's accomplishments on the baseball field, but said he had to impose a jail sentence out of fairness. ``Foremost, we must recognize that there are two people here: Pete Rose, the living legend, the all-time hit leader and the idol of millions; and Pete Rose, the individual who appears today convicted of two counts of cheating on his taxes,'' Spiegel said. ``Today we are not dealing with the legend.'' Rose's tax problems began to surface when baseball investigator John Dowd started looking into his betting habits in early 1989. A federal grand jury was convened in Cincinnati to see whether Rose reported all of his income. Rose agreed to plead guilty April 20 to two counts of failing to report income. Federal prosecutors agreed not to pursue further charges. Rose admitted he hid $354,968 in income from 1984 to 1987. He has repaid the Internal Revenue Service $366,042 as part of the plea agreement. Two of Rose's reputed gambling associates, former roommate Thomas Gioiosa and bookmaker Ronald Peters, were sentenced last year on drug and tax charges. Peters received a two-year term for tax evasion and cocaine distribution. Peters claimed he accepted Rose's bets, including bets on Reds games. Rose admitted Gioiosa placed his bets with bookmakers. Gioiosa was sentenced to a five-year term for transporting cocaine and five months on two tax counts.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Mom Bakes Her Own Bread, Complains He Never Visits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `The new ...' to clarify that house was painted.
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's 79-year-old mother only recently got a new color television to replace her old black-and-white set, still bakes her own bread and complains her son never visits. In an unusually revealing story about the family of a Soviet leader, the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda reported Thursday that the only privilege given to Maria Pantelyevna Gorbachev are the KGB agents who provide security down the road from her small house in the southern Russian village of Privolnoye. The KGB is there not so much to guard her from the many journalists who find their way to the farming village where Gorbachev was born, but to keep ordinary citizens from pestering her with petitions for her son, the newspaper said. Until recently, the private lives of Communist Party leaders and their families rarely appeared in the state-run media, but under Gorbachev's policy of greater openness, or glasnost, many restrictions have been lifted. Although the Western media have reported on Gorbachev's roots and his family, such things are new to Soviet readers. Thursday's front-page article, titled ``Home of the President,'' was complete with an old photograph of a young, plump Gorbachev reclining in a field wearing a jaunty beret. Gorbachev's widowed mother, the newspaper said, still does the chores around the house and bakes her own bread, even though a collective farm bakery was built several years ago to feed the village's 3,000 people. A new paint job on her house and the color TV that recently replaced the old ``Rekord'' model black-and-white set ``have not cost the state or the party one kopeck,'' wrote Komsomolskaya Pravda correspondent O. Shapovalov. Not long ago, a rumor spread that Mrs. Gorbachev was moving to Moscow and selling her house, the newspaper said. Residents of Privolnoye were ready to make inquiries about buying her house, but she told Nikolai Dorokhov, her neighbor and secretary of the party organization of the collective farm: ``I have already lived in Moscow. I don't see my son here and I wouldn't see him there. He leaves home at 6 a.m. and returns late in the evening. ... I will not go anywhere.'' Gorbachev last visited his birthplace 3{ years ago, the newspaper reported, and while he was there spent only 40 minutes inside his house and another 40 minutes talking to villagers. Earlier this week, he met with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl in nearby Stavropol, where he began his Communist Party work in 1955. But he apparently didn't visit his mother in Privolnoye. Alla Georgievna Zavalikhina, ideology secretary of the party committee in nearby Krasnogvardeisky, usually accompanies journalists who visit Privolnoye, and complained to the newspaper about the manners of Soviet reporters. ``Foreign correspondents are more tactful. At least no one who was warned beforehand tried to get into her house,'' Mrs. Zavalikhina said. ``It's more difficult to explain to ours. One Soviet TV crew wanted to interview her for a popular show by any means,'' she added. ``Isn't it clear that it isn't decent to bother an elderly woman, even if this woman is not the president's mother?'' The newspaper reported that although there is a small Gorbachev display at the party offices in Stavropol, Privolnoye has no museums or plaques to mark its historic significance _ by presidential request. All this is to the chagrin of Venyamin A. Lutsenko, director of a small party museum in in Krasnogvardeisky, 12 miles away. He told the newspaper he'd really like to have the pen that Gorbachev and former President Reagan used in 1987 to sign the treaty to destroy medium-range nuclear weapons.
