Thus, the only monument in Privolnoye is the roadblock manned by the KGB agents who, according to the newspaper, tell citizens trying to pass along their petitions to use the mailbox.

DOC.HEAD: Infant Killed by Pit Bull
DOC.TEXT: A 6-month-old girl was killed by a neighbor's pit bull terrier as the infant slept in her bedroom, police say. Tionna Kenny was bitten on the head, neck and arms by the dog, whose owner apparently was caring for the child at the time of the attack Wednesday, police said. The dog's owner, Tyrone Hardy, told police he heard the dog growling and the child cry out. Hardy said he could not free the child from the dog's grip, according to police officer Ed Barkowski. The dog will be destroyed, said Peter Poholik, director of the city's Animal Care and Control Commission.

DOC.HEAD: Spokesman Flustered Over Question of Zhao's Rehabilitation
DOC.TEXT: Media reports from Hong Kong and Washington that ousted Communist Party leader Zhao Ziyang is being rehabilitated drew flustered claims of ignorance Thursday from a Foreign Ministry spokesman. ``I haven't seen such a report,'' Jin Guihua said at the ministry's weekly news conference. ``I advise you not to believe this kind of rumors too easily.'' After the news conference, worried he might be misunderstood, the normally unflappable Jin told reporters in flustered English: ``I must say that, the conditions of Zhao Ziyang, I don't know, I don't know. His present status, I don't know, so don't misquote me. ``What I want to advise you, there are so many rumors. The honest advice I give you is not to believe. There are too many rumors. Rumors are rampant. Be careful. That's all.'' Jin refused to deny the reports outright. However, the official Xinhua News Agency later quoted an unidentified Foreign Ministry official as saying the reports were ``a groundless rumor'' and that Zhao was still being investigated. Jin made no such statement at the news conference. The Hong Kong-based South China Morning Post on Tuesday quoted an unidentified U.S. official as saying senior leader Deng Xiaoping was planning to send Zhao on an inspection mission throughout China. The paper said the information came from members of a delegation of Chinese mayors touring U.S. cities. The Los Angeles Times quoted an unidentified U.S. official in Washington as saying that Zhao already was making an inspection trip. Giving Zhao such an assignment would be tantamount to rehabilitating him and would signal a reassessment at the highest party levels of the handling of last year's student-led demonstrations for democracy. That in turn would reflect a major realignment of forces at the top of the party one year after ideological hard-liners prevailed with their position that pressure for democratic reform must be quashed at all costs. Zhao was ousted last year as party general secretary for allegedly supporting the demonstrations and opposing the army attack that crushed them. The party Central Committee accused him of ``splitting the party,'' a serious offense, and official media reports accused his aides of plotting a virtual coup on his behalf. Officials say his case is still under investigation, indicating he has powerful supporters. One is believed to be Deng himself, who brought Zhao to Beijing in 1980 to help carry out his market-style economic reforms. Zhao was an enthusiastic economic reformer but was not an advocate of sweeping political changes. Shortly before his ouster, however, he visited the demonstrating students in Tiananmen Square and expressed sympathy for them. There have been subtle signals recently of political jostling behind the scenes. Analyzing the signals has become a preoccupation among Beijing intellectuals. Many believe the signals reflect growing strength in the reformist camp. Zhao, meanwhile, is widely believed to be living at in a small walled compound in central Beijing. Also Thursday, the Beijing Economics Institute confirmed unofficial reports that fugitive student leader Zhai Weimin had been arrested and jailed. A university official contacted by telephone said she had no details and did not give her name. Zhai, 22, is the fourth Beijing student known to have been arrested without publicity in the past three months, even as the government tries to ease foreign criticism by announcing large prisoner releases. The other three were students at Beijing University suspected of involvement in underground activities. In February, Zhai held a secret conference in Beijing of his underground reform group, the Democratic Front for the Salvation of China. Participants in the conference told foreign journalists at the time that more than 60 people took part.

DOC.HEAD: Proposal for Mandatory Organ Donations for Poor Stirs Uproar
DOC.TEXT: A proposal to sell the organs of dead welfare recipients has prompted such outrage that some people fear it will undermine other plans to solve a serious organ donor crisis. Milwaukee County Board Supervisor T. Anthony Zielinski made the proposal in an effort to reduce the county's burial expenses. But a flood of criticism persuaded him to drop the plan, and it now has no chance of passage. Still, some observers are worried that the political backlash from Zielinski's plan will doom other proposals to help relieve donor organ shortages. One such proposal would have allowed welfare recipients to sign forms permitting the county to donate their organs after death. That plan is now likely to be scuttled, according to Jeff Aiken, a spokesman for the Milwaukee County Social Services Department. ``There is a desperate need for organs. This was one way to make welfare recipients aware of the need for organ transplant,'' Aikin said. Zielinski had proposed selling the organs whether or not the welfare recipients had granted permission. ``If they can't help society while they're alive, maybe they can help it while they're dead,'' he said after introducing the proposal in May. He said the organs could be sold to hospitals or organ donor networks, although it is not clear whether they would be willing to purchase the organs. All organs now are donated. Critics, including colleagues of Zielinski and advocates for the poor, said his plan would rob the poor of dignity even in death. ``I don't think we ought to start selling poor people's organs just because they died on welfare,'' Supervisor Elizabeth Coggs-Jones said. Zielinski, 29, dropped the idea after initial criticism. Then he renewed anger a short time later when he suggested Wisconsin legalize donor organ sales, which now violate the state constitution. He also proposed that the county cremate rather than bury dead welfare recipients to save money. He has since apologized for both plans and changed his position. He also said he doesn't support the proposal to ask welfare recipients if they would like to become organ donors. ``I'm opposed to asking welfare recipients that question. I'm opposed to cremating them. If they don't state a choice they should be buried. It should be the preference of the individual. Whatever they want,'' Zielinski said. Elizabeth Bolt, organ procurement director for Milwaukee's Froedtert Memorial Hospital, said despite the serious need for more donor organs she understood why Zielinski's proposals met opposition. ``There's a very strong feeling that this should be voluntary. We talk about the gift of life, the gift of organ donations,'' Ms. Bolt said Wednesday. Like Aiken, she said she believed the response to Zielinski's proposals could doom other efforts to encourage organ donations by welfare recipients.

DOC.HEAD: Cubans Reportedly Leave Home of Czechoslovak Diplomat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 16 grafs to UPDATE with Cuban prosecutor accusing U.S. of ``instigating'' activists, Spain cutting aid. Pickup 9th, `Spain said...'
DOC.TEXT: Five Cubans who entered the residence of a Czechoslovak diplomat in Havana to seek asylum left the building today wearing masks and were taken away in a Cuban police vehicle, a news agency reported. The brief report from Havana by Mexico's official news agency Notimex quoted unidentified journalists. It did not say whether the Cubans had acted voluntarily or explain why they were wearing the masks. The four Cuban men and one woman took refuge in the residence of the charge d'affaires, Jan Doemoek, last week. They were among small groups of Cuban asylum-seekers who began entering embassies in Havana eight days ago. Their departure came as Spain and Cuba exchanged barbs over the flight of asylum-seekers to the Spanish Embassy in Havana. Madrid recalled its ambassador after Cuban police seized one of the refugees, sent more guards to the compound, and suspended $2.5 million in grants to Cuba. The European commissioner for Latin American relations, Abel Matutes of Spain, said through a spokesman today in Brussels that three ``symbolic'' aid projects about to be undertaken by the EC with Cuba would not go ahead. At least 13 Cubans have reportedly holed up in embassies or residences of Spain, Czechoslovakia and Italy. The embassy standoffs have drawn wide publicity because similar situations in East German embassies last year helped precipitate the fall of that nation's hard-line Communist government. Albania, which like Cuba has refused to adopt Western-style reforms, also recently allowed hundreds of people who occupied embassies in its capital, Tirana, to leave for new lives in the West. State radio and television in Cuba today gave extensive coverage to the trial of 11 human rights activists who were convicted in Havana of crimes against the state, the official Cuban news agency Prensa Latina said. The coverage featured the prosecutor accusing U.S. officials in Havana of ``instigating'' the activists, the dispatch from Havana said. Prosecutor Sara Nieves said officials at the U.S. Interests Section had provided logistical support and ``orientation'' to the members of Pro-Human Rights Youth, who were convicted on Wednesday. According to Prensa Latina, she said the United States was using the group to ``foment economic chaos and carry out terrorist acts.'' The activists were given sentences ranging from 15 years in prison to three years of house arrest for counterrevolutionary crimes such as terrorism and rebellion. The dispatch said the defendants had planned to steal explosives to blow up the National Library and the Cuban Institute of Radio and Television. Nieves also accused the defendants of contact with other Western diplomatic missions and with Venezuelan diplomats, Prensa Latina said. The dispatch, monitored in Mexico City, said Nieves described Pro-Human Rights Youth as the armed wing of the outlawed Pro-Human Rights Party. Spain said it has recalled Ambassador Antonio Serrano de Haro for consultations. It accused Cuba of words ``removed from the customary niceties of international co-existence.'' The tensions broke into the open earlier in the day when Spain's foreign minister, Francisco Fernandez Ordonez, suggested to reporters that leader Fidel Castro knew his regime would crumble if he opened the door to all Cubans who want to leave. Cuba, a former Spanish colony, has 11 million residents. ``The situation in Havana is very nervous due to Cuba's isolation from the world and because of the extremely serious economic problems there,'' Fernandez Ordonez told Spanish National Radio. ``No one wants a catastrophe there. What is needed is a peaceful transition to democracy.'' Cuba retaliated later in the day, issuing its own statement saying Spain had violated Cuban and international law by harboring asylum-seekers. It said in a statement that it would never yield to ``pressure or blackmail'' by people seeking to leave the Caribbean island, Prensa Latina reported. The Cuban statement also accused Spain's foreign minister of suffering from an ``attack of historical amnesia,'' displaying a ``scandalous lack of education about international law'' and being ``morally disqualified'' from commenting on Cuban human rights. Cuba was a Spanish colony from the 16th century to 1898. Castro's government has portrayed the asylum-seekers as ``antisocial elements.'' Also Wednesday, Madrid sent a special security squad to Havana, Cuba's capital, to reinforce security at the Spanish Embassy. Cuban police entered the grounds of the Spanish Embassy on Friday in pursuit of a young Cuban asylum-seeker and arrested him. Three other Cubans were reportedly inside the embassy, and a fourth arrived Wednesday, according to the Spanish news agency EFE. On Tuesday, Cuban police arrested a man in the U.S. diplomatic post in Havana. Both Spain and the United States protested the incidents. The Cuban refugee crisis has attracted attention in part because it is reminiscent of the East German refugees who sought passage to the West at embassies in Eastern Europe last year. Their exodus helped precipitate the fall of East Germany's rigid Communist government. Albania, which like Cuba has refused to adopt democratic reforms, just last week allowed hundreds of people who had entered embassies in its capital to leave for new lives in the West.

DOC.HEAD: Four Presidents Attend Nixon Library Dedication
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with ceremony, presidents' speeches. Picks up 11th graf, `As a ....'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto ANS2
DOC.TEXT: Three Republican presidents who followed Richard Nixon into office today praised him as a man who made the world a safer place. Thousands turned out on a sweltering day for the dedication of Nixon's presidential libary and hear speeches from President Bush and former Presidents Ronald Reagan and Gerald Ford. Nixon was the nation's 37th president and only one to resign from office. ``Nothing we have ever seen matches this moment, to be welcomed home so warmly on this day,'' Nixon said on behalf of himself and his wife, Pat. Bush paid tribute to Nixon as ``a true architect of peace,''; Ford's and Reagan's speeches were laced with humor and fond remembrances. ``You, Dick Nixon, have the gratitude of men and women everywhere who cherish peace with liberty,'' said Ford. ``I do not think it is an exaggeration to say that the world is a better place _ a safer place _ because of Richard Nixon,'' Reagan said. In a glowing tribute, Bush said ``Richard Nixon was the quintessence of Middle America,'' a leader who presided over the nation during times ``perhaps as tumultuous as any since Lincoln's.'' ``Richard Nixon helped change the course not only of America but of the entire world,'' said Bush. He said Nixon's path-breaking trip to China in 1972 ``revolutionized the world,'' and recalled that it was Nixon who signed the first agreement with the Soviets to limit strategic nuclear arms. Among those at the dedication were former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger and other Nixon administration officials and Nixon's daughters, Julie Nixon Eisenhower and Tricia Nixon and their husbands. Tourists also turned out for the event. Wearing sandals, shorts and carrying beach chairs, thousands waited outside the Nixon library at dawn, paying $15 to park and shelling out another $15 for presidential T-shirts. Police said 15,000 people were at the gates when they opened after dawn. ``It's a very historic event, especially with four presidents here,'' said Margaret Gavras, 29, of Huntington Beach who arrived Wednesday night and parked her motor home at a church. Jimmy Carter was the only living former president _ and the only Democrat among them _ not attending the opening. He had a previous commitment, said Carrie Harmon, spokeswoman for the Carter Presidential Center in Atlanta. She would not elaborate. Nixon and his wife visited the $21 million library Wednesday for the first time and viewed restoration of the house where he was born. A handful of tourists applauded him and some Girl Scouts handed Mrs. Nixon a bouquet. ``As a young boy in Yorba Linda, I never thought of being the president of the United States,'' Nixon says on a tape recording to be played for visitors to the 900-square-foot home. ``My goal was to become a railroad engineer.'' Many of the furnishings in the house were there when he was born Jan. 9, 1913, including the bed he was born in and the quilt that covered it. He was 9 when his parents moved to Whittier, where Nixon made his first successful run for Congress in 1946. Library displays follow his career from there to the Senate in 1950, the vice presidency in 1952 and the presidency in 1968. The Watergate scandal culminated in Nixon's resignation on Aug. 9, 1974. The resignation also is treated in library displays. Visitors to the library can hear crucial White House tapes of conversations Nixon had about Watergate with administration officials _ recordings that lost Nixon the political support he needed to survive calls for his impeachment. ``If anything, the opening of the library and the birthplace will draw more attention to Watergate because that is what most of those who are covering the event for the media are most interested in,'' Nixon told the Los Angeles Times. ``Over time, as their interest fades, and if the public continues to visit the museum, I would think that all the events covered will be seen in a more objective perspective,'' Nixon said in a written response to the newspaper's questions. On Wednesday, Nixon met with some former officials of his administration who gathered for the dedication. ``I've never been concerned about his place in history,'' said Bruce Whelihan, who worked in the Nixon White House press office. ``I always knew it would happen. It was just a matter of time,'' said former speechwriter Kenneth Khachigian. San Clemente, which Nixon put on the map as his ``Western White House,'' had been the planned site of the library. There was even a ceremonial groundbreaking, but the project got caught in red tape. Nixon eventually withdrew his permission and was delighted when Yorba Linda offered a home. The library will simply be a museum for a year until papers from before and after Nixon's presidency are brought here and made available to scholars. Nixon's presidential papers were impounded by Congress and are in a government warehouse in Alexandria, Va. Some 1.5 million of the White House documents will be recorded on digital disks for use by scholars at the library. By Nixon's choice, his library will get neither federal money nor Secret Service protection. He contributed $2 million to the library. Admission is $3.95 for adults.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Join To Approve Eastern European Aid Bill
DOC.TEXT: A plan to provide U.S. support for emerging Eastern European democracies became tangled in a political dispute Thursday as Senate Foreign Relations Committee Democrats approved an aid package despite a Republican boycott. The Democrat-controlled panel voted 10-0, with all nine Republican members absent, to send the $535 million bill to the full Senate. The measure would give President Bush a long menu of ideas for advancing economic reform in the former Warsaw Pact nations, including ``technical assistance'' for the Soviet Union. The committee's senior Republican, Sen. Jesse Helms of North Carolina, said in a letter to Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., who chairs the panel, that ``the feeling of comity has collapsed'' during work on the East Europe aid bill. Helms complained that the measure was being rushed into action without time for Republicans to review it and his aides said the Bush administration had an extensive list of concerns about the measure's overall cost and its specific provisions. Unlike foreign aid legislation passed last year, in which U.S. help was limited to Poland and Hungary, the measure approved Thursday makes assistance available to any Eastern European country that Bush believes needs help on its road to democratic and economic reform. The bill makes available $535 million for the programs in the year that begins Oct. 1, well in excess of the $300 million Bush had sought and an increase from the $489 million already approved by the House. Pell said the measure would provide ``an expanded American role in the effort to transform Eastern Europe'' by helping U.S. businesses invest in the countries, promoting trade and development and encouraging educational and cultural exchanges. The bill contains $100 million for environmental, housing and medical assistance. It also includes $70 million for the first U.S. payment to start up the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, an institution set up to encourage East Europe's emergence into the economic mainstream. But the committee's hour-long meeting included almost no discussion of the 114-page bill. Members instead defended their procedures in bringing it up for action, insisting that Republicans had no cause to boycott the session. Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., said he had already made numerous changes to accommodate Bush administration concerns after meeting July 11 with Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger. ``This is what the administration wanted,'' Biden said. But in a letter dated Tuesday, Eagleburger told Biden that even with the changes the administration still prefers the House version of the bill. Biden said he was not prepared to sit ``twiddling our thumbs'' while Eastern European economies are in a desperate need of help. ``I would at least hope people would show up and take a position on'' the bill, rather than boycotting the committee's meeting, he said. ``If one party has to govern, let's govern,'' said Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., and the Democrats voted.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls Nixon Architect of Peace
With PM-Nixon Library Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 13-14, After Bush, with Nixon remarks.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today paid tribute to Richard M. Nixon as ``a true architect of peace'' whose troubled presidency helped change the course of the world. In a glowing tribute at the dedication of the Nixon Library, Bush said ``Richard Nixon was the quintessence of Middle America,'' a leader who presided over the nation during times ``perhaps as tumultuous as any since Lincoln's.'' Ronald Reagan and Gerald Ford joined Bush and Nixon with their wives at the rare gathering of four American presidents for ceremonies opening the $21 million library and museum on the site of the farmhouse where Nixon was born. Speaking to a crowd of thousands on a sweltering hot morning, Bush made only a passing reference to Watergate, the scandal that forced Nixon to resign. Sixteen years ago, as chairman of the Republican National Committee, Bush wrote an anguished letter urging Nixon to resign rather than fight impeachment. Nixon announced his resignation the next day, Aug. 8, 1974. Bush said visitors to the Nixon library will learn ``that more people voted for Richard Nixon as president than any other man in history.'' Noting Nixon's eight books, Bush said, ``he had an intellectual's complexity.'' ``Richard Nixon was the quintessence of Middle America and touched deep chords of response in millions of her citizens,'' said Bush. He said Nixon invoked a ``silent majority'' to support his policies during his turbulent years in office. ``Richard Nixon helped change the course not only of America but of the entire world,'' said Bush. He said Nixon's path-breaking trip to China in 1972 ``revolutionized the world,'' and recalled that it was Nixon who signed the first agreement with the Soviets to limit strategic nuclear arms. ``Richard Nixon endured much in his quest for `Peace with Honor' in Vietnam. He knew that true peace means the triumph of freedom, not merely the absence of war,'' said Bush, the 41st president. ``Today, as the movement toward democracy sweeps our globe, you can take real pride that history will say of you: `Here was a true architect of peace','' said Bush. Bush also paid tribute to former first lady Patricia Nixon, saying she ``ranks among the most admired women of postwar America.'' After Bush introduced Nixon, the former president said, ``This is the first time I've ever been introduced by the president of the United States.'' Nixon said that in all his world travels, ``Nothing we have ever seen matches this moment, to be welcomed home again so warmly.'' Jimmy Carter, the only Democrat to occupy the White House since Nixon's presidency, was the only living president not at the ceremony. He had business elsewhere. ``I'm very pleased to be going to this dedication,'' Bush told reporters Wednesday as he flew west with Nixon's daughter, Tricia Cox, her husband and son as guests aboard Air Force One. It was the first gathering of four presidents since Nixon, Carter, Ford and Reagan met at the White House in 1981 after the assassination of Egyptian President Anwar Sadat. Reagan, at 79, is the oldest of the group. Both Nixon and Ford are 77; Bush is 66. Bush's ties with Nixon go back to the early 1960s, a decade before Watergate, when Bush was a politically ambitious Harris County Republican chairman looking to the former vice president for help. Nixon stumped in Texas for Bush in his unsuccessful race for Senate in 1964, then again at the kickoff of Bush's successful 1966 run for a House seat from Houston. In his autobiography, ``Looking Forward,'' Bush wrote that he was mentioned as a possible running mate for Nixon in 1968. After passing the Texan over for Spiro Agnew, Nixon told him, ``I really couldn't pick a one-term congressman.'' After Bush lost a second Senate race in 1970, Nixon tapped him as ambassador to the United Nations, and three years later recruited him as Republican national chairman. Bush stepped into the party job as the Watergate scandal was erupting over the White House, eventually ensnaring Nixon for ordering a cover-up of Republican operatives' break-in at Democratic Party headquarters in 1972. Nixon's final months in office were ``a political nightmare,'' Bush wrote. At the end, he said, he was afraid Nixon ``would bring the party down with him'' if he stayed in office to fight impeachment. On Aug. 7, 1974, Bush wrote the embattled president: ``It is my considered judgment that you should now resign. ... I now feel that resignation is best for the country, best for this president.'' Bush conferred with Nixon last fall after the former president returned from a visit to China.

DOC.HEAD: Divers Find Bodies After Dog Brings Home Feet
DOC.TEXT: Divers found the bodies of two people in a submerged car after a neighborhood dog brought home shoes with decomposing human feet in them, authorities said. The bodies found Wednesday were believed to be those of two people reported missing May 5, Lt. Ralph Dyer of the Bay County Sheriff's Department said Thursday. The names were withheld pending confirmation by the medical examiner, he said. Honey, a golden retriever-Labrador mix, brought a soggy old shoe to her owner Monday in this Florida Panhandle community north of Panama City. ``I thought it was my neighbor's, so I went over and looked at it and there was an ankle bone sticking up,'' said Tammy Quick, the dog's owner. Honey, who swims and forages daily in Fanning Bayou, found another shoe with a foot in it Wednesday before sheriff's scuba divers discovered the car and bodies 20 feet below the surface of creek leading into the bayou, Dyer said.

DOC.HEAD: President's Preppy Wardrobe Needs Western Twang
DOC.TEXT: A radio station wants to give President Bush's preppy wardrobe the boot during his visit and instead spur the chap on to wearing cowboy clothes. An offhand comment by a Denver radio talk show host that Bush's clothes don't fit the frontier image started the search for the perfect _ if imaginary _ presidential cowboy wardrobe. Steve Kelley of KOA-AM, Denver's all-talk radio station, which can be heard in Cheyenne, noted on the air Wednesday that Bush ``looks a little too preppy for the West, at least as far as we're concerned.'' The result of listeners' suggestions and Kelley's calls to Denver-area Western clothing stores to find the most outlandish duds on the market is a wardrobe that runs the gamut of Western flash and trash. The list includes a Western shirt complete with rhinestone snaps, a silver-inlaid mother-of-pearl bolo tie which ``at 45 bucks (is) not too cheap,'' chaps and ostrich-skin cowboy boots. The boots, Kelley found, run $499 a pair. Like most Western get-ups, the president's make-believe Western gear will be capped by a belt buckle of grand proportions. ``We wanted to find one that was manhole-sized because, after all, he is the president. But the best we could do was dish-sized,'' Kelley said. The hardest item to locate was a pair of chaps, suggesting to Kelley that there might be a dearth of real cowboys. To his amazement, the talk show host said, he received a call from a woman claiming to be from the White House who said the president wants to bring some spurs back from his trip out West. Bush was scheduled to be in Cheyenne and southeast Wyoming for a few hours on Friday and was planning to do some fishing in addition to making a speech marking the state's centennial as well as Frontier Days, a 92-year-old rodeo and Western festival. Kelley says he plans to be in Cheyenne for the presidential visit and will try to come up with a Western gift, even if he can't put together a dream outfit.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: The New Kids on the Block repaid a favor to the group that helped make them stars. Two years ago, when they were trying to break into the music business, the New Kids performed for 3,000 people at the Boy Scouts of America National Law Enforcement Explorer Conference in Boston. At the time, it was their biggest show, said group member Donnie Wahlberg. Now the New Kids' single ``Step By Step'' is on the top of the charts and they draw huge audiences, such as the crowd of 50,000 Tuesday night at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in Washington, D.C. The group hustled here after that show to headline ``Star Night'' at this year's Explorer conference, held at the University of Colorado. ``It was such a big show for us at the time,'' Wahlberg said, referring to the 1988 concert. ``We just wanted to return the favor.'' New Kids performed for free at Wednesday's conference, which brings together young people who plan careers in law enforcement.

A social services center named for Rose Kennedy was dedicated Thursday as part of the family's observance of their matriarch's 100th birthday. Robert F. Kennedy Jr., son of the late U.S. senator and host of the event, said the center was inspired by his grandmother's ``long lasting commitment to the family and the values that are derived from a caring and nurturing environment.'' The Brooklyn center will serve elderly women and homeless young mothers when it opens in 1991. It is in the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration area, a project backed by the late senator. Rose Kennedy turns 100 Sunday.

The Country Music Association announced 10 semifinalists Thursday for its 1990 Horizon Award for career development. They are Garth Brooks, Jann Browne, Mary Chapin Carpenter, Lionel Cartwright, Alan Jackson, the Kentucky Headhunters, k.d. lang, Lorrie Morgan, Doug Stone and Travis Tritt. The list will be narrowed to five Aug. 16 and the winner is to be announced Oct. 8 during a nationally televised awards show.

Count Nikolai Tolstoy said Thursday he will abandon his appeal against a libel award because he cannot afford to post a deposit required by the Court of Appeal. Tolstoy had sought to overturn the record award of $2.7 million to Lord Aldington, whom Tolstoy had accused of war crimes during World War II. Three judges of the Court of Appeal ruled Thursday that Tolstoy's appeal had little chance of success, and that if he wished to proceed he must depost $226,000 within 14 days as security for Aldington's costs. ``I cannot possibly raise that kind of money within 14 days so this is the end of the legal road,'' said Tolstoy, author of the book ``Victims of Yalta'' and a descendant of the Russian author Leo Tolstoy. Tolstoy wrote a pamphlet that accused Aldington of arranging to hand over 70,000 Cossacks and anti-Titoist Yugoslavs to their communist enemies, knowing they faced torture or death. Aldington was Brigadier General Staff in the Eighth Army V Corps in southern Austria at the close of World War II. Lord Justice Beldam, one of the three justices hearing the case, said Tolstoy's interpretation of documents ``lacked in many instances the intellectual objectivity and reasoned impartiality upon which his reputation is based. ``That he failed to convince the jury of the charges against Lord Aldington was amply demonstrated by its unprecedented and enormous award,'' Beldam said. The appeal judges refused Tolstoy permission to appeal to the House of Lords. They also ordered him to pay the estimated $39,800 costs of the Court of Appeal hearings.

DOC.HEAD: Heat Wave in Britain Brings Insects, Pollution and Water Shortage
DOC.TEXT: A hot and unusually dry summer has Britons choking on pollution, swatting insects and snitching on their water-wasting neighbors. Even the water provides no relief: the National Rivers Authority says algae in many waterways is causing rashes, nausea and diarrhea. But it wasn't until a visitor punched an attendant in a public garden _ a place considered only slightly less sacred than a church in England _ that the seriousness of the island's latest heat wave became apparent to all. Temperatures have been in the eighties on seven of the past eight days. Monday was the exception, with a balmy 79. Although many Americans would be disappointed if the mercury didn't reach that high during the summer months, British officials responded with warnings. Joggers, the elderly and infirm have been warned by the Environment Department to avoid strenuous exercise. ``Don't swim here,'' says the National Rivers Authority at 177 stretches of water choked with algae. Eight pollution-sensitive tobacco plants were planted in the Parliament Square flower beds in central London by junior conservationists. On Wednesday Environment Minister David Trippier got a first-hand look at how bad things are. The plants had already developed brown spots from pollution. Some peoples' tempers weren't in much better shape. On Sunday an attendant at Oxford's world-famous Botanic Garden was punched by a visitor who didn't want to leave at closing time. It must have been the heat, surmised the superintendent, Tim Walker. ``It was a hideous day, 93 in the shade.'' The garden shut for a week in protest, overreaction perhaps, considering the attendant suffered only a bruised cheek, but as Walker pointed out: ``It's not the sort of behavior you expect from the British garden-loving public.'' Then there are wasps, thrips, thunder-flies and leaf-hoppers, which multiply in flowers and shrubbery and lie in wait for plant lovers bending to smell a blossom or cut the hedge. Rashes, splotches and bites soon follow. ``Thunder-Fly Plague Feared,'' The Daily Telegraph headlined Tuesday. ``The shop is full of people complaining about the heat and saying they are being bitten to death,'' said Sue Birch, a south London pharmacist. ``The trouble seems to come from midges, little flies. We also get complaints about fleas. The hot weather makes the fleas fidgety and they jump off cats and dogs and land on people. ``The other big complaint is about suntan burns, especially from families who take off their car roofs. We aren't used to so much sun in this country.'' Although Britain is stereotyped as a rainy, gloomy place, temperatures exceed 80 every summer, and in eight years of this century have hit 95. London has had less than 8.5 inches of rain this year compared with nearly 15 inches in the same period last year. A ban on watering gardens and washing cars begins Saturday for 1 million people north and east of London, in Hertfordshire and Essex, and in some northern parts of the capital. Bans are already in force for more than 1 million people in Yorkshire, Sussex, Kent and large parts of Devon. The restrictions are announced in the media, and neighbors who spot people watering their gardens or washing their cars with hoses are expected to turn them in to the local authorities, who can then impose fines. In severe drought, helicopters are used to spot rogue lawn waterers. Water authorities say water supply problems are cause for concern, but not panic. August will be a scorcher with severe drought, says Piers Corbyn, a long-range weather forecaster. ``It is expected to be one of the hottest Augusts this century, probably breaking many records,'' he predicted. Corbyn, a lecturer in astrophysics, said he made more than $3,600 by betting on the weather last year. He currently has 29 different bets with bookmakers on the weather and said he won $513 last month.

DOC.HEAD: Coalition Urges Congress To Act To Halt Loss Of Black-Owned Farms
DOC.TEXT: With minority-owned farms disappearing three times as fast as white-owned farms, a coalition of religious and farm groups called Thursday for congressional action to reverse the trend. The coalition, joined by about 25 black farmers from across the South, urged passage of legislation sponsored by Sen. Wyche Fowler Jr., D-Ga., and Rep. Mike Espy, D-Miss., to help minority farmers stay in business and provide opportunities for minority youth to enter farming. Fowler said the situation has worsened since 1982, when the Civil Rights Commission reported that the number of black-owned farms in the United States had declined by 94 percent since 1920. While the commission found that black farms were disappearing 2.5 times as fast as white-owned farms, a new study this year by the Washington-based Rural Coalition found that between 1982 and 1987, the rate of decline of black farms was 3.6 times that of white farms. Between 1978 and 1987, the study found, the number of black-owned farms declined 23 percent while the number of white-owned farms dropped by only 6.6 percent. Of the nearly 10,000 black-owned farms that were lost during the decade, 92 percent were in the South. ``Minority farmers ... are being plowed under,'' Espy said, ``and we think that through the policies of USDA and the Farmers Home (Administration) ... they're being left for weeds.'' Espy charged that the federal farm credit system has been insensitive to the financial needs of minority farmers. He said the switch in federal farm policy during the 1980s from loans to loan guarantees was particularly harmful, because many commercial banks won't make loans to minority farmers, even with government guarantees. Espy and Fowler said they hope to incorporate their Minority Farmers Rights Act into the 1990 farm bill, which will set the nation's farm policy for the next five years. The Senate opened debate on its version of the farm bill Thursday. The Espy-Fowler bill would establish policies in the Department of Agriculture to end discrimination in the awarding of federal farm benefits, create an affirmative action program within the department, and establish an appeals process for discrimination complaints.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Puts Priest in Prison After Child Molest Probation Violation
DOC.TEXT: A judge who four years ago gave a priest probation for molesting altar boys said he would throw him in prison if he was ever caught with children again. This week, the judge kept his word. The Rev. Andrew Christian Andersen, convicted of 26 counts of child molestation in 1986, was sentenced Wednesday to six years in prison. ``I gave you a chance to straighten your life out. You let me down,'' Superior Court Judge Luis A. Cardenas told Andersen. The former parish priest was convicted four years ago of molesting altar boys at St. Bonaventure Roman Catholic Church in Huntington Beach. Cardenas placed Andersen on five years' probation but threatened him with prison if he had unsupervised contact with children. Andersen was arrested March 12 in Albuquerque, N.M., for investigation of kidnapping and attempted child molestation. Police said he lured a 14-year-old boy into his car and fondled him. No charges have been filed. Andersen's lawyer said the 38-year-old priest denies any criminal wrongdoing in that case but admits he violated terms of his probation. ``He thinks that he ended up breaking his agreement with Cardenas so he got what was coming,'' said attorney William Monroe.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Chief's Pledge May Help Deficit Talks, Eventually Hurt Economy
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan may have offered just the ingredient the administration needs to reach a budget deal with Congress. But ultimately it could poison the economy. One problem is that jittery investors are reading Greenspan's pledge to lower interest rates in exchange for a budget agreement as a sign that the Fed chief is caving in to political pressure and abandoning the fight against inflation. Many economists, recalling the experience of the 1960s, fear that the outcome of all the economic tinkering will be rising inflation and weaker growth _ the worst of all possible worlds and a prescription for the very recession the administration wants to avoid. Financial markets, which normally rally on the promise of lower interest rates, went into a funk after Greenspan's Wednesday promise. Investors worried about his motivations in discussing lower interest rates on a day when the government was reporting a worrisome jump in consumer inflation. The Federal Reserve, as the protector of the nation's money supply and key defender against inflation, is supposed to be above the political fray. But the timing of Greenspan's comments raised questions about whether the Fed chief is now worrying more about his possible reappointment by President Bush next year than he is about keeping inflation under control. The Bush administration has recently intensified its pressure on the Greenspan Fed to relent and lower interest rates. The Federal Reserve had been resisting those entreaties, contending that a dose of high interest rates was needed to slow the economy and thus bring inflation under control. Then suddenly last week, Greenspan took the unusual step of announcing Fed intentions in advance, saying that the central bank planned to ease credit slightly to offset overly cautious lending practices by the nation's banks. Just a month ago, Greenspan had said he could not detect any broadbased tightening by lenders. On Friday, the Fed did ease, moving to push a key interest rate, the federal funds rate, down to 8 percent. It had been at 8.25 percent since December. Then this week in his twice-a-year appearance before Congress to explain the Fed's monetary policy, Greenspan held out the promise of further interest rate declines should Congress and the administration agree to ``major, substantive, credible cuts in the budget deficit.'' Greenspan's words were hailed by the administration, which wants Fed participation in any budget deal with Congress. Their fear is that the $50 billion to $60 billion in spending cuts and tax increases being contemplated to lower the budget deficit would take a lot of momentum out of an economy that is already sputtering along at near-recession levels. The economy, as measured by the gross national product, grew at a sub-par 1.9 percent annual rate in the first three months of 1990 and by some measurements of employment as many as 16 states are in a virtual recession at present. The administration sought and got Greenspan's assurance that he would loosen monetary policy to offset the huge drop in spending power that would come from a deficit deal. Lower interest rates, by this reasoning, would give a boost to the economy by encouraging more business and consumer borrowing. But what has economists concerned is that the weak growth is occurring at a time when inflationary pressures are rising. The Labor Department reported Wednesday that consumer prices shot up 0.5 percent in June and have been rising at an annual rate of 5.9 percent so far this year, the worst price performance since former Fed Chairman Paul Volcker was fighting double-digit rates at the beginning of the 1980s. Some economists worry that the nation may be on the verge of another bout of stagflation _ the term coined in the 1970s to describe a combination of slow economic growth, rising prices and rising unemployment. In such instances, the Fed's ability to lower interest rates to boost economic growth is constrained by the need to battle inflation. In addition, the financial markets, looking at the inflation numbers, may resist and demand even higher interest-rate premiums for their investments. Also, policies even at the powerful Federal Reserve work with uncertain lag times. And the ability to fine-tune monetary policy, which is controlled by the Fed, and budgetary policy, controlled by Congress and the administration, has not often been successful before. Veteran Fed watchers say the last time there was an attempt at a coordinated hike in tax revenues and cut in interest rates came more than two decades ago. President Lyndon Johnson pressured then-Fed Chairman William McChesney Martin to lower interest rates to offset the effects of a 10 percent tax surchage Congress enacted in 1968 to pay for the Vietnam War. The tax increase was not enough to offset the stimulative effects of the interest rate cuts, thus sending inflation ratcheting upward and laying the groundwork for a recession which began at the end of 1969, ending the nation's longest economic recovery at just over nine years. The current recovery, which is in its eighth year, may be headed for the same fate. ``There is a parallel between Martin's situation and Greenspan's situation,'' said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., who has written two books on Fed policy. ``If you make a deal with politicians, there is always the danger that you will end up with the worst of both possible worlds. You will get higher inflation and lower growth.''

DOC.HEAD: Hefner Bunny Goes on Endangered Species List
DOC.TEXT: A rare rabbit found only in the Florida Keys and named after Playboy magazine founder Hugh Hefner was added to the federal endangered species list, government biologists said Thursday. Only about 200 of the Lower Keys marsh rabbits are believed to live on a few islands of the archipelago that extends from the southern tip of Florida. The animal is the only rabbit among the 1,000 creatures on the endangered species list, said U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service biologist Michael Bentzien. But it joins 16 other animals from the islands _ including the Key deer _ already classified as endangered, which is not surprising, said Washington-based Fish & Wildlife biologist Jay Sheppard. ``There's only a small amount of habitat left,'' Sheppard said. ``And for almost all animals found on islands and isolated for a period of a time, the rule of thumb is a lower (fertility) rate.'' The dark brown, marsh-dwelling rabbits were only identified as a separate spcecies in 1980, thanks to the work of the private Conservation Agency and its President James Lazell. He in turn was financed by the Playboy Foundation and in gratitude the rabbit's Latin name is Sylvilagus palustris hefneri, after Hefner. The marsh rabbit's name was entered in the Federal Register on June 21, and the protection goes into effect Saturday, 30 days later, said Sheppard. The designation means that no development project funded or authorized by the federal government may threaten the rabbits' habitat, and no one may shoot, trap or harass the animals, said Sheppard. The rabbit is not the only Florida animal to make the list as of Saturday. The little-known Squirrel Chimney Cave shrimp, which lives only in an underground sinkhole in Alachua County west of Gainesville, also has won that protection. The unpigmented inch-long shrimp resembles the grass shrimp often found along Florida rivers, but lacks eyes because of its underground existence.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Victory in Cold War Painful for Workers Facing Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: By the end of the year, thousands of McDonnell Douglas employees in cities such as Long Beach, Calif., and St. Louis will be out of work, victims of the U.S. victory in the Cold War. ``Turning swords into plowshares is not painless,'' Rep. Nicholas Mavroules, D-Mass., said Thursday _ just four days after McDonnell Douglas, the nation's largest military contractor, announced it was laying off 17,000 employees. Mavroules and several other House Democrats have crafted legislation to assist communities, businesses and workers who will be hard hit by the certain cuts in defense spending. The legislation, formally known as ``The Economic Stabilization, Adjustment and Defense Industry Conversion Act of 1990,'' is the product of repeated attempts in Congress to produce a financial-assistance package. The collapse of the Warsaw Pact as a military alliance and demands at home to reduce military spending gave impetus to the legislation. Mavroules, who chairs the House Armed Services subcommittee on investigations, held a hearing on the package Thursday. The legislation calls for using $200 million from the defense budget for retraining workers, helping companies switch from military to commercial production and providing grants to communities, among other provisions. Existing economic-development programs, such as the Defense Department's Office of Economic Adjustment, would be expanded to handle the money with the president's Economic Stabilization and Adjustment Council providing the oversight. Democrats believe the legislation must be approved this year. ``Congress tends to react to a crisis rather than planning ahead,'' said Rep. Mary Rose Oakar, D-Ohio, who testified before the Armed Services panel and then oversaw her own subcommittee's approval of a section of the economic conversion legislation. Oakar chairs the House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs subcommittee on economic stabilization. Mavroules said recent estimates from the Bush administration indicate that the nation has 3.4 million people working in the defense industry. About 30,000 have been laid off this year and the number will likely grow as military spending decreases. President Bush has proposed spending $307 billion on defense in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, but the Senate Armed Services Committee has approved $289 billion. The House Armed Services Committee is scheduled to craft a bill beginning next week based on a budget of $283 billion. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., whose constituents will be affected by the McDonnell Douglas layoffs, criticized the administration for rejecting the concept of economic assistance. ``Secretary of Defense Richard Cheney said, and I quote, `We have enough to do just figuring out how to cut the defense budget; we are not spending lots of time thinking about conversion.''' Gephardt said that assessment was ``irresponsible, unfair and naive.'' Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., who also testified before the panel, said there was little enthusiasm for the economic-assistance plan in the Senate, where lawmakers feel uneasy about singling out defense when other industries are also facing severe problems. Dr. Robert M. Rauner, director of the Defense Department's Office of Economic Adjustment, said the administration opposes the House legislation because it duplicates existing efforts and would be costly. ``The existing economic adjustment program is comprehensive and coordinated,'' Rauner said. ``It is tailored to help meet local needs.''

DOC.HEAD: East German Economy Hits New Low
DOC.TEXT: East Germany checked the pulse of its economy Thursday and released a grim diagnosis: industrial production has plunged and at least 9 percent of its workers have lost all or part of their wages. Industrial production fell by 15 percent in June and half a million workers have had their hours and salaries slashed since July 1, when the nation became a free market and merged its economy with West Germany's. The figures follow by one day the government's estimate that up to 40,000 East Germans have been thrown out of work weekly since the economic merger. As it lurches through its first weeks of the free market, East German lawmakers debated Thursday how to pull the country through its final months as a nation. The country is facing a $38.6 billion deficit in the budget for the second half of the year. The budget will be the country's last before East Germany unites with West Germany in December. While lawmakers debated the budget, about 2,500 uniformed police officers gathered in front of the Parliament building to demand higher wages to cope with rising food costs. ``Penalize the guilty, not us,'' read a banner carried by the demonstrators, who hooted and jeered when Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel told the group the country has no money. Labor Minister Regine Hildebrandt told a news conference that about 500,000 East German workers have had their hours and wages slashed since July 1. The workers normally would have been laid off, but are being kept in their factories under a $1.2 billion program financed by West Germany. Under the program, workers who normally would be targeted for layoffs are being paid about 60 percent of their salaries to remain in the factories, where they are to receive training for other jobs. On Wednesday, the government announced that unemployment was at 223,876 in mid-June, about 2.7 percent of the 8 million East German workers. That was up from 30,000 jobless in March. Together, the number of workers who have either lost their jobs or are in the subsidized jobs program is at least 724,000, or about 9 percent of the workforce. However, the actual jobless figure is likely much higher than the most recent figures from mid-June. The government estimated Wednesday that 30,000 to 40,000 workers have been thrown out of work each week this month. The government statistics office announced Thursday that industrial production was down 15.1 percent in June from the same time a year earlier, and down 7.3 percent during the first six months of this year compared with the same period last year. Economists say unemployment could reach 3 million within a year as uncompetitive East German companies go bankrupt, unable to make the adjustment from a centrally planned economy to a free market. On Tuesday, the government said 2,400 of the country's 8,000 companies _ 30 percent _ were unable to pay their bills. Arno Donda, statistics office chief, also said that living costs for East Germans rose 12.1 percent in June compared with June 1989. Like the industrial production figure, that statistic was recorded before the July 1 economic merger, when East Germany's borders were opened to Western products, prices for basic necessities skyrocketed, and East German enterprises felt the full brunt of Western competition. The East German Parliament failed to iron out a feud over whether to merge with West Germany a day before all-German elections expected on Dec. 2 or immediately after the vote. East German lawmakers will meet in a special session on Sunday and are expected to decide on a date then. Also Thursday, in a gesture of good will, Poland removed the last stretch of barbed wire on its side of the border with East Germany, Polish TV news reported. The move came two days after the two Germanys pledged to respect the postwar border with Poland after German unification.

DOC.HEAD: House Leaders Dismiss Complaint on Campaign Financing Reform
DOC.TEXT: Democratic House leaders on Thursday dismissed a private group's charges that they are blocking action on campaign finance reform because they are addicted to the current system. Rep. Al Swift, chairman of the the Elections subcommittee and a task force on campaign finance reform, said the Democrats intend to send a proposal to the floor as soon as they work out conflicts among themselves. ``We can't do it to the timetable of advocates outside the institution who say we want it by noon Tuesday,'' he said. Public Citizen, a consumer advocacy group founded in 1971 by Ralph Nader, said eight House leaders with direct influence on the reform process received an average of $337,233 each from political action committees in 1988 _ 61 percent of all their campaign contributions. The group called that ``a gross conflict of interest.'' The eight lawmakers examined in the report were House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash.; Majority Leader Dick Gephardt, D-Mo.; Majority Whip Bill Gray, D-Pa.; Steny Hoyer of Maryland and Vic Fazio of California, the chairman and vice chairman of the Democratic Caucus; chief deputy whip David Bonior, D-Mich.; Beryl Anthony of Arkansas, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee; and Swift, D-Wash. Public Citizen said a larger group of 148 Democratic House leaders, including deputy whips and chairmen of committees and subcommittees, received average PAC contributions of $198,161 each in 1988 _ 52 percent of their warchests. By contrast, the group said, Republican challengers averaged $11,586 each _ only 11 percent of their funds. Joan Claybrook, president of Public Citizen, said the Democrats ``seem intent on killing campaign reform legislation this year. Perhaps one of the reasons is that they are addicted to PAC funds and to the current system.'' Jeff Biggs, a Foley spokesman, said the leadership wants very much to have a bill on the floor this year and discussions are continuing. ``The suggestion that somehow this has all ground to a halt is not true,'' he said. The House and the Senate have been unable so far to agree on a bipartisan approach to campaign finance reform. Proposals in both chambers are in flux. The Public Citizen report said PACs ``migrate to legislative decision-makers and PAC dollars are very easy to raise ... It is little surprise then that the leadership is endorsing PAC reform which would do little more than codify the status quo.'' The group said that plan, proposed by Swift, would restrict PACs with fewer contributors but permit those with many small contributors to continue business as usual. In addition, Public Citizen said, the plan puts no aggregate cap on PAC receipts and does not provide for public financing. A Swift aide, however, said the final bill is expected to restrict PAC contributions to a certain percentage or dollar amount of a candidate's warchest. Swift said PACs are the one area in which Public Citizen's concerns have not yet been met. He said the group has praised two other elements of his proposal _ closing a loophole that permits virtually unlimited spending by parties and voluntary overall spending limits with incentives to comply. ``Positive reinforcement is not one of the tools they use very often,'' Swift said of the Nader group. ``These aren't ivory tower boys. These are people who know how to fight in the street. They are trying to twist our arm as hard as they can.''

DOC.HEAD: Loans from Japan to Resume in September
With AM-China
DOC.TEXT: Japan will free up a five-year, $5.4 billion loan package to China that was frozen after last year's bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators, the Japanese Embassy said Thursday. Former Japanese foreign minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka told China's foreign minister, Qian Qichen, that the first payment of $405 million would be made in September, followed by another of the same amount in February. Japan's deputy foreign minister, Hisashi Owada, had told Qian earlier this week that Japan planned to gradually resume lending, but Thursday's announcement was the first indication of the timetable for China recieving the funds. The loan package is for 42 projects involving railways, telecommunications, ports, power plants, airports, fertilizer plants, highways and sewage systems. Freezing the loan package was part of Japan's sanctions against China after the army attack on pro-democracy protestors in June of 1989. The seven industrialized powers, in an economic summit in Houston last week, decided to maintain economic sanctions imposed against China after it killed hundreds, perhaps thousands of unarmed civilians in crushing a popular democracy movement. But the summit leaders gave Japan tacit approval to resume lending, which Japan says is in the interest of regional stability.

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Rages in South Lebanon Village
DOC.TEXT: Red Cross rescuers dodged sniper fire Thursday to remove 11 bloated bodies from a hilltop village in south Lebanon where pro-Iranian militiamen and Syrian-backed rivals have fought for four days. Police said two people were killed and five wounded in the fighting Thursday. That raised the casualty toll to 66 people killed and 223 wounded since Monday when the battles erupted just north of Israel's self-designated security zone. The International Committee of the Red Cross said the fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the more secular Amal agreed to observe a brief ``humanitarian truce'' Thursday afternoon to allow the rescuers into Iqlim al-Tuffah, or Apple Province. But when the convoy of five Lebanese Red Cross ambulances and two Red Cross cars rolled into Jarjou, shells rained on the embattled hilltop village and the rescuers pulled out empty-handed, police said. An hour later, the fighting ebbed into sporadic sniper fire and the rescuers, wearing masks because of the heavy stench of death, entered Jarjou again. They wrapped 11 bodies in plastic bags and piled them in the ambulances. The fighting suddenly escalated and the rescuers sped out in the ambulances, leaving behind four corpses. By mid-afternoon the rugged mountains above Sidon, provincial capital of south Lebanon, were shaking with artillery and rocket blasts. It was unclear when the rescuers will be able to bring out the remaining bodies. Amal and Hezbollah gunners battled with howitzers, mortars and multi-barreled rocket-launchers. Caught in the middle were Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas manning a 4-mile-long buffer between Amal and Hezbollah. The 600-strong PLO force had deployed Tuesday to end the inter-Shiite bloodbath. On Wednesday, six guerrillas were wounded when Hezbollah fired at their positions. One of the victims died in hospital Thursday, police said. There were no casualties among the guerrillas in Thursday's duels. Amal and Hezbollah have been fighting on and off for three years for mastery of the 1.2 million Shiites who make up Lebanon's largest sect. More than 1,100 people have been killed and nearly 3,400 wounded in the inconclusive showdown. The hostilities in the south appeared to be spreading slowly to the capital, Beirut, where reprisal kidnappings were reported during the night. Police said masked gunmen from Amal and Hezbollah raided houses in west and south Beirut and abducted at least 40 people belonging to the rival groups. Militiamen of the two parties also took to the streets before dawn as tension heightened, but they fled when Syrian troops in charge of security in the capital's Moslem sector moved in to prevent gunplay. Beirut's independent newspaper An-Nahar said the PLO has lifted an ultimatum for Hezbollah to withdraw from Jarjou. PLO chief Yasser Arafat's representative in south Lebanon, Zeid Webe, said Wednesday that if Hezbollah did not withdraw in 24 hours, it will be evicted. Hezbollah, in a statement, warned of ``grave consequences resulting from the unjustified Palestinian expansion in south Lebanon.'' The PLO disengagement force is drawn mainly from Arafat's mainstream Fatah faction. It intervened to prevent Hezbollah from seizing Nabatiyeh, the main Shiite town in the central sector of south Lebanon, or thrusting west toward the Mediterranean. Hezbollah needs the sea outlet to bring in supplies from Iran.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Explosion Rocks Chemical Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with 38 injured, quote from plant worker. ADDS byline.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Explosions ripped through a chemical plant Thursday, igniting a fire and injuring at least 38 people, officials said. Flames engulfed the BASF plant, a four-story, brick building that covers most of a city block on the north side. The blast shattered windows in neighboring homes and businesses. Ben Diedenhofer, a production manager, was in a lab overlooking the plant's resin building when the first explosion occurred about 2:15 p.m. ``It blew out all the windows. The whole resin building was engulfed in flames,'' Diedenhofer said. ``I couldn't get in to help anyone. I saw one person hanging on to the building. I was able to get him off,'' he said. Diedenhofer said there was a second explosion about a half hour later. He said about 200 people work at the plant, which makes linings for cans. ``I looked out a window and I could see a huge ball of fire and smoke, it must have been 100 - 150 feet in the air,'' said Dan Delaney, who works near the chemical plant. ``Everybody was running down the street ... just getting out of there as fast as they could.'' ``Police and firemen are all around, fighting the blaze. They just keep getting small explosions and more fireballs shooting up in the air,'' he said. Rescue workers throughout Hamilton County and from Cincinnati suburbs in northern Kentucky responded. The injured were taken to four hospitals. At least 19 people were taken to Bethesda Hospital with minor injuries, said spokeswoman Julie Whiteley. The University of Cincinnati Hospital received 16 patients with burns, broken bones, cuts and bruises, said spokesman David Bracey. Four were in critical condition. At least one victim was at Good Samaritan Hospital, said spokeswoman Jackie Heinitz. Five people were brought to Jewish Hospital, spokeswoman Pat Seger said, but she said none of the patients were in the plant. Ms. Seger said two people were injured by shattered glass at a supermarket.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Alleged Secrecy, Californians Praise Bob Hope Land Exchange
DOC.TEXT: California congressmen on Thursday praised a proposed swap of federal land near Los Angeles to entertainer Bob Hope for potential parkland acreage despite complaints the deal was ramrodded through the National Park Service. ``I, too, dislike seeing a career park service official overruled by a political appointee,'' Rep. Anthony C. Beilenson, D-Calif., testified at a House subcommittee hearing into federal land trades. ``But that shouldn't be used as a reason to oppose the trade.'' Even Rep. George A. Miller, D-Calif., long a critic of federal land trade practices, said the deal has its good points. The deal would involve the trade of 59 acres of federal land near Los Angeles for 5,600 acres in the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area. Key to the deal is a 2,300-acre tract, known as Jordan Ranch, owned by Hope. Hope wants to build houses and a PGA Tour golf course on the property, which the National Park Service has previously said it wants to acquire. In order to make the site easily accessible to the Ventura Freeway, Hope needs to build a road through federal land. The proposed trade would give Hope 59 acres of park service land so he could build the road. In exchange, he would give the park service 864 acres from a parcel he owns and sell at bargain prices or give the remaining 4,772 acre he owns on four parcels to a state land conservancy. Beilenson, Rep. Howard L. Berman, D-Calif., and other supporters say the proposed acquisition, the largest single parkland acquisition in Southern California in two decades, probably would not be accomplished otherwise because of the soaring real estate market and the lack of federal acquisition dollars. They say the deal would protect wildlife, including eagles and mountain lions, native oaks, and provide a corridor for wildlife to roam from the mountains to the Pacific coast. The congressmen testified at a hearing of the House Government Operations subcommittee on environment, chaired by Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla. The hearing is the second in a series by the subcommittee on the federal practice of acquiring desired federal lands through exchanges rather than purchases. The practice began more widespread during the Reagan administration. Miller and others contend public interests are inadequately protected because the deals are done in secret. Critics say also that the Interior Department risks being fleeced by sophisticated developers because of a lack of safeguards assuring trades are fair. Critics of this particular deal, including Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., say the park service should not be promoting private land development interests, especially since the park service wanted the Jordan Ranch land. Synar tried to demonstrate that department employees had originally opposed the deal three years ago, only to be overruled by a political appointee, William P. Horn, assistant secretary for fish, wildlife and parks.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Raises Fresh Veto Threat on Job Discrimination Bill
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle said Thursday the president will veto a Senate-passed bill to combat job bias unless it is purged of provisions the administration contends invite hiring quotas. House sponsors left the door open to modest changes. ``The administration is not going to have a quota bill crammed down its throat disguised as a civil rights bill,'' Quayle said the morning after the Senate passed the bill. House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jack Brooks, D-Texas, said he believed there were enough votes on the House floor to pass the bill without changes, even if the administration was ``still screaming about quotas.'' But he and other Democrats suggested the bill could be altered. One Democratic sponsor, Don Edwards of California, said, ``We're going to listen respectfully'' to any administration proposals. ``We're going to be discussing one or two items that might make them feel a little better.'' Republicans suggested that Democratic willingness to dicker over the provisions could signal concern about the chances of overriding a Bush veto. ``It's obvious that 34 votes are enough to sustain a veto,'' said Rep. James Sensenbrenner, R-Wis., speaking of the Senate margin. Democratic leaders said the bill _ which tops the civil rights movement's congressional list _ most likely would clear its final committee hurdle in the House on Tuesday without changes. But House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., said it most likely would not reach the House floor until September because of a logjam of bills awaiting action. The bill would effectively overturn five Supreme Court decisions last year that civil rights leaders see as setbacks for their movement. Provisions range from banning racial discrimination in the workplace to allowing victims to seek punitive damages in the most severe discrimination cases. The sharpest clashes surround a provision that would make it easier to challenge hiring practices at companies where the work force does not mirror the ethnic makeup of the local labor pool. Until last year, it was up to employers who were challenged to justify their hiring practices on the basis of business necessity. A high court ruling last year put the burden of proof on those who file the suits to show the hiring motive was other than business necessity. The bill would again put the burden on employers. The administration maintains that the business-necessity language, along with damages provisions, would attract lawsuits and spur employers to adopt their own unofficial hiring quotas as a defensive measure to keep out of court. Bush has said repeatedly that he wants legislation to combat discrimination in the workplace but will not sign a bill that would lead to hiring quotas. Quayle, meeting with reporters in San Antonio, Texas, said major surgery would be needed before Bush could sign the legislation passed Wednesday night by the Senate. He said there would be enough votes to sustain a veto if the measure arrives on the president's desk in unaltered form. Brooks, the Democratic chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said he expected the panel to approve the bill without any changes on Tuesday but left the door open to negotiations. ``They haven't worked out any compromise with me or with Mr. Edwards,'' Brooks said. ``I want it written down. I want to take a look at their suggestions.'' Senate sponsor Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said Wednesday night he was encouraged by the 65 votes the measure received _ two short of the number needed to override. But Rep. Henry J. Hyde, R-Ill., said he doubted that it would be easy to switch the votes of two senators. Hyde also said he believed that Senate passage of the measure guaranteed that employer groups ``will start lobbying and do so with a vengeance.''

DOC.HEAD: Blast Shatters Windows in Large Area, Interrupts University Schedule
DOC.TEXT: The explosion Thursday at the BASF chemical plant shattered windows up to four blocks away and sent a cloud of black smoke drifting over Xavier University, where classes were called off for the day. It caused a momentary panic in the residential neighborhood near the plant. ``I was sitting in my living room talking on the telephone, and it blew me right out of my chair. I thought somebody threw a bomb,'' said Dorothy Douglas, who lives about a quarter mile from the building. ``I heard a big boom and thought a car had hit the building. Then I looked up and glass was falling every which way,'' said Dilsey Freeman, a barber at the Curtis Styles Unlimited shop. ``Two little kids were running past, and they were cut by the glass and they were bleeding.'' Flames engulfed the four-story, brick BASF building, which covered most of a city block. Dozens of workers at the plant were injured. Dan Delaney, who works near the plant, said he saw a huge ball of fire and smoke out his office window. ``Shortly thereafter, everybody was running down the street, out of the building to get out, sort of in a panic, just getting out of there as fast as they could,'' Delaney said. The explosion knocked out electrical power and broke windows on the Xavier campus, about four blocks from the explosion site, said Xavier spokesman Charlie Carey. ``It shook the building,'' Carey said. ``It knocked out power immediately.'' Smoke from the explosion drifted over campus for about an hour before it began to dissipate, he said. Carey said the campus was cleared of students and staff, and remaining afternoon and night classes were canceled. Exams scheduled for Thursday night were rescheduled for Friday night, Carey said.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Abolishes Privileges for Officials in Russian Republic
DOC.TEXT: Russian federation president Boris N. Yeltsin, who won popular support by denouncing the privileges enjoyed by the ruling elite, has abolished those luxuries for the republic's officials, Tass reported Thursday. The decree did not appear to apply to thousands of high-ranking officials of the national government and Communist Party who live and work in Moscow, which is both the capital of the Soviet Union and the Russian federation, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics. The decree from the presidium of the Russian parliament that was signed by Yeltsin abolished all kinds and forms of privileges to officials in the Russian federation as of Aug. 1, saying they ``violate social justice,'' the official news agency reported. Abolished were privileges ``on power, on unearned payments, on undeserved benefits, (and) on undeserved and unearned comfortable working and living conditions of organizations, enterprises, offices and workers of the apparatus of state organs.'' It said that as of Aug. 1, all legislative acts, resolutions, instructions and regulations directly or indirectly ensuring privileges to officials, ``no matter what posts they hold,'' will be considered invalid. Special food and clothing stores, sleek black limousines, fancy homes and high-quality medical care for the government and party elite have generated massive public resentment in a country where there are shortages of housing, food and consumer goods. Yeltsin built his election campaign to the national parliament on the issue last year and was extremely popular because of it. There was no explanation why the 2-day-old decree, which was signed Tuesday, was released only by Tass on Thursday. The Russian parliament said in the document the mass media had 10 days to publish it. In February, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev took some action against the privileged elite by deciding the country's current and former leaders _ excepting himself and Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov _ were no longer entitled to luxuries such as country houses. Many retired members of the Communist Party Politburo _ some in their 90s _ were ordered to move out. They also lost the right to their household workers, cars and special government food stores. Under public pressure, Gorbachev last year reluctantly agreed to endorse an attack on the privileges given the Soviet elite. Many of the Soviet elite's country houses, known as dachas, are believed to feature tennis courts, private swimming pools and fountains. On the outskirts of Moscow, they are surrounded by fences and guards.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Department Disagrees With Osprey Aircraft Study It Commissioned
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Department still believes the tilt-rotor V-22 Osprey assault transport aircraft isn't worth buying despite conclusions of a study showing long-term cost advantages over helicopters, a top official said Thursday. David Chu, assistant defense secretary for program analysis and evaluation, told the Senate Appropriations defense subcommittee that the study by the Institute for Defense Analyses assumes the department will have more money to purchase assault transports than it will actually have. That extra money would buy more assault transport capability than the Marine Corps, primary user of the V-22 for attacking defended beaches, would need, Chu said. The department must ``figure out how to accomplish its most important missions _ perhaps less well than would be possible with more resources _ while still achieving substantial savings,'' he said. ``The alternative helicopter forces _ perhaps in smaller numbers at lower investment and operating costs _ can perform the higher-priority DoD missions at acceptable levels.'' The institute's study acknowledged the higher initial cost of the V-22 and said that would be offset by lower operating costs. Chu, however, said those savings in operating costs ``are dubious and would accrue gradually over many years, to the extent that they occur at all.'' As an example, he said the institute assumed one helicopter, the CH-47M, could be used only 1.7 hours per day, but Army data on a related model, the CH-47D, suggest availability of four hours per day. ``Moreover, the IDA study assumes we can change operational practices to play to the V-22's major strengths but downplays the advantages of the larger helicopters in the alternative forces,'' Chu said. Chu said the Ospreys would cost about $3.7 billion more, during fiscal years 1991 through 1997, than Secretary of the Navy H. Lawrence Garrett III recommended be spent on medium airlift. Released three weeks ago, the institute's study was ballyhooed by congressional backers of the aircraft, which received no production money for the current year after Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said he wanted to kill it. Congress ordered the study, but the Pentagon chose the institute, a non-profit group with close ties to the Pentagon, to perform it. Cheney has cited the case of the Osprey as illustrating the difficulty of killing any program even when many in Congress cry for smaller defense budgets. With its twin end-of-wing propellers pointed up, the Osprey can take off like a helicopter, and then can rotate the propellers to point forward and fly like a plane faster and farther than helicopters.
