Its prime contractors are Boeing Helicopters, a suburban Philadelphia division of Boeing Co.; and Bell Helicopter Textron of Fort Worth, Texas. The Senate Armed Services Committee has authorized $238 million in Osprey research and development money for the new fiscal year beginning Oct 1. That money would have to be made available in an appropriations bill, and backers hope to get production funds as well.

DOC.HEAD: Spring Rise in Farm Milk Prices Pushed Up Retail Prices
DOC.TEXT: Milk prices at the farm declined last winter but regained some of their lost ground during the spring. That also pushed up consumer prices, an Agriculture Department report said Thursday. ``However, continued substantial growth in milk production and reductions in probably swollen user inventories of non-fat dry milk likely will limit further advances in milk and dairy product prices,'' the report said. Milk production was up more than 2 percent during the April-June quarter from year-earlier levels. The number of cows held about steady but milk output per cow was up. ``High farm milk prices since 1989 spurred the expansion, although financial caution and forage concerns have restrained growth,'' the report said. Milk production in the second half of 1990 probably will rise about 3 percent from a year earlier, the report said. That would raise total 1990 milk output by about 2 percent from last year. If wholesale prices hold relatively steady for the rest of 1990, analysts said the average price increase for farm milk prices may be in the range of 3 percent to 5 percent for the entire year. The overall retail prices of dairy products _ including milk, cheese, butter and other products _ were up about 10 percent from a year earlier during the second quarter as widening price spreads between producers and consumers more than matched the increase in farm milk prices. ``Retail prices during the rest of 1990 likely will remain near recent levels, and the increases from 1989 are expected to average 8 percent to 10 percent for the year,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Ailing Former First Lady Makes Rare Public Appearance
With AM-Nixon Library, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Pat Nixon, the shy, reclusive, former first lady, made a rare public appearance Thursday, walking with her husband to center stage at the dedication of his library. She got the longest applause of all. President Bush called her ``a mirror of America's heart and love.'' Mrs. Nixon, at 78, has seldom been seen in public since she moved with her husband to California after he resigned the presidency in 1974. Since then, the Nixons have moved to a large estate in New Jersey. There, too, neighbors seldom see her. Nearly all of the public mention of the former first lady in recent years has been her frequent hospitalizations. She suffered a major stroke in 1977 that left her paralyzed on one side and a milder one in 1983. Still, she shows few effects. She walks with a firm step and talks without any trace of impairment. Her daughter, Julie Nixon Eisenhower, said her mother spends a good deal of time in her garden. However, the Nixons are moving out of their house in Saddle River, N.J., to a nearby condominium apartment because taking care of a large garden has become too much for her. Nixon met his wife, the former Thelma Catherine Ryan, during an acting tryout when he was a young lawyer in Whittier, Calif., and she was a school teacher. He said for him it was a case of love at first sight. She was given the nickname Pat by her father and it stuck. They celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary last month. In his speech, President Bush praised her as ``a gracious first lady who ranks among the most admired women of post-war America.'' The president said that during her time in the White House, Mrs. Nixon ``championed the Right To Read program, and helped bring the Parks To People program to the disadvantaged.'' He said that Mrs. Nixon was ``our most widely traveled first lady.'' With Nixon she visited five continents and 22 nations. ``When, in 1958, foreign mobs stoned the Nixon's car she was, an observer said, `stronger than any man.''' The president wound up his reference with these words: ``Mrs. Nixon, the Secret Service (code-named) you `Starlight.' Your husband has said it best; you fit that name to a T.'' At that point Nixon smiled and nodded.

DOC.HEAD: Most Farmers Would Back Changes in Law to Protect Environment: Poll
DOC.NOTE: For Release 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: A majority of farmers would support changes in federal law to help protect the nation's environment, a survey by a national conservation group said Thursday. Officials of the American Farmland Trust said the survey provided ``strong evidence that farmers are more supportive of environmentally sound farming practices than their Washington lobbyists admit.'' The survey results were released as the Senate began debate on the 1990 farm bill, a complex measure that will guide U.S. farm programs and policy for the next five years. In recent months, the AFT said, much of the debate about farm bill amendments has centered on alleged farmer resistance to changes in federal law to help clean up the environment, including reduced use of chemicals and fertilizers. According to the survey, more than 70 percent of about 1,000 farmers interviewed in 22 states were ``interested in participating in a federal cost-sharing program that would reduce contamination of water through the adoption of new farm management practices.'' Further, the AFT said, majorities of these farmers approve of pesticide and fertilizer use plans that would help farmers economize on the use of these materials. Ralph Grossi, president of AFT, a non-profit Washington-based membership organization, said he gave House and Senate agriculture committees high marks for their efforts to protect wetlands and set the right course on water quality planning and flexible cropland use. But he added, ``I give them very low marks on long-term soil protection, promotion of environmentally sustainable farming, and protection of farmland from urban encroachment.'' The survey and its analysis was conducted for AFT by a team at Northern Illinois University. It was based on about 1,000 interviews from a data base of 1,435, said spokesman David Dyer. The survey was said to have a margin error of approximately 5 percent. The data base was selected randomly from 42,860 producers of six major federally supported commodities _ corn, wheat, rice, cotton, peanuts and milk _ in 100 counties of 22 states. Dyer said the survey was designed to reflect national attitudes. It did not show state breakdowns. The states where the survey was conducted are Alabama, Arkansas, California, Georgia, Iowa, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Louisiana, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Montana, North Dakota, Nebraska, New York, Ohio, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Texas, Washington and Wisconsin.

DOC.HEAD: Smiley Face Pins Bring Complaints About Re-Election Bid
LaserPhoto BA2
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Griisser cq in penultimate graf
DOC.TEXT: Bright, yellow happy-face pins emblazoned with the governor's name are part of a public service campaign, officials say. But some state employees complain the buttons are for his re-election campaign. The lapel buttons, which also feature the slogan ``YES, WE CAN!,'' are part of a campaign organized by Gov. William Donald Schaefer's office to encourage Maryland's 70,000 state employees to offer the public service with a smile. Some state employees complained that they were being used in an election year. ``It certainly did appear that it was politically motivated,'' William Bolander, executive director of the state chapter of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said Thursday. Bolander said he was not blaming the Democratic governor, who may not have had anything to do with putting his name on the pins. Bolander said he also supports the campaign to improve service to the public. ``It's just the way you go about it,'' he said. ``You could get that message across without having the governor's name attached to everything.'' ``This has absolutely no political overtones whatsoever,'' Schaefer press secretary Paul Schurick said angrily. ``I am deeply insulted by anyone who questions the motives of a campaign to improve public service.'' Schaefer said he wasn't worried about the complaints because ``only the press'' is upset about the buttons. ``It's not a campaign gimmick'' but an attempt to make state employees better public servants, he said. ``Just putting a button on ... there's nothing wrong with that,'' Schaefer said. Schurick said having Schaefer's name on the button is in keeping with the policy he has followed for 19 years as mayor of Baltimore and governor. ``The governor has made a career out of Don Schaefer. He is well-known for high-profile campaigns of all kinds with his name attached,'' Schurick said. ``The governor cannot stop being governor just because it's an election year,'' he said. Most of the complaints came from employees of the Department of General Services, who were told in a July 6 memo: ``All DGS employees are to wear their `YES WE CAN' buttons during working hours.'' Robert B. Silver, who wrote the memo, said it was a request, not an order. ``If they choose not to wear the buttons, there is no disciplinary action that's going to be taken,'' he said. William Seth Shepard, who is seeking the Republican nomination for governor, said incumbents such as Schaefer should show ``self-restraint'' in putting their names on billboards, buttons and other paraphernalia purportedly promoting the state. Fred Griisser, a real estate agent and gun control foe trying to upset Schaefer in the Democratic primary, said it was ``inappropriate'' for state workers to be told to wear the buttons. ``It obviously looks like they are expected to promote him for the office,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Group Says Voters Willing to Pay for Better Child Health Care
DOC.TEXT: Most American voters are willing to pay higher taxes to fund better child health care programs, according to a study released Thursday by a children's advocacy group. The report was released by the National Association of Children's Hospitals and Related Institutions as part of its campaign to make children a major issue in the 1990 elections. ``The American people are profoundly interested in their kids and the kids of this country,'' said Robert Sweeney, president of the group. The study, ``Kids' Clout: Americans' Attitudes on Children's Issues,'' indicated that 59 percent of those polled are willing to have their taxes raised the estimated $100 annually it would take to guarantee health care for all uninsured children. Two-thirds of the people asked said they would be more likely to vote for candidates who favor increased spending for children's health care programs, even if it meant a tax hike. Among occasional voters, 85 percent said they would be more likely to vote if they thought it would have a significant impact on the health and welfare of American children, according to the study. The study is the result of a June 9-17 telephone survey of 1,000 adult Americans conducted by Washington-based Penn & Schoen. The poll's margin of error is plus or minus 3.1 percent. Association officials are using the study's findings to provide voters with information about the status of children's health. The group also is urging voters to press candidates to bring children's health care issues onto their platforms. ``For too long, children have been seen and not heard at election time when we decide this nation's future course,'' said Jon Vice, chairman and president of Children's Hospital in Wisconsin. The campaign, ``I care for kids _ and I vote,'' aims to increase funds allocated to health care programs for children, such as Medicaid, by having the American public push the issue among candidates. The association's campaign includes bumper stickers, buttons, booklets and handbooks, and a telephone hotline. The association of children's hospital, a non-profit group founded in 1968, promotes the well-being of children through advocacy, research and education.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Insist on Purge of Salvadoran Military ^By DOUGLAS GRANT MINE ^Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Despite El Salvador's intention to prod peace talks past the sticky subject of an armed forces' overhaul, leftist rebels say they will insist on a purge of officers they allege are responsible for human rights abuses. The two sides meet Friday in Costa Rica for a third round of U.N.-mediated peace talks that began in Venezuela in May. Guerrilla leaders say they are preparing a major offensive, perhaps on the scale of November's push, if the new talks make no progress. The Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, or FMLN, has fought U.S.-backed governments since 1979. The war has killed an estimated 72,000 people. ``There is a sector of the armed forces that must pay the bill for so much oppression imposed on the country,'' guerrilla commander Schafik Handal, the chief rebel negotiator, said in an interview with The Associated Press at the rebels' Mexico City office. Handal rejected the government's call to a cease-fire while negotiations proceed. ``First, there must be agreements on how to demilitarize Salvadoran society. If we halt military pressure, recalcitrant elements would feel free to embark on a bloodbath like that of the early 1980s,'' he said. During those years, troops and military-linked death squads summarily executed about 30,000 suspected leftists, according to international rights groups. No officer has been convicted or tried for such a crime. The U.S. Congress, which has financed the government war effort, intends to reduce and condition military aid for the 1991 financial year, which begins in October. Draft legislation makes disbursement of some funds dependent on progress in peace talks and on successful prosecution of the army men responsible for November's massacre of six Jesuit priest-educators. Some legislators echoed the guerrillas' demand for a purge. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., said this week about 50 upper-echelon officers should be removed. He predicted that the war would go on for years in the absence of drastic military reform. ``Fifty seems to us a low number,'' said Handal. Major guerrilla leaders have mentioned the figure 200 when estimating how many officers should be purged. ``We do not reject the idea of purifying our institution. The armed forces, like any other insitution is subject to evolution, to improvement,'' said Gen. Humberto Larios, the defense minister, in a recent interview. But he insisted the military must do the weeding-out. ``We are purifying ourselves,'' he said. Handal replied, ``If Larios maintains that the army is being constantly `purified' and nevertheless it continues to play the role of repressor, then it's obvious that `purification' is not enough to clean it up. It should be abolished flat-out, which is our conclusion.'' The FMLN proposes that accords on gradual ``demilitarization,'' which would include its own disappearance as a fighting force, conclude with abolishment of the armed forces. The rebels point to Costa Rica, which abolished its army in 1949 and is the only Central American nation to enjoy in recent decades a stable and functioning democracy. A civilian-led police force would ensure law and order in a demilitarized El Salvador, according to the FMLN proposal. Larios and other military chiefs bristle at idea of their institution disappearing. ``The continued existence of the armed forces is not a subject of discussion,'' President Alfredo Cristiani said after last month's five-day round of talks in Mexico. That session dealt almost exclusively with the military, and produced no argeement. The agenda worked out in Venezuela also includes rights; judicial, electoral and constitutional reform; and means of international verification of compliance with eventual accords. Cristiani says prospects for agreement on those points are good. The guerrillas say accords on other issues would be moot in the absence of agreement on military overhaul.

DOC.HEAD: Police Charge Arts Patron With Insurance Scam
DOC.TEXT: A man known as an arts patron and philanthropist was arrested at his estate in the Philadelphia suburbs and charged in a $15 million insurance scam. Richard Scholl, 36, who recently founded the Philadelphia Philanthropic Opera Company, was charged Wednesday with grand larceny by detectives from the Manhattan District Attorney's Office in New York. Also arrested was Roy Hatch, 42, who lived with Scholl. A third man, Salvatore DiTrapani, 43, was arrested at his home in Hazlet, N.J. New York City District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau issued a statement saying the three men pocketed liability insurance premiums for several major New York law and accounting firms starting in 1986. Officers also executed search warrants at local banks where they believed Scholl rented safe deposit boxes, according to Thomas Jackson, supervising investigator for the Morgenthau's office. Jackson, one of the arresting officers, said Scholl's 20-room house, purchased in 1986 for $680,000, was filled with antique furniture and artwork. Detectives went through the 11-bedroom mansion, videotaping every room to make an inventory of Scholl's possessions. Outside, tents still stood on the grounds from a fund-raiser Scholl reportedly held Sunday for a local hospital. Scholl was an accomplished tenor and most of his society contacts involved music. He performed in May at the annual ``champagne and strings'' benefit for the Academy of Children's Music in Fort Washington, Pa. The grand larceny complaint alleged the three men used the money they took from the premiums to buy ``homes, securities, automobiles, paintings, rare books, antiques and other items.'' Hatch's attorney, Glen A. Zeitz, described the case in court as a dispute over commissions. The two defendants, led into the courtroom in handcuffs, wouldn't speak with reporters. According to the district attorney's statement, several companies sought insurance through Minet International, which is based in Montreal and the United Kingdom. Minet put together a group of insurance underwriters, including American International Underwriters, where Scholl worked from 1986 to 1988, and Transatlantic Reinsurance Co., where DiTrapani worked. Scholl and DiTrapani allegedly instructed Minet to pay premiums to an intermediary, the International Reinsurance Brokerage Operation, which was controlled by Hatch. Scholl and DiTrapani wrote policies for the coverage but never filed them with their companies, according to Morgenthau. Instead, they split up the premiums with Hatch. Scholl and Hatch were arraigned Wednesday before Judge Benjamin Crahalla in Lower Providence Township. Each was ordered held in Montgomery County Prison in lieu of $5 million bail on a fugitive from justice charge.

DOC.HEAD: 46 States Form Coalitions to Urge Control in Tobacco Use
DOC.TEXT: Only four states in the nation do not have grass-roots organizations opposed to smoking, and three of those states are linked to the nasty habit through the tobacco industry, the government reported Thursday. Hawaii, Kentucky, Mississippi and South Carolina are the only states without such anti-smoking groups, said the report by the federal Centers for Disease Control. Kentucky and South Carolina are leading tobacco producers, noted Tom Novotny of the CDC's Office on Smoking and Health. Mississippi also grows a small amount of tobacco. The CDC's annual Behavioral Risk Factor Survey earlier this month showed Kentucky to be the state with the highest number of smokers. Thirty-four percent of the adult respondents to the study in Kentucky said they were smokers. ``The tobacco issue is something else in Kentucky,'' said Phyllis Skonicki, manager of the Health Promotion Branch for the Kentucky Department of Health Services. ``We're one of the largest growing states in the nation. ... From the smallest farm to the largest, you're going to find some tobacco.'' In the United States, 29 percent of the adults age 18 and older smoke, according to the CDC's latest statistics. The anti-smoking coalitions are made up of community volunteers, sometimes aided by public health workers. Their growing number represents ``an increasing level of concern in the government and among people not strictly in the health field,'' said Novotny, who prepared the report. ``It just shows a strong sort of grassroots, institutionalized effort to take on the problem of tobacco use,'' he said. ``There's been a general shift in the social attitude. Smoking no longer is seen as socially acceptable. It's continually identified as the major cause of preventable death in this country.'' A total of 390,000 people in the United States died from smoking-related illnesses in 1985, the last year for which statistics are available, Novotny said. ``It will undoubtedly be more than that when the figures are updated. We know lung cancer has increased since then.'' Restrictions on smoking in public places have grown with concern about the health hazards involved with smoking, he said. Colorado established the first grass-roots anti-smoking coalition in 1963, the CDC said. Most of the other states formed coalitions after 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Study Sees Shortage Of `Gold Collar' Workers
DOC.TEXT: Most American employers are worried about a shortage of skilled workers, but few have made job training for new employees a priority, according to a study delivered to Congress Thursday. A majority of 645 employers who were surveyed said they thought there was already a labor shortage in America or one on the way, according to a study called ``Workforce 2000, ``Competing in a Sellers Market: Is Corporate America Prepared?'' Employers are specifically concerned about a potential shortfall of so-called ``knowledge workers'' who are professionals or have technical skills, said the study, conducted by Towers Perrin, a management consultant firm. Those ``knowledge'' workers are also sometimes called ``gold collar'' employees because demand for them is expected to be so great that they will be able to name their own salaries and the conditions of their employment, the study said. Those workers include people in such fields as electronics, computers and communications who have technical skills. ``Whether or not knowledge workers will have such bargaining power, our survey companies are clearly worried about hiring these important employees, especially over the next five years,'' the study said. However, the study said most companies are still using traditional solutions for recruitment or helping employees learn and improve skills, rather than trying novel approaches. For instance, 78 percent of the firms use the traditional process of reimbursing employees for the costs of tuition, while just 8 percent have their own remedial training program, the study said. The most common reason for rejecting potential job candidates was inadequate writing or verbal skills, the study said, but few firms had made training a priority. Two-thirds of the firms surveyed spent less than $2,000 a year on training for entry-level hires and many companies spend nothing at all, the study said. About half of the survey respondents reported hiring more than 150 entry-level workers a year. Of those new hires, about 28 percent end up quitting or being fired within their first year, usually because of an unacceptable job performance, the study said. ``The high cost of turnover notwithstanding, most companies do not appear to be devoting significant financial resources to training,'' said the study. About 5 percent of the employers spent more than $5,000 annually in classroom and on-the-job training for new employees in their first year. The study was delivered at a Senate Labor task force hearing on the workforce and workplace readiness. Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., who chairs the task force, said the study ``reveals that most companies run their businesses like we were still in the 1950s.''

DOC.HEAD: Italian Man Comes Out of Coma After Nearly Three Years
DOC.TEXT: Uttering ``mama,'' a 25-year-old man came out of a nearly three-year-long coma and is now moving his limbs and speaking, Italian media reported Thursday. The man, Marcello Manunza, came out of the coma on Monday in a hospital near Genoa, responding to tickling and encouragement from his family, the reports said. ``For a few days we had realized that my son seemed to respond to external stimuli,'' his mother Giuseppina told the Italian news agency ANSA on Thursday. ``He followed my movements with his eyes, he seemed to recognize my voice. He stared for a long time at signs we had hung near his bed, where we all had written brief phrases of encouragement. You could see he was trying to force his eyes to read, even to the point of their reddening.'' The man had undergone special physiotherapy under the direction of a Philadelphia professor, Glen Doman, the reports said. The man had been placed on a board at a 45-degree angle to help him move, and had been given frequent massages, the reports said. Manunza, who went into a coma after a November 1987 car accident, can now eat and understand what is said to him, according to the reports.

DOC.HEAD: Spy Suspect Tries To Quit Foreign Service
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf pvs, ``The department'' to CORRECT Boucher to Bloch
DOC.TEXT: Felix Bloch, target of a U.S. spy investigation, wants to quit the Foreign Service, but the State Department is trying to decide whether to fire him instead, a spokesman said Thursday. Bloch, 55, lost his job in the European Affairs bureau in February and his $80,000-a-year pay stopped with his suspension. In the meantime, the Justice Department looked into suspicions Bloch gave sensitive information to the Soviet Union and had been paid by Moscow. However, law enforcement sources have said the FBI was unable to prove that Bloch passed along specific classified information, which is necessary to prove espionage. A grand jury, meanwhile, had examined his finances in an attempt to trace any Soviet payments. If Bloch is fired, he will be branded a violator of U.S. national security. Spokesman Richard Boucher, confirming an account in The Washington Times, said Bloch submitted his resignation on July 5 and also withdrew a request for a hearing on the State Department's attempt to fire him. ``The department has informed Mr. Bloch that it will continue with the proceedings initiated last February to remove him from the Foreign Service for national security reasons,'' Boucher said. ``The department will take no action on Mr. Bloch's tendered resignation pending the outcome of these proceedings.'' lthough Bloch was the subject of FBI surveillance for months, he was never arrested or charged with a crime. As a senior Foreign Service officer he would be eligible on retirement to receive up to 70 percent of his salary, or about $56,000 a year. Bloch had served in East Germany and Austria beginning in the early 1970s. His most recent assignment dealt with economic policy in the European Affairs bureau in Washington. The State Department had prepared evidence and witnesses for a hearing scheduled for July 9 at Bloch's request. Now that his lawyers have withdrawn the request, the next step is for Secretary of State James A. Baker III to review the record against Bloch and decide whether to fire him on security grounds, Boucher said. There will be no action on the retirement request in the meantime, the spokesman said. It was no clear whether Bloch would lose his pension if he is fired.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Prosecutors Accuse Leadoff Defense Witness of Using Drugs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with 2nd guard's testimony, inserting 4 grafs after 20th graf, When she; testimony over for the day
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors accused one of Marion Barry's security guards of using cocaine Thursday, interrupting the guard's testimony as the leadoff defense witness in the mayor's drug and perjury trial. Prosecutors also suggested that the guard, Washington police officer James Stays, had told another policeman the name of a Barry drug supplier. Stays denied he had made such a statement, then the jury was sent out of the room before prosecutors made the drug-use allegation in remarks to U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson. Jackson, rejecting defense objections, ruled that Stays could be questioned about using cocaine but suspended proceedings to allow him to consult with a lawyer. After a lunch recess, Stays twice denied using drugs when Retchin asked about the subject. On further questioning from Barry attorney Robert Mance, Stays also denied talking to the other officer about a drug supplier. Outside the courtroom, Barry accused the prosecution of ``satanic dirt-like tactics.'' The surprise developments came as Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin began cross-examining Stays, a member of the elite 24-member security detail that accompanies Barry to all his public and private functions. All members are police officers. The jury heard only this exchange on the subject: Retchin: ``Did you tell Detective Goodwine (another security officer) that Willie Davis supplied Mr. Barry with cocaine?'' Stays: ``Me? No.'' After jurors were sent out of the courtroom, Retchin told the judge, ``The government has evidence that this witness has used cocaine.'' The issue came up after Stays testified he knew Willie Davis, a man whom government witnesses have testified used cocaine with Barry. Davis, a former aide to Birmingham, Ala., Mayor Richard Arrington, has not been called to testify in the case. After a 30-minute recess, Jackson ruled, over the protests of Barry attorney R. Kenneth Mundy, that Retchin could pursue her line of questioning. ``I deem Miss Retchin's cross-examination of Mr. Stays to be related to the credibility of the witness,'' Jackson said. ``The defense has asked prosecution witnesses, at great length, about their prior drug use.'' Mundy argued that Stays had no knowledge of Barry drug use and had not told other security officers the name of anyone supplying drugs to the mayor. Stays at one point had demanded to take a urinalysis test to determine whether he used drugs when asked about it by other police detectives working on Barry's case, the mayor's attorney said. ``He is anxious to come in here and answer ... and lay any rumors to rest,'' Mundy said. ``Officers from the Internal Affairs Division have informed me he (Stays) was not willing to take a urinalysis,'' Retchin retorted. ``There has been testimony under oath before the grand jury of Mr. Stays' own drug use.'' When she resumed her questioning of Stays, Retchin asked whether he had used drugs at a private home in Kettering, Md., or in a suite at a Washington hotel where Barry and others were present. Stays answered no to each query. Defense lawyer Mance said outside court that Barry had told him he had never used drugs with any defense witnesses. Later, officer Warren Goodwine, a former member of Barry's security force, said under cross-examination that he told police investigators he ``tried to stay out of Mr. Barry's activities as much as possible.'' Under further questioning from Mance, Goodwine said he had not meant to suggest he suspected that the mayor used drugs. ``If I said that ... I felt the mayor was entitled to some privacy,'' Goodwine testified. He was not asked about the question concerning what Stays might have told him about a Barry drug supplier. Earlier Thursday, Stays had contradicted minor points in the testimony of a key government witness. Stays, a 29-year police veteran, said that he never babysat the children of Rasheeda Moore and never delivered money to her. Moore, the government's star witness, had testified that Stays looked after her children on one occasion while she and the mayor used drugs. She also told the court that Stays had delivered to her a package from the mayor that contained money for drugs. Before the defense began making its case Thursday, Jackson denied motions to acquit Barry of four of the 14 charges against him. On Wednesday, he rejected a similar effort with regard to the other 10 counts the mayor faces. Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy count, and three felony charges of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Recommend Against Approving AIDS Home Test Kit
DOC.TEXT: A panel of experts recommended the Food and Drug Administration turn down an application to market the nation's first home blood-collection kit for AIDS antibody testing. The FDA's Blood Products Advisory Committee on Wednesday voted 3-1 against approval of the proposal by University Hospital Laboratories Corp. of Bethesda, Md. With the company's test kit, an individual would use a lancet to draw a small sample of blood, which would be collected on special filter paper, and send the sample anonymously to a laboratory where it would be tested. The individual would receive the results by telephone. Panel members echoed the FDA's concerns about the safety of people drawing their own blood and the validity of tests obtained through this system, said Dr. Jay S. Epstein, chief of the retrovirology laboratory in FDA's Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research. The experts also were concerned about the adequacy of telephone counseling for individuals who test positive for antibodies to the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome, he said. The FDA is also concerned whether anonymous AIDS-related testing is in the public interest, since public health workers would be unable to follow up on counseling for individuals who tested positive. Epstein said on Thursday the FDA would complete its review of University Hospital Laboratories' application by Aug. 8. The FDA began accepting applications for AIDS home test kits last spring after officials said they would reconsider their opposition to home blood-collection kits for AIDS-related testing. University Hospital Laboratories' application was the first received, Epstein said, but he could not say how many others, if any, have been received since then. At the time, Dr. Paul Parkman, director of the Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research, said officials were persuaded to rethink their opposition because of medical advances in treatment that could slow progression of the disease in its early stages. Other considerations included technical advances that, for example, have shown accurate test results could be obtained using a blood sample prepared and transported on a filter paper. University Hospital Laboratories had filed a lawsuit seeking to force the FDA to accept its application, which had been filed in December 1987. The lawsuit was settled April 10, but FDA officials said the lawsuit had no effect on its decision to begin accepting applications. Epstein said the advisory committee's recommendation affected only University Health Laboratories' application.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Defends Surprise Inspections of Radio, TV Stations
DOC.TEXT:
Federal regulators Thursday defended their first surprise inspections of 30 radio and television stations to check compliance with political advertising and equal opportunity rules. The Federal Communications Commission inspections, carried out Monday and Tuesday in five cities, kicked off an auditing process that is expected to be completed before the fall congressional elections. FCC Chairman Alfred Sikes said Thursday the inspections were necessary in light of reductions in permanent FCC monitoring stations and did not reflect a belief that violations of political programming rules w Sikes, in a meeting with reporters, said the audits will determine how well stations are complying and ``lead to more voluntary compliance.'' The inspections were carried out in Cincinnati; Dallasere widespread.-Fort Worth; Philadelphia; Portland, Ore., and San Francisco. The FCC said the stations were chosen because of their diverse locations and because they serve large areas. Milton Gross, chief of the FCC's political branch, acknowledged that this was the first such FCC audit of broadcasters. ``Heretofore, we generally operated on a complaint basis,'' Gross said in an interview. The commission in April fined an Indianapolis television station, WXIN, $10,000 fy belligerent Iraq, a Kuwaiti source said. This was seen as an indication that the crisis was resolved. Slug AM-Kuwait-Iraq. Sent as a0686. By Nabila Megalli.
With AM-Iraq-Saddam from NICOSIA: Iraq's Parliament has proposed that President Saddam Hussein be president for life, the official Iraqi News Agency said Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: WHAT'S A MOTHER TO DO? Mrs. Gorbachev Never Gets To See Her Son
DOC.TEXT: MOSCOW _ Mikhail S. Gorbachev's 79-year-old mother only recently got a new color television to replace her old black-and-white set, still bakes her own bread and complains her son never visits. Slug AM-Gorbachev's Mother. Sent as a0575. By Brian Friedman.

DOC.HEAD: Bills Seek to Shift S&L Burden From Middle Class, Northeast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS figure in 3rd graf, $100 billion sted million
DOC.TEXT: Wealthy Americans and Texans would bear a greater burden of the savings and loan bailout under separate bills filed in Congress Thursday. Rep. Joseph P. Kennedy II, D-Mass., backed by consumer advocate Ralph Nader, argued that wealthy investors used federal protection for up to $100,000 in deposits to reap substantial interest income. Now that scores of S&Ls have gone under, poor and middle class taxpayers are unfairly being asked to pay, he said. Kennedy proposed legislation that would raise $100 billion in bailout costs over five years by imposing three new taxes: a 7.5 percent surtax on interest, dividends and capital gains for individuals reporting income more than $100,000 per year; a 5 percent surtax on corporations earning more than $75,000 per year; and elimination of an inheritance tax provision that forgives taxes on appreciated capital gains at death. ``The bailout represents nothing less than the single largest transfer of wealth from the working class to the wealthy in the history of America,'' Kennedy said at a Capitol Hill news conference. ``The working people of America must not be made to pay for a party that they were not invited to.'' The Northeast-Midwest Congressional Coalition proposed legislation that would shift the burden of the bailout geographically rather than based on income. The coalition bill would remove federal deposit insurance benefits from state-regulated S&Ls or require state taxpayers to bear a heftier share of the bailout. In some instances, backers say, deregulation at the state level led to lending and investment abuses at S&Ls. If states caused the problem, the coalition argues, federal taxpayers shouldn't be forced to pay all of the bailout. As it currently stands, the bill would only affect Texas, according to Keith Laughlin, who drafted the bill. Of the $57 billion in bailout costs to date, $20.9 billion is attributable to state-chartered banks in Texas. If all the S&Ls in question seek to retain federal deposit insurance, the state would pay an extra $2.8 billion toward the bailout.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll in Kirghizia Rises to 212
DOC.TEXT: New fighting between ethnic Kirghiz and Uzbeks in Soviet Central Asia has increased the death toll to 212, and incidents of ``sadistic cruelty'' have taken place, state media reported Thursday. The newspaper Rabochaya Tribuna said about 1,200 people have been hospitalized from violence since early June. On Wednesday, 204 people had been reported killed in the fighting, which broke out June 4 in western Kirghizia in a land dispute between the ethnic groups, both largely Sunni Moslems who speak Turkish dialects. Tass said Thursday, ``Reports are still coming in of fights, arson and pogroms. Passing cars are being stoned. Barricades are being built.'' Tensions had eased during 40 days of mourning for those killed in the June fighting, but violence flared again this week when that period ended. Most of the fighting has raged in Osh. This week's violence shut down industrial enterprises and snarled public transport, Interfax news service said. In nearby Uzgen, which is predominantly Uzbek, residents demand that Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov go to the region, it said. Soviet authorities bolstered security troops in the region by sending Col. Gen. Yuri Shatalin, commander of Interior Ministry troops, there, Tass said. The unrest has caused an estimated $68 million in damage and left more than 400 people missing and possibly dead, Rabochaya Tribuna said. Earlier, Soviet media had reported 800 people were missing in the area. The newspaper said security police have been informed of 65 to 80 burials that have yet to be investigated. It said there have been cases of ``sadistic cruelty,'' but gave no specifics. Of the 212 dead, at least 132 are Uzbeks and 47 are Kirghiz, the paper said. It did not give the nationalities of the other victims. In reporting on causes of the bloodshed, Rabochaya Tribuna said unemployment has tripled in the region the past five years, reaching 47,000 by the time violence broke out. Many of the jobless are youths who no longer want to live in rural areas and have flooded cities and towns looking for housing, it said. The newspaper also blamed the unrest on calls among ethnic groups that the indigenous population should prevail in urban areas. It said the Osh border region is made up of 60 nationalities. About 60 percent of the population of the region is Kirghiz and 25 percent is Uzbek, the newspaper added. Although Uzbeks make up nearly half the population of Osh, no Uzbeks are among its municipal and Communist Party leaders, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Army Having Trouble Drafting Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: A new Lithuanian law conscripting young men into the service of the secessionist republic rather than the national army further clouds an already gloomy draft outlook for the Soviet armed forces. The Lithuanian law, passed Wednesday, does not create a separate army. It requires instead a year of mandatory civic service or military training for men aged 19 to 26, said Simas Ardziunas, a representative of the parliament's information bureau. Results of the annual spring draft for the Soviet armed forces read like a barometer of regional dissent. About half or fewer conscripts reported for duty in the secessionist Baltic republics and the troubled southern republics of Georgia and Armenia had even lower rates. Only 33.6 percent of draft-age Lithuanian men reported as required this year for the Red Army, compared to 91.6 percent last year, the Soviet army newspaper Red Star reported last week. The rates in Latvia were 90.7 percent last year and 54.2 percent this year, and Estonia, 79.5 percent last year and 40.2 percent this year. The worst rate was in Armenia, 7.5 percent, influenced by a law passed by the republic requiring young men to remain there to continue repair work from the December 1988 earthquake. Red Star quoted Lt. Gen. N. Ter-Grigoryants as complaining about laws passed by republics restricting military service outside their borders. He said 6,500 young men did not report for service last year. Numbers for this year are not yet known, he said. The article did not disclose the total number of draftees. An armed forces spokesman said all inquiries should be directed by letter through the Ministry of Foreign Affars. The Soviet armed forces contain about 5.1 million people, according to the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London. The Kremlin had no immediate reaction to the new Lithuanian law, passed by the republic's Supreme Council parliament on a 68-16 vote, with 22 abstentions. Ardziunas said the legislation would not go into effect until the government issues a directive on details of service. No barracks or camps yet exist for the force, and the law ``says nothing about any weapons,'' he said. Youths in the force would be available for border service and in case of natural disasters, he said. Thousands of Soviet troops remain in Lithuania, although the republic declared its independence from the Soviet Union on March 11. Lithuania then became embroiled in a dispute with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and he imposed an economic embargo to force it into line. On June 29, the Lithuanian Supreme Council approved a moratorium on the declaration, to take effect when talks with Soviet officials begin on independence. Soviet officials immediately began lifting the embargo.

DOC.HEAD: New Allegations in Lawsuit Against Montana GOP, National Republican Committee
DOC.TEXT: The former executive director of the Montana Republican Party has accused the organization, its chairwoman and a national GOP committee of breaking federal racketeering laws. The allegations involved the handling of political money during the 1988 campaigns. Terry Merica made the allegations in a complaint filed in U.S. District Court on Wednesday. It amends a lawsuit he and his wife, Neida, filed in December. The complaint alleges that the state GOP, Chairwoman Barbara Campbell and the National Republican Senatorial Committee committed wire and mail fraud by illegally funneling money into the campaigns of Sen. Conrad Burns and Gov. Stan Stephens. Burns, at the time a county commissioner in Billings, upset Democratic incumbent Sen. John Melcher in the November election. Stephens defeated former Democratic Gov. Tom Judge in the race for governor. The complaint says the defendants used a series of letters and money transfers in the spring and summer of 1988 to defraud the citizens of Montana and the United States. The original lawsuit alleged the Mericas were fired in late 1988 for questioning whether financial dealings between the state Republican Party and the national committee violated state and federal election laws. Neida Merica was an administrative secretary for the state GOP. Wednesday's complaint contends there were additional violations of the federal Racketeer Influenced, Corrupt Organizations Act. Charles Erdmann, attorney for the Montana GOP, said the new contentions may reflect Merica's concern that the original suit will be dismissed. ``This may be nothing more than an attempt to bolster their complaint,'' he said. He would not comment on specifics, saying he had not seen the new complaint, but he questioned the timing of its filing. The state GOP convention began Thursday in Billings, with President Bush scheduled to appear in the evening on behalf of Lt. Gov. Allen Kolstad, who is challenging Democratic incumbent Sen. Max Baucus. ``The timing of this would make you think this is politically motivated,'' Campbell said Thursday. James Goetz, the Mericas' attorney, said the timing was coincidence. The National Republican Senatorial Committee, which helps organize campaigns of GOP Senate candidates, had no immediate comment on the new allegations. The complaint alleges the defendants committed mail and wire fraud by not legally reporting as much as $200,000 in campaign contributions in 1988. It cites several instances of questionable handling of campaign financing. It alleges that: _The national committee conducted a voter identification project in Montana, but gave results only to the Burns and Stephens campaigns. The cost of the project was never reported as a contribution to the campaigns and the expense exceeded the federal limit on what such committees can give to a candidate. _The national committee transferred thousands of dollars through the Montana GOP's accounts to help pay for a direct mailing by a Texas company for the Burns campaign in violation of federal election laws. _Between Aug. 8, 1988, and Nov. 16, 1988, the national committee shifted $178,145 into the Montana GOP's account. The money transfers prompted a Nov. 8 memo from Ward Shanahan, the state party's lawyer, to GOP headquarters warning that the national committee was using the Montana Republican Party for ``financial shenanigans.'' _In October 1988, the Republican Governors' Association gave $8,000 to the Montana GOP with a letter from Executive Director Michele Davis saying the money should be reported as coming from the Republican National Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Immigration Contributes to Measles Outbreak in United States
DOC.TEXT: A measles epidemic in Washington state was spread in large part by unvaccinated immigrants who brought the virus from Mexico, federal health officials said Thursday. At least 26 percent of the 266 measles cases reported in Washington state so far this year were acquired in Mexico or were linked to cases acquired there, the Centers for Disease Control said in its weekly report. Last year, 15 percent of all cases reported in the state were linked to Mexico, it said. Nationwide, 3 percent of the 17,850 measles cases reported last year were acquired outside the United States, it said. Across the country, measles continue to be spread in medical settings, especially hospital emergency rooms, because cases often are not diagnosed and isolated promptly and because many medical workers are not immune, the CDC said. In the first 26 weeks of 1990, nearly five times more cases were diagnosed in Washington than during all of 1989, when 55 measles cases were reported, state health officials said. The outbreak is the largest since 1979. Nearly half of the cases occurred among unvaccinated people, the CDC said. Of those unvaccinated, more than half were Hispanics, who account for 4 percent of the state's population of 4.5 million and are its largest ethnic minority. The state's Hispanic population increased by about 39 percent from 1980 to 1988, the CDC said. Detailed data available for 218 of the 266 cases showed that 97 of them were Hispanics, the CDC said. Of those 97 cases, Mexican citizens working in Washington accounted for 72 percent and Hispanic U.S. citizens made up 28 percent. The state Department of Health spent $1.1 million for 76,000 doses of measles vaccine this spring, said Barbara Baker, Washington's immunization director. Vaccination clinics were publicized in Spanish and English on radio and television, in newspapers and by sound trucks in Hispanic neighborhoods, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Boy's Ensemble Swelters Through U.S. Singing Debut
DOC.TEXT: Singing in sauna-like conditions, the Leningrad Boys' Choir made its American debut Thursday, at the Capitol Children's Museum. The young men, dressed in heavy black suits and bow ties, sang Soviet folk songs, classics and sacred songs for an audience of about 150 people. The singers also were introduced to Washington's muggy summer weather, performing in 90-degree heat in a room without air conditioning. ``In Leningrad it is much cooler,'' 12-year-old Eugene Meehaiev said through a translator. ``But it really doesn't matter because I put all my feelings in to my song. That's all I think about.'' Audience members enthusiastically applauded each selection _ especially after young soloists, nudged on by conductor Vladimir Stolpovsky, took their bows. The choir's trip to the United States is sponsored by the Greater Philadelphia-Leningrad Partnership, said Eric Schippers, public liaison at the United States Information Agency. Philadelphia had sent a boys' choir to Leningrad and the two choirs will sing together for the first time in Philadelphia. ``If there are two things that'll unite the world, it's young people and music,'' said museum director Anne Lewin. The 37 choir members, ranging from ages eight to 17, arrived in the United States on Tuesday, said museum spokeswoman Mary Abbajay. The youths attended a cookout and swimming party at the home of Esther Coopersmith, a trustee of the Children's Museum. In addition to seeing other Washington sights, the group toured the White House Thursday and gave an impromptu performance afterward, Schippers said. ``They were so excited they burst into song on the White House lawn,'' Mrs. Coopersmith said. Choir member Eugene Vishnevsky, who doesn't know much English besides ``How do you do?'' said of the United States: ``The people here are very kind and very hospitable.'' ``I'd like very much to meet more American children,'' the 12-year-old said through a translator. Another choir member said the best thing about the United States is ``the sun-shining people.'' ``The people are more happy,'' Nicolay Kruglov, 17, said. ``It's more free here, I think.'' The choir, the oldest musical establishment in the Soviet Union, was founded in 1479 by Ivan III, and began touring across the Soviet Union and Europe in the 1930s. The boys attend Leningrad's M.I. Glinka Choir School.

DOC.HEAD: US Says Salvadoran Left Should End Violence
DOC.TEXT: The State Department accused leftist rebels in El Salvador on Thursday of engaging in a campaign of violence and said they should change tactics in the interests of reaching a peace settlement. Deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said the insurgents have carried out a series of ``brutal assassinations'' directed at Salvadoran military personnel and their families. ``The purpose of this violence seems to be to polarize the situation further and to elicit a reaction from extremists on the right,'' Boucher said. As examples, Boucher cited the recent murders of a Salvadoran off-duty officer and of an Army major who was on his way to law school. He said the rebels also are preparing for a military offensive. He added that ongoing peace talks with the government can only succeed if both parties negotiate seriously and honestly. With talks set to resume Friday in Costa Rica, Boucher said the insurgents ``should put aside its tractics of assassination and violence and go to the table committed to a just peace.''

DOC.HEAD: Four Presidents Join in Historic Dedication of Nixon Library
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Never before...' to clarify four presidents were together once in the White House
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos ANS2,4; LaserColor
DOC.TEXT: Richard Nixon, a political outcast no more, basked Thursday in the praise of three other men who held America's highest office during a ceremony where the word Watergate was mentioned only once. That mention, almost in passing, came from George Bush. The president, and former presidents Gerald Ford and Ronald Reagan, along with their wives, joined to give the new Nixon Library and Birthplace a festive send-off. It was an occasion as red, white and blue as the thousands of balloons that were released at the end of the 2{-hour ceremony. Never before have four presidents of the United States shared the same speaking platform, although Nixon, Ford and Jimmy Carter were together at a reception given in the White House by Reagan before the three flew to Egyptian President Anwar Sadat's funeral in 1981. Bush said that visitors for years to come will learn of Nixon's six crises _ the title of his first book _ ``and the seventh crisis, Watergate.'' None of the other speakers mentioned the scandal that drove Nixon from office in 1974. For Nixon, it was a major milestone in his relentless drive for acceptance. The man who was elected with the most votes in history had been shunned by fellow Republicans at their national conventions and only in recent years has been invited to their functions. ``This is a very special day for all of us,'' he told a crowd of more than 10,000. ``Nothing we have ever seen matches this moment, to be welcomed so warmly.'' Bush led the tributes to the 37th president. ``To occupy this office is to feel a kinship with these and other presidents,'' he said. ``Each of whom, in his own way, sought to do right and thus achieve good. ... Each wondered, I suspect, how they could be worthy of God, and man.'' Bush, who as chairman of the Republican Party in 1974 urged Nixon to resign, urged visitors to the $21 million library to ``look at Richard Nixon the man.'' Nixon, said Bush, ``was the quintessence of Middle America'' who touched a cord with millions of citizens. ``He loved America's good, quiet, decent people; he spoke for them; he felt, deeply, on their behalf.'' Ford, who served out Nixon's term, began his speech with ``Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. President. If I overlooked a president, will he please stand up.'' He told Nixon, ``This day is a celebration richly deserved by you and by Pat.'' Reagan said, ``the world is a better place, a safer place, because of Richard Nixon.'' The library, adjacent to the 900-foot-square house where Nixon was born 77 years ago, tells the story of Nixon's life, from his boyhood through the political offices he held _ congressman, senator, vice president and president. The exhibits also include a treatment of Watergate, the scandal that was Nixon's undoing. The audience in 90-degree heat outdoors was said by library spokesman Fred Gorell to number 40,000. Police, however, estimated the crowd at 10,000-plus. Most of the crowd was on the suburban streets surrounding the spacious library grounds 25 miles southeast of downtown Los Angeles. Within the building, there were 2,400 seats for invited visitors and bleacher space for 1,400. Many stalwarts from the Nixon administration showed up. Former Secretaries of State Henry Kissinger and William Rogers were in the audience, as was Alexander Haig, Nixon's chief of staff in the final year, and William Simon, Nixon's secretary of the treasury. Some protesters showed up and two were ejected. Outside on Yorba Linda Boulevard, people waved signs saying ``He's still Tricky Dick,'' and ``Richard Repent.'' Evangelist Billy Graham, an old Nixon friend and frequent guest in the Nixon White House, spoke in his opening prayer of ``the upheavals and uncertainties through which the world passed'' during the Nixon era. Simon, chairman of the foundation that built the library with $21 million in private funds, also touched on the controversies that surrounded Nixon throughout his 25-year political career. ``Despite all of that, as well as the unrelenting hostility from the national media, President Nixon managed to lead America out of the Vietnam War and bring back our POWs.'' Before the ceremony, in the cool of the library, Nixon was asked how he felt. ``I feel as good as the rest of them look,'' Nixon said pointing to his fellow presidents. Nixon toured the library Wednesday for the first time and was asked how he liked it. ``What I've seen of it, I've been impressed but I'm not the best judge,'' he conceded. ``I'm going to let these three be the judge and jury. I'm glad to be in the hands of this jury.'' Ford already has a library, in Michigan; Reagan will open his in Simi Valley, 60 miles to the northwest of Nixon's, next February and plans already are under way for one to house Bush's papers and artifacts. Nixon's library is more of a museum since it houses none of Nixon's papers. Next year, if plans are followed, the library will get Nixon's archives from his congressional and vice presidential days and those that followed his presidency. But the real presidential papers, 42 million pages of documents, are in a warehouse in Alexandria, Va. The Nixon papers were seized by Congress after he left office to prevent him from destroying any Watergate documents. Millions of pages have been opened for perusal by scholars and the library will play tapes of 33 conversations that Nixon recorded secretly. But nearly 4,000 hours more of tapes as well as 15,000 important documents have been withheld from the public through actions by Nixon's lawyers. At Thursday's ceremony, the wives of the four presidents shared the stage. Pat Nixon, who has been nearly a recluse for 16 years, got the loudest applause. Reagan, characteristically, had a quip about the man who was being honored. ``Much has been written and said about Richard Nixon,'' said Reagan. ``Some of it has even been true. ... It will come as no surprise to anyone here that there will always be a good deal of debate about Richard Nixon.''

DOC.HEAD: FCC Says Foreign Phone Companies Charging Too Much
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 1-3 to RECAST and CORRECT that excessive charges are for outgoing, sted incoming calls
DOC.TEXT: Federal telephone regulators are warning foreign phone companies that if they don't stop padding charges for international calls, the United States will take unilateral action to lower prices. The Federal Communications Commission says U.S. phone customers may have paid as much as $1 billion too much for international calls in 1988 due to outmoded contracts that allow overseas phone companies to charge inflated prices for handling the other end of international calls. Not only does the practice hurt individual pocketbooks, it adds greatly to the U.S. trade deficit because far more calls go out of the United States than come in. U.S. phone companies paid out $2 billion more in 1988 than they took in from foreign phone companies, according to the FCC, which last Thursday threatened to limit what American phone companies can pay to overseas carriers. The FCC says roughly half of the $2 billion deficit represented an overpayment by U.S. consumers to foreign telephone companies that have refused to keep prices in line with cost-reducing advances in technology, such as direct dialing. The FCC proposed to ease restrictions on how American Telephone & Telegraph and other U.S. long-distance companies such as MCI and US Sprint negotiate ``accounting rates'' with foreign companies. These accounting rates determine how the two sides divvy up the charges consumers pay for international calls. Competition gives U.S. companies an incentive to lower prices, but foreign phone companies, which typically are state owned, don't face competitive pressures. Their accounting rates may be based on the cost of operator-assisted international calling, and not reflect the lower costs of today's ubiquitous direct-dialing. West Germany, for instance, has not lowered its accounting rate since 1983. U.S. phone companies still pay half of $1.56 a minute, or 78 cents a minute, to the Germans for completing calls to West Germany. AT&T and its rivals charge between $6.20 and $11.58 for a 10-minute call from the United States to West Germany, depending on when and how the call is made. But a German caller gets hit with a flat $19.07 for the same call. If AT&T charges 62 cents a minute, it loses money. It makes up such losses, however, by collecting 78 cents a minute for completing calls from West Germany to the United States. But the inflated $1.56 accounting rate keeps prices high _ and customers foot the bill. Foreign governments argue that the U.S. payments represent much-needed dollars that not only subsidize local phone systems but also help pay for schools or imported goods. Thomas Luciano, deputy director for international settlements at AT&T, said Wednesday that ``65 percent of the U.S. out payment goes to developing countries. We recognize we need to be sensitive to the concerns of some of the foreign telephone companies we're dealing with.'' But Luciano argued that if foreign nations lower their rates, they'll more than make up the lost revenue in increased volume of calling _ both in and out of their countries. Lower rates also will boost foreign economic development, he said. Luciano said AT&T, which has about 89 percent of the U.S. overseas phone market, succeeded in lowering international accounting rates with more than 70 nations in 1989. But he said he welcomed the FCC's ``impetus.'' ``We have already been expressing the deep concerns of the U.S. government, including the FCC, as part of our negotiations,'' Luciano said. South Korea, he said, has reduced its accounting rate steadily _ from $2.36 a minute to $2.10 a minute, and Japan dropped its rates in 1985 from $2.35 to $1.75 a minute. Sweden has cut its accounting rate in half, he added.

DOC.HEAD: On Anniversary of Presidency, Jaruzelski Hints at Resigning
DOC.TEXT: President Wojciech Jaruzelski, once Poland's Communist leader and now for many Poles the symbol of that disgraced regime, marked his first anniversary in office Thursday by saying he was prepared to resign. Jaruzelski, in the rare appearance on national television, said he would not take a position in the public debate on how long he should stay in office. ``I think it would be better if others made the statements,'' said the former Communist Party leader. He assumed his new office as president on July 19, 1989. ``I don't consider myself anointed, just performing a service for the nation and for the country,'' said 67-year-old Jaruzelski. ``And the moment recognized as proper for a change of the president will be treated by me with full understanding.'' Jaruzelski was elected president for a six-year term last year during a joint meeting of the new, freely elected Senate and the partially democratically elected Sejm, or lower house. Although the office makes him commander-in-chief of the armed forces and gives him the power to veto legislation, Jaruzelski uses his prerogatives sparingly. The more powerful position of prime minister is held by Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a former activist in the Solidarity labor movement. Solidarity controls the government. Even though Jaruzelski was resented for imposing martial law against Solidarity in 1981, many members of parliament believed he could help assure smooth relations with the Soviet Union and the rest of Eastern Europe. Poland's neighbors were still hard-line Communist as this country pioneered the East bloc's transition to democracy. Many Poles view Jaruzelski as an anachronistic vestige of the old Communist system now that the Soviet Union has accepted East bloc changes and Communist rule has ended in neighboring Czechoslovakia and East Germany. Advocates of Solidarity leader Lech Walesa want Walesa installed as president this fall by parliament. Jaruzelski's two longtime loyalists in the Cabinet, Interior Minister Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak and Defense Minister Gen. Florian Siwicki, resigned at Mazowiecki's request on July 6.

DOC.HEAD: South African Police, Youths in Running Battles
DOC.TEXT: Police fired tear gas and guns in running battles in two townships Thursday with black youths throwing gasoline bombs and stones, police and witnesses said. Three people were reported injured, including one youth police said was shot in the arm when he tried to throw a firebomb. Police said 18 people were arrested, and officers continued patrolling the townships of Vosloorus and Katlehong, east of Johannesburg. Houses and businesses of black town council members were gutted by gasoline bombs thrown by the youths, witnesses and police said. Newspaper and radio reports said violence began when students from a high school in Vosloorus tried to march toward township council offices to demand the release of two recently arrested teachers. The charges against the teachers were not available. Keith Montsisi, spokesman for the Vosloorus Civic Association, told the South African Press Association that police fired tear gas to stop the march, although community leaders assured the officers the protest would be peaceful. Police spokesmen said the march was illegal, and tear gas was fired when marchers ignored an order to disperse. Police said the violence spread to nearby Katlehong, where a house was stoned and burned and a beer delivery truck was attacked. In an unrelated case, two white right-wingers were charged in magistrate's court Thursday with illegal possession of hand grenades, including the type rolled into a hotel bar Saturday night. One black man was killed and 27 were injured at the Roodepoort Hotel. Police are investigating whether one of the arrested men may be connected with the blast, The Star newspaper reported.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Banana Company Cuts Off Strike Talks in Honduras
DOC.TEXT: Chiquita Brands International is severing talks with a union whose three-week-old strike has crippled banana exports to the United States, officials of the Cincinnati-based company said Thursday. Honduras' president, Rafael Leonardo Callejas, said the strike has caused more than $4.5 million in economic losses to his Central American country. Chiquita, formerly United Fruit, accounts for 60 percent of Honduran banana exports of 50 million boxes a year. San Francisco-based Castle & Cooke exports the other 40 percent. ``The rigid position of the union has kept talks stalled for the past two weeks,'' said Chiquita's general manager, Karl F. Koch, in a prepared statement. The 10,000 workers struck June 25 to demand the first increase in six years in their pay, now averaging $15.32 a day. They want a 58 percent increase. ``The last offer by Chiquita Brands was to approve a salary raise of 14.33 percent, which was immediately rejected by the union,'' said union president Rene Ayestas. He called the company's previous offers ``humiliating.'' For his part, Koch said the company's original optimism ``has turned to frustration at finding that the union still maintains its original position.'' President Callejas earlier sent a presidential mediation team to try to solve the impasse. ``I believe we will reach a negotiated end to the strike this weekend, although the present situation is tense and difficult,'' the president said. The walkout initially was joined by 30,000 other workers in the health, postal and industrial fields. But those workers returned to their jobs after 10 days.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs one graf for 23rd graf, ``These most...', to CORRECT `ethnic' sted `ethic.' Original moved Thursday in advance for Fri AMs and thereafter.
DOC.HEAD: Interreligious Official Boosts Peace and Children
DOC.NOTE: With Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: ``Let the children come to me, and do not hinder them,'' Jesus said, ``for to such belongs the kingdom of heaven.'' That special blessedness of the young taught in Christianity and the concern for them expressed in sacred writings of other religions are to be shared next week in a special forum. A variety of religious leaders _ Christians, Moslems, Jews, Hindus, Sikhs, Shintoists, Zoroastrians and others _ are to meet July 25-27 at Princeton Theological Seminary in New Jersey on behalf of children around the world. ``Religious leaders that do not normally come together about anything are coming together in the cause of children,'' said William P. Thompson, chairman of the conference steering committee. ``All the major religions have in their traditions a concern for children,'' he said in an interview. ``Their plight is getting worse in the world today.'' Thompson, associate secretary general of the World Conference on Religion and Peace, which is sponsoring the meeting in cooperation with the United Nations Children's Fund, added: ``When children are exploited, we're sowing the seeds of our own destruction.'' In many ways and places, that's now happening, he said, citing impoverished conditions in which ``kids are being pushed out to live on the streets'' and the rising proportion of children among the world's homeless and refugees. Thompson, longtime U.S. Presbyterian leader, said that ``we want to maximize attention of religion leaders to the problem of children'' and ``bring that thinking to the forefront'' of public awareness. The three-day meeting, involving 100 religious leaders from 40 countries and representing 10 major religions, is expected to adopt a ``declaration for children'' and an action program for protecting their development. Being held as a precursor to the ``World Summit for Children'' at the United Nations Sept. 29-30, the interreligious meeting seeks both to stir concern for children in religious ranks and also actions by governments. ``Defending the rights of children is one of the significant ways of working for future peace,'' Thompson said, noting that recent striking changes in Eastern Europe have meant ``great progress'' in that cause. ``But we still have to work at building sufficient justice for peace to last,'' he said, including more equitable economic conditions and help for the underprivileged. ``There are dauntless problems still before us,'' he said. Thompson, 71, chief executive of the United Presbyterian Church for 18 years and a member of the governing boards of the Nationa Council of Churches and World Council of Churches, fills his interreligious peace post without pay. ``The sacred writings of all of the great religions commit themselves to peace,'' he said. Some people now and in the past have supported wars in the name of religion, but the teachings of those faiths themselves invariably oppose war and advocate peace, he said. To blame ``religion as the cause of conflict'' _ which often is done by anti-religionists _ ``overlooks the facts of the religions themselves, which in their basic beliefs commit themselves to peace,'' Thompson said. ``Secularists think we're at each throat,'' he added, but he maintained such judgments were drawn from deviations from religious principles not adherence to them. However, he said, there are extremists in every religion who fan the flames of conflict, who see no truth in any faith but their own and who try to maximize their political power to control others. In doing so, such a ``person may be hypocritical in not stating accurately what he knows to be a fact about his religion, or he may be uninformed about what its religious teachings really are,'' Thompson said. In view of ``human motives to seek power and be prideful,'' he said, ``some use religion as a cloak behind which to hide'' their real motives, using religious symbols to annimate followers in conflicts and gain power. Asked about regional conflicts such as those between Roman Catholics and Protestants in Ireland, Moslems and Jews in the Middle East, Buddhists and Hindus in Sri Lanka or Moslems and Christians in the Sudan, he said: ``These most always are between ethnic groups identified by their religions. The disputes often are based on ethnic-economic differences rather than religious motivation as the names suggest.'' In many cases, he said the conflicts have complex roots in the past, involving rivalry over power, territories or economic status, with hostilities extended into the present under religious labels. Thompson, a Kansas-reared lawyer who was a U.S. Army captain in World War II and a war-crimes prosecutor, said war ``is connected to sin,'' to defections from the principles of all major faiths. It happens because of errant human nature, not fidelity to religions, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Denies Injunction Intervening in Wisconsin Indian Gambling Dispute
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge who was asked to intervene in a bitter dispute over Chippewa Indian gambling in Wisconsin has ruled that tribes that do not have gaming compacts with the state cannot operate casinos. U.S. District Judge Barbara Crabb on Wednesday denied a request from two Chippewa bands seeking an injunction prohibiting the state from closing down reservation casinos that opened in the last year. Mrs. Crabb ruled such casino operations are and will remain illegal until the tribe and state negotiate and enact federally required gaming agreements. But she also declared that the state, which threatened to prosecute the tribe, doesn't have authority to close down the operations. She said that authority rests with the U.S. attorney's office. Jerry Maulson, gaming manager for the Lac du Flambeau Chippewa band that filed the lawsuit, said the tribe won its argument that the state doesn't have jurisdiction to prosecute gambling issues on reservations but lost on the ruling that Indian gambling was illegal without a gaming compact. ``It's sort of like a double-edged sword,'' Maulson said. U.S. Attorney Patrick J. Fiedler in Madison said he would consult with Justice Department officials before deciding whether to close any reservation casinos in Wisconsin. He said previous advice from Washington indicated it was more ``sensible to rely on state prosecutors,'' although it was believed the state and federal governments had ``concurrent jurisdiction.'' The year-long dispute in Wisconsin began last fall when the state and its dozen Indian tribes failed to reaching gambling regulation pacts by October as required by the U.S. Indian Gambling Regulatory Act passed by Congress in 1988. The government has since extended the deadline until next May. The negotiations broke off late last year and tensions were worsened when the state's top law official, Attorney General Donald Hanaway, issued an advisory opinion in February that casino gambling was illegal in Wisconsin. The opinion led several local prosecutors to warn tribes they would raid and close down the several reservation casinos that had begun operations in the last year. Most of the tribes closed their reservations voluntarily, but two bands of Chippewas sued, asking Mrs. Crabb to stop the state from enforcing state gambling laws on the reservations. Mrs. Crabb denied the request, saying the tribes could avoid prosecution by the government by not sponsoring casino operations until the required gaming compacts are enacted. The ruling came a day after Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan announced guidelines that would allow tribes to buy non-reservation land to open bingo parlors and other gaming establishments. Under the guidelines, such purchases would have to be approved by the governor of the state, Lujan said. The guidelines also bar tribes from buying out-of-state land for gambling sites. The Interior Department will seek input from tribes before putting the guidelines in effect.

DOC.HEAD: Sioux City Crash Survivors Confront Their Past, Look to Future
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 18 grafs with quotes, color from prayer service; edits to conform, picks up 13th graf, Despite survivors....
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos SXC1, SXC2
DOC.TEXT: A year after they tumbled out of the smoke-choked fuselage of a shattered jumbo jet into a hot corn field, survivors of United Flight 232 returned Thursday to give prayers of thanks and sympathy. A memorial service, forced into an airport hangar by heavy rains, coincided with the moment a year ago when the plane tumbled in flames while attempting an emergency landing. Many cried quietly as the Rev. Gregory Clapper, a United Methodist minister from Le Mars, led the assembled survivors and families of victims in part of the 23rd Psalm. Some survivors described feelings of guilt. When Air National Guard jets roared off to form a ``missing man'' formation, some clasped hands over ears and held clenched fists to their mouths. ``It's been an emotional roller coaster for all of us, but even so, the remembering has been an important part of the healing process,'' said United Capt. Al C. Haynes, who led the crew of the DC-10 in guiding the plane to the airport, where it cartwheeled while attempting an emergency landing. Haynes told the crowd of several hundred it was important for all involved to deal with the painful memories of the crash. ``Somehow, we must find a way to take them away from our present and make them part of the past,'' Haynes said. Many survivors said returning to site of the crash helped them deal with tragedy. ``I wanted my boys to know that Sioux City is a place where normal things happen, that it's a place of mending as well as catastrophe,'' said Brownell Bailey of Bowmar, Colo. Bailey's wife, Francie, was one of 112 people who died when the plane crashed after an engine broke apart, severing a hydraulic system that controlled the plane. There were 296 people aboard the July 19, 1989, crash.
