Survivors and their families, plus Sioux City rescuers, were allowed to walk around the crash site Thursday. ``I have a lot of memories of some pretty gruesome things, and we both feel guilty that we walked away unharmed while so many others didn't,'' said Sharon Bayless, who with her husband, Brad, of Littleton, Colo., escaped with minor injuries. ``I knew it would be hard to come back,'' she said. But her husband said a visit to the airport was important. ``I want to see it without bodies and luggage and airplane parts strewn all over,'' he said. The Baylesses said one of their first priorities was to thank the rescuers. ``I suppose it's the old Midwest cliche, but there's a lot to be said about the way the people of Sioux City pitched in to help. I'm not sure that would have happened if this crash occurred somewhere else,'' Bayless said. Many of the survivors sought out Haynes to thank him for the job the crew did in guiding the crippled airliner to the airport. Despite survivors' thanks and praise, Haynes insisted there were no heroes in the cockpit. But he said some people needed to look up to the crew as part of their healing. ``If we are serving some kind of function by being called heroes, so be it,'' Haynes said. ``I'd like to think that any other well-trained crew would have responded as we did.'' Roman S. Popielak, a crash survivor also from Littleton, said he returned ``so I could close the books.'' ``This is not opening wounds for me. It depends on your strength or makeup. I prefer to deal with my problems myself. Other people may need to lean on others and may feel more vulnerable,'' Popielak said. Adriene Badis, 41, of Durham, N.C., his wife and two children survived the crash, but they were separated for three hours. ``I told my older son (Eric, 7) that his brother and mother had died,'' he said. When he found them alive, ``I was numb, elated, there are no adjectives.'' Lori Michaelson used the reunion to put pressure on Congress to require child restraints on airliners. Currently, small children are permitted to sit on their parents' laps. Ms. Michaelson's 11-month-old daughter, Sabrina _ ripped from her grasp during the crash _ was saved by another passenger. The passenger, Jerry Schemmel of Denver, heard her cries and pulled her from the wreckage. ``Let's have something positive come out of this crash,'' she said. ``My actions have been overblown,'' said Schemmel, who appeared with Ms. Michaelson in one of numerous news conferences at Briar Cliff College. ``You'd be surprised, you'd do the same thing. I didn't run through a wall of fire to get her. God was looking over us. I didn't do anything spectacular. I just reacted,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U. of Mich. Entry Takes First Place in Solar Car Race
With AM-Solar Car Race-List
LaserPhoto Planned
DOC.TEXT: The Sunrunner, a student-built solar car that runs on ``the power of a hair dryer,'' hummed across the finish line Thursday to win a Florida-to-Detroit race by 32 sun-powered vehicles. Western Washington University's Viking XX was first to finish, but the University of Michigan's Sunrunner had the best elapsed time in the 11-day, 1,641-mile competition: 72 hours, 50 minutes and 47 seconds. Its average speed was 22.5 mph. ``This is about as good as engineering can get,'' said Michigan team member Bill Kaliardos. ``It's an exciting way to display solar energy and its applications.'' The Sunrunner triumphed despite its first mechanical delay, a 10-minute stop Thursday to repair a drive chain. Western Washington's entry was second in the early, unofficial standings, and the University of Maryland's Pride of Maryland came in third. The vehicles completed the final, 84-mile leg of the race under strong sun and with temperatures in the 80s. The flat, lightweight vehicles finished with faint whines and hums rather than the booming exhausts and smoking tires of their internal-combustion cousins. The Sunrunner _ just over 3 feet high but 19 feet long and 6.6 feet wide _ and other cars were designed to expose the maximum area of solar cells to the sun and run on minimum power, in the Sunrunner's case 1.5 horsepower. ``We're trying to run the car on the power of a hair dryer,'' said Susan Fancy, a 27-year-old mechanical engineering student who was the Sunrunner's project manager. The GM Sunrayce USA, which began July 9 at Disney World in Lake Buena Vista, Fla., was sponsored by General Motors Corp., the U.S. Department of Energy and the Society of Automotive Engineers. GM plans to send the top three finishers to Australia's World Solar Challenge, a 2,000-mile race across the Australian outback from Darwin to Adelaide. It starts Nov. 11. ``We're going to take our car back and start preparing it to go to Australia,'' said Bill Lingenfelter, 23, a Western Washington University industrial technology student and the Viking XX team captain. Lingenfelter said some 35 people worked for about 18 months on the Viking XX. ``One thing that I really like: it's all student-designed and student-built,'' said Lingenfelter of the car, which was featured on the cover of Popular Science last August. One of only three two-passenger vehicles in the race, the pontoon-like vehicle had two fishbowl-shaped cockpits facing each other. ``It's very radical,'' Lingenfelter said. GM held a parade of the finishers and another banquet for the racers, who were treated to a lobster dinner in Mason on the eve of the final race day. The Star II from small Crowder College in Missouri showed that small could be beautiful, finishing first in Wednesday's 190-mile leg from Greenville, Ohio, to Mason. Crowder finished fifth overall, edging out such engineering powerhouses as MIT, in sixth place, and Stanford, in seventh. In fourth place was the Solar Eagle of California State University-Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Bickering Dominates Resumption of Budget Talks
DOC.TEXT: Bickering prevailed Thursday as White House officials and congressional leaders spent their first budget bargaining session in more than a week fighting over recent partisan statements by both sides. ``We simply had to kind of yammer at each other,'' said negotiator Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore. The squabbling came as negotiators hit a lull in their efforts to find enough tax increases and spending cuts to lop $50 billion off next year's federal deficit. Last week, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said he would demand higher income tax rates for the wealthy if President Bush continues to seek a capital gains tax reduction. Democrats argue that the rich would be the main beneficiaries of a reduction. Wednesday, House Republicans voted informally to oppose any deficit-reduction deal that includes tax increases of any kind. They also accused Mitchell of hindering the search for a budget deal. On Thursday, Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla., blistered Mitchell and the Democrats again, claiming they ``go to bed at night worried that there might be something they haven't taxed yet.'' But House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., said that at Thursday's session, Republican leaders promised to try do what Democrats have demanded: deliver the votes of at least half of Congress' GOP lawmakers for whatever budget deal emerges. ``They reassured us that provided we reach an agreement, they'll work to do that,'' Panetta said. Participants said no substantive ground was covered as full negotiating teams from both sides met for the first time since July 11. The 2{-hour session illustrated how politically sensitive a task the budget bargainers have. ``There's a lot of concern that you can't work what are very difficult issues and have grenades thrown in one direction or the other,'' said Panetta. ``Hopefully, the summit will get back on track.'' The negotiators plan to meet again Monday, and meet with Bush that evening.

DOC.HEAD: German, American Pilots Not Enemies Anymore
DOC.TEXT: On March 6, 1944, Col. Hub Zemke sent an enemy German plane spiraling through the sky in flames, the fate of its pilot unknown. On Thursday, his former foe reappeared. ``There's no need to have a personal war,'' said Wolfgang Kretschmer, 68, the former first lieutenant Zemke shot down. ``The war's over with.'' Zemke, 76, now an almond grower in Oroville, Calif., joked with Kretschmer and his wife, Elli, before the two former pilots signed prints of a painting depicting their air battle over Germany. They were brought together here by The Greenwich Workshop, Inc., an art production company that made the prints. On Friday they will appear at the workshop's gallery in Southport. ``See the holes I put in you?'' said Zemke, pointing to Kretschmer's plane in the painting. The two men laughed. Zemke, in a P-47, shot down Kretschmer during the first American raid on Berlin. Kretschmer, in an FW 190, flew directly into a group of 40 American fighter planes with no cover, said Zemke. ``I jumped on him and after giving him two blasts, I saw that he was on fire,'' said Zemke. ``He probably never saw me.'' Kretschmer, who lives in Haan, West Germany, said he suffered second- and third-degree burns on the upper half of his body that burned off part of his nose and left his wrists ``crisp.'' But he recovered and returned to military service, becoming an architect after the war. Zemke's plane crashed during a thunderstorm seven months later and he was held prisoner in Germany for five months. Both men say they have no regrets. After a decade of exchanging letters, the two met for the first time in April at the Airman Memorial Museum near Washington, where the painting was first displayed. Artist William S. Phillips, 45, of Ashland, Ore., said he has reunited other former foes to sign prints of their battles. ``I've never had a situation where people got together and weren't friendly and refused to talk,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cubans Reportedly Leave Czech Diplomat's Home; Surrender to Police
DOC.TEXT: Five Cubans abandoned their bid for political asylum and surrendered to police on Thursday after spending a week holed up in a Czechoslovak diplomat's apartment, according to reports from Havana. The four men and one woman emerged wearing hoods and were taken away in a Cuban police vehicle, the official Mexican news agency Notimex said. They agreed to leave after assurances they would not be prosecuted, the official Cuban news agency Prensa Latina and the Czechoslovak state news agency CTK reported. ``After the interrogation of Cuban police, (they) ... will be allowed to go home, and no legal proceeding will be started against them,'' CTK said. At least eight other asylum-seekers remained on diplomatic grounds Thursday _ four in the Spanish Embassy and four in the residence of the Italian ambassador, who is not in Cuba. Small bands of Cubans seeking asylum began taking refuge at diplomatic missions eight days ago. Prensa Latina said Thursday's surrender was negotiated with a Cuban Foreign Ministry official and a representative of the Czechoslovak Embassy. Hours before they gave up their refuge, the asylum-seekers vowed to stand fast, Notimex said. ``We have decided to stay here, at least as long as the food holds out!'' one yelled to reporters outside the building, Notimex said, quoting unidentified journalists. The agency said a special Czechoslovak security squad arrived in Havana Thursday to reinforce security at Prague's diplomatic missions in Cuba. Spain also reinforced security at its missions in Havana. The five Cubans who surrendered occupied the apartment of Charge d'Affaires Jan Doemoek July 12, holding Doemoek hostage for a few hours before he escaped. The Italian news agency ANSA said efforts continued to negotiate the fate of the four Cubans in the Italian ambassador's residence. Relations between Spain and Cuba continued to deteriorate over the asylum crisis. Spain suspended $2.5 million in grants to Cuba on Thursday and persuaded the European Community to put on hold three ``symbolic'' aid projects for Cuba. On Wednesday, Madrid recalled its ambassador after Cuban police arrested a young man on Spanish Embassy grounds last Friday. Spanish Foreign Minister Fernandez Ordonez has suggested President Fidel Castro knew his government would crumble if he opened the door to all Cubans who want to leave. Cuba, a former Spanish colony, has 11 million people. ``The situation in Havana is very nervous due to Cuba's isolation from the world and because of the extremely serious economic problems there,'' he said on Spanish National Radio Wednesday after recalling the ambassador to Havana. ``No one wants a catastrophe there. What is needed is a peaceful transition to democracy,'' he said. Cuba has accused Spain of violating Cuban and international law by harboring asylum-seekers and swore never to yield to ``pressure or blackmail'' by people seeking to leave the Caribbean island. Castro's government portrays the asylum-seekers as ``antisocial elements'' and says none of them has a legitimate political reason for wanting to leave Cuba. The Cuban media meanwhile played up the case of 11 human rights activists convicted of counterrevolutionary crimes, Prensa Latina said. The prosecutor accuses U.S. officials in Havana of ``instigating'' the activists, whose are accused of planning to blow up the National Library and the Cuban Institute of Radio and Television. Prosecutor Sara Nieves said officials at the U.S. Interests Section in Havana provided logistical support and ``orientation'' to members of Pro-Human Rights Youth, which authorities describe as the armed wing of the outlawed Pro-Human Rights Party. She said the United States used the group to ``foment economic chaos and carry out terrorist acts.'' Nieves also said the defendants had been in contact with other Western diplomatic missions and with Venezuelan diplomats. The activists drew sentences ranging from 15 years in prison to three years of house arrest Wednesday for counterrevolutionary crimes such as terrorism and rebellion.

DOC.HEAD: Wildfire Erupts After Military Plane Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with crew members rescued, acreage increased, other details; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A Navy attack jet with two people aboard crashed in the Santa Ynez Mountains just north of this coastal resort, igniting a brush fire that roared across 300 acres, forest service officials said. The jet crashed just before 1 p.m. in the Los Padres National Forest about 11 miles north of the city, said U.S. Forest Service spokesman Maeton Freel. Firefighting aircraft began dumping slurry on the raging flames. The two crew members were rescued near the crash site at about 2:30 p.m., one by a Navy helicopter and the other by a Coast Guard helicopter, said Bob Hubbert, a spokesman for the Point Mugu Naval Air Station. Both apparently parachuted out of the plane before it crashed, he said. The pilot was taken to Goleta Valley Hospital, said Donna Fogarty, a hospital spokeswoman. ``He is alert and awake and in good condition,'' said Ms. Fogarty. She could not provide specifics information his injuries. The other crew member, who also was not identified, apparently was not seriously injured. The Navy A-7 Corsair jet crashed at 12:55 p.m. while on a training mission, Hubbert said. The cause of the crash was unknown. The cause of the crash was unknown. Some 250 firefighters were battling the blaze, which was burning northward. No structures were threatened, Freel said. Firefighters were being hampered by hot and humid weather and rugged terrain, he said. The fire broke out near Gibralter Reservoir, just north of Santa Barbara, which was struck by a devastating brush fire June 27 that killed one person and caused more than $300 million in damage to more than 600 homes.

DOC.HEAD: Sihanouk Criticizes Change in U.S. Policy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 5 `The U.S.' to RECAST, ADD details. Picks up 6th pvs, `Some analysts...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Cambodia-Khmer Rouge, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prince Norodom Sihanouk on Thursday criticized a cutback in U.S. support for his guerrilla coalition, saying that would only make it ``more firm and fierce'' in battling the Cambodian government. China indicated it would continue its crucial aid to the Khmer Rouge, while some of the coalition's other allies in Southeast Asia said they doubted the U.S. shift would promote a peaceful settlement. Cambodia's government, along with its Vietnamese backers, welcomed the U.S. move Wednesday to withdraw recognition of the resistance coalition and open a dialogue with Vietnam on resolving the 11-year-old civil war. Britain also praised the U.S. decision and said it also opposes the Cambodian resistance alliance, dominated by the fanatical Khmer Rouge, having Cambodia's seat at the United Nations. The U.S. decision reflected fears of a resurgence of the Communist Khmer Rouge, which killed or starved to death hundreds of thousands of Cambodians in slave labor camps and in rural villages during their 1975-78 rule. Vietnam invaded in late 1978 and installed the current government. Some analysts say the U.S. move could open the way for diplomatic relations between the United States and Vietnam, estranged since the end of the Vietnam War in April 1975. The Soviet vice minister of foreign affairs, Igor Rogachev, said Southeast Asia could not achieve real stability without normal diplomatic ties between the United States and Vietnam and Cambodia. ``For the moment, there isn't normalization, but we hope there soon will be,'' he said in Paris. Sihanouk, a non-Communist who leads the three-party resistance coalition, said the U.S. move was ``an act of very serious injustice.'' The coalition now will be ``more firm and fierce in their determination to continue to resist,'' he said in a statement from North Korea's capital of Pyongyang, where he lives part of the year. It will only keep alive a government in Cambodia that is ``a creature and creation'' of Vietnam, he said. Phnom Penh's official SPK news agency quoted a foreign ministry spokesman welcoming the U.S. shift as ``paving the way for achievement of an early political settlement.'' The official Vietnam News Agency quoted Vietnam's Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach as applauding the U.S. move. Thach said Hanoi wanted ``an early, fair and equitable solution ... (and) is ready to negotiate with concerned countries on the Cambodia issue.'' Some guerrilla leaders said the U.S. shift could force them closer to China and strengthen the Khmer Rouge. Prince Norodom Ranariddh, son of Sihanouk and commander of his army, said Wednesday that if the United States suspends its $7 million in annual aid to the non-Communist guerrillas, China has promised to double that amount. ``To cut off the non-Communist resistance you will strengthen the Khmer Rouge,'' he said. Peace talks have foundered. The guerrillas reject Phnom Penh's wish to retain power in the period leading to elections. The guerrillas want to share power or have the United Nations assume authority. Sihanouk and the head of the third guerrilla group, former Prime Minister Son Sann, have refused Phnom Penh's demand they abandon the Khmer Rouge. They say the group would only fight on if excluded from a settlement. In Beijing Thursday, Foreign Ministry spokesman Jin Guihua said all Cambodian factions must be included in any political settlement. ``So long as Vietnam does not withdraw all its troops from Cambodia genuinely, China will continue to support the Cambodian people in their resistance against the foreign invaders,'' he told a news conference. Thailand also has not indicated it will decrease its sanctuary, logistical and other support to the guerrillas. The U.S. shift will not affect the Khmer Rouge militarily, and ``might push them to concentrate on a military solution,'' said a Thai official involved in the aid program, who spoke on condition he not be named. The Khmer Rouge's 30,000-member army is reported to have struck in virtually every province in Cambodia, attacking five provincial capitals in recent weeks.

DOC.HEAD: 10,000 Rally in Timisoara to Demand that Romania's Leader Quit
DOC.TEXT: More than 10,000 people Thursday demanded the resignation of President Ion Iliescu during a demonstration in this western city that gave birth to Romania's anti-Communist revolution. The protesters, who equated Iliescu with communism, also called on his government to step down and urged the release of a jailed activist. In a main square of Timisoara, the demonstrators accused Iliescu and his government of a new form of totalitarian rule. They cheered ``Down with Communism!'' and ``Down with Iliescu!'' Iliescu, a former Communist official, won free elections in May, but opponents demanded he step down because of his hard-line past. He has repeatedly said he favors democracy and a free-market economy. Timisoara is the Transylvania city where street protests touched off a revolution in December against Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. He and his wife Elena were executed Dec. 25 under orders of a revolutionary tribunal. In an open letter to the government, the demonstrators Thursday also urged the release of Marian Munteanu, the leader of a 53-day round-the-clock opposition rally broken up by police last month. Munteanu was later badly beaten by rampaging miners answering an Iliescu call for help against anti-government rioters. She was arrested on suspicion of involvement in the riots. Earlier Thursday, Iliescu promised university students he would contact the prosecutor general about Munteanu. But he told students seeking Munteanu's release that ``it is the task of justice to take a decision'' in the case, the state Rompres news agency said. Munteanu's detention ignited a mass protest July 13, when 20,000 demonstrators marched in Bucharest to demand his release. It was the largest rally since the December revolution. The world community harshly criticized Iliescu for the miners' rampage, and the United States and other Western nations cut off all non-humanitarian aid to Romania. On Wednesday, Premier Petre Roman told French President Francois Mitterrand that ``it is possible that Marian Munteanu will be set free.'' Roman was visiting France. The open letter from Thursday's demonstrators also asked the government to ``cast light'' on what happened to Securitate, Ceausescu's feared secret police, as well as the dictator's hard currency accounts and the funds of the Communist Party.

DOC.HEAD: Rescuers Stymied in Search for 42 Soviet Avalanche Victims
DOC.TEXT: Bad weather hindered rescuers looking for 42 climbers killed in an avalanche in the Pamir mountains in Central Asia, Tass said Thursday. It said the toll could mount if the snow had engulfed other, unregistered groups. An earthquake last Friday set off the avalanche that hit the base camp of a Soviet-Swiss expedition at 16,000 feet, more than two-thirds up Lenin Peak, 1,800 miles southeast of Moscow. About 55 to 60 people were at the camp at the time, including Bulgarian and East German climbers and Soviet tourists, the Soviet news agency said. Victims included 23 members of the Leningrad climbing team, four climbers from Israel, six from Czechoslovakia, two from Switzerland and one from Spain. ``The search, which is being conducted despite very cold weather, the snow storm and gusting winds, is very risky,'' Tass quoted the newspaper Sovetsky Sport as reporting. ``The avalanche sent the climbers, who were in the camp at the moment of the catastrophe, tumbling down into deep fissures and covered them with snow.'' It said the earthquake, centered in Afghanistan, caused a huge slab of ice to split from a glacier, ``which, in turn, started the colossal avalanche, engulfing the camp with more than 40 mountaineers.'' Three climbers were found alive, and two of them were hospitalized. Konstantin Leonov, chief of the Tadzhik Mountaineering Rescue Service, told Tass the camp has existed for more than 10 years and was considered ``to a considerable extent safe. However, absolute security in the mountains in non-existent.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Accuse Administration of Withholding Owl Information
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration suppressed a government report that offered ways to reduce significantly the timber job losses that would result from protection of the rare northern spotted owl, two Northwest lawmakers charged Thursday. Reps. Peter DeFazio, D-Ore., and Jolene Unsoeld, D-Wash., gsaid the May 1 report was leaked to them by ``a source in the administration.'' The White House declined comment. A spokesman for Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. said the report was an internal document that never was intended for release. ``They are just playing partisan politics,'' said the spokesman, Steve Goldstein. The report prepared by the Forest Service, an arm of ther Agriculture Department, and the Bureau of Land Management, part of the Interior Department, outlines ways to save as many as 21,000 timber jobs by, among other things, adding new restrictions on log exports and boosting spending on Forest Service programs, DeFazio said. He said it was prepared for release at the same time the two agencies projected that one controversial plan to save the owl would cut timber harvests in the region by nearly 50 percent and cost the region more than 28,000 jobs by the end of the decade. Each nesting pair of owls needs large areas of undisturbed old-growth forest to survive. The Fish and Wildlife Service last month classified the owl as an endangered species, which means the government must come up with a protection plan. The Bush administration has not drafted complete plans, but has said it expects 1,000 timber jobs in the Northwest will be lost. Bush has said he wants to balance the needs of timber communities against owl protection. ``This report has been suppressed by the administration,'' DeFazio said during a hastily called news conference at his office. ``I find it absolutely outrageous that the administration on May 1 could give on us one-half of the equation _ that is they dropped on us the job impacts, the fear of loss of livelihood that came to so many thousands of people in the Pacific Northwest. DeFazio said Forest Service workers have told him of the report and have been urging him to obtain a copy of it for several weeks, but he said administrators denied it existed. Goldstein declined comment on the allegation that administration officials denied the document existed: ``I can't speak to that. I don't know who they talked to,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules in Favor of Newspapers in Confidential Source Case
DOC.NOTE: For release at 1:01 a.m. EDT Friday; Time set by court.
DOC.TEXT: The Minnesota Supreme Court overturned a $700,000 damage award to a man who sued the state's two largest daily newspapers for revealing his identity after he was promised anonymity. In a 4-2 decision to be filed Friday, the state's highest court said the Saint Paul Pioneer Press and the Star Tribune of Minneapolis could not be held liable for breaking reporters' promises of confidentiality to Dan Cohen in 1982. The ruling, which one attorney called a ``major victory'' for news organizations, upheld a state Appeals Court panel's dismissal of Cohen's claim of fraudulent misrepresentation, but reversed that court's ruling allowing his breach-of-contract claim. ``To impose a contract theory on this arrangement puts an unwarranted legal rigidity on a special ethical relationship, precluding necessary consideration of factors underlying that ethical relationship,'' Associate Justice John Simonett wrote for the majority. The court also said enforcement of the promise of confidentiality under a doctrine that implies a legal contract where none exists in fact would violate the newspapers' First Amendment rights. Cohen's attorney, Elliot Rothenberg, said Thursday the case will be appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court. ``This case isn't over by a long shot,'' Rothenberg said. ``It's a very important case, one with far-reaching implications,'' he said. ``The issue is, to what extent do newspapers and the media have a constitutional right to violate promises to which everyone else in society would be held liable?'' Attorneys for The Associated Press, which filed the only friend-of-the-court brief in the case, said Cohen's trial court victory had produced a spate of similar lawsuits around the country. The latest decision is ``the first definitive opinion by a supreme court of a state directly addressing'' the issues in Cohen's case, and one in which the news media ``can take considerable comfort,'' said attorney Dick Winfield of the Rogers and Wells law firm in New York, the AP's general counsel. Louise Sommers, also of Rogers and Wells, said the ruling was a ``major victory'' for the news media. The newspapers and the AP were able to ``convince the Supreme Court that the First Amendment mattered in a case like this, where a source who had grounds to sue for conventional libel chose to mask it as a breach-of-contract suit,'' she said. The case stemmed from a 1982 incident in which Cohen gave reporters copies of court documents showing that Marlene Johnson, then seeking her first term as lieutenant governor, had been convicted of shoplifting 12 years earlier. Johnson's conviction was vacated in 1971 with no sentence. She was elected as Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich's running mate in 1982, re-elected in 1986 and is running with Perpich this year. Cohen, who was doing public relations work for 1982 Republican gubernatorial candidate Wheelock Whitney, provided information about Johnson on condition he not be identified. Reporters for the newspapers gave him that assurance, but editors decided to name Cohen as their source of the documents. Editors testified that they named Cohen because they felt the public had a right to know the information came from the Whitney campaign. Reporters for the AP and WCCO-TV also promised Cohen anonymity and received the documents. The AP published the story and honored its promise, while the television station did not run the story. Cohen claimed in his lawsuit that he lost his advertising agency job after the newspapers breached an oral contract to keep his name out of the story. In rejecting Cohen's argument that contract law should apply to his case, the Supreme Court majority said, ``We are not persuaded that in the special milieu of media newsgathering a source and a reporter ordinarily believe they are engaged in making a legally binding contract. ``They are not thinking in terms of offers and acceptances in any commercial or business sense,'' the majority said. ``The parties understand that the reporter's promise of anonymity is given as a moral commitment, but a moral obligation alone will not support a contract.'' In addressing whether a promise of confidentiality might otherwise be enforceable, the court said it had to balance the constitutional rights of a free press against the common-law interest of protecting a promise of anonymity. ``Of critical significance in this case ... is the fact that the promise of anonymity arises in the classic First Amendment context of the quintessential public debate in our democratic society, namely, a political source involved in a political campaign,'' the court said. ``The potentiality for civil damages for promises made in this context chills public debate, a debate which Cohen willingly entered albeit hoping to do so on his own terms. In this context, and considering the nature of the political story involved, it seems to us that the law best leaves the parties here to their trust in each other.'' In his dissent, Associate Justice Lawrence Yetka said the result of the majority opinion was to ``carve out yet another special privilege in favor of the press that is denied other citizens.'' Associate Justice Glenn Kelley, who joined Yetka's dissent, said the decision ``serves to inhibit rather than to promote the objectives of the First Amendment by `drying up' potential sources of information on public matters.'' Chief Justice Peter Popovich took no part in the decision. Saint Paul Pioneer Press attorney Paul Hannah said the court's majority recognized the difficulties editors and reporters face in ``making decisions about what voters are going to know about the candidates and campaigns.'' Star Tribune Executive Editor Joel R. Kramer said in a statement for release Friday that the newspaper was ``especially pleased that the court has ruled that the decision to publish true facts relating to the activities of `a political source in a political campaign' is one that is protected by the First Amendment.'' The court, following its policy, allowed attorneys in the case to be contacted Thursday, but forbade contacts with parties in the case until Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Singapore Bars Reporters from Covering Conference
DOC.TEXT: The government said Thursday that reporters for The Asian Wall Street Journal and the Far Eastern Economic Review would be barred from covering the Asia-Pacific Economic Conference. The three-day conference, which begins July 29, will discuss the economic course of the Asia-Pacific region. Representatives of the United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, South Korea, Japan, Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Philippines and Singapore are attending. The government has been at odds with the Journal and the Review, a weekly magazine, for several years over alleged interference in the domestic politics of this island city-state. Both are published in Hong Kong by Dow Jones & Co. of the United States. Dow Jones in a statement Thursday from New York said that ``for reasons that are unclear'' it appears Singapore ``is extending its long-asserted right to restrict coverage of Singapore for Singaporean readers (and) restrict coverage of international economic meetings for all Asians. ``Dow Jones fears that the government's actions against the Review and Asian Journal are therefore entirely coercive or punitive,'' the statement said. In 1987, the government required the Journal to reduce its daily circulation here to about 500 copies from 5,000. The Review was ordered to cut its circulation to 400-500 copies a week from 10,000 but the magazine refused to continue selling in Singapore. The Dow Jones statement also noted ``that Singapore has given reporters for the U.S. edition of the Journal and for AP-Dow Jones permission to attend'' the conference. AP-Dow Jones is a joint venture of The Associated Press and Dow Jones. On Wednesday, the government introduced a bill in Parliament that would require foreign newspapers wishing to circulate in Singapore to get permission annually.

DOC.HEAD: Wet Sidewalks at Bus Terminal Keep Homeless Away
DOC.TEXT: Neighborhood merchants are cheering, but advocates for the homeless have cried foul over a newly-enforced policy to hose down the sidewalks around New York City's main bus station throughout the day. The policy is aimed at keeping the homeless and their bodily wastes off the pavement around the Port Authority Bus Terminal, which has become a magnet for those without shelter. The sidewalks are being hosed down every couple of hours for 16 hours starting at 6 a.m. ``I think it's the greatest idea in the world and I started doing it too,'' said Vincent Dimino, owner of the Seabreeze Fish Market on Ninth Avenue across from the terminal and president of the 40th Street Merchants Association. ``Between the urination ... and everything else they put out on the street we have to keep it clean and that's the only way we can,'' Dimino said Thursday. But Mary Brosnahan, director of the Coalition for the Homeless, said she felt ``utter frustration'' because of the policy. ``We've shoved them off the platforms, we've kicked them off the trains and now we are literally flushing them off our sidewalks,'' Brosnahan said. ``I don't know how to get the message across _ the shell game doesn't work.'' The summertime policy has been in effect two years but wasn't enforced until June 1 because of water restrictions, according to a Port Authority spokeswoman, Lynn Tierney. Tierney said the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has been ``in the forefront of providing social services for the homeless'' over the past 10 years, including providing a drop-in center across the street from the bus terminal. ``We're in a constant struggle to balance the rights and expectations of the 200,000 people that commute through this facility every day with the needs of the homeless population that have made this facility their home,'' she said. The homeless had to be moved from the sidewalks, along with their wastes, for health and safety reasons, she said, adding that a concrete stairway had to be replaced because of accumulated wastes. ``We've had situations at times where people had built entire towns out of cardboard along the 41st Street side of the building,'' Tierney said. One problem with the policy has cropped up: water was seeping into the newly renovated locker room of Port Authority police, but caulking will be put in to stop the seepage.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises Nixon, 16 Years After Urging Resignation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, bgng: After the xxx and INSERTS 4 grafs following to UPDATE with president's remarks in Idaho.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Nixon Library, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Sixteen years after urging President Nixon to resign, President Bush praised the nation's 37th chief executive Thursday and urged fellow Americans to ``look at Richard Nixon, the man.'' Bush, standing with Nixon and former presidents Reagan and Ford, made only passing reference to the Watergate scandal that wrecked Nixon's presidency, noting only that it was Nixon's ``seventh crisis.'' Nixon, who wrote a book called Six Crises, served in ``tumultuous times,'' he said. Bush, speaking at the dedication of the Nixon Presidential Library and Birthplace, focused on Nixon's foreign policy achievements and other successes. He said, ``Richard Nixon helped change the course not only of America but of the entire world.'' He cited Nixon's trip to China and his peace efforts in the Middle East, and he said, ``Who can forget how in Moscow, Richard Nixon signed the first agreement to limit strategic nuclear arms _ giving new hope to the world for a lasting peace?'' Bush credited Nixon with working for ``returning power to the people'' with revenue sharing and other programs to shift powers to state and local governments. He also hailed Nixon's environmental initiatives and his decision to end the military draft. At the outdoor ceremony in 90-degree heat, Bush said that he would say to visitors to the nation's 10th presidential library, due to open on Friday, ``Look at Richard Nixon the man.'' A beaming Nixon said, ``This is the first time I've ever been introduced by the president of the United States.'' After the dedication, the four presidents had lunch together, the first time that has happened. Former President Carter was invited but declined. Bush, as chairman of the Republican National Committee, wrote a letter to Nixon on Aug. 7, 1974, saying his resignation would be ``best for the country.'' Nixon resigned two days later. Before the library ceremony, Bush attended a private fund-raising reception in Anaheim, Calif., that was expected to raise $300,000 for the California Republican Party. After the dedication ceremony and lunch at the presidential museum, Bush flew to Boise, Idaho, to bolster the Senate campaign of Rep. Larry Craig. In Boise Bush called on the Democratic-led Congress to break the impasse over budget negotiations. Noting that ``I did my part'' by reversing his 1988 ``no new taxes'' pledge, Bush told a GOP fundraiser for Republican Senate candidate Larry Craig: ``Now it's their turn.'' ``I have said I'll negotiate without preconditions,'' Bush said in prepared remarks. ``And I will.'' He called the congressional budget process ``clumsy and illogical _ and at worst, cynical and chaotic. In short, a metaphor for what's wrong with Washington today.'' Bush's ties with Nixon go back to the early 1960s. Nixon stumped in Texas for Bush in his unsuccessful race for Senate in 1964 and also appeared at the kickoff of Bush's successful 1966 run for a House seat from Houston. Nixon passed over Bush in picking Spiro Agnew as his running mate in 1968, but in 1970 he tapped the Texan as U.N. ambassador and three years later recruiting him as Republican national chairman. In that office, Bush finally wrote to the then-president: ``It is my considered judgment that you should now resign. ... I now feel that resignation is best for the country, best for this president.'' Bush, as president, has consulted several times with Nixon. At one point Thursday, he joked that Nixon's dog while he was vice president, Checkers, was ``Millie's role model.'' Millie is the Bush family's pet spaniel. Bush praised Nixon as the author of eight books, ``each composed on his famous yellow legal pads,'' and as a man who, ``like his favorite author, Tolstoy, admired the dignity of manual labor.'' He also praised Nixon's wife Pat as ``a mirror of America's heart and love.''

DOC.HEAD: Electrician's Manslaughter Conviction Leaves Industry Jittery
DOC.TEXT: The manslaughter conviction of an electrician whose faulty work caused a fatal fire has left other electricians worried that honest mistakes could lead to criminal prosecution. Richard E. Salz, 49, of East Haven, was convicted June 1 and faces sentencing Friday in Superior Court for second-degree manslaughter in the fire death of a 12-year-old boy. He faces a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison. Phil Simmons, executive director of the Park Ridge, Ill.-based International Association of Electrical Contractors, said he knew of no other case in which an electrician has been charged with manslaughter for a death resulting from his work. The boy, Burton Gorman III, died of smoke inhalation in a Dec. 28, 1988, house fire caused by a baseboard heating unit that Salz had improperly installed the month before. Besides failing to get a permit for the work, Salz ignored the manufacturer's instructions for installing the heater and committed more than a dozen electrical code violations, witnesses at his trial said. Salz connected the 120-volt heater to a 240-volt circuit box, doubling the amount of heat that was supposed to come from the heater, witnesses said. When the unit overheated, it ignited the wall paneling. Lou Acampora, president of the Connecticut Electrical Contractors Association, said that while Salz had shown a ``total disregard for safety,'' the conviction set a bad precedent. ``It puts a lot of good electricians in jeopardy for making a mistake,'' said Acampora, who said the heads of trade groups in neighboring New York also had expressed concern about the ruling. The case also has drawn the attention of electricians in other parts of the country, said Simmons, a former chief electrical inspector for the state of Washington. ``I hope it has a sobering effect and that people realize they will be held responsible for their actions,'' he said. Authorities involved in the prosecution said the fears of a precedent are unfounded. They say Salz, who at one time worked as a part-time electrical inspector, was charged only because he recklessly took actions he should have known would cause a fire hazard. ``This was not just John Q. Public making an honest mistake,'' said Lawrence Acquarulo, an assistant state building inspector who testified at Salz's jury trial. Salz's license as a contractor was revoked in July 1989, but the state Electrical Work Examining Board this spring gave him a journeyman's license allowing him to work under supervision.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Declares Optimism In War On Drugs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told civic leaders involved in fighting drugs that he thinks the tide is turning in the national war against illegal narcotics. Bush spent 45 minutes before a political fund-raiser for Republican Senate candidate Larry Craig in a roundtable discussion on drugs with Mayor Dirk Kempthorne and nine others. ``There are some signs that create a sense of optimism,'' said Bush, citing surveys that indicate cocaine use is down among high school seniors. ``I don't want to sound euphoric about it,'' he said, but ``we're making some headway.'' Kempthorne told Bush, ``Boise is not immune from the drug scourge. We have our tragedy as well as our triumphs.'' But he and other local leaders portrayed a city that has the police, educators, drug treatment experts and ordinary citizens pulling together. John Southworth, 52, a recovered cocaine addict who is now a licensed drug abuse counselor, told Bush his personal tale of recovery. ``Myself, I was allowed to manipulate the criminal justice with seven DUIs (driving under the influence) and received no alcohol-drug evaluation, no treatment or any education,'' he said. ``I ended up going to harder drugs. I started up with marijuana and ended up free-basing and selling cocaine.'' Finally, he got help and went into recovery 7{ years ago, Southworth said. ``Education doesn't work alone. Treatment doesn't work alone, and law enforcement doesn't work alone,'' he said. ``We must fight this problem together''. Bush appeared intrigued by the man's personal tale and asked if he found drugs readily available. ``They were for me. Birds of a feather flock together,'' said Southworth. ``There was no problem for a coke addict to find coke.'' ``Is that supply still as readily available, would you reckon?'' Bush asked. ``I've been sober for 7{ years, and I don't hang out with those people anymore,'' Southworth said, evoking laughter. But Police Chief James Carvino said, ``You can get drugs if you're looking to get drugs.'' Carvino also said the federal war on drugs has driven ``drug entrepreneurs'' to move their business to smaller cities. Greg Bower, the Ada County prosecutor, praised the work of a narcotics task force operating under a $200,000 federal grant, and urged Bush to keep up that support. ``Drug traffickers are afraid of the federal government. They're afraid of federal prosecutors and federal mandatory minimum sentences,'' Bower said. Bush said the war on drugs is not going to be won ``through mandated federal programs'' but community efforts like the one Boise is mounting. Kempthorne, the mayor, assured him that ``City Hall is ready to join your White House'' in the fight. Bush came to Idaho after attending the dedication of Richard M. Nixon's presidential library in Yorba Linda, Calif. He was leaving later Thursday for Billings, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Boggs Reportedly Retiring; Candidates Surveying Race
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Rep. Lindy Boggs scheduled a Friday news conference amid reports she will not run for re-election to the congressional seat she and her late husband have held for 46 years. Mrs. Boggs, 74 has been widely reported as planning to retire to spend more time with her daughter, Barbara Sigmund, who is suffering from cancer. Her office in Washington refused to confirm or deny the reports Thursday. Mrs. Boggs is the only white member of Congress representing a black-majority district. She has been on Capitol Hill 17 years; her husband Hale had held the seat for all but two terms starting in 1940. Mrs. Boggs took over the post in March 1973 after winning a special election to succeed her husband, the powerful House majority leader, whose plane disappeared during a flight over Alaska in 1972. The primary election for the 2nd Congressional District, which encompasses most of New Orleans, will be Oct. 6. A runoff, if needed, would be Nov. 6. At least two prominent candidates, both Democrats, hope to become Louisiana's first black congressman. State Sen. Jon Johnson kicked off his campaign in April. Marc Morial, a lawyer and the elder son of the late Mayor Dutch Morial, had a gala reception Thursday night to formally announce his candidacy. State Sen. William Jefferson has said he will probably enter the race if Mrs. Boggs steps out. Some analysts have predicted New Orleans Mayor Sidney Barthelemy might enter the race as well. Hale Boggs won the seat in 1940. He lost a re-election bid in 1942, but reclaimed the job in 1946. Boggs was one of the few Southern Democrats in Congress to support the civil rights movement in the 1960s.

DOC.HEAD: Wounded Samaritan Always Wanted to Help, Wife Says
DOC.TEXT: A man who was shot and critically wounded while responding to a stranger's scream for help has always tried to lend a hand to people in trouble, his wife said Thursday. ``That's how he is. He just cares about people. He doesn't want anybody to get hurt,'' Sandra Smith said of her husband, Gary. ``He'll always help anybody.'' Smith, 35, was shot in the face, arm, leg and abdomen Wednesday after confronting a fleeing burglar whose break-in was cut short by a resident who surprised him. Smith was in extremely critical condition Thursday at Scripps Memorial Hospital in this San Diego suburb, where he underwent three operations within 24 hours, hospital spokeswoman Edie High said. Two bullets remained lodged in his head and abdomen and his prognosis was guarded, meaning doctors didn't know whether his condition would improve or deteriorate. Smith was expected to undergo more operations, High said. Just three days before the shooting, Smith tried to help another crime victim, his wife told a hospital news conference. ``We were shopping (Sunday) at Mission Valley Center, and we heard a woman screaming in the underground parking lot,'' she said. ``Gary ran down the stairs to help, and found the woman had just had her purse taken by a purse snatcher.'' Mrs. Smith maintained a vigil at the hospital while friends and relatives cared for the couple's three children. She said she has seen her husband, but couldn't talk to him. If she could, ``I'd tell I love him and we need him,'' she said. Smith, who has two daughters and a son aged 9 months to 7 years old, was laying carpet in a San Diego condominium Wednesday when he heard a woman's scream from an adjacent unit, police Officer Robert Chorny said. The woman, Christiane Chazin, had arrived home to find her door unlocked and an intruder in the living room. The burglar, brandishing a gun, brushed past Mrs. Chazin and her 3-year-old son Daniel, warning them not to move, Chorny said. Smith arrived a moment later, and ran after the man. Police said they didn't know if Smith knew the man was armed. He caught up with the burglar a block and a half later, and after a brief struggle was shot at close range with a .22-caliber pistol, Chorny said. Police said they were pursuing a couple of leads in the case, including the attempted use of a credit card stolen from the Chazin home. The San Diego Police Officers Assocation donated 21 units of blood from its account at the San Diego Blood Bank to help Smith, said police Sgt. Willie P. Smith, no relation to Gary Smith. It was believed to be the first time the association has taken such action for someone other than a law enforcement officer, said Sgt. Smith, who is director of the association. ``The guy was trying to help. He put himself in jeopardy by trying to do a job we do all the time,'' the sergeant said. ``In essence, during that time he made himself one of us.''

DOC.HEAD: Murder Charge Dropped After 7-year Battle Over Paperwork Error
DOC.TEXT: A confessed killer who was acquitted because of a typing error in a police report will not be retried. Palm Beach Circuit Judge Marvin Mounts on Wednesday dismissed a first-degree murder charge against Frank ``Mr. Lucky'' Mars, ending years of legal wrangling over the case. In 1983, Mars confessed to murdering a friend but was acquitted because the time of death listed in a legal document submitted as evidence was off by 12 hours. The document said Mars shot Willie Berry between ``5 o'clock P.M. January 29, 1983 and 12:59 A.M. January 30, 1983.'' The entry should have read ``12:59 P.M.'' Testimony presented by prosecutors showed that Berry could not have been killed until after 1:30 a.m., when he left a party with Mars to buy cigarettes. When prosecutors sought to retry the case with corrected documents, the defense cited double-jeopardy objections and Mounts agreed. The case was appealed to the Florida Supreme Court and the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, which in March upheld Mounts' decision. He dismissed the charge Wednesday. ``You can't let your personal beliefs make your ruling,'' he said. ``The ruling must be based on the law.'' Mars' attorneys hailed the decision as a simple defense of a basic constitutional right. The double jeopardy clause of the Fifth Amendment provides that a person cannot be tried twice for the same offense. ``They were seeking to put my client in the electric chair,'' said Assistant Public Defender Cherry Grant. ``I'm sorry, but if you're going to kill someone, you'd better dot all your i's and cross all your t's.'' Mars is scheduled for release in 1991 from Glades Correctional Institution, where he is imprisoned for violating the terms of parole on an earlier conviction.

DOC.HEAD: Baby Found in Outhouse in Campground
DOC.TEXT: Stunned campers said they found a baby girl in an outhouse pit, where the crying newborn apparently had been abandoned for at least nine hours. ``Not in my worst nightmare did I think something like this could ever happen in this world,' said Cheryl Ramirez, one of the campers at the Lower Log Campground in east-central Arizona. Mary Lou Ramirez, Cheryl Ramirez' sister, said she thought she heard a whimper when she visited the privy around 5:30 a.m. Saturday. ``And I thought an animal, maybe a cat, had fallen in,'' she said.`` But I didn't think anything more about it right then and forgot about it.'' She returned to the privy around 2:30 p.m. ``I heard the cry again. And this time, I knew it couldn't be an animal. It had to be a baby.'' Mrs. Ramirez summoned her husband, Louie, and his brother, Ernie, who used a flashlight to find the baby. The infant was lying on her stomach, with her face turned to one side. The brothers raced to Hon Dah on the Fort Apache Indian Reservation eight miles to the northwest, and telephoned police. With help from the Ramirez brothers, police and fire personnel tipped over the outhouse and rescued the baby. The child was released Tuesday from Tucson Medical Center in Tucson, and was placed in temporary custody of the state Department of Economic Security's child protection services unit.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian Companies Sue U.S. For Looting Losses After Invasion
DOC.TEXT: Sixty Panamanian companies sued the U.S. government Thursday to recover more than $30 million in damages caused by vandalism and looting that occurred after last year's invasion. The lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan claims the U.S. violated international law and treaties by failing to provide security in Panama after the military action. The complaint also alleges that the U.S. military used excessive force that resulted in damage to some of the businesses. The four-page lawsuit did not contain specific incidents. The alleged acts of the U.S. government were ``all done in a tortuous, careless and negligent manner with disregard for the property of innocent Panamanian residents,'' the lawsuit said. U.S. military forces invaded Panama on Dec. 20 to overthrow Gen. Manuel Noriega and bring him to the U.S. to stand trial on drug charges. Looting that followed the invasion, which stripped all Panamanian security forces of power, cost companies between $1 billion and $2 billion. The plaintiffs are Panamanian stores and factories and foreign companies that lost about $30 million in damage, said Dennis T. D'Antonio, their New York lawyer. A State Department spokeswoman referred a request for comment to the Pentagon, where a duty officer said Thursday evening that no one was available.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Delegation Going to Luanda
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. delegation will go to Angola this weekend to confer with Angola's Marxist government about stalled peace talks with the country's U.S.-armed rebels and about efforts to feed more than a million hungry Angolans, the State Department said Thursday. Jeffrey Davidow, the No. 2 official in the department's African affairs bureau, Jim Woods of the Defense Department and two other officials will travel to Luanda on Saturday, the department said. Despite the urgency of providing food in both government and rebel-held territory, international relief efforts have been stalled by disagreement between the warring sides over supply routes. Several international donors have revoked their pledges because of backlogs at Angola's ports and pilfering of relief supplies. The International Committee of the Red Cross, leading the relief project, has decided that airlifts are too expensive and is trying to arrange safe passage through land corridors for trucks. The organization estimates 250,000 people are in immediate need and hundreds of thousands more are in less dire straits. Angola's government wants the food delivered via Port Namibe on its western coast and from there trucked to government and rebel areas. The UNITA rebels, led by U.S. protege Jonas Savimbi, want the food delivered through Namibia and Botswana, which border territory it controls in southern Angola. But the Angolan government says it is worried weapons could be smuggled to the rebels with the food. The U.S. team will tell the Angolans that the administration favors multiple routes for the supplies so that as much food as possible gets in, said a U.S. official who spoke on condition that his name not be used. It will also urge Angola to return to peace talks with the rebels, which broke off last month in Portugal and have not resumed, said the official. The United States has no formal diplomatic relations with Angola. Angola's ambassador to the United Nations, Manuel Pacavira, met Thursday with Davidow and other officials. He told reporters later that he had promised his government would protect all foreign relief convoys.

DOC.HEAD: Committee to Recommend Reprimand
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4th graf: ``The committee,'' and grafs 9-10: ``Among matters,'' to note non-sexual concerns
DOC.TEXT: The House ethics committee voted without dissent Thursday to recommend a reprimand of Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., for his relationship with male prostitute Stephen Gobie, according to sources familiar with the closed-door deliberations. The reprimand would be a more severe sanction against Frank than Democrats on the 12-member panel had been advocating. ``That's what people (in the House) were sort of expecting would happen,'' said one source. The committee was concerned not only with Frank's sexual relationship to Gobie but with actions he took on Gobie's behalf. Committee members refused to discuss the case and Frank refused to comment. One member, Rep. Larry Craig, R-Idaho, was back in his home state for a visit by President Bush and it was not known whether he had voted by proxy. The committee hurriedly left its meeting room after more than two hours of discussion. Members all but ignored reporters waiting outside. ``The committee is adjourned. I have no statement,'' said Rep. Julian Dixon, D-Calif., the committee chairman. The committee, which has been looking into the Frank case for 10 months, scheduled no new meetings. Among matters of concern to the committee were the fact that Frank wrote favorable letters on his congressional letterhead to court officials who were supervising Gobie's probation on several felony convictions. He also invoked congressional privilege to waive parking tickets incurred by Gobie while using Frank's car. Frank said he only sought to have the tickets waived when Gobie was using the car for official business. The recommendation would have to be voted on by the House. Reprimand is a relatively new punishment, having been used against six members since 1976, and simply consists of a vote to accept the committee report. The committee could have recommended the more severe censure, used before 1976, in which the member must stand before his colleagues as a resolution condemning his behavior is read. Or it could have recommended expulsion, which no one expected. First word of the committee's decision was broadcast by CBS and NBC in their evening news programs. The House committee's action comes a day after its Senate counterpart recommended that the Senate denounce Sen. Dave Durenberger, R-Minn., for financial misconduct and require him to pay $124,000 to the Senate or to charities as restitution. The case has been one of the most difficult ever considered by the ethics panel, because what it dealt with was personal behavior rather than official duties. Conservatives on the 12-member panel have been holding out for a strong punishment, which would involve a vote by the full House criticizing Frank's behavior. When the case first became public late last summer, Frank admitted that he paid Gobie $80 for sex in 1985 and then hired him as a housekeeper and driver with personal funds. He said he fired Gobie in August 1987 after learning that Gobie was running a prostitution ring out of Frank's Capitol Hill apartment. Frank has repeatedly denied Gobie's allegation that he was aware of the prostitution long before he ended the relationship. In past cases, the committee has voted and not released the decision for a day or two. Dixon touched off speculation that the panel may have done just that Thursday when he said, without being asked, that he would not comment on any votes the committee may or may not have taken. But neither Dixon nor other members would discuss the deliberations. Frank, in an interview in his office, said he had not received word from any committee member on Thursday's meeting. He declined to discuss the committee deliberations and said he had no idea when the panel planned to meet again. ``I have gotten no word, official or unofficial,'' Frank said. The committee, made up of six Democrats and six Republicans, had been deadlocked on the severity of punishment Frank should receive. Democrats reportedly wanted to issue a letter of reproval, one of the mildest sanctions possible because it would not require a vote of the full House on Frank's conduct. Republican committee members had pushed for a tougher sanction. Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., has said he would seek a vote to expel Frank if the ethics committee sought a lesser sanction. Frank, a five-term liberal Democrat representing a group of Boston suburbs, is one of two acknowledged homosexual members of the House. He is seeking re-election in a race against Republican John Soto, who has never held public office and who was soundly defeated two years ago in a bid for state representative in his home town.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Official: Government Would Buy Land Claimed by Mohawks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with federal official qualifying earlier report of agreement, other Indian protests. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Canada's minister of Indian affairs said Thursday that the government is ready to buy a land tract claimed as ancestral territory by armed Mohawks, but told the Indians they must first lay down their weapons. Earlier in the day, an Indian spokeswoman demanded the federal government provide additional guarantees over a parcel of land that municipal leaders want to build a golf course addition on before the Mohawks would put down their arms. The standoff centers on a 55-acre tract in Oka, a town 18 miles west of Montreal where the addition is planned. A federal purchase or expropriation of the disputed land would block the project, which the Indians oppose. The Indians have barricaded themselves at the site for four months.The confrontation has left one police officer dead and prompted an anti-Indian backlash. It was not clear if the officer was shot to death on July 11 by fellow police or Indians. At his news conference Thursday in Ottawa, Indian Affairs Minister Tom Siddon said the federal government ``is prepared to pursue the acquisition of that land'' to settle the Mohawk claim. He said expropriation could be used by the province if necessary. He added that Ottawa recognizes the inadequacy of the Mohawk land base at Oka as a problem to be resolved. The Mohawks live in a centuries-old community there, but it has not been recognized by the federal government as a bona fide reservation. Siddon insisted, however, that the process of land acquisition ``is a very long way down the road.'' ``We won't talk while there are barricades, and we won't talk in circumstances where firearms are used to provoke negotiations,'' Siddon told reporters. His remarks threw some cold water on an announcement earlier in the day by a provincial official. At the earlier news conference in Montreal, Quebec's native affairs minister, John Ciaccia, said federal officials have approved the purchase or expropriation of the tract of forest. However, he made no mention of the federal demand that the Indians lay down their weapons before any more talks. In remarks after Ciaccia's announcement, Indian negotiator Ellen Gabriel said that before any land deal, several earlier Mohawk conditions to end the armed standoff must be met. They include allowing the shipment of food, water, clothing, bedding and medical supplies to the Indians, as well as granting entry to independent observers from the United Nations or Amnesty International, a human rights group. The Mohawk spokeswoman demanded a 48-hour grace period to allow any Mohawks behind barricades to leave without police interference. ``There are demands to be met, and we're ready to continue as long as it takes,'' she said. Solicitor General Pierre Cadieux, at the news conference with Siddon, said ``If you're asking me my personal opinion, there should not be any amnesty.'' In recent days, Indian leaders and provincial officials have been stepping up pressure for the federal government in Ottawa to intervene in the dispute. Indian groups across Canada rallied to the aid of the Mohawks on Thursday. Indians from the Grand Rapids reserve near Lake Winnipeg in the central province of Manitoba set up a blockade, closing a main highway. In Ontario province, Ojibway Indians slowed traffic on the Trans-Canada Highway near Georgian Bay. Since the shootout, Mohawks at the Kahnawake reservation have been demonstrating their sympathy by blocking a bridge between Montreal and its southern suburbs. Local residents have vented their anger at the bridge blockade with protests and racist slurs. On Tuesday, the residents broke through police barriers there but stopped when confronted by 100 officers standing shoulder-to-shoulder. No injuries were reported.
