DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CS7, CS9
DOC.TEXT: Explosions ripped through a chemical plant Thursday, killing one person, injuring as many as 63 others and shattering windows in houses and businesses up to a quarter-mile away, authorities said. The two explosions ignited a fire that took 2{ hours to contain enough so that firefighters could enter the four-story brick building. The blast sent fireballs 50 feet into the sky. A column of thick, black smoke poured from the building into the surrounding residential neighborhood. Some of the injured were cut by shattered glass at a supermarket. Fire Chief Bill Miller said the plant had accounted for all its employees. He said up to 63 people were injured. Area hospitals said they were treating 56 people; four were critically injured. About 1,000 people were evacuated from houses in the neighboring incorporated area of Norwood for the night while authorities checked for structural damage, said Norwood safety director Darryll Maxwell. He said six homes had been declared uninhabitable. Air tests performed by the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency around the plant found no toxic gases in the smoke, Miller said. About 200 people work at the BASF Corp. plant, which makes linings for cans and coatings for paper cups. The building contained about 50 chemicals, including explosive solvents and varnishes, workers at the scene said. Volatile and explosive solvents may have leaked from a mixing vat and been ignited by a spark, said Malcolm Adcock, an assistant health commissioner. But he stressed this was merely a hypothesis. Kenneth D. Diedenhofer, a BASF production manager, said the company was investigating the possibility of a ``pressure buildup'' of chemicals in equipment that was being cleaned. Dan Delaney, who works near the plant, said he saw a huge ball of fire and smoke out his office window. ``Shortly thereafter, everybody was running down the street, out of the building to get out, sort of in a panic, just getting out of there as fast as they could,'' Delaney said. ``Police and firemen are all around, fighting the blaze,'' he said. ``They just keep getting small explosions and more fireballs shooting up in the air.'' Ken Kinderman, 29, a materials handler at the factory, said he was walking out of a locker room in an adjacent building when the explosion occurred. ``I opened the door and when the explosion hit, it threw me back through the locker room,'' Kinderman said. He said he had cuts on his back and arms, but was not seriously injured. Kinderman said the building where the explosion occurred was used for handling solvents and varnishes. ``I saw the flames shoot from the other building into mine. The whole back of my building is gone,'' Kinderman said. Windows also were shattered at some houses three blocks away. Whalen identified the dead man as Lawrence H. Krechting, 58, an employee at the plant. Most of the injured, including an 8-year-old boy, sustained minor injuries, hospital officials said. Four people were in critical condition at the University of Cincinnati Hospital, said spokesman David Bracey. Diedenhofer said he was in a lab next door when the explosion occurred about 2:15 p.m. ``It blew out all the windows. The whole resin building was engulfed in flames,'' Diedenhofer said. ``I couldn't get in to help anyone. I saw one person hanging on to the building. I was able to get him off.'' Windows in homes and storefronts as much as a quarter mile from the plant were blown out. The second blast occurred about 2:50 p.m., and it was that blast that did most of the apparent damage, Diedenhofer said. Diedenhofer said about 200 people work at the plant, which makes linings for cans. Dan Lawrence, a student at Summit Country Day School more than a mile from the blast site, said he was working at the school when the blast shook his building. Lawrence said he thought an earthquake had struck.

DOC.HEAD: International Bar Association Scraps Nairobi as Convention Site
DOC.TEXT: The International Bar Association announced Thursday it has canceled plans to hold its annual convention in Nairobi, Kenya, because it cannot guarantee delegates' safety. Executive Director Madeleine May said the association was also concerned ``about the state of human rights and the rule of law in Kenya'' following civil disturbances this month. The convention will instead be held in New York City Sept. 19-23, she said. ``Safety of delegates is paramount and following three days of serious unrest in Nairobi and other central areas from 7-9 July 1990, which left some 25 dead and many more injured, I and my fellow officers feel that such safety cannot be guaranteed,'' Ms. May said in a letter to more than 1,000 delegates. ``Everywhere is now peaceful but we cannot be sure this will be the case in September. ``Another matter of great concern to us is the state of human rights and the rule of law in Kenya. A number of persons are detained without being charged, including four lawyers, at least one of whom was arrested when he went to a police station to interview his client.'' The letter continued, ``Many hold the view that by proceeding with our conference the IBA would be lending support to a regime that has suppressed those attempting peacefully to express their political views and exercise their internationally recognized human rights.'' The association, founded in 1947 and now with more than 13,000 members, describes itself as the largest international forum for lawyers. The human rights organization Africa Watch issued a news release in New York, its headquarters, saying it ``applauds the decision'' of the association. Africa Watch, a division of the private Human Rights Watch that monitors abuses around the world, said ``the arrest, exile and harassment of human rights lawyers makes Kenya a singularly inappropriate venue for a meeting'' of such an organization as the International Bar Association.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish-Language News Teams Left Out Of Quayle Interview Coverage
DOC.TEXT: Spanish-language television stations excluded from interviews Thursday in which Vice President Dan Quayle discussed a job bias bill attacked the action as insensitive and demanded explanations. ``I just don't understand the reason. If they don't want to deal with the Hispanics, then that's pretty stupid,'' said Angelica Figueroa, news producer at KVDA, an affiliate of the Spanish-language network Telemundo. ``The irony of the thing is he was talking here about a discrimination bill passed by the Senate,'' said KWEX News Director Ed Barrera, whose station is an affiliate of the Spanish-language Univision network, Telemundo's competitor. A spokesman for Quayle, who in the interviews discussed his opposition to a bias bill passed in the Senate Wednesday night, said no station was intentionally left out. Affiliates of ABC, CBS and NBC were invited to interview Quayle at a San Antonio hotel Thursday morning after he spoke with newspaper and radio reporters. Two cameras were allowed to tape the interview and were asked to share the videotape with others who were present, said reporters who attended. A reporter from the Mexican network ECO also was allowed in after protesting his exclusion, reporters said. Barrera said his station had asked before Quayle's visit about covering the event and was not told of the Thursday interviews. He later learned there was a press pool only for the three English-language networks, and called Quayle's press office to complain. ``Some guy said, `That's the way we do it,' and that was it,'' Barrera said. ``I think it's discrimination.'' A Quayle spokesman who spoke on condition he not be identified said the interview was not open to all news organizations and that a limited number of local stations routinely are invited to interview Quayle when he travels. Ms. Figueroa said she wouldn't call the action discrimination, but said it was ``very insensitive,'' especially in a city of 1 million people where more than 50 percent are Hispanic. ``If they're trying to pick up the vice president's image, it was a very dumb thing to do,'' she said. She and Barrera said that even though Quayle doesn't answer questions in Spanish, they wanted videotape of him and to be in on the interviews. Quayle's spokesman said that when KWEX asked about press coverage of Quayle, the station was told only the vice president's arrival and departure would be open to all news media. He said KWEX covered Quayle's arrival, and was invited to cover the vice president's motorcade. ``The bottom line here is somebody's trying to make something out of nothing,'' he said. ``We can't include everybody.'' Texas Republican Pary Chairman Fred Meyer said Barrera called him to complain. Meyer then called Quayle's office. ``We, as a Republican Party, are interested in all the media,'' Meyer said. ``I'm sure that the vice president would not want to overlook these kinds of things, and none of us as Republicans do.''

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Police Officer Used Hot Iron to Torture Drug Suspect
DOC.TEXT: A report that a police officer tortured a drug suspect with a hot iron during questioning has prompted calls from the NAACP and other community groups Thursday for the police chief to resign. The groups urged the U.S. Justice Department to investigate the incident, which is already being investigated by the police department's Internal Affairs Bureau. The Dayton Daily News, citing police investigative records, reported Wednesday that officer John Gamble last January used the iron to scorch David Greer three or four times while another officer pinned Greer face-up to a mattress. Gamble kept asking the 18-year-old a question until Greer told him what he wanted to know after Gamble threatened to burn his genitals, the newspaper said. Greer later pleaded guilty to aggravated drug trafficking, and was sentenced to three to 15 years in prison. Both Greer and Gamble are black. Gamble denied burning Greer until two other officers acknowledged June 7 that it had taken place, the Daily News said. Gamble made a tape-recorded statement to police July 6. ``I did it,'' the newspaper quoted Gamble as saying. ``I'm not proud of it. It happened. There's nothing I can do about it now. I wish it didn't, but it did, and it's time for me to deal with it.'' Montgomery County Prosecutor Lee Falke announced he had appointed a special prosecutor to determine whether criminal charges were warranted. The Daily News story triggered calls Thursday for the resignation of Police Chief James Newby by local chapters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and the Urban League, as well as the Interdenominational Ministerial Alliance. ``We are outraged and disappointed, but not surprised at this latest incident of police brutality and the subsequent attempt to cover up this brutal act,'' said NAACP chapter President Jessie Gooding. ``This highlights the pattern of ongoing police brutality and injustice in the Dayton Police Department.'' The Rev. William T. Head, an investigator for the NAACP, said Newby is responsible for his officers' actions. ``Finally, the community has knowledge that the police are not above lying and are not above committing illegal acts,'' said Head. ``It's time for Chief Newby to step aside.'' Head, who has led efforts to investigate other alleged instances of police brutality, said the officer's race was irrelevant. ``He's a policeman,'' Head said. ``He's wrong.'' Newby declined to comment on the call for his resignation. ``There was no coverup,'' he said, pointing out that the investigation was initiated by the police department and that the information reported by the newspaper was uncovered by police investigators. Newby said that when he first learned of the allegations, his reaction was ``somewhere between (being) sick to my stomach (and) disgust.'' He said he expects to announce some disciplinary action Friday. County Prosecutor Falke said prosecutors first became aware of the allegations against Gamble last March, but were skeptical and decided to wait until the police department completed its investigation. ``My assistant just couldn't believe it,'' Falke said.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaragua's Ortega Says More Sandinista Strikes Possible
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with rally, Ortega speech, details. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MGA3
By DORALISA PILARTE
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Former President Daniel Ortega said Thursday the fight wasn't over and more unrest could result if the conservative government doesn't stick to accords reached last week after a violent Sandinista strike. Ortega spoke at a rally celebrating the 11th anniversary of the popular insurrection that ended the 45-year Somoza family dictatorship. ``The struggle had not concluded,'' he told thousands of people at a plaza. ``We were able to defend that conquest of the revolution, but the struggle has not ended ... with the accord between the government and the workers; (or) with those who have extremist positions, who want to disavow the accords.'' Ortega was refering to the firing of more than 100 Managua municipal workers after the strike ended July 11. Broad concessions won by the the strikers included a promise by the government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro not to fire those taking part in the walkout. Clashes during the strike between heavily armed Sandinistas and government supporters killed at least six people and wounded more than 100. Ortega warned government officials to ``proceed with caution because they are provoking more conflicts.'' ``Now we have to defend democracy against those who want to return to Somocism,'' he said, adding that extremists within the government ``want to see our heads rolls, but if any heads roll it will be theirs.'' The Chamorro government, which ended a decade of Sandinista rule April 25, declared Thursday a national holiday but did not hold public celebrations. Mrs. Chamorro accused the Sandinistas of trying to restore a dictatorship. She said in a televised speech Wednesday night that all Nicaraguans had supported the revolution of July 19, 1979, because ``we all believed that we were breaking the gate of a tyranny to enter the promised land of democracy and freedom ... ``Unfortunately the revolution was confiscated by an exclusive party with a totalitarian ideology it had kept hidden. Instead of democracy, dictatorship rose again like a cadaver.'' Sandinista supporters shooting machine guns and other weapons into the air cruised Managua streets at dawn Thursday to kick off the festivities, and shouted the newest Sandinista slogan: ``The revolution continues; not one step back!'' In an apparent attempt to draw people away from the Sandinista rally, Nicaragua's only TV station, government-run Channel 6, scheduled back-to-back movies all day, including ``Batman,'' ``The Fly'' and ``Crocodile Dundee.'' But neither movies nor rain kept away the crowds, estimated by reporters at about 40,000, half the attendance projected by Sandinista officials. Last year's July 19th Sandinista rally drew about 100,000 people, but many were government workers compelled to attend or risk losing their job. Mrs. Chamorro said ``bad Nicaraguans'' want this July 19 ``not to signify democracy, but military dictatorship again,'' and asked the people to support her. ``I want to teach those who only know violence the benefits of respecting (legal) rights and of brotherly love.'' Managua residents awakened to the sounds of fire from machine guns, pistols and AK-47s in nearly every neighborhood. The noise smacked of the day 11 years ago when Sandinista leaders and others who fought dictator Anastasio Somoza rode triumphant into Managua to celebrate the secret flight two days earlier of the last of the Somozas. Chamorro supporters say the president should have taken a tougher stance with the strikers, and Mrs. Chamorro alluded to that in her speech. ``It is difficult to educate those who have been fanaticized by violence and terror,'' she said. ``We carry an inheritance of barbarian aggression that almost destroyed Managua in a few hours. ``But we must prove to them the value of peace and the well-being that freedom brings and the greatness we can achieve working together as brothers.'' Mrs. Chamorro was on the original five-member Sandinista junta. She is the most prominent of those Nicaraguans who backed the Sandinistas in their early years but became disenchanted.

DOC.HEAD: Visit of Two Presidents to End Waldheim Isolation
DOC.TEXT: Presidents Richard von Weizsaecker of West Germany and Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia will meet Kurt Waldheim July 26, ending four years of near-isolation for Austria's head of state, officials said Wednesday. Waldheim has been barred from entering the United States and largely shunned by world diplomats for concealing his wartime service in Yugoslavia and Greece as an intelligence officer with the invading army of Nazi Germany. The Czechoslovak Charter 77 human rights movement, which was instrumental in strengthening the opposition and toppling Communist rule in Czechoslovakia last year, called on Havel to cancel his visit to Austria and avoid meeting Waldheim, the Czechoslovak state news agency CTK reported. In an open letter addressed to Havel, Charter 77 representatives said that by snubbing Waldheim, ``the international community voted for truth and ethics, i.e. for those political principles on which Vaclav Havel based his mandate.'' The letter asked Havel, a co-founder of the dissident movement established in 1977, to publish the reasons that led him to make ``such a serious step or to reconsider his visit,'' CTK said. President Georgios Vassiliou of Cyprus met Waldheim in early July, the only Western head of state up to now to officially visit the Austrian president. Weizsaecker and Havel will see Waldheim, the former secretary-general of the United Nations, at the opening of the annual Salzburg Festival, Waldheim spokesman Kurt Skalnik said. Havel's arrival had been in doubt. The Prague daily Lidove Noviny said Wednesday that Havel would not make the trip, but CTK quoted Havel's press spokesman as saying the president would visit Salzburg on the agreed date. In a report issued in February 1987, a world commission of historians did not find that Waldheim was implicated in World War II crimes, but said he must have known about wartime atrocities committed by his unit. Waldheim denies any wrongdoing. He says charges directed against him by the World Jewish Congress and other international critics were aimed at keeping him from being elected president, and after that failed, at forcing him to resign.

DOC.HEAD: Seabrook, Battleground for Nuclear Future, Reaches Full Power
DOC.TEXT: The $6.6 billion Seabrook nuclear power plant went to full power Thursday for the first time in the 22-year history of the project, a major battleground in the fight over nuclear power. The reactor reached 1,150 megawatts, enough power for 1 million homes, at 9:52 p.m., according to plant spokesman Ron Sher. ``Reaching full power fulfills the dream we have all worked so hard to achieve,'' said Edward Brown, president of New Hampshire Yankee, the plant's operator. For plant opponents, the milestone was the latest in a rapid series of disappointments since the decade-late plant received its commercial operating license in March from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. ``What they're doing now is another step in the long process of the abuse of power,'' said Roy Morrison, spokesman for the anti-nuclear Clamshell Alliance. ``It's a complete disregard of the public safety. The plant is unsafe. It's operating in a place where there is no evacuation possible.'' The group will distribute leaflets at nearby Hampton Beach on Sunday, but no other protests were planned, said another Clamshell spokesman, Sam Miller. More than 3,200 people have been arrested in anti-Seabrook protests that began even before ground was broken for the project in 1976. Hampton Beach, a focus for Seabrook foes who argue there is no way to safely evacuate the area, was crowded with beachgoers Thursday as temperatures climbed into the 90s. Tom McDermott, 28, of Lowell, Mass., said he felt plant operators had ``everything pretty much under control or they wouldn't be going up to full power. I guess I'm just relying on them to take care of it, to let us know if something's wrong.'' Gloria Flanders is a Hampton Beach regular from Amesbury, one of six Massachusetts towns within Seabrook's 10-mile emergency zone. She said she comes to the shore on weekdays, but will avoid it on weekends, when crowds are bigger. ``A lot of people are paranoid,'' she said. ``I'm not paranoid. I'm just uncomfortable.'' Cliff Moss, co-owner of the New Yorker Bed & Breakfast, is neither. An inspector at Niagara Mohawk's nuclear plant in Oswego, N.Y., for six years, Moss said he has confidence in Seabrook's safety systems. So does Jack O'Brien, whose gas station is practically in the plant's back yard. ``Seabrook has been scrutinized under the biggest microscopes for years,'' he said. Full power ``should've happened eight years ago.'' Public Service Co. shelved a nuclear plant proposal in 1969, but three years later proposed Seabrook as a twin-reactor plant with a cost of less than $1 billion. Construction delays and cost increases forced owners to scrap Seabrook 2 in the mid-1980s, and pushed lead owner Public Service into bankruptcy reorganization in 1988. As New Hampshire's governor during the 1980s, White House Chief of Staff John Sununu played a major role in keeping the project alive. Under the plant's emergency plans, a summertime peak population of 247,000 would be moved out of the 10-mile emergency zone in an accident. Critics say that's impossible without an unacceptably high risk of exposure to radiation. Plant supporters and the NRC disagree. One of the chief opponents is Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis. Massachusetts has refused to take part in emergency planning for its six communities in the emergency zone. Two of the 17 New Hampshire communities involved, Kensington and Rye, also are not participating.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed When Sides Of Pit Cave In At Construction Site
DOC.TEXT: Three construction workers died under several feet of dirt Wednesday when a pit caved in, authorities said. The workers were in a hole dug to accommodate a concrete pipe, said Jones County Civil Defense spokesman Don McKinnon. McKinnon, who was one of the first people to reach the cave-in described a chain-reaction disaster that left the men buried under 15 feet to 20 feet of dirt. ``A mound of dirt had fell and pinned the legs of one of the men,'' McKinnon said. ``The other two ran over to help him and they about had him free when it all caved in.''

DOC.HEAD: South Korea Asks Free Travel, End of Cold War with North Korea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10 grafs for 3-9 bgng `Acceptance by' to UPDATE with no reax from North, comment by dissident group, Roh quote. Picks up graf 10 pvs, `The Korean...'
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo called on Friday for an end to Cold War on the Korean peninsula and proposed unrestricted travel between communist North Korea and South Korea. ``The time has come to end total division,'' Roh said in a major nationwide radio and television broadcast. ``Korea must not remain the world's only land still partitioned by Cold War politics.'' There was no immediate reaction from North Korea. Acceptance by North Korea would open the peninsula for the first time since 1945 and set the stage for national unification. Roh noted in the speech that President Kim Il Sung of North Korea proposed conditional free travel on Jan. 1, and said, ``I am convinced there will be no obstacle.'' Roh said South Korea would open its border at Panmunjom in the Demilitarized Zone for five days as of Aug. 13 and ``accept breathren from the North without restrictions.'' Roh said North Koreans would be allowed to freely visit any place in the South and meet anyone they want. He challenged North Korea to offer the same provisions to South Koreans. He said that ``in the near future'' foreigners would be permitted to freely travel across the border, a move which might allow tourists and could be expected to speed up the easing of tensions between the Koreas. ``A tide of openness and reconciliation has torn away the Iron Curtain separating the East and the West and is now shaping a new world in which nations are cooperating with each other regardless of differences in ideology and political systems,'' he said. ``Even if North Korea cannot agree to mutual exchanges at this time for some unavoidable reason, we will one-sidely open our society competely,'' Roh declared. South Koreans reacted by welcoming the president's announcement. But many doubted totalitarian North Korea, one of the last remaining closed societies, would allow its citizens to visit the South. The United National Movement for Democracy, South Korea's largest dissident group, called the border proposal ``a step forward.'' It also demanded the immediate release of political prisoners in South Korea, including a student and pastor jailed for travel to North Korea. Roh's Cabinet will meet Saturday to review proceedures for allowing travel to take place. South Korean law now makes it a violation of national security to visit North Korea without government permission, which has been rarely given. The Korean peninsula was divided into communist North and capitalist South in 1945 at the end of World War II. The two fought a bitter three-year civil and ideological war in the early 1950s and have remained hostile. ``The fact that compatriots in the South and North are still unable to visit each other is a shame on us who are a proud people with a rich cultural heritage that has evolved over many millenniums. Such a state of affairs should not continue any longer,'' he said. Both North and South Korea have talked about free travel, but have never negotiated it. The border has remained tightly closed to virtually all travel, mail and telephone communication for more than four decades. Two weeks ago, North Korea announced it would open a portion of its border for restricted passage within a small border area beginning Aug. 15. The Korean peninsula was freed from 35 years of Japanese colonial rule on Aug. 15, 1945, and the day is historically symbolic to both Koreas. The proposal by both Koreas calls for the border to be opened at Panmunjom, the truce village in the Demilitarized Zone that divides the peninsula in half. Panmunjom, about 35 miles north of Seoul, is the site of periodic North-South talks. Panmunjom is inaccessible to the average Korean citizen from either side. The border between the Koreas is the most heavily fortified in the world with more than 1 million armed soldiers behind concrete bunkers and barbed wire. The southern half of the Panmunjom area is guarded by the U.S.-led United Nations Command. The command has said that it would honor the wishes of the Koreans regarding a border opening. In 1985, the Koreas exchanged 151 citizens from both sides for a four-day family exchange but the visits were limited to the capitals of the two nations. The two Koreas are to sign an agreement July 26 setting a date for their first prime ministers' talks expected to be held in Seoul in September. ``Consider how magnificent and great an age the 21st century could be for our people if only the country is unified and the 70 million Korans become one again,'' the president said. South Korea has about 43 million residents, while North Korea has a population of about 22 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Dunkirk Veterans Turn Out for Queen, Heat Takes Toll
DOC.TEXT: Veterans of the Dunkirk evacuation in World War II marked its 50th anniversary on Wednesday with a parade before Queen Elizabeth II, but the heat took its toll. One woman fainted while sitting in the reviewing stand near the queen and was taken away by stretcher. The parade was held in the garrison town of Aldershot, 35 miles southwest of London. First-aid was given to about 25 people affected by the 88-degree temperatures. ``Some of them thought they were back in the desert again,'' said Maj. Gen. John Carpenter, chairman of the Dunkirk Veterans Association. Some of those on parade also fought in the desert campaign in which British and U.S. armies drove German and Italian forces from North Africa. ``To all of you the country owes a great debt of gratitude,'' the queen told the 2,000 parading veterans, some in wheelchairs pushed by young paratroopers. The main anniversary celebrations were held in late May, climaxing with a ragtag flotilla of 50 vessels making their way across the English Channel from the French port of Dunkirk to Ramsgate, England. Over 10 days in May and June 1940, British, Dutch, French and Belgian warships and civilian craft evacuated 338,000 British, French and Belgian troops from Dunkirk, which was surrounded after the Germans broke through across northern France. Those saved amid the bombs and gunfire helped form the nucleus of the victorious allied armies which invaded Normandy in June 1944. For morale purposes, Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill ordered the Dunkirk defeat to be announced as a deliverance and it has since been regarded in Britain as something of a miracle. The queen and her husband Prince Philip later met some veterans after the parade. ``What are you all standing around here for? The bar's open,'' said Philip, gesturing toward a drinks tent.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Extremists Kill Policeman in Egypt
DOC.TEXT: Moslem fundamentalists stabbed a policeman to death on Wednesday in southern Assiut province, the Middle East News Agency said. One suspect was arrested and police were searching for others who fled, the state-run news agency quoted the province's security chief, Maj. Gen. Mahmoud el-Fakhrany, as saying. The policeman was attacked with knives and swords in Deirout, about 190 miles south of Cairo. Last Friday, two Moslem extremists were killed and nine wounded in a clash with police in Deirout. Five police were also wounded. Police sources said the clash followed an attack on a wedding party by Moslem fundamentalists who were protesting the presence of a belly dancer and band. The fundamentalists view such activities as violations of Islamic teachings. Moslem fundmentalists demand the immediate application of Islamic law in Egypt. They have been involved in numerous violent incidents in the past few years, mostly in Cairo and southern Egypt.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Whales Died of Natural Causes
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-three gray whales that washed up on the Trinity Islands in the Gulf of Alaska recently probably died of natural causes, federal officials said. The National Marine Fisheries Service decision against taking tissue samples for tests drew fire from some environmentalists. Critics said the endangered mammals should be tested to see if they ingested oil from the Exxon Valdez oil spill in nearby Prince William Sound. ``We have no reason to think at this point that it's anything other than natural mortality,'' Steve Zimmerman of the fisheries service said Tuesday from Juneau. He noted the whales had migrated several thousand miles from their feeding area in the Bering Sea to the Mexican coast last fall, then returned. ``Any that are physiologically weak are going to have problems toward the end of that long migration,'' he said. He said the number of fatalities was high, but the whales could have died of old age, parasites, genetic defects, marginal feeding and exhaustion, among other possibilities. Environmentalists have expressed concern because gray whales feed on the ocean's bottom, where weathered oil would sink and accumulate in sediments. ``Grays are the first ones to get nailed if there are tar balls on the bottom,'' said Cindy Lowry, Alaska director of Greenpeace. ``I'm going to encourage them to take not only tissue samples but stomach samples as well. This is an endangered species _ they should be taking it seriously. That's too many whales dying in the same place.'' Biologists from the fisheries service and the University of Alaska Fairbanks examined 14 of the whales Sunday and Monday on Tugidak Island, about 350 miles south of Anchorage. Of the 14 whales on Tugidak, one apparently was the victim of a killer whale, they said. Two apparently had been dead since last year, and one of the 14 was a calf or yearling.

DOC.HEAD: Four Police Officials Die in Helicopter Crash near Lima
DOC.TEXT: A helicopter carrying four police officials crashed into a barren hill outside Lima, killing the occupants, an Interior Ministry spokesman said Wednesday. Mechanical failure is thought to have caused the crash, which occurred Tuesday afternoon near Nnana, a town 14 miles east of Lima, the spokesman said. Interior Minister Augustin Mantilla immediately ordered an investigation of the accident, the spokesman said. A police commander was among those killed, he said. The helicopter was one of six recently purchased by the police from a West German manufacturer, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Professor Who Denied Holocaust Suspended For One Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to RECAST lead to mention magazine article, Notin's reaction; ADDS background on damages award to anti-racism group. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `The article...'
DOC.TEXT: A university professor who questioned the existence of Nazi gas chambers in a magazine article lost a disciplinary hearing Wednesday and was suspended from his job for one year. Bernard Notin will draw only half-salary during his suspension as an economics and law instructor at Jean Moulin University-Lyon III, the university's disciplinary committee ruled. Notin is a leading member of Jean-Marie Le Pen's far-right National Front party, which favors expelling immigrants from France. Le Pen once called the Holocaust a ``detail'' of history. ``This punishment for my ideas, that they've purposely turned into caricatures while forgetting about my years of teaching and research, can only leave a bitter taste in the mouths of free men,'' Notin said, following the committee's ruling. He then asked his fellow citizens to show tolerance toward him. The decision comes a week after an anti-racism group won an award of 20,000 francs, or $3,623, as damages against Notin in a civil complaint based on the same magazine piece. The article Notin wrote for the review Economy and Society in January created a national uproar that led to a clash between the university and Mayor Michel Noir, who is bitterly opposed to the National Front. The mayor threatened to cancel the city's plans to donate a building to the university, named for a leader of the Resistance, unless Notin was fired. The university initially said Notin's opinions were protected by academic freedom but eventually set in course the process leading to the disciplinary hearing. ``The mayor of Lyon has already given the verdict in advance,'' Notin said as the hearing began Tuesday. ``He has the money, he buys universities. I don't have anything to stand up to that.'' Notin's lawyer, Gilbert Collard, said he would appeal the verdict and ask that a new hearing be held outside Lyon. Notin's article said that visiting concentration camps is a ``hardly credible'' way to prove the gas chambers existed, and described accounts by Holocaust survivors as ``hearsay.'' It outraged Jewish leaders, students and Holocaust survivors. In March, 60 people took over Notin's classroom and conducted a lesson on Hitler's extermination program. Fears of an outbreak of anti-Semitism peaked in May after the desecration of a Jewish cemetery at Carpentras, where a recently buried corpse was dug up. No one has accused Notin of spreading his ideas in the classroom. But the article was signed by Notin and listed his title as a professor at the university. Though his suspension will last only one year, university faculty members say privately it is unlikely Notin will be allowed to return. Under French law, it is a crime punishable by fine to claim that the Holocaust never existed.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Urges CDC to Set Stricter Limits on Lead in Blood
DOC.TEXT: An advisory committee told the federal government it should tighten the standard for safe levels of lead in blood. New research shows that even low levels of lead in the blood contribute to childhood learning disabilities and high school dropout rates, the 14-member committee told the Atlanta-based Centers for Disease Control on Tuesday. Currently the CDC's standard calls for medical intervention and environmental controls when someone's blood contains 25 or more micrograms per deciliter. The committee recommended continuing the standard for medical intervention, but said environmental controls should be considered whenever screening shows a level of 10 micrograms per deciliter in children, said Dr. Paul Mushak, a professor of environmental pathology at the University of North Carolina.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explodes in Front of Police Station in Medellin Suburb
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded Wednesday in front of a suburban Medellin police station, wounding one person and causing extensive damage, officials said. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the blast, but authorities blame drug traffickers for a long series of bombings and assassinations in Colombia. The bomb was placed in a push cart carrying mangos outside a municipal building that houses the mayor's office and police station, Colombian Red Cross official Arturo Arenas told the RCN radio network. Drug traffickers are engaged in an all-out war against Medellin policemen. So far this year, they have been blamed for killing more than 150 law officers in the Medellin area. They are also blamed for five car bombs that have exploded in the city this year, killing at least 60 people.

DOC.HEAD: Fashion Editor Madge Garland Dies at 92
DOC.TEXT: Lady Ashton, better known as Madge Garland, who was fashion editor of English Vogue in the 1930s and founded the Royal College of Art's Fashion School, has died, according to news reports Wednesday. She was 92. She had been cared for at a London convent in recent years and died Sunday, The Times of London reported. It gave no cause of death and funeral details were not announced. She was born Madge McHarg on June 12, 1898, in Melbourne, Australia, where her father was in business. She grew up in London and became a journalist in the 1920s, first working for English Vogue with novelist Aldous Huxley and photographer Cecil Beaton, and later free-lancing for Women's Wear Daily in the United States. Her friends included the couturier Paul Poiret and the sculptor Brancusi. She chose clothes for Virginia Woolf. Artists Marie Laurencin and Edward Wolfe painted her and she was one of Beaton's earliest subjects. She returned to English Vogue as fashion editor from 1933, bringing readers the best of Paris fashion until World War II. She became merchandising manager for London's main department store, Bourne and Hollingsworth, during the war and designed some fashion. After the war, she visited the United States to study ready-to-wear marketing methods for the British fashion industry. In 1947, Sir Robin Darwin of the Royal College of Art invited her to found the first British school of fashion. As Professor Garland, she opened the school the following year and remained at its head until 1956. Designers David Sassoon and Gina Fratini were among her students. During the 1960s, she produced five books on fashion, beauty and the history of costumes. She was married briefly in the 1920s to Capt. Ewart Garland. In 1953, she married Sir Leigh Ashton, then director of Victoria and Albert Museum. The marriage lasted less than a year although they were not divorced until 1962. She retained the name Lady Ashton for formal purposes. She had no children.

Sponsors of a bill to combat job bias, fresh from victory in the Senate, say they would welcome a compromise to ease White House concern that the plan could lead to hiring quotas. ``We'll continue to consider any proposals from the president,'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., the chief sponsor, said Wednesday night after the Senate approved the measure, 65-34. ``But we're not going to sacrifice the essential principles of this legislation.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, traveling with President Bush in Anaheim, Calif., said the administration was disappointed by the outcome of the Senate's vote. ``We'll work to change it in the House,'' Fitzwater said. ``We still want a bill we can sign.''

The Senate Ethics Committee is calling on the full Senate to denounce Sen. Dave Durenberger, who is agreeing to pay up to $124,000 in restitution for his financial misconduct. The Minnesota Republican said he would repay the money as a ``tangible sign of my regret.'' The committee unanimously approved a resolution Wednesday saying that Durenberger ``knowingly and willingly'' violated Senate rules through financial dealings that were ``unequivocally unethical.'' Leaders of the Senate say they hope to put the recommendations to a vote by the time Congress leaves for its August recess.

The earthquake that struck the main Philippines island of Luzon caught President Corazon Aquino's government ill-prepared for disaster and dramatized her administration's organizational shortcomings. Three days after the quake, which measured 7.7 on the Richter scale, the government has no comprehensive picture of the extent of damage and casualties. Relief operations appear centered in areas such as Baguio, where media focused its attention. ``The immediate task is the rescue and feeding of survivors,'' said the newspaper Malaya. ``Three days after the earthquake, the abject failure of the government on this score is appalling.''

Moscow's decision to drop its objection to NATO membership for a reunited Germany likely will put East-West arms control negotiations back on track, administration officials and private arms control experts say. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told reporters Wednesday that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's concession on German participation in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization ``removed the last roadblock'' to clinching two landmark arms control agreements. Cheney referred to 23-nation negotiations to sharply reduce the number of conventional arms _ tanks, troops and aircraft _ in Europe, and to U.S.-Soviet talks on slashing strategic, or long-range, nuclear missiles by one-third. The conventional arms negotiations have been bogged down for months by several key disputes, including NATO resistance to a Soviet demand that the West German government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl accept a numerical limit on its armed forces.

If you were to telephone West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, as President Bush did the other day, it would cost between $6.20 and $11.58 for 10 minutes, depending on how and when you called. But if someone called you from West Germany, it would cost them $19.07 for the same call, regardless of how or when. That may sound as though you're getting a good deal. But you aren't. The Federal Communications Commission says that due to outmoded international telephone pricing agreements between U.S. companies and their overseas counterparts, you may be paying twice what it actually costs to place such calls.

DOC.HEAD: HBO's ``El Diablo'' A Shaggy Western Story
DOC.TEXT: Billy Ray, the dude schoolteacher, is reading to his class from a penny dreadful about the Old West, ``Kid Durango: The Dust Devils.'' The Kid, of course, is brave, strong and quick with a gun. One of his students, the fair Nettie, sighs at the part about a terrible band of outlaws from Mexico. Just then, such a band gallops into her dusty Texas town for purposes of robbing a bank and killing people. The fair Nettie dashes outside to see all this. El Diablo, the gang's handsome, ruthless leader, rides up and kidnaps her, even though she's only oh, maybe 17. Billy Ray, although from Boston, vows to rescue her. This, buckaroos, starts Home Box Office's ``El Diablo,'' a shaggy Western tale arriving Sunday on the pay-cable service. It co-stars Anthony Edwards as the dude schoolteacher who believes the Old West cliches, and Lou Gossett as an ex-sergeant from the Army's black cavalry. The latter now is a gunfighter hired to help save Nettie. Representing Old West reality, he sort of instructs the dude in how ride a horse _ he lets the horse drag Billy Ray when he falls off _ and how to shoot and hit something, such as another man with a gun. Gunnery protocol, he says, includes looking at an opponent's gun hand, not his eyes, and shooting opponents in the back whenever possible. With a script by a trio that includes John Carpenter of ``Halloween'' and ``The Fog'' fame, such assault on Western verities should be pretty funny. Well, at times the script is. Its early moments include an old codger who smiles at Billy Ray and the fair Nettie (Sarah Trigger) as they head to school, then cheerily says, ``Beautiful mornin' for procreation.'' There also is a scruffy townie who, after El Diablo rides off with fair Nettie, recalls seeing him hanged once, but ``he wouldn't die. He just hanged there by his neck, spittin' at the crowd like they disgusted him.'' There is a lot to be said for such lines, likewise the lowlife posse gunfighter Gossett digs up _ a man with a store leg, an Indian with whose wife El Diablo has consorted, and a preacher who holds fake hangings with two colleagues in return for donations. All have varied motives for joining the chase. They're later joined by Truman Feathers (Joe Pantoliano), a dusty, but prissy British author of the ``Kid Durango'' series. Upon meeting Billy Ray, now clad in gun and wooly chaps, the writer is moved to say: ``I love your outfit.'' Problem is, the ``El Diablo'' script is in dire need of editing. When the funny lines and situations arise, and there are quite a few, the authors stretch things out. This tends to fritter away the funny. They also don't seem to realize that shock for comic effect should be sparingly used, as when the dude accidentally shoots and kills his horse while trying to ride out of town. Sure enough, it happens again later. And while the show is beautifully photographed, director Peter Markle usually moves things along at a snail's pace, a mortal sin for an Old West show. The pace does pick up as the posse approaches and enters Mexico, where El Diablo is keeping both his stolen gold and the fair Nettie in a town ringed by mountains. Guns go off and bodies fall all over the place. But even with the preceding moments of doom, it takes a while for the show to get moving. Markle tends to make the proceedings going downright leisurely, almost an art-film edition of ``Blazing Saddles,'' minus the fine bean-dinner scene and its ensuing blasts of hot air. Still, ``El Diablo,'' whose title cad is played by Robert Beltran, has some good performances by Gossett and Andrews. The supporting players also do fine work, particularly Pantoliano. If you have HBO, the movie is worth a look-see, flaws and all. But it could and should have been a whole lot funnier.

Elsewhere in television... MORE ABOUT NEWS STARS: In keeping with TV growing tendency toward programs concerning network anchors and correspondents, CBS plans a one-hour special on the 40-year career of ``60 Minutes'' newshawk Mike Wallace, still a hard-charger at age 72. Scheduled for broadcast on Sept. 26, the show has an impressive title: ``Mike Wallace, Then and Now, a CBS Special.'' DEPT. OF WOE: NBC's ``Today,'' despite its revamping and vows of better times, last week had its lowest ratings since Aug. 6, 1983, and was second to ABC's ``Good Morning America'' for the 28th consecutive week. ABC's show had a 4.3 rating, up from the previous week's 3.9. ``Today'' dipped slightly to a 3.0. ``CBS This Morning'' rose slightly in the Nielsens, but is still mired in third with a 2.3. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes.

DOC.HEAD: The Big and The Small of Stocks
DOC.TEXT: The biggest companies seem to make the biggest news in the stock market, and for obvious reasons: They and their products are known to the public, and their stocks make up the popular averages and indices. But the biggest companies are not a proxy for the economy as a whole, as a number of small-business and medium-size business groups feel compelled to point out from time to time. What happens to the biggest names in corporate America can be, and often is, at variance with what is happening in the rest of the economy, and evidence of that is contained in the latest dividend actions. Many of the biggest companies have been raising dividends. The smaller companies have tended to stay put, with relatively few of them taking positive action, such as resuming dividends, raising them, and adding extras. Observe the contrast: In the first half of 1990, cash dividends paid by companies making up the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 12 percent. For the 12 months through June, the same companies paid out 56 percent of profits as dividends. That latter figure, say researchers at Wright Investors' Service, compares with just 49 percent for the past decade and 51 percent for the period 1950-1989. Figures of that sort suggest a high level of management confidence among the larger companies, since companies looking for a downturn aren't likely to commit themselves to larger payouts. Now enlarge the measurement to 10,000 companies. Among these companies, which make up the entire S&P universe, only 868 took positive dividend action in the first six months of the year, down 25 percent from a year earlier. Says Wright: ``This is the lowest number of positive dividend actions in the first half of any year since 1971, a fact which illustrates corporate management's lack of confidence regarding the near-term profit outlook.'' The contrast with the bigger companies becomes even sharper on further examination. According to Wright, the total of 187 dividend cuts and omissions in the first half of the year was more than 70 percent higher than in the first half of 1989, and the highest six-month total of unfavorable actions since 1983. Other studies have shown similar disparities between the performance and expectations of smaller and larger companies. In contrast to a long-term trend, for example, the performance of small-company stocks has lagged behind that of bigger companies since 1983, casting much doubt about the veracity of the so-called small-stock effect. Small-company stocks, according to that theory, have a tendency to outperform larger companies, one factor being that good small companies have the ability to grow at a faster rate than ponderously large operations. Other factors enter the picture as well: Small-company stocks are often run by the original entrepreneur, who understands the company and demands nothing but the best; and, unexamined by analysts, small-company stocks are more likely to be undervalued, their prices exploding when they are finally discovered. In recent months, some analysts say they are seeing signs of a recovery by the smaller stocks, but if dividend actions are an indicator, similar signs are hardly evident among the larger stocks. The dividend yield on the S&P 500 stock index recently was 3.3 percent, or well below its long-term average yield of 4.2 percent. Such figures suggest that big-company stocks might be overpriced.

DOC.HEAD: Emirate Debates What to Do About Democracy
DOC.TEXT: Kuwaitis are debating how to pursue democracy four years after the ruling family closed the Western-style parliament and press. Some feel the choice for the emirate, where oil provides one of the world's highest per capita incomes, is between reviving the old system and developing an Islamic brand of democracy. The government and dissidents have traded accusations of blame for setbacks to the democratic institutions, but dissident leader Ahmed al-Saadoun said: ``Our loyalty to our leader, the emir, is undiminished by our unrelenting struggle for democracy.'' ``Security authorities have tried to cast an undue tinge of rebellion on our movement,'' Saadoun, speaker of the dissolved parliament, said in an interview. ``Riot police ruthlessly dispersed peaceful rallies, closed our diwaniyas, and arrested parliament deputies.'' Diwaniyas are informal gatherings at the homes prominent citizens to discuss current issues. The government declared the diwaniyas of former deputies illegal at one point and ordered them closed. Dissidents and witnesses said police used clubs and tear gas to disperse pro-democracy demonstrators. They said some members of the former parliament were beaten up and 15 were arrested. ``The respected institution of diwaniya has been badly abused,'' Sheik Salem al-Sabah, the interior minister, told reporters. ``The diwaniya became a platform of diatribe and anti-government agitation. We had to put an end to that.'' About 30 of the 50 former deputies, under Saadoun, lead a pro-democracy movement that has broad support among wealthy merchants in the Persian Gulf emirate. Native Kuwaitis ``are the largest minority in our own country and, with the population structure being infested with all kinds of hostile and begrudging elements, we desperately need national unity today more than ever before,'' said Mohammed al-Qadiri, a close aide of Saadoun. Fewer than 40 percent of the emirate's 1.8 million people are Kuwaitis. About 30 percent of the residents are Shiite Moslems, some of whom sympathize with the Islamic revolution in nearby Iran. Kuwait once had the Arab world's only free press and freely elected parliament, both of which were eyed with suspicion by neighboring Saudi Arabia and other conservative regimes in the gulf region. When the Iran-Iraq war began in 1980, the government decided democracy was a luxury no Persian Gulf nation could afford. Pro-Iranian Shiites spread terror in Kuwait with bombings and made a daring attempt to kill the emir. Relations between Kuwait and Iran have improved since a cease-fire halted the war in 1988, and Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati of Iran visited recently. Several times during the war, the press and parliament embarrassed the government with accusations of corruption and open debates of subversion and foreign policy. Criticism of the government became increasingly harsh after the unofficial Souk al-Manakh stock market collapsed in 1982. The press also blamed the government for the crash, which was worthless, post-dated checks totaling $97 billion. Deputies claimed the government had allowed influential people close to the ruling Sabah family to borrow speculation money from banks without collateral. That prompted the emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, to suspend the National Assembly in 1986 and censor the press. ``The emir acted on his constitutional authority when he dissolved parliament, but the constitutional stipulation that elections for a new parliament be held within 60 days was ignored,'' Saadoun said. On July 9, Sheik Jaber ordered the detainees freed and introduced a ``transitional'' legislature dissidents rejected as unconstitutional. Jaber said the 75-member National Council would pave the way for a parliament within four years. He ordered the council of 50 elected and 25 appointed members to create ``controls'' to avert the acrimony that precipitated two suspensions of parliament in a decade. Saadoun and other activists expressed fear the government would amend the constitution to curtail the powers of parliament. ``This rape of democracy cannot be tolerated,'' he said. ``All non-constitutional action, including the current National Council, must be abolished without delay.'' The emir has spoken of eventual return to a ``desired parliament,'' which was widely interpreted as return to a Western-style body. Several activists believe, however, that Jaber might opt for an Islamic-type Shura consultative council rather than a genuine legislature, which would please theocratic Saudi Arabia and other conservative Arab states.

DOC.HEAD: Lebanon Seeks Help to Rescue Economy
DOC.TEXT: The economy is in shambles after 15 years of civil war and President Elias Hrawi has gone on the road, seeking at least $20 billion in foreign aid to rescue it. One safeguard against total economic collapse is Lebanon's gold reserves of about $3.2 billion, but falling gold prices have cost the treasury about $500 million in the past 18 months. The national debt is estimated at $2.3 billion. One-third of the bullion is stored at Fort Knox, Ky., and the rest in underground Central Bank vaults in Moslem west Beirut. Foreign currency reserves held by the Central Bank, virtually the only state institution that still functions, have declined to $650 million from $1 billion in December. Heavy fighting early this year drove down the Lebanese pound and the bank sold some reserves to support the currency. Hrawi has been touring Arab capitals in search of financial aid and a three-member Arab League committee, entrusted with ending the war, is trying to raise $2 billion for Lebanon. Premier Salim Hoss, an economist and former banker, said $2 billion would be barely enough to ``reconstruct the infrastructure'' of an economy that once was the most flourishing in the Middle East. Lebanese economists estimate reconstruction will cost at least $21 billion, but many put the figure higher. Citizens of Lebanon are believed to have about $30 billion in assets outside the country. Bankers believe an end to the Christian-Moslem war, which has cost an estimated 150,000 lives since 1975, would bring much of it back. A settlement remains elusive despite a peace plan, mediated by the Arab League and endorsed by Lebanon's parliament, and the election of Hrawi in October to implement it. The long war has devastated the Lebanese pound. It was 2.5 to the dollar 15 years ago, but hit 690 to the dollar in June. All the several dozen banks in Beirut speculate on the volatile Lebanese money market. They buy pounds if they believe things will improve, even for a short time, and dollars when they expect bad news. Even the Central Bank plays the market. It uses the profits to finance the budget, because government revenues have virtually disappeared. Revenue from customs levies collapsed when militias took over ports, operating them illegally, and even built their own ports. The cost to the treasury is about $200 million a year. Prices are soaring in a country that imports at least 85 percent of its necessities. Precise statistics are rare, but economists and bankers estimate the annual inflation rate at 400 percent. The General Federation of Labor Unions, which represents 250,000 workers, puts unemployment at 47 percent and says most people with jobs must moonlight to make ends meet. Lebanon has no social welfare system, so the unemployed rely on working relatives, leave the country, resort to crime or join militias. Fierce fighting in the past 18 months between Christians and Syrians and between rival Christian forces have taken a terrible economic toll. Artillery battles destroyed or damaged hundreds of factories an shops. A U.N. report in June said fighting between Christians that began Jan. 30 had caused damage totaling $500 million. ``Unprecedented damage to electricity, water and telecommunications systems has directly affected 1.5 million people ... seriously affecting all social and economic life,'' it said. Last month, economist Marwan Iskandar predicted economic and social catastrophe unless effective action was taken ``in the next few months.'' Iskandar, writing in the independent An-Nahar daily, urged the government to sell its gold reserves and invest the money in European government bonds to bring in about $350 million a year. He said government spending should be limited to that amount and such state-owned utilities as power plants, water, oil refineries and communications systems should be sold to private investors. Finance Minister Ali Khalil noted that, four years ago, the parliament forbade the sale of bullion ``because we feared that replacing gold with foreign currencies would open the door wide to government spending.'' Beirut was the Middle East's banking capital before the war, bustling with Western tycoons and Arab oil sheiks. When the Israeli army invaded in 1982, billions of dollars in Arab assets held in Lebanon fled to Europe. Even now, most of the several dozen Lebanese banks keep up to 90 percent of their assets liquid. Lebanon's economy has been cushioned by aid from Arab and other countries, and by large amounts of money given the militias by foreign backers, including Syria, Libya, Iraq, Iran, Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization. Economists estimated there are 80,000 armed irregulars in Lebanon. Another source of invisible income is the trade in opium and hashish grown in the Syrian-controlled Bekaa Valley of east Lebanon, which earns about $200 million a year for the growers.

DOC.HEAD: South African Communist Joe Slovo: Love Him or Hate Him
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Joe Slovo, lionized by blacks and vilified by whites, is a lifelong revolutionary who leads one of the few Communist movements still in ascendancy. Slovo the mild-mannered white lawyer was on the African National Congress team that met with the white National Party government in talks between South Africa's two most powerful political forces. The other Joe Slovo, who angers whites and is an idol to young blacks, is general secretary of the South African Communist Party and former head of the ANC guerrilla campaign. ``By marking me out as enemy No. 1,'' he said in an interview, the government ``has endeared me in the hearts of most people in this country.'' At 64, Slovo looks more like a favorite uncle than a leader of revolution. He is good-humored, engaging and slightly rumpled, with bushy eyebrows, thick glasses that slide down his nose, a full head of gray hair and a gravel voice from heavy smoking. Slovo fled South Africa in 1963 and returned in April, wearing a dark blue suit, loud floral tie, cherry red socks and a wide smile. ``As I was saying before I was so rudely interrupted 27 years ago,'' he said at an airport news conference, ``we are really on our way.'' Nelson Mandela said Slovo was the primary African National Congress speaker on most major issues discussed with the government in May. Slovo probably will play a similar role in any future negotiations on ending apartheid. However easygoing the exterior, he is a dedicated revolutionary who became a Communist Party member at age 15. Slovo's parents immigrated from Lithuania. He does not apologize for his years as leader of an ANC bombing and sabotage campaign that caused hundreds of deaths and injuries, mostly to blacks. His wife and fellow Communist, Ruth First, was killed by a parcel bomb in neighboring Mozambique in 1982. Slovo says that South African agents were responsible and that he also has been a target. ``What sustained me was the certainty that I would come back,'' Slovo said of his long exile. ``I never doubted that for one moment.'' In 1987, he gave up leadership of the ANC's armed wing to concentrate on the Communist Party. He remains on the ANC policy-making body, the National Executive Committee. The ANC and South African Communist Party have been allies since the 1920s, and Slovo is one of several people who holds posts in both. An angry reader wrote in The Citizen, a conservative newspaper: ``He and his ilk have destroyed the peace of South Africa. Red Joe should never have come back.'' Former President P.W. Botha cited the government's decision to allow Slovo's return as one reason he quit the National Party after more than 50 years. At rallies in black townships, chants of ``Viva, Nelson Mandela, Viva!'' often are followed by cries of ``Viva, Joe Slovo, Viva!'' The red flag of the Communist Party invaribly hangs beside the green, gold and black of the ANC at such rallies. ``South Africa seems to be one of the last places on earth where the display of the hammer and sickle at public rallies still evokes cheers,'' Herman Nickel, a former U.S. ambassador to South Africa, wrote in the Wall Street Journal. Many blacks equate apartheid with capitalism and are drawn to the socialist economics of the Communist Party, but young blacks in particular have little formal understanding of either system. The South African Communist Party was founded in 1921 and banned in 1950. Secrecy about policies and membership makes its strength hard to measure, but its key role in the ANC is unquestioned and the Communists also are considered influential in the trade union movement. President F.W. de Klerk legalized the party in February along with other anti-apartheid groups. Slovo said he remains convinced socialism can succeed in South Africa despite the collapse of Communist governments in Eastern Europe. ``Perhaps the reason they changed their names and their leadership and their policies is because they have a past to be ashamed of,'' he said of the East European Communists. ``I don't think we have.'' Nonetheless, the South African Communists have moderated their positions after decades of loyalty to the Soviet Union's Communist Party. Slovo calls for a multiparty democracy and says transition from capitalism to a socialist state would be a long-term process pursued peacefully. Many white South Africans still suspect the worst of the Communists, however. Ken Owen, editor of financial daily Business Day, wrote: ``Behind the smiling mask lies an organization that thrives on secrecy: totalitarian, driven by fascist instincts, undemocratic, manipulative.''

DOC.HEAD: Garcia Presided Over Disaster, But May Plan Comeback
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Saturday in 1st graf is July 28.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: President Alan Garcia will leave office Saturday in disgrace, having presided over the most disastrous economic decline in Peru's 169-year history, but he may be back. Many politicians and analysts think he plans to seek the presidency again in 1995, after sitting out a term because Peruvian presidents cannot serve consecutive terms. ``Alan Garcia is a first-rate politician,'' said independent congressman Alfredo Barnechea, a former ally. ``He's a man full of political resources and talents.'' Barnechea is skeptical of Garcia's chances, however, because of the liberal, free-market revolution spreading over the world. Garcia has ``entered a hard rock disco singing boleros from the 1950s,'' said Barnechea, who quit the president's center-left Aprista Party and is allied with the more conservative Democratic Front. ``At some point, the people are going to realize this.'' When he took office five years ago, Garcia was 36 years old, 6-foot-3 with a baby face, the youngest president on the continent. Some called him the John F. Kennedy of Latin America because of his youth and the hope his populism inspired. His waist has thickened since 1985 and his speeches draw more jeers than applause. One pundit described him as less the Kennedy of the region than the Elvis Presley. Garcia's most publicized actions were limiting payments on the foreign debt to 10 percent of foreign earnings, then stopping all payments. He used the money to finance a dramatic, short-lived economic expansion. As the boom slowed, the government was plagued by labor strife, leftist insurgencies and an elephantine bureaucracy that gobbled up intis, the Peruvian currency, as fast as they were printed. Garcia's popularity plummeted. During his term, inflation totaled 2 million percent and 10,000 people were killed in a spreading guerrilla war. Four-fifths of Peruvian workers do not have steady jobs. The nation owes $20 billion abroad and is isolated from international lenders. On two occasions, Garcia fended off coup threats by the military. At one point in 1988, he did not leave the Government Palace for 34 straight days and offered his resignation to Vice President Luis Alberto Sanchez, who was 88 years old and blind. Sanchez refused it. An understanding of the Aprista party is necessary to any assessment of Garcia's potential appeal and chances of a comback, Barnechea said. It is officially called APRA, for American Popular Revolutionary Alliance, and was founded in 1924 as a non-communist alternative to the anti-imperialist left and anti-elitist middle class. The party won elections in 1962, but the military prevented it from taking power. In 1985, Garcia became the first Aprista president. APRA became Peru's best-organized party during 61 years of opposition, with its own flag and anthem. Many of those years were spent underground, with the party leaders in exile. Barnechea described APRA as a ``complex institution'' that had lost its sense of political identity. ``Like all mythologies, it exists at a distance from reality,'' he said. ``The victory or failure of its deeds have no relation to the rise or fall in the faith of its followers.'' He said the party's 20 percent of the vote in the first round of the 1990 presidential election came mostly from party diehards, and ``it's perfectly conceivable Garcia believes this to be a good start for a presidential campaign'' in 1995. Garcia regained his stride and some of his popularity in the 1990 campaign. Although Aprista candidate Luis Alva Castro was eliminated in the first round, the president remained a factor in the runoff between centrist Alberto Fujimori and novelist Mario Vargas Llosa, a champion of free markets. He used the government newspaper and television station, as well as Pagina Libre, a new Lima newspaper in which he is said to hold a major share, to attack Vargas Llosa's ``economic shock'' proposals. Fujimori won the June 10 election in a landslide, and Garcia quickly claimed the victory. ``Mr. Fujimori represents the negation of everything the other candidate stood for,'' he said. ``The voters said no to liberalism, no to the right. ... I'm totally identified with the feeling behind that vote.'' Since the election, Fujimori has slowly warmed to the idea of an economic shock and has begun mending fences with foreign lenders. The new president has said he will dismantle Garcia's price subsidy programs and controls on currency exchange rates. The shift by Fujimori leaves Garcia an opening to lead the opposition, which analysts say would help his chances in 1995 if the new government falters. ``Alberto Fujimori shouldn't forget his commitment and responsibility is first with Peru's poor majority,'' said an unsigned editorial in Pagina Libre that many believe Garcia wrote. Political commentator Fernando Rospigliosi wrote of Garcia in the news magazine Caretas: ``Between being the head of the opposition or an ally with the government, there's no doubt which role he would prefer.''

DOC.HEAD: The Strangest Bedfellows? Don & Buster & Steve & John
DOC.TEXT: For two ugly weeks, boxing's dirty laundry filled a Manhattan courtroom: promoters discussing their lies, lawyers flinging charges and countercharges, the heavyweight champion of the world reduced to mere verbal sparring. When it ended this past week with a negotiated peace, Las Vegas hotel casino owner Steve Wynn stepped into the sunshine of a downtown sidewalk and proclaimed the whole exercise beneficial to business. ``I hope so. I hope so,'' Wynn replied when asked if the legal shenanigans would help hype the upcoming James ``Buster'' Douglas-Evander Holyfield fight, which may itself visit the courtroom before it reaches the ring. ``This will be the biggest betting fight since Hagler-Leonard,'' said Wynn, cutting quickly to the one thing that turns boxing's bitterest enemies into fast friends: money. As Don King, an expert on boxing's scheming and scamming, has said again and again and again, ``Only in America.'' Buster hates Don. Buster's manager hates Don. Don is afraid of Steve. Buster thinks Don's a liar. Don thinks Buster's breaking a contract. Which means, of course, that all four are now partners in promoting Buster's next fight after Holyfield. Wynn's elation was over an agreement that could pit Douglas against Holyfield on Oct. 25 in the first heavyweight title fight since Feb. 10 _ eight months of lawyers instead of lefts, juries instead of jabs. Douglas has spent more time on the witness stand _ 40 minutes _ than he has in the ring _ none _ since his upset knockout of ex-champ Mike Tyson. ``It's a horrible shame that Buster Douglas' reign is characterized by repeated lawsuits,'' said Kathy Duva of Main Event Monitor Promotions. ``This whole thing has been a sin.'' Duva's company handles Holyfield, and they intend to hold Douglas to a Sept. 21 fight date to which both sides agreed before the Douglas-King legal battle. Main Event joined in the interminable litigation by asking a judge to order that the fight take place as originally scheduled. This follows the U.S. District Court trial in a suit brought by King against Douglas. Lowlights of the case included: _ King's description of the heavyweight champion as a hot dog-and-beer fighter: ``When he came on, people went to the refreshment stand.'' _ King and fellow promoter Bob Arum's bizarre excuses for their mendacious behavior. According to Don: ``I wouldn't call it lying. That's just my style.'' As for Arum, he pleaded hyperbole: ``Hyperbole is not lying. Hyperbole is exaggeration.'' _ Wynn, who will be King's co-promoter for Douglas' first fight after Holyfield, was ominously characterized by his spiky-haired soon-to-be business partner as someone ``everyone's afraid of.'' _ Arum boasted that his description of WBC President Jose Sulaiman and WBA President Gilberto Mendoza as ``two little Noriegas'' was ``one of my better lines.'' _ Arum also told the jury what constituted peace in the boxing world: just a single lawsuit pending between himself and King. ``Do you know how many times Don King and I have sued each other over the past 10 years?'' Arum asked. ``We've done dastardly things to each other we wouldn't do to other people.'' Arum, who spent most of the last decade going after King's throat, appeared as a witness on his ex-adversary's behalf. Things were so strange in the courtroom that U.S. District Judge Robert W. Sweet, who presided over the trial, told attorneys for both sides, ``I wouldn't want to be a juror in this case for anything.'' One exasperated lawyer, worn out by attempts to cross-examine King, told Sweet, ``Mr. King's perception of what is being asked often differs from reality.'' ``Sometimes that's a problem,'' the judge acknowledged. But all the problems were worked out, as they always are, so that everybody can make a buck. Forgive and forget _ until next time. ``The issue was emotional. The problem started in Tokyo. But once we got together and worked things out, it went away,'' Wynn explained after the settlement. Translation: King and Donald Trump received several million dollars just to walk away. Douglas will make his money again in the ring, benefiting his manager, Wynn and Wynn's Las Vegas hotel casino. After the settlement, King announced he'd finally give Douglas a promised $100,000 bonus for defeating Tyson. ``I'm a man of my word,'' King said in the hallway outside the courtroom, ignoring the smirks of reporters. King also invited all the jurors to his next fight promotion, the Sept. 22 Atlantic City bout between Tyson and Alex Stewart. The panelists appeared amazed by the greed, backstabbing and chicanery they'd heard about in court. One of the jurors, talking with Douglas' manager, John Johnson, after the settlement, summed it up best. ``In boxing, it doesn't seem you can listen to what anybody says,'' Gabrielle Mellett told Johnson, who nodded in agreement. ``What they say isn't really what they mean.''
