DOC.HEAD: State Uses Beetles To Attack Pesky Weed
DOC.TEXT: David Hirsch left Bismarck before dawn and headed for Canada _ on a beetle run. He should be back with a cooler full of 5,000 flea beetles eating leafy spurge. The strange odyssey is part of the stepped-up battle against the weed considered one of North Dakota's most persistent pests. Hirsch works for the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, which is importing the beetles in the hope they will ravage the spurge infesting 1.2 million acres across the state. North Dakota has North America's worst infestation of the tall weed with green-yellow flowers that was brought over from Europe in the 19th century, said Peter Harris, an entomologist with Canada's department of agriculture at a research station in Regina, Saskatchewan. He is considered the dean of biological control of leafy spurge. He's also in charge of the beetles Hirsch is picking up. The adult bugs Hirsch brings back will lay eggs in North Dakota soil this summer. The eggs will hatch this fall, and the larvae will ``hibernate'' and next spring eat spurge root systems before they become adults. After several years, tests in Canada show that up to 90 percent of a spurge stand could be eliminated, Harris said. The state will spend about $460,000 on spraying leafy spurge over the next two years, mostly in a cost-share program with counties.
DOC.HEAD: Western Scientists Unprepared for Effects of Interfamily Marriages
DOC.TEXT: As incestuous marriages become more common in the United States, scientists are unprepared to offer counseling about the likelihood of genetic disorders, a University of Michigan researcher said. ``I'd been brought up to believe that inbreeding was pretty nasty,'' said Alan Bittles, a geneticist who has spent 10 years researching interfamily marriages in Pakistan and India. ``We never consider that in other parts of the world it's perfectly normal to marry a cousin.'' Bittles said he has determined that 500 million people worldwide are married to relatives, typically uncles and nieces or first or second cousins. ``All those have got to be rock-bottom low estimates, because we're missing information from so many parts of the world,'' he said. And as people move to the United States and other Western nations, traditions follow. Although there are fewer genetic disorders among children born to married family members than Westerners believe, scientists have made few studies of those problems and have little information about them, he said. Inherited disorders include some blood diseases, protein deficiencies, spina bifida, cleft palates and hip and heart deformities. If parents from the same family marry and seek genetic counseling, doctors can give only occurrence rates derived from general population studies, Bittles said. ``We may be giving wrong advice,'' he said. ``We would be hard-pressed in this community to tell them what their risks are.'' Bittles, a Fulbright Fellow in the University of Michigan Population Studies Center, is a geneticist from Kings College in London. He is one of only a few researchers studying intermarriage but expects the field to grow. ``Once people recognize that this is a subject that needs investigation, that it has tremendous importance on a community, then they'll start studying it,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, July 23

DOC.TEXT: Surging food, housing and gasoline costs sent consumer prices soaring 0.5 percent in June, more than double the inflation rate of the two previous months. The unexpectedly steep rise Wednesday in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index followed 0.2 percent increases in both April and May. Through the first six months of the year, consumer prices rose at an annual rate of 5.9 percent, compared with 4.6 percent for all of 1989.

Housing construction fell for a fifth straight month in June, hitting its lowest level since the last recession, the Commerce Department said. Analysts said Wednesday the 2.3 percent decrease in housing starts last month offered disturbing evidence of continued weakness in the overall economy, especially in the housing industry.

Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan told Congress the central bank is ready to push interest rates lower to keep the country out of a recession _ once policy makers agree on a deficit reduction package. But the head of the central bank Wednesday tempered his pledge by insisting that he sees no signs of a recession. He also indicated the Federal Reserve is not contemplating any immediate follow-up to a small credit easing move it made last Friday.

Job security loopholes that allowed General Motors Corp. to close four plants in the last three years must be closed before a new labor contract can be signed, UAW President Owen Bieber said. Bieber made the comments Wednesday as negotiations began with the giant automaker. Talks between the union and Ford Motor Co. open Thursday and with Chrysler Corp. on Friday.

Safety and police groups asked the government to bar radar detectors in interstate trucks, citing new evidence suggesting that as many as half the truck drivers in some states use the detectors as a defense against being nabbed for speeding. Eight groups, including the nation's largest trucking group, signed a petition Wednesday to the Federal Highway Administration to ban what they called electronic ``partners in crime'' in all commercial vehicles in interstate commerce.

A Long Island woman has filed a $150 million lawsuit against the makers of the anti-depressant drug Prozac, claiming the drug caused her to engage in self-mutilation and suicide attempts. The state Supreme Court lawsuit, filed Tuesday by Rhonda Hala of Shirley, claimed the drug's manufacturer, Eli Lilly & Co. of Indianapolis, failed to warn users that Prozac could cause an obsession with death and violence. There are approximately 1.5 million people in the United States taking Prozac, with 650,000 prescriptions written each month.

Iraq warned fellow OPEC members it viewed violations of the cartel's production quotas as virtual acts of war, and accused neighboring Kuwait of stealing its oil for the past decade. After meeting in emergency session, Kuwait's National Council, or Parliament, issued a statement Wednesday rejecting what it called the Iraqi ``policy of violence, threats and blackmail.'' OPEC, beset by disputes over production levels and prices, opens its mid-year meeting in Geneva next Thursday.

Gannett Co. Inc. posted a 6.1 percent profit decline, its first quarterly earnings dip in 22 years as a public company, and the New York Times Co. reported a 35 percent drop in its second quarter earnings. A weak advertising market hurt both media companies. Gannett reported Wednesday that it earned $105.3 million, or 66 cents a share, in the quarter, down from $112.1 million, or 70 cents per share, a year earlier. The Times earned $26.8 million, or 35 cents per share, in the three months ended June 30 compared with $41.3 million, or 53 cents a share, a year earlier.

Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. said John S.R. Shad had resigned as chairman as part of a restructuring at the Wall Street firm during its bankruptcy court proceedings. The restructuring includes the addition of three new outside directors. It comes as creditors are challenging Drexel's attempts to maintain control over asset sales as it reorganizes under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law.

The stock market retreated Wednesday from its recent record highs. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had closed Monday and Tuesday just fractionally below 3,000, dropped 18.07 points to 2,981.68. The dollar ended mostly higher. Bond prices fell after the government reported inflation rose at a greater-than-expected pace last month. Snow in Chile and a volcano in Guatemala helped boost coffee futures prices; near-term gasoline futures plunged while other energy futures were mixed; most pork futures fell sharply; cattle futures gained; grains and soybeans were mixed; and precious metals were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Rare Bird Discovery Raises New Questions About Saving Old Growth Forest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The first nest ever reported in Washington of a bird called a marbled murrelet has been found in old-growth hemlock, cheering ornithologists and stirring new questions about logging of old-growth forests. ``That's really exciting news,'' said Jim Pissot, executive director of the Audubon Society of Washington. He said it will strengthen the society's drive to see the chubby little shorebird listed as threatened by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. The bird is fairly common elsewhere, and little is known about its nesting habits. But the Audubon petition, filed in January 1988, contends mounting biological evidence shows logging of coastal old-growth forests threatens the bird's nesting habitat. Logging of millions of acres of public old-growth forest in Washington, Oregon and California already is threatened since the Fish and Wildlife Service declared the northern spotted owl a threatened species. The owl nests in old-growth forest. Federal officials are working out a management plan to protect the owl and still take into account the affect on timber communities. Officials say reductions proposed in a federal scientific report could mean the loss of more than 20,000 jobs over the next decade. The murrelet nest, containing one chick, was found last week by state Department of Wildlife researcher Tom Hamers roughly 25 miles inland from Port Susan in Snohomish County, department spokesman John Pierce said Wednesday. Its parents apparently visit the nest only at dawn and dusk to feed the chick, he said. ``I can't tell you how exciting this is. Although we've had egg fragments turned in and fledglings found in the forest, this is the first nest found after years and years of searching,'' he said. Pierce said the only other marbled murrelet nest found this year was in Oregon's Siuslaw National Forest. Little is known about the nesting behavior of the brown and white, robin-size murrelet, according to a recent study by the state Department of Wildlife. ``Ornithologists have searched for its nests throughout its range from central California to the Bering Sea and from Kamchatka (Soviet Union) to northern Japan. Yet only 13 nests have been found,'' said the study, written by Lora L. Leschner and Eric B. Cummins. ``The nests that have been found and recent discoveries of marbled murrelets at inland locations in Oregon and California indicate that the species may be traveling inland to nest in old-growth forests,'' Leschner and Cummins wrote. ``The harvest of the last of the old-growth forests in coastal Washington, Oregon and California and the increased harvest of old-growth in British Columbia and Alaska could pose a serious threat to marbled murrelet populations,'' they said. Rick Johnson, associate Northwest representative of the Sierra Club, said the nest discovery ``shows how little we really know about the ancient forest ecosystem, and in this case points to yet another species that is probably dependent on the forests for survival. It means we have an even greater need to know.''

DOC.HEAD: Bankrupty Court Examiner Raises Possibility of Suits in Revco Case
DOC.TEXT: The Revco drugstore chain was an ignominious groundbreaker in 1988 when it became the first company to file for bankruptcy court protection after a billion-dollar takeover financed with junk bonds. Now another precedent could be emerging from the tangled mess of Revco D.S. Inc.: An examiner appointed by the bankruptcy court said this week the company's creditors may have grounds to sue shareholders, investment bankers and other parties to recover losses caused by the 1986 leveraged buyout. The report by examiner Barry L. Zaretsky will only be used as an advisory opinion by the judge overseeing Revco's reorganization. But the opinion, if it eventually finds its way into the law, could have a chilling effect on other companies and other takeovers. In his report, Zaretsky said that under the laws of Michigan, where Revco is incorporated, creditors might be able to sue because of the so-called ``fraudulent conveyance'' of the company. The conveyance occurred when shareholders sold the company to the management-led investor group that engineered the $1.5 billion LBO. A fraudulent conveyance ``is a transaction made without fair consideration if the debtor is rendered insolvent or is left with unreasonably small capital,'' said Zaretsky, a professor at Brooklyn Law School in New York. Zaretsky admits litigation is no panacea for those waiting to paid. But considering the rash of failed takeovers during the past year, the prospect of a new avenue of redress for a firm's creditors is nonetheless appealing. In considering who might be liable to Revco creditors, Zaretsky notes that investment bankers and others who helped arrange the buyout were paid $80 million in fees, an amount he called ``grossly disproportionate to the benefit, if any, received by'' Revco. If investment firms could be held liable for the failed buyouts they arrange, they might worry more about the ultimate success of the deals than with the fees they stood to make. Zaretsky stressed in his report that his conclusions were tentative and based on an as-yet uncompleted examination of Revco's problems. But he said he has found ``a basis for proving the financial elements of a fraudulent conveyance'' and that ``Revco was left with insufficient capital to conduct its business.'' He also found evidence the leveraged buyout rendered Revco insolvent. In reaching his conclusions, the examiner cited, among other factors, the impact on Revco's business of loan agreements reached in the buyout process. Zaretsky also found fault with financial forecasts used by proponents of the buyout. ``Reasonable projections based on the same assumptions as those used in projections made available to the examiner would have shown that Revco was left with insufficient capital to satisfy its then known obligations,'' he said. Zaretsky's findings were filed with the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Akron, Ohio, which is handling the Revco case. Revco, headquartered in Twinsburg, Ohio, filed for protection from its creditors after it missed an interest payment on $700 million in junk bonds used to finance the LBO. Zaretsky admits he has raised more questions than he has answers for. Calling remedies for creditors under a fraudulent conveyance suit ``largely virgin territory,'' he said he would do further research before making recommendations on just who should pay, and how. However, he said, ``The courts could fashion an equitable remedy which would allow unsecured general creditors to be paid in full with interest at the expense of the parties who contributed to the fraudulent conveyance.'' Several times in his report, Zaretsky stated that negotiations between Revco and its creditors would be a better means of resolving the situation although the talks have been bogged down for some time. The examiner advised the court to bring in a mediator to hasten the processs. If a reorganization plan for the company is not in the offing by November, when statutes of limitations in the case are about to expire, Zaretsky warned he is ``likely to recommend the commencement of fraudulent conveyance litigation'' as well as suits on several other grounds. It is possible he is raising the specter of a lawsuit as a way to get the parties off the dime. Zaretsky warned that if new litigation is spawned, it will be a long process with uncertain results, and it may take a further toll on Revco's business.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Supports New Restrictions on Investment Advisers
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission says it supports new restrictions on the multibillion-dollar business of advising people how to invest their money, but says it could do more with more money. SEC Commissioner Mary L. Schapiro told a House panel Wednesday that the commission now favors legislation requiring tougher SEC registration requirements rather than farming out responsibility to an independent self-regulating organization. She said the SEC believed direct SEC regulation of investment advisers is preferable to self-regulation. Last year, the SEC submitted legislation that would give investment adviser oversight to a self-regulatory organization such as the National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees the over-the-counter market. But in testimony before the finance subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, Ms. Schapiro said the SEC relunctantly lent its support to industry self-regulation because it didn't have the money to adequately police the industry and didn't think it was going to get more money soon. She called for increasing registration fees investment advisers pay the SEC and earmarking the money for enforcement. The SEC now does not keep any of the money it collects in fees, but must turn it over to the Treasury Department for general government spending. Rep. Rick Boucher, D-Va., a member of the subcommittee, has submitted a bill that would require anyone offering investment advice for pay to register with the SEC whether they call themselves an investment adviser or a financial planner. They would be required to provide clients with accurate information. The bill also would give customers the right to sue for damages when they lose money because of violations of the law. Boucher's bill would not increase SEC fees, however. The bill also would continue the exemption from registration now in effect for banks as well as lawyers, accountants and other professionals who give investment advice only as a sideline. Ms. Schapiro said she had no problem with that but others did. Mary A. Malgoire, of the National Association of Personal Financial Advisors, a professional association of planners that earn only fees _ not commissions _ opposed the exemptions for lawyers and accountants. She said such professionals, if not registered with SEC, would not be subject to financial planning oversight from state licensing boards. Outside the hearing room, Ms. Schapiro told reporters the SEC currently spends $5.7 million annualy on registering and reviewing investment advisers. To do everything recommended in a General Accounting Office report on investment adviser regulation, she said, the agency would have to spend an additional $17 million. In a report issued Monday, the GAO, the accounting arm of Congress, warned that investors may be lulled into a false sense of security because investment advisers must register with the SEC, although the agency does not evaluate adviser competence. The GAO study noted that since 1980, the number of investment advisers has tripled to about 14,000 while assets they manage have increased from $440 billion 10 years ago to about $4.6 trillion today. The GAO also found the SEC was behind in reviewing registered advisers. When advisers are reviewed, usually only inadequate disclosure or record-keeping problems are uncovered and the SEC does little to ensure that deficiencies are corrected, the report said. SEC oversight ``provides investors little assurance that the information they receive from advisers is accurate or that advisers operate in accordance with'' the law, according to the GAO study. The GAO recommended that the SEC inspect all newly registered advisers within a year and periodically thereafter. The SEC, however, noted that to implement the report's recommendations would require tripling the 53-person staff now devoted to investment adviser review. Ms. Schapiro began her testimony by defending the SEC's track record and noting the GAO report said ``virtually all of its important recommendations for a more effective adviser regulatory program could only be implemented in the commissioner were given significant additional resources.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards $20 Million For Birth Defects Attributed To Dilantin
DOC.TEXT: The makers of Dilantin epilepsy medication knew the drug could cause birth defects in pregnant women but failed to warn doctors, a Superior Court jury ruled. The jury on Wednesday ordered Parke Davis Co. to pay $20 million to Michael and Brian Keenan, who were born mentally retarded in July 1978 after their mother took the medication while pregnant. ``Parke Davis knew or should have know about the propensity of the drugs to cause these defects, but failed to warn the medical community, and in fact suppressed the information,'' said Max Wistow, the family's lawyer. The boys, now 12, live with their parents in Seekonk, Mass., he said. Their father, Richard, is a construction worker and their mother, Sandra, is a teaching assistant, he said. She no longer takes the medication. He described the children as ``mildly retarded'' but said there was doubt they would ever be able to live independently. Most of their damage is mental but the boys also have some facial deformity, he said. ``We were able to show that in the medical literature through the world'' there was evidence that Dilantin caused birth defects, Wistow said. ``Parke Davis had access to this information, and indeed had it, and wasn't passing it on to physicians through package inserts.'' Joseph Kelly, the attorney for Parke Davis, could not be reached for comment late Wednesday. Telephone calls were not answered at his home or office. He argued during the trial that there was a great deal of controversy over whether the drug caused birth defects and that the benefits of the medication outweighed any risks, according to Wistow. The company also maintained the warnings were adequate, Wistow said. The lawsuit also named Pawtucket Memorial Hospital as a defendant, claiming it had some knowledge of the potential danger and failed to convey it, but the jury exonerated the hospital. The jury deliberated for almost three days before returning to Judge John P. Bourcier's chamber. It awarded $2 million in compensatory damages and $4.9 million in putative damages to each child. It also ordered $6 million in interest on the compensatory damage awards. The Keenans have a 15-year-old daughter who is healthy, Wistow said. ``Obviously, after eight weeks, we are gratified to see the jury accepted our position,'' said Wistow.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Sues Drug Maker Claiming Suicide Effects
DOC.TEXT: A Long Island woman is suing the makers of the anti-depressant drug Prozac for $150 million, claiming the drug caused her to mutilate her own body and to attempt suicide. Rhonda Hala of Shirley charged in her suit that the manufacturer, Eli Lilly & Co. of Indianapolis, failed to warn users that Prozac could cause an obsession with death and violence. There are about 1.5 million people in the United States on Prozac, with 650,000 prescriptions written each month. An Eli Lilly spokeswoman, Marie Abbot, said the company is not removing Prozac from the market and said it has not been shown that the drug causes suicidal thoughts. Mrs. Hala began taking Prozac in 1988 after a spinal disc procedure and withdrawal from painkillers left her depressed. Within two weeks, she said, her thoughts turned to suicide. During her 18 months on Prozac, she slashed her arms, legs and stomach with razor blades and dug scissors and screws into her flesh about 150 times, she said. ``I thought I had someone else's brain in my body,'' said Mrs. Hala, 40, a school secretary. She tried six times to kill herself, requiring hospitalization four times. Her husband and two teen-age children were afraid to leave her alone. ``It was as if I was possessed,'' said Mrs. Hala. ``I was always a happy, up person, but I became obsessed with self-mutilation.'' As her mental state deteriorated, her psychiatrist doubled her dose of Prozac. It was not until he read an article in the American Journal of Psychiatry that he immediately took Mrs. Hala off the drug and her life returned to normal. In the February article, Dr. Martin Teicher of Harvard University and his colleagues reported that six patients had developed violent suicidal thoughts within weeks of taking Prozac. Officials at Eli Lilly and the federal Food and Drug Administration, which approved Prozac in 1988, acknowledge nationwide reports of serious adverse effects from the drug, including ``suicidal ideation.'' But they said it may be impossible to determine if the drug directly caused the suicidal thoughts, or if they were the result of the patient's mental depressed state. ``The idea that Prozac is a killer drug is a little bit silly,'' said psychiatrist Dr. Jerrold Rosenbaum, chief of the Psycho-Pharmacology Unit at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston and associate professor at Harvard University. ``The bottom line is that Prozac is no wonder drug. It has no extravagant claims attached to it, but it has helped a lot of people suffering from depression appreciate the benefits of life,'' Rosenbaum said. Prozac's known side effects include nausea, a rash, agitation and jittery nerves. In the last year, various Prozac support groups have been formed by former users of the drug to publicize their claims of side effects. ``This is a terrible drug,'' said Sharyn DiGeronimo, a Selden resident who founded Prozac Survivors Support Group in New York. DiGeronimo said she receives calls from Prozac patients who report of loosing control or judgement while on the drug. Some were prescribed Prozac to help them stop smoking or loose weight. Abbot, the Eli Lilly spokeswoman, declined comment on the litigation, but acknowledged the company revised its package literature on Prozac last May. The update listed adverse effects reported to the company since Prozac went on the market, including ``suicidal ideation or thoughts associated with the drug.'' ``Suicidal thoughts are unfortunately common among depressive patients,'' Abbot said. ``It is important to note that there has been no cause-effect relationship established between Prozac and the reports of suicidal ideation.'' Dr. Paul Leber, director of the FDA's neuropharmocological products department, said the agency has been monitoring the reports of suicidal or homicidal thoughts. ``We have taken a good, hard look and haven't found anything that leads us to believe that Prozac causes suicidal thoughts,'' said Leber.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Chief Says He's Prepared to Cut Interest Rates
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan says he is ready to support a big deficit-reduction package by lowering interest rates. But some private economists wonder whether that means the Fed is giving up its battle to control inflation. Greenspan told Congress on Wednesday that ``a major cut in the budget deficit is unquestionably the right thing to do.'' He said the central bank stands ready to counteract any adverse impact that would occur from implementing a $50 billion package of spending cuts and tax increases at a time when economic growth is very weak. The administration, which has been pressuring the Fed for months to reduce interest rates, immediately welcomed Greenspan's comments as very supportive of President Bush's efforts to get a budget agreement with Congress. However, some private economists expressed concern that Greenspan's statements, coming on a day when the government reported a worrisome 0.5 percent increase in consumer prices in June, would spook financial markets by signaling that the Fed was no longer concerned about controlling inflation. ``Greenspan apparently has decided that it is more important to keep the economy out of a recession than it is to fight inflation,'' said Michael Evans, head of a Washington forecasting firm. Evans said Greenspan's decision to relent in the Fed's inflation battle with prices still rising at an uncomfortable clip would turn out to be a mistake and require even higher interest rates later to bring inflation under control. ``It is bad for the economy. It will make inflation worse and in the long run that could lead to the very recession he is trying to avoid,'' Evans said. However, other economists said Greenspan was trying to walk a difficult line between being supportive of deficit-cutting efforts while still maintaining vigilance against inflation. ``Greenspan is walking a tightrope,'' said David Wyss, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill Inc. ``Inflation is not going away, but the Fed clearly wants to support the budget negotiations.'' For his part, Greenspan tempered his pledge of support for a budget accord by insisting that the budget package would have to offer a credible package of deficit cuts. He also insisted there was no danger that the nation was about to topple into a recession and therefore the central bank had no plans for an immediate follow-up on the small dose of credit easing taken last Friday. At that time, the Fed supplied enough additional cash to the banking system to push a key interest rate, the federal funds rate, down from 8.25 percent to 8 percent, the first decline since last December. The drop in this rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, triggered a big rally on Wall Street, pushing the stock market to record highs as investors expressed hope that further rate declines would be forthcoming. Greenspan in his testimony Wednesday confirmed that the Fed had eased slightly last week. He said the action was taken to offset the effects of banks becoming overly cautious in making loans. Based on his comments, many analysts predicted that the Fed would push the federal funds rate down by another 0.25 percentage point, perhaps by Labor Day if Congress and the administration have agreed on the outlines of a deficit-cutting package by then. For his part, Greenspan told members of the Senate Banking Committee, ``I can only offer the assurance that the Federal Reserve will act, as it has in the past, to endeavor to keep the economic expansion on track.'' His statements came as part of his midyear report on the state of the economy. In its economic outlook, the Fed said it expected the economy to grow at a modest rate of between 1.75 percent and 2.5 percent in 1991, lower than the administration's forecast Monday of 2.9 percent growth. In assessing current developments, Greenspan said the country had an ``economy which is not on the edge of either falling apart into a recession or about to take on highly inflationary characteristics.''

DOC.HEAD: FTC Won't Endorse Requirement for Health Warnings on Alcohol Ads
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Trade Commission says health warnings on alcohol advertisements could help curb drinking problems, but it's not endorsing a bill to require the labels. Janet D. Steiger, FTC chairwoman, told a House panel Wednesday that requiring advertising warnings, like the labels now required on alcohol cans and bottles, ``can be an effective component of a multi-faceted effort'' against alcohol abuse. The beer and alcohol industry is waging a strong fight against legislation sponsored by Rep. Joseph Kennedy, D-Mass., and Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., that would require five rotating health warnings on beer, wine and liquor ads _ including television commercials. Steiger said ``the evidence is inconclusive'' whether advertising encourages alcohol consumption. ``The decision whether to require the proposed rotating health warnings in alcohol advertisements is a question of public policy that is most appropriately decided by the United States Congress,'' she said. Kennedy told a hearing of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on transportation, tourism and hazardous materials that beer and other alcoholic beverage ads glamorize drinking and are aimed at young people. Rep. Jim Slattery, D-Kan., criticized the beer industry for aiming its advertising at young people. To make his point he displayed a magazine ad for Bud Lite beer featuring the brand's dog mascot sporting sunglasses and a guitar, beneath the headline: ``Play that funky music, Spuds boy.'' ``Somebody has got to put pressure on the industry to be more responsible,'' Slattery said. Steiger responded that the FTC was ``assessing'' whether beer producers were violating federal laws, including the prohibition on unfair and deceptive advertising. But she refused to reveal what might come of that investigation or any private conversations between the FTC and the industry. Alcohol beverage producers spend more than $2 billion a year on advertising and promotion in the United States, according to FTC figures. The bill would require five rotating warnings with messages that drinking during pregnancy may cause birth defects, that drinking and driving is dangerous, that drinking may become addictive, and that it's illegal to buy alcohol for people younger than 21. Opposing the bill, James C. Sanders, president of the Beer Institute, told the panel in written testimony that advertising doesn't cause alcohol abuse and that warnings may be counterproductive. He said the brewing industry is trying to fight alcohol abuse with advertising that urges responsible drinking. Tony Debevc of Chalet Debonne Vineyards in Ohio, representing the Association of American Vintners, said the warnings would impose a burden on small wineries that rely on promotional displays and brochures. For both large and small producers, he said, the warning on ads ``will have the effect of reducing consumption and thus income.''

DOC.HEAD: Budget Bargainers Say GOP Rebellion Won't Deter Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Bush quote cq in 4th graf, ``A lot ...'; Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and congressional leaders say they will continue their long-running effort to reach a budget deal, despite a high hurdle House Republicans have flung in their path. Bush and leaders of the House and Senate met privately Wednesday for 90 minutes at the White House. Both sides said they had made no significant progress in their hunt for $50 billion worth of spending cuts and tax increases for next year. But they said they would meet again Monday and that other meetings between White House staff and lawmakers would be held over the next few days. ``A lot of work still to be done,'' Bush told reporters afterward. Earlier Wednesday, rebellious House Republicans voted informally to oppose any new taxes as part of a deficit-reduction package. Participants in the closed-door meeting said the non-binding resolution passed by a 2-1 margin. This put them in awkward counterpoint to Bush, who last month abandoned his 1988 campaign pledge to reject increased levies. But GOP lawmakers insisted their beef was with Democrats, who they accused of repeatedly opposing efforts to rein federal spending. ``Today we sent a message to congressional Democrats that if they want to raise taxes, they can do it without us,'' said Rep. Richard Armey, R-Texas, who sponsored the resolution. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said lawmakers and Bush had agreed that the Republican vote would not halt the budget summit, which has been under way for more than two months. ``Our decision is to go forward and attempt to reach an agreement,'' Foley told reporters. ``We will not be derailed in our effort to reach an agreement.'' The Democrats reiterated their demand that any budget package written by negotiators must be approved by a majority of both parties in the House and Senate. The GOP resolution singled out Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, for special vilification. ``Mitchell has abandoned the summit goals and emerged as a consistent roadblock to real spending cuts or growth incentives, and has championed tax increases at every turn,'' the document said. Congressional officials, speaking on condition they not be identified, said Armey inserted the clause after reading his original draft _ which did not mention Mitchell _ to White House chief of staff John Sununu. Sununu said the resolution should attack Mitchell, the sources said. Last week, the majority leader said he would reject a cut in the capital gains tax unless income tax rates on the wealthy are increased. Bush is a staunch advocate of reducing the levy on capital gains _ profits from the sale of investments. Mitchell had little to say about his mention in the GOP resolution. Saying he was quoting Abraham Lincoln, he said, ``But for the honor, I would decline.'' Attending the White House meeting were Bush, Foley, Sununu, House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo.; Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan.; House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill.; White House budget director Richard Darman; and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. On Monday, the White House estimated that the budget gap in fiscal 1991 _ which starts Oct. 1 _ will reach $168.8 billion, and tens of billions more if the counts of the savings and loan rescue are counted. The Gramm-Rudman law sets a shortfall target for next year of $64 billion. The law will trigger automatic spending cuts of more than $100 billion unless a budget pact is reached. Lawmakers from the two parties have been meeting separately since last week, trying to put together packages of spending cuts and tax increases that could be advanced at the talks as offers.

DOC.HEAD: Teamsters Threaten UPS With Nationwide Strike
DOC.TEXT: A Teamsters union threat to call a nationwide strike against United Parcel Service of America Inc. marks the second round of difficult contract negotiations between the two sides in less than a decade. The union said it may strike if a new three-year contract isn't approved by July 31, the day the old three-year pact expires, a UPS spokesman said Wednesday. ``We have been informed by the union leadership that if it is rejected, that is their intent,'' said the spokesman, Ken Sternad. ``We think we've made a very good offer.'' Sternad said 140,000 to 150,000 part-time and full-time UPS employees are Teamsters members. The company employs 230,000 workers. Repeated calls to the Teamsters union office in Washington, D.C., and the local office were not returned. When the deadline passed during national negotiations in 1982 and talks were extended, UPS informed its customers that it would stop picking up packages, said Paul R. Schlesinger, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. in New York. ``It was, in essence, a lockout. ... The Teamsters quickly got right-thinking and there was a settlement,'' Schlesinger said. He said a strike wasn't likely, partly because both sides would have too much to lose. ``The Teamsters have the ability to hurt UPS badly. UPS has the ability to take the Teamsters out completely,'' he said, adding that there are more Teamsters at UPS than at any other company. Ballots were mailed during the weekend so union members could vote on the proposed contract, Sternad said. He said the proposal calls for higher wages, improved benefits and better working conditions, adding that the union members are already ``the highest paid of any Teamsters in the country.'' UPS is the world's No. 1 package delivery service. It made 2.8 billion deliveries last year for a record $12.4 billion in revenue. There has never been a national strike against UPS, which has had a national Teamsters contract since 1979, but scattered work stoppages have occurred, Sternad said. The last and biggest one was in 1976, when 18,000 workers in 15 northeastern states walked out for 13 weeks. The proposed contract would raise the wages for the average UPS full-time driver to $18 an hour within two years, Sternad said. UPS drivers now make an average of $16.10 per hour, he said. Part-time workers, mostly package handlers and truck loaders, currently start at $8 or $9 an hour. Under the proposed contract, their wages would go up $1.50 an hour, he said. Company contributions for health benefits and employees' pensions, currently at $8,300 a year for full-time workers, would increase to $10,500 by the end of the three years, Sternad said. For part-time workers, the rate would increase by $1.05 an hour. The proposal also offers a one-time bonus, to be paid within the first month of ratification, of $1,000 to full-timers and $500 to part-timers, he said. If the workers were to strike, customers could turn to the U.S. Postal Service, Federal Express, Roadway Package System and other package delivery companies, analysts said. But opinions were mixed as to whether those services could handle UPS's business. ``UPS handles 10 million pieces a day,'' Schlesinger said. ``There's no way 10 million packages a day are going to be handled by the competitors.'' However, Kevin Murphy, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Co. in New York, said other package delivery services would be able to ``pick up the slack.'' ``The world could live without United Parcel. It wouldn't live as well, but it could live without them,'' Murphy said. Tony Robertson, an analyst with Alex Brown & Sons. Inc. of Baltimore, said in the event of a strike, UPS would lose some business to its competitors, but not much. ``My guess is a certain percentage of air customers and ground customers would never come back,'' Robertson said. ``I think any sort of disruption is going to cost UPS some market share.'' Sternad said no decision has been made about whether UPS would hire replacement workers if the union was to strike.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Merc and Board of Trade Propose Revised Circuit Breaker Limits
DOC.TEXT: Chicago's Mercantile Exchange and Board of Trade have urged other exchanges to join them in endorsing a panel's recommendation for expanded use of trading halts to curb market volatility. The Merc and the Board of Trade on Wednesday jointly proposed revising their ``circuit breakers'' and procedures on stock index futures. Circuit breakers halt trading when certain triggers are reached. They are usually keyed to movement in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The revised circuit breakers modify existing price limits on both the Merc and the Board of Trade, which since 1988 have been set in coordination with the New York Stock Exchange. The NYSE calculates its circuit breakers based on the Dow Jones Industrial Average. In June, an 18-member New York Stock Exchange panel proposed halting trading for an hour when the Dow moves up or down 100 points from the previous day's close, 90 minutes when it moves 200 points, and two hours when it moves 300 points. The longer halts are designed to give market participants more time to react. The Merc and the Board of Trade also endorsed a recommendation calling on other securities, securities options and futures exchanges to adopt these coordinated circuit breakers. The New York panel was formed after the 190-point plunge by the Dow on Oct. 13, 1989. The proposed revised circuit breakers need final approval of the Commodities Futures Trading Commission, and are conditional on acceptance of the longer halts by the NYSE and other exchanges. In the meantime, the Merc and the Board of Trade will maintain their daily stock index futures price limits.

DOC.HEAD: Top British and Japanese Computer Makers Negotiating Link
DOC.TEXT: STC PLC, the parent company of Britain's biggest computer maker, today said it was negotiating the sale of a majority stake in its computer arm to Japan's leading computer manufacturer, Fujitsu Ltd. Such a stake in the subsidiary International Computers Ltd., or ICL, would give Fujitsu a major foothold in Europe ahead of the creation of the single European market in 1992, while offering ICL security for the future, analysts said. STC, formerly known as Standard Telephones and Cables, confirmed the negotiations after Fujitsu President Tadashi Sekizawa said earlier in Tokyo that his company was considering purchasing an interest in ICL, but that ``nothing has been decided yet.'' Newspaper reports in Britain and Japan have said Fujitsu would acquire 50 percent to 60 percent of ICL's equity for about 650 million pounds, or about $1.2 billion. ICL is worth about 1.2 billion pounds, or $2.2 billion, analysts estimate. There have been rumors for a year about a possible equity tie between ICL and Fujitsu, which already have technology links, London analysts said. But analysts said they were surprised that STC might sell a controlling stake to the Japanese company. Such a deal could inflame nationalist sentiment, which frequently meets foreign bids in Britain. ``This is a significant event,'' said Andrew Harrington, an analyst at the London investment firm Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd. ICL is the most profitable computer company of its kind in Europe, analysts said. It makes mainframe computers mostly for the British market. Fujitsu's major activity in Europe is selling semiconductor computer chips, although it makes office computers in Spain, and semiconductors in Ireland. It has marketing and development arms in Britain, West Germany, and the Netherlands. ICL uses Fujitsu's computer chips and disks. Given those ties, Fujitsu is the only company that could take control of ICL, said an analyst who requested anonymity. ``They are the brains in ICL's mainframe computers,'' she said. ``Technologically, they are vital to the future of ICL.'' STC Chairman Alan Walsh said earlier this year that his company was looking for a partner to help carry the burden of heavy research and development costs associated with the rapidly changing computer industry. ICL's operating profit increased 13 percent to 146 million pounds, or $266 million, from 129 million pounds, or $235 million, last year. Its sales were up 18 percent to 1.61 billion pounds, $2.9 billion, from 1.36 billion pounds, or $2.5 billion. STC said after-tax profit figures were not available. Despite ICL's healthy 1989 performance, STC issued a profit warning in June. The parent company said it anticipated a sluggish market due to launch costs of new ICL products and key customers deferring capital purchases.

DOC.HEAD: Industrial Production Plummets; 30,000 More Lose Jobs
DOC.TEXT: East German industrial production plunged by 15 percent in June and half a million workers have had their hours and wages slashed in the past two weeks, the government said today. More than 700,000 workers now have either lost their jobs or faced sharp cuts in their salaries because of the country's quick move to a free market, the government said. Lawmakers debated how to keep financing the country until unification with West Germany, as more than 2,000 uniformed police officers demonstrated outside the Parliament to demand better wages. About 500,000 East German workers have had their hours reduced since July 1, when the nation merged its economy with West Germany's in a step to full unification, said East Germany's labor minister, Regine Hildebrandt. Under a program financed by West Germany, workers who normally would be targeted for layoffs are being paid about 60 percent of their salaries to remain in the factories, where they are to receive training for other jobs. On Wednesday, the government announced that unemployment was at 223,876, about 2.7 percent of the 8 million East German workers. That was up from 30,000 jobless in March. Together, the number of workers who have either lost their jobs or are in the subsidized jobs program is nearly 724,000, or about 9 percent of the work force. The government statistics office announced today that production was down 15.1 percent in June from the same time a year earlier, and down 7.3 percent during the first six months of this year compared with the same period last year. Economists say unemployment could reach 3 million within a year as uncompetitive East German companies go bankrupt, unable to make the adjustment from a centrally planned ecomomy to a free market. On Tuesday, the government said 2,400 of the country's 8,000 companies _ 30 percent _ are unable to pay their bills. The two Germanys joined their economies and monetary systems on July 1 and are expected to merge into one nation by the end of the year. Arno Donda, statistics office chief, also said that living costs for East Germans rose 12.1 percent in June compared to June 1989. The figure does not cover the economic union that began July 1, when East Germany's borders were opened to Western products and many prices for basic necessities skyrocketed. About 2,500 East German police demonstrated in front of the Parliament building to demand job security and better wages to keep up with higher living costs. They also said they need more money for their expanded duties, including dealing with rising crime. The East Berlin newspaper Berliner Zeitung reported today that crime has risen since East Germany threw off its Communist government last fall, embraced democracy and opened its borders to the West. About 130,000 robberies, break-ins and larcenies were reported from January to June, a 6.2 percent increase from the same period in the previous year.

DOC.HEAD: U995
Editors:
DOC.TEXT:
The fixture that moves as BC-WTI Noon will be renamed BC-Noon Oil, effective today, to reflect a change in the product quoted by the New York Mercantile Exchange.
AP Business News

The stock market gave ground today, weighed down by earnings disappointments at several high-technology companies. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 3.21 to 2,978.47 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 375 up, 585 down and 496 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 22.47 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The day's most conspicuous losers were concentrated in over-the-counter technology issues with wide followings in the financial world. Lotus Development tumbled 6{ to 24}. On Wednesday the company posted strong earnings, as expected, for the second quarter, but said its third-quarter profits might fall short of comparable year-ago levels. Apple Computer dropped 3] to 41\ after the company also warned that its earnings for the current quarter might show a decline. Ashton-Tate, which reported an unexpectedly wide loss for the second quarter, tumbled 1] to 9. Given that kind of turbulence, analysts said it wasn't surprising that the market as a whole experienced a bumpy ride. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost .30 to 198.53. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .63 at 361.43. On Wednesday the Dow Jones industrial average fell 18.07 to 2,981.68. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 2 to 1 on the NYSE, with 469 up, 1.012 down and 546 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 168.76 million shares, against 176.79 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Backers Trying to Salvage Crop Insurance Program
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 10-14th grafs `The Apropriations...' to add details on crop insurance; Picks up 10th graf pvs `Whitten objected...' This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of federal crop insurance for farmers are looking for ways to save the program, despite elimination of its funding for fiscal 1991 by the House. Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., assailed the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee for cutting the program's money from the $50.35 billion agriculture spending bill that the House approved, 335-86, Wednesday. He said the action by Rep. Jamie Whitten, D-Miss., posed ``a direct threat to the economic well being of farmers of this nation.'' But neither English, who chairs the House Agriculture subcommittee studying ways to improve crop insurance, nor any other proponents tried to amend the bill on the floor. Agriculture Committee Chairman Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, said he thought farmers would get the wrong signal from the bill. ``Crop insurance has become a tool of the new farming era,'' said de la Garza. He said many farmers can't get loans to do their planting without the insurance. Rep. Edward Madigan, R-Ill., ranking Republican on the Agriculture Committee, said crop insurance would be saved somehow. ``In the farm bill, we can do something to offset what Whitten has done,'' he said. ``It would be easier than to fight with him on the floor.'' He also indicated that the appropriations bill might be adjusted by the Senate to reinstate crop insurance. The Appropriations Committee cut the amount available to the crop insurance program by $337 million and instructed the Agriculture Department not to sell any new policies after Sept. 10. A total $262 million was appropriated for phase-out costs and to make payments on policies that are being written now and until the cut-off date. The Bush administration also opposes the program and has said $601 million would be needed in 1991 to operate at the current level. Spending for 1990 has been $400 million. The alternative to crop insurance is straight-out disaster payments, which Congress has regularly made when multi-state weather problems cause extensive crop losses. Only about 40 percent of the eligible farmers are participating in the insurance program. Farmers who don't buy it say its premiums are too high, yields are inadequate and price forecasting for certain crops by insurance companies is inaccurate. Insurance policies can be purchased through private companies or the federal government. Thirty percent of all costs are paid for by the government. Whitten objected to the program as unsuccessful and costly. ``We have a long record of trying to work out an actuarially sound crop insuranc program,'' he said. ``I don't know if that can be done or not. ... The big money goes to those engaged in the insurance business.'' Whitten's stronginterest in agriculture and his 41-year tenure as chairman of the agriculture appropriations subcommittee has made him a powerful force in American farming whose wishes are not easily challenged. Five efforts to cut his bill's spending across the board were defeated. Debate over one of them, offered by Republicans to rib the Democrats, degenerated into partisan accusations about the federal deficit. Rep. Robert Walker, R-Pa., sought an amendment to cut $19.90 frm the bill after four others that would have skimmed 2 percent to 9.5 percent from all programs covered by the legislation were defeated. Minority Whip Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., acknowledged that the Walker amendment was a joke offered in reaction to House defeat Tuesday of a constitutional amendment to balance the budget. Walker said: ``If in 1990, we can cut $19.90, then next year we can muster the courage to go to $19.91.'' The comments led Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., to charge that the Republicans caused the deficit problems. ``When poor, old, beleaguered Jimmy Carter left office the national debt was $932 billion,'' said Obey. ``The national debt today is $3.38 trillion. It has been tripled because this Congress gutlessly and spinelessly followed the policies of the Reagan administration and its successor.'' The overall agriculture appropriation for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1, is $5.2 billion more than this year's funding, but $86.5 million less than requested by the administration. ``I just can't understand the efforts to cut,'' said Whitten. ``I get asked about the balanced budget. I advise that I believe in the balanced budget, but not at the expense of sound programs that are absolutely essential to the well-being of the American people.'' The measure provides money for the Agriculture Department administrative operations, research projects, price supports, rural development, domestic food assistance and international programs. The bill also funds the Food and Drug Administration and Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

DOC.HEAD: Textron Earnings Improve 21 Percent in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Textron Inc. reported today that its net income in the second quarter improved 21.5 percent to $72.1 million. The company said the earnings, which amount to 80 cents per share, had improved from the $59.3 million, or 67 cents per share, it earned from April through June 1989. Last year's second quarter included an extraordinary loss of $9.5 million. Revenue rose during the three months this year to $2 billion from $1.8 billion. B.F. Dolan, chairman and chief executive officer, credited the company's financial services subsidiaries for the improvement. Among its aerospace technology companies, its systems segment increased earnings significantly, but other divisions, particularly helicopters, had poor results. Systems earned $17.9 million, up from $5 million. But helicopters earnings declined to $27 million from $34.7 million, largely because Bell Helicopter had a ``less favorable mix of non-U.S. government sales,'' Dolan said. For the first six months, Textron's net income improved 12.8 percent to $138.3 million, or $1.53 per share, on revenue of $3.9 billion. For the first half of 1989, income was $122.6 million, or $1.40 per share, on $3.7 billion in revenue. Textron's commercial products sector included dividends of $6.5 million from Avdel for the first half of the year. But interest expense on borrowing related to the purchase of the company amounted to $10.6 million, wiping out the dividend. The Federal Trade Commission has obtained a preliminary injunction barring Textron from acquiring Avdel because of concerns over competition.

DOC.HEAD: Day 2 at GM; Day 1 at Ford
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs with Ford talks opening; picks up 5th graf pvs `The contracts ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing.
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers union will press automakers for better job-protection guarantees than they agreed to in 1987, UAW President Owen Bieber says. Since the current agreements with the Big Three were signed, two of the companies have halted production at six assembly plants, putting about 17,000 people out of work. Those closings, what the companies call ``indefinite idlings,'' are among the reasons the union has tapped job security as its No. 1 priority in this summer's negotiations with General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. As talks opened this morning at Ford, company Vice President Peter Pestillo reached across the bargaining table with two fingers bandaged to shake hands with Bieber. Pestillo pleaded with the 6-foot-5, 250-pound Bieber to squeeze lightly, explaining his dog was hit by a car and the animal bit Pestillo when he went to its aid. He didn't say how the dog was before reporters were ushered from the room to allow talks to begin. Talks started Wednesday at GM and get under way Friday at Chrysler. The contracts cover more than 450,000 active workers and nearly as many retirees. All three contracts expire at midnight, Sept. 14. It's the first time that's happened in 11 years. Besides job security, the union will seek recalls for laid off workers, wage and pension improvements, more accountability from management and a linking of executives' bonus payments to profit-sharing awards for hourly workers. The companies are expected to press for increased flexibility in work assignments and a variety of cost-reduction issues, including health-care, which is likely to take up a good deal of bargaining time. After a brief preliminary meeting between the full company and union bargaining committees at the GM Building on Wednesday, Bieber sharply criticized the huge automaker for ``performing the cynical, semantic maneuver represented by the term `idling' plants.'' ``We told the corporation that disappointment is far too mild a word to describe our feelings about how they perceived their job security commitments they made to us three years ago,'' he said. GM's chief negotiator, Vice President Alfred Warren Jr., declined to get into a discussion about specific issues likely to command time at the main bargaining table or in smaller, issue-oriented subcommittees. However, he referred frequently to GM's need to cut costs, especially in its component operations. ``We must find innovative and cost-effective ways to become more competitive in component manufacturing,'' he said. GM has about 40 percent of its 280,000 active, UAW-covered employees working in component plants, which make, for example, air-conditioning systems, radios and transmissions. GM makes more of the components that go into its cars and trucks than do Ford or Chrysler, and it sells components to other manufacturers. Warren declined to say how GM thought it could become more competitive with other component manufacturers, but said competition dictated that it must. Each of the Big Three have said the age of their work forces, at an average of about 42 years, coupled with UAW-negotiated health-care provisions, boost the price of each car. Warren said company provided health-care benefits add $622 to the cost of every car and truck GM sells. Such costs for Japanese companies making vehicles in the United States, with an average worker age of younger than 30, are between $50 and $100. One of the most emotional issues on the UAW side of the talks is cost-of-living protection for retirees. At a demonstration outside the GM Building on Wednesday, about 2,000 protesters sought a contract provision linking pension payments to inflation. Such a proposal, the company and union have said, could cost billions of dollars, perhaps more than the rest of a contract combined. It's more likely that the two sides can reach agreements on lump-sum payments to retirees rather than tying pension boosts to increases in the inflation rate.

DOC.HEAD: As Expected, AT&T Reports Lower Second-Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. today reported its second-quarter earnings fell 6.4 percent due to lower equipment sales and unexpectedly high startup costs for the company's new credit card. AT&T warned of an expected drop in earnings in an unusual announcement three weeks ago, but it did not say how much it would be. AT&T said it earned $657 million, or 60 cents a share, in the quarter ended June 30, down from $699 million, or 65 cents a share, in the same quarter of 1989. Revenue also fell, to $9.03 billion from $9.26 billion in the same quarter of last year. The company said the disappointing results were due mostly to slower sales of corporate telephone systems, data communications gear and equipment sold to the federal government, as well as unexpectedly high costs for processing applications for its Universal card, which combines a MasterCard or Visa with telephone charging privileges. AT&T blamed the lower equipment sales on a sluggish economy, while it said the Universal card proved far more popular than it expected. It also said its long-distance revenue was down in the quarter due to less favorable access charge settlements with local phone companies and customer shifts to lower-cost AT&T services. ``We still expect 1990 to be better than 1989, a record earnings year,'' said Chairman Robert E. Allen. ``These results do not alter our confidence in our direction or our future prospects.'' For the first six months of the year, AT&T earned $1.325 billion, or $1.22 per share, up from $1.293 billion, or $1.20 a share. Revenue totaled $17.9 billion, virtually unchanged from the same period of 1989. AT&T's announcement last month of expected lower earnings sent its stock price tumbling. AT&T is the nation's most widely held stock. In early trading today, AT&T shares were off 25 cents at $36.87{.

DOC.HEAD: Earnings Dip, Reflecting Costs of Great Northern Takeover
DOC.TEXT: Georgia-Pacific Corp. said today its second quarter earnings were down 38 percent from a year ago, reflecting the costs involved in its recent $5 billion takeover of Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. Earnings for the three months ended June 30 were $107 million, or $1.25 a share, down from $172 million, or $1.90 a share, in 1989's second quarter. The recent three-month period was the first full quarter in which the two corporations were combined. The rival paper products companies agreed to merge in February, ending nearly four months of resistance by Connecticut-based Great Northern. Georgia-Pacific's sales for the quarter were $3.5 billion, up from $2.6 billion in the second 1989 quarter, but the increase was offset by takeover-related interest expenses, the company said. Interest expenses for the quarter were $185 million, up from $66 million a year ago. In the earnings report released today, Georgia-Pacific Chairman T. Marshall Hahn Jr. stressed the sales gains. ``The company's building products business has experienced a record second quarter,'' he said, noting that despite a decline in housing starts the company has benefited from an increased demand for materials used in the remodeling and repair market. Prices for the company's forestry products are up also because of a diminishing supply of timber in the Northwest, he said. The company's pulp and paper divisions have shown gains mainly because of demand for communication papers, Hahn said. For the six months ended June 30, Georgia-Pacific's net income was $208 million, or $2.43 per share, down 36 percent from $326 million, or $3.55 a share, for the first half of 1989. Six-month net sales were $6.2 billion, up from $5.1 billion during the same period a year earlier.

DOC.NOTE: $adv23
For release Monday July 23
DOC.HEAD: Government Holding Big Closeout on Businesses From Airline to Phone Co.
LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: If Argentina placed a classified ad, here's how it might look: Buyers wanted for used planes, trains, roads, power plants and a phone company. For information, contact President Carlos Menem. Dozens of inefficient businesses, industries and monopolies created by the government or nationalized decades ago are now up for grabs in what amounts to a large-scale closeout sale. They're worth many billions of dollars. In late June, the government peddled a majority stake in the telephone company ENTel, leased more than 6,000 miles of federal highways and granted foreign companies access to potentially rich oil fields. Other items on the for-sale agenda range from radio stations to gambling casinos. Under Menem, the reform-minded leader who took office a year ago, the state-run bureacracy that has dominated Argentina's economy since the 1940s is redefining its role, and stepping back. The main reason is that the once prosperous South American nation is undergoing recession, high unemployment and triple-digit inflation all at the same time. Its foreign debt of $66 billion is third-highest in the developing world. The government is bankrupt. ``Argentina is not well. Argentina is broken,'' Menem said when inaugurated last July. ``At this historic time begins the reconstruction.'' As he said little about it in his campaign, few Argentines suspected Menem had in mind selling companies taken over by his party's founder, Juan Domingo Peron, beginning in the 1940s. But Menem concluded the entities that once were an economic engine had become an anchor, which he is trying to cut loose. Oil production stagnated in the 1980s because the state company YPF lacked money and technology. Promising areas were never explored. Potentially an exporter, Argentina barely produces enough for domestic needs. One-third of the state highway system of 14,670 miles is in marginal shape or worse, government assessments show. Private studies say half the roads need basic repairs. Forty percent of the locomotives are out of service at any given time, the state train company Ferrocarriles Argentinos admits. Nearly half the track is so worn that train engineers creep over it slowly to avoid derailment. Argentines wait years to get a new telephone line only to find it's impossible to call another city because of jammed circuits. Within Buenos Aires, calls frequently are misdirected, callers often cannot hear each other and sometimes they don't get a dial tone. ``The system is in collapse,'' said ENTel director Maria Julia Alsogaray. By all accounts, state-run companies are poorly managed, overstaffed and strangled in bureaucracy and petty corruption. Strikers often shut them down. Fares go uncollected on state trains. Employees of the state water and electricity companies get service at a discount. Politicians receive free tickets on the state airline. The 13 biggest state-run companies, which ring up huge debts among themselves, lost nearly $4 billion in 1989, enough to pay off a sizable chunk of foreign debt. Buenos Aires, once known as one of the loveliest and most sophisticated capitals, is getting a reputation for Third World deprivation. The city of 10 million rationed energy last year when drought shriveled production at already-overburdened hydroelectric complexes. Among other problems, labor unions are intransigent, courts are too overworked to adequately enforce contracts, and markets are so volatile that currency and interest rates seesaw daily. So who would want to buy Argentina's companies? Surprisingly, bidders abound. Bell Atlantic Corp. of the United States and Telefonica of Spain bought a controlling stake of ENTel by offering $214 million cash and $5 billion in debt securities. They hope new investment and tighter accounting will pay off. The government will sell the balance of the company later this year. About 50 Argentine and foreign companies agreed to improve nearly 6,200 miles of federal highways in return for the right to charge tolls. The state carrier Aerolineas Argentinas fetched $260 million cash and $2 billion in assumed debt _ both higher than the government expected _ when it was put to bid. Iberia, Spain's state airline, is expected to take formal ownership later this year. For Menem, privatizations are a political gamble. Organized labor helped elect him and now opposes his sell-everything policy. Even allies in the Peronist party aren't too happy. Businesses executives clamor for the state subsidies Menem curtailed, and resent the tariff reductions and free-market currency exchange rate that push them to compete more aggressively with overseas producers. Provincial governors want federal revenue sharing increased. Menem, however, views economic austerity and free market orientation as the only way Argentina might regain the prosperity it had through the 1940s, based on the export of beef and grain. In his view, the last thing Argentina needs are dinosaur-like money-losers. By selling ENTel, for example, the government will save hundreds of millions of dollars in interest payments on the company's debt. It also won't have to absorb ENTel's staggering losses, which totaled $250 million last year. Moreover, terms of the sale call for the investment of several hundred million dollars within two years that the government could hardly have afforded. Jobs will be saved and services improved, Menem contends. In the energy sector, $4 billion in private funds will be invested in oil, natural gas and petrochemical projects in the next four years, energy undersecretary Julio Araoz has projected.
