DOC.HEAD: Hasbro Reports Sharply Reduced Second-Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Sharply lower sales during the past three months cut Hasbro Inc.'s second-quarter profit nearly 52 percent from the comparable period a year earlier, the company reported today. The Pawtucket-based toy maker earned $8.7 million, or 15 cents per share, from April through June this year, compared to $18.1 million, or 31 cents per share, during the same three months of 1989. That was because of dismal revenue of about $277.3 million during this year's second quarter, down 7.8 percent from the year earlier's $301.3 million. Some expenses also rose this year, contributing to the poor results. Those expenses included such things as research and product development, the cost of sales and distribution and administration. Hasbro blamed the poor performance on slow domestic sales. ``While our European units are enjoying continued strong levels of revenues and earnings, both in U.S. dollars and their local currencies, our domestic units have not fared as well,'' Alan G. Hassenfeld, chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement. The company is banking on improvements during the third quarter, primarily because of the planned introductions of two new products. Those are dolls based on the pop music group New Kids on the Block and on performers affiliated with the World Wrestling Federation. ``If anticipated improvements in customer order trends in the second half of the year occur and there is a positive response to new promotionsl products being shipped in the third quarter, we believe 1990 full-year results will approximate those of 1989,'' Hassenfeld said. For the first six months of this year, earnings plummetted 23.6 percent to $28.2 million, or 48 cents per share, from $36.9 million, or 63 cents per share. That was based on revenue of $578.4 million for the first half of this year, compared to $589.7 million last year. Hasbro's announcement of its poor performance comes on the heels of a lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court in which a shareholder complained that the company hid its declining sales to prop up its stock price. Frederic Braunschweiger, who filed his suit in Providence, said Hasbro executives knew that orders from retailers were down from 1989 and that the company's market share was dropping quickly, but did not acknowledge that publicly until Hassenfeld told the Dow Jones New Service in an interview late last month. If Hasbro had disclosed its problems earlier, investors would not have bought Hasbro stock ``at the artificially inflated prices that they did,'' Braunschweiger charged in court documents.

DOC.HEAD: Unisys Profit Drops Sharply in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Unisys Corp. today reported its second-quarter profit plunged and that it had a net loss per common share after paying preferred stock dividends. The nation's third-largest computer company blamed the results in part on weak domestic sales. Unisys said it earned $11.8 million, down from $53.6 million in the second quarter of 1989. After allowing for the mandatory preferred dividends, the company had a loss per common share of 9 cents, compared with per-share earnings of 17 cents in the year-ago quarter. Revenue totaled $2.47 billion, down from $2.57 billion for the second quarter of 1989. That quarter benefited significantly from the initial volume shipment of the company's new 2200 Series mainframe computers, the company said. Unisys stock was up 12{ cents a share at $12.75 this morning in New York Stock Exchange trading. Unisys said its worldwide orders posted a slight gain in the quarter as defense systems orders rebounded from depressed levels a year earlier. Gains in international commercial computer orders were offset by continued weakness in U.S. orders. The quarterly comparison was hurt by last year's strong 2200 Series sales, particularly abroad, Unisys said. James A. Unruh, Unisys' president and chief executive officer, said the company was making gradual but steady progress in improving its business operations and financial structure. The company reduced its debt by $265 million in the quarter. Unruh said Unisys made ``significant progress'' toward its goal of reducing its debt by $600 million to $800 million during 1990. For the first six months of the year, Unisys said it earned $8.6 million on revenue of $4.8 billion, compared with a loss of $25.1 million on virtually identical revenue a year ago. The company reported a per-share loss of 28 cents in this year's first six months, compared with a loss per share of 50 cents in the year-ago period.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Slightly Higher
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were slightly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, paced by gains in the soybean complex. Analysts said soybean prices have fallen low enough over the past two weeks to stimulate new export demand, and trading on the European soybean meal market has grown more active in recent days. But the early gains were limited by beneficial crop weather. Showers and cooler temperatures were expected to spread across the Corn Belt tonight and tomorrow. A new National Weather Service forecast for mild, rainy weather next week in the Midwest held no threat of heat stress to the corn crop, which is moving through its critical pollination phase. In early trading, wheat futures were } cent to 1} cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.01{ a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to 1 cent higher with July at $2.72} a bushel; oats were \ cent to } cent higher with September at $1.23 a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 4{ cents higher with July at $6.02{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures fell in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork futures were down sharply with near-term pork bellly contracts down the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound. Live cattle futures were .05 cent to .22 cent lower with August at 76.05 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .27 cent lower with August at 87.12 cents a pound; live hogs were .23 cent to .90 cent lower with July at 63.72 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .90 cent to 2 cents lower with July at 46.50 cents a pound. Cattle futures advanced on Wednesday; pork futures were mostly lower.

DOC.NOTE: $adv25
For release Wednesday July 25
DOC.HEAD: Budding Business: Items That Clean the Wax Off Your Produce
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The typical cucumber is so caked with wax you could add a wick and almost call it a candle. But it's waxed foods that catch the eye of even the savviest shopper who will meticulously pick through produce for that picture-pretty item, leaving the duller _ but perhaps healthier _ alternative behind. The wax itself isn't harmful. What concerns people are pesticides and fungicides found in the wax. Some businesses have capitalized on this fear, developing scrub products they claim will remove waxes and other chemicals from the surface of fruits and vegetables. ``I was cleaning my produce at the kitchen sink using water when it dawned on me that if I'm going to invest my time washing, I should at least be doing a thorough job,'' said Steve Abo, president of a Los Angeles company that markets a produce wash in spray bottles. Many consumers know that apples, like cucumbers, get much of their luster from wax. What they may not realize is how many fresh produce items are coated with wax _ oranges, grapefruits, avocados, bananas, beets, watermelons, pineapples, eggplants, peaches, peppers, squash, garlic, onion, potatoes, tomatoes and turnips. Even if there is no sheen, a fruit or vegetable could still be covered. Wax is now applied in such a thin film that it's hard to tell just by looking. About 10,000 apples can be coated with a single ounce. The wax replaces natural coatings removed by scrubs and detergent washes between picking and packing. It keeps food from losing moisture and spoiling. What's troubling is that fungicides _ some considered possible causes of cancer _ are encased in the wax, said Beth Kaufman of the Washington-based Center for Science in the Public Interest. ``Consumers look for the prettiest vegetable or fruit, which is usually waxed,'' Kaufman said. ``Consumers have to let producers know they're more concerned about the food than just how it looks.'' Abo, who grew up on avocado and lemon farms in California and Arizona, said his product removes chemicals that don't wash off with water alone. He won't disclose what's in his spray, except to say the ingredients are non-toxic. Another company, Bio Scrub Industries near Albany, N.Y., is planning to market a ``veggy fruit scrub brush'' which claims to remove surface wax, soil, chemicals and pesticides. The product is a soft-bristle brush that emits a liquid containing purified water and cleaning agents. It will be sold through mail-order catalogs and cost $8.45 per three-pack, said company president Mark Sterman. Consumer groups are skeptical. The Center for Science in the Public Interest, for example, said the ingredients in these washes look suspiciously like those in ordinary dishwashing detergent. ``We're not convinced that specialty scrubs are any better than plain old detergent, and they can cost up to eight times more,'' said Lisa Lefferts, a staff scientist at the center. Lefferts questioned whether these products will even remove wax, as many claim. Abo, a biochemist, said he understands the center's position. ``I think their angle is that there's a lot of entrepreneurs putting detergent in bottles, diluting it and selling it,'' he said. The Food and Drug Administration says fungicides approved for use with waxes are safe within certain limits. But among those approved by the FDA is Benomyl, considered a possible carcinogen in humans. Also included is ortho-phenylphenol, an immune-system suppressant, and sodium ortho-phenyl phenate, another possible carcinogen. Food-coloring agents may be added, a common practice for Florida oranges which are often picked green. Some waxes are made with animal lard. Critics question the safety of fungicides, particularly in combination with wax, which keeps them bound to food. ``While there is no reason to believe that waxes pose a health risk to humans, there is reason to be concerned about the pesticides that are often mixed with waxes. A number of fungicides that are added to waxes have been shown to cause increased risk of some diseases, including cancer,'' says ``The Wax Cover-Up,'' a report issued this spring by the Center for Science in the Public Interest. For more than 50 years, federal law has required that shipping cartons and store labels disclose when wax is used. Another federal law adopted in the 1950s also requires disclosure of post-harvest pesticides. Critics say these laws aren't strictly followed and in some cases are ignored, because the federal government relies on state inspectors to enforce them. But some states are enacting their own tough labeling laws. Maine requires food retailers to post signs informing consumers that its produce may have been treated with chemicals. The New Hampshire legislature has passed a bill requiring labeling of produce coated with wax. Similar legislation is pending in Illinois, Tennessee and New York. Efforts for tighter enforcement have upset growers, however. The United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association, for example, said labeling waxed produce is nearly impossible. The group said different shipments of the same item, which may be coated with different wax ingredients, are often mixed together on supermarket shelves. The association, which represents producers nationwide, said keeping the differently treated items separate is difficult. Health experts say consumers should scrub produce to remove residues and coatings. The Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association recommends using a vegetable brush, hot water and detergent. Removing the peel will reduce exposure to wax and fungicide coatings. But it's a tradeoff since the peel contains fiber which may help reduce the risk of cancer. Health experts say organic fruits and vegetables are grown and treated without the use of synthetic chemicals and wax coatings are not applied.

DOC.HEAD: American Express Reports Flat Earnings
DOC.TEXT: American Express Co. reported Thursday its results were virtually flat in the second quarter as gains in its charge card and travelers check business were partially offset by a profit decline at its Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. brokerage subsidiary. The financial services company said it earned $319.6 million, or 73 cents per share, up 1.1 percent from $316.1 million, or 73 cents per share, in the second quarter of 1989. Revenue fell to $6.06 billion from $6.36 billion a year earlier, reflecting a drop in Shearson's revenue to $2.62 billion from $3.29 billion. American Express said its results reflected the costs of purchasing $750 million in preferred stock from Shearson at the end of the first quarter. American Express, which currently owns about 60 percent of Shearson, plans to take full control of its subsidiary and issue 25.4 million new shares to finance the transaction. Stockholders will vote on the plan next month. Shearson reported $51 million in earnings, down from $55 million a year earlier. American Express said its share of Shearson's earnings was $26.5 million, down from $33.8 million last year. American Express has pumped $1 billion in capital into the struggling division in recent months and ordered a restructuring that included about 2,000 layoffs. Shearson is reorganizing its corporate structure, combining four divisions into two and plans to rename itself Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. American Express' standout division in the second quarter was its Travel Related Services division, which includes the firm's charge card and travelers check business. The division posted a 16.3 percent rise in earnings, to $249.2 million from $214.2 million a year earlier. Earnings at American Express Bank, which generally operates outside the United States, fell 10.5 percent to $31.7 million from $35.4 million a year earlier. The division suffered a $7 million drop in earnings from its lesser developed country activities, a business from which American Express is withdrawing. The company's IDS Financial Services division, a financial planning business, reported a 20.6 percent earnings gain to $51.6 million from $42.8 million. American Express' Information Services Co. recorded a 25.3 percent earnings gain to $21.9 million from $17.4 million. For the first six months of the year, American Express said it lost $300.2 million, or 75 cents per share, compared with earnings of $568 million, or $1.32 per share, in the first half of 1989. This year's first-half results include a $915 million loss at Shearson. First-half revenue fell to $11.97 billion from $12.22 billion in the same period last year.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 9 Percent Profit Growth
DOC.TEXT: Ralston Purina Co. on Thursday reported a 9 percent quarterly profit gain, reflecting lower costs for pet and human food ingredients combined with higher sales of cereals and strength in baked goods. The company earned $92.4 million, or $1.55 a share, in its third quarter, up from $83.8 million, or $1.27 a share, in the corresponding 1989 quarter. For the three months ended June 30, the St. Louis-based company had sales of $1.71 billion, up 5 percent from $1.62 billion for the same 1989 period. Company spokesman Pat Farrell said the increase stemmed largely from lower ingredient costs for pet and human foods, higher sales of cereal and bigger profits in baked goods. Ralston Purina is a leading maker of pet food and cereal. The company also makes Eveready and Energizer batteries and owns Continetal Baking Co., which makes such well-known products as Wonder bread and Hostess Twinkies. Farrell said profits declined at Eveready Battery in the third quarter primarily because of lower sales and heavy discounting. The company also noted in the second quarter report that it was increasing its stock repurchase program. In March, the company announced a plan to buy up to 2 million shares of its common stock and now says it's authorized to buy an additional 521,000 shares. For the first nine months of the year, the company reported income of $314.3 million, or $5.08 a share, compared with $377.3 million, or $5.75 a share, for the same period a year earlier. The decrease was a result of the absence of profits from the discontinued Van Camp Seafood operations, which Ralston sold last year. Sales for the first nine months were $5.31 billion, up from $4.89 billion for the same period last year.

DOC.HEAD: Stotler Announces Investor Offer
DOC.TEXT: A financially strapped commodity brokerage headed by Chicago Board of Trade Chairman Karsten Mahlmann said today it has tentatively accepted an investor's offer to buy a substantial stake in the company. The brokerage, Stotler and Co., also confirmed that it had brought itself into compliance with the federal government's minimum capital requirements. The developments mean Stotler could avert a cash-flow crisis and will avoid restrictions on its brokerage operations while sparing Mahlmann further embarrassment. Stotler's parent company, Chicago-based Stotler Group Inc., made the announcements in a one-page statement. Stotler and Co., an old-line grain-trading firm, is Stotler Group's principal subsidiary. Stotler Group did not identify the prospective investor or the size of the stake the party would buy in the parent company. The statement said the offer was subject to approval by the investor's board of directors. The offer would terminate if such approval is not granted by 11 a.m. EDT Monday, Stotler Group said. Stotler Group confirmed Wednesday's Board of Trade announcement that it had brought itself into compliance with the minimum capital requirements of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. In a three-paragraph statement released late Wednesday, the Board of Trade said Stotler had given the exchange a plan last week for meeting a CFTC requirement that futures brokerages maintain in a separate account liquid assets equal to 4 percent of customer funds. ``The exchange believes the firm has achieved the requisite capital requirements,'' the exchange said. ``They have at all times during this period had more than enough in segregated liquid assets to cover all customer segregated fund obligations and the exchange is continuing to monitor the compliance status of Stotler and all other member firms,'' the statement concluded. Board of Trade spokesman Michael O'Connell said he could not elaborate on the statement. Officials at Stotler and its parent company, Stotler Group Inc., did not return telephone calls. The exchange ordered Stotler on Monday to boost its capital to the required level by the close of business Wednesday or face restrictions on its trading activities. The parent company said Stotler would try to meet the capital requirement by both reducing the size of its business and seeking outside financial help, without which it said Stotler might have trouble meeting its debt obligations. The exchange can force a brokerage out of the business of trading for customers if the capital level falls below 4 percent of customer funds. Stotler Group's stock, which trades on the American Stock Exchange, closed unchanged at $5.62{ Wednesday. Stotler's capital problems are seen as a major embarrassment to Mahlmann, now in his fourth consecutive one-year term as chairman of the world's largest commodity futures exchange. Mahlmann has said he has not been involved in Stotler's day-to-day operations for several years. People in the commodities business said Wednesday that some of Stotler's customers were liquidating their accounts Wednesday and others were transferring to other brokerages. But they couldn't provide specifics. ``We don't see any of that on the floor because it's all done in the back offices, but it is going on,'' said John Frazier, director of agricultural trading for Gerald Inc., a commodity brokerage. Stotler, one of the country's 10 largest commodity brokerages, is an old-line firm with its roots in the grain business. The company also trades financial futures, which have outstripped agricultural commodities in trading volume in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Colgate-Palmolive Reports Higher Second-Quarter Earnings and Revenue
DOC.TEXT: Colgate-Palmolive Co., a leading global consumer-products company, reported record second-quarter earnings and sales Thursday, attributing the gains to its powerful distribution system and better known brands. The New York-based company said it earned $81.91 million or $1.17 a share in the three months that ended June 30, an 11.3 percent gain over the $73.60 million or $1.06 a share earned a year earlier. Sales totaled $1.45 billion vs. $1.29 billion, a 12.4 percent gain. ``Colgate's increased worldwide sales and profits in the second quarter shows the growing strength of our worldwide distribution network and well-known brand equities,'' said Reuben Mark, chairman, president and chief executive officer. He said growth was strongest among its European, Mexican and Venezuelan businesses, but operations in Brazil weakened due to that country's economic austerity program. Growth in the Far East, particularly in Thailand and the Philippines, also helped offset weakness in Australia, he said. In the United States, a cost-cutting program contributed to sharply higher profits on lower sales, as did growth of Colgate's Specialty Marketing unit, comprised mainly of Hills Pet Products, a leading animal dietary care company. For the first six months of 1990, Colgate said it earned $163.15 million or $2.32 a share, up 15.9 percent from the $140.80 million or $2.04 a share earned in the year-earlier period. Revenues totaled $2.75 billion vs. $2.49 billion, up 10.4 percent. Colgate-Palmolive makes products for oral and body care, household cleaning and animal nutrition. Brands include Colgate toothpaste, Ajax cleanser, Palmolive-Gold soap, Rapid Shave shaving cream and Science Diet pet foods.

DOC.HEAD: Shearson Profits Down Slightly, But Firm Shows Progress; Smith Barney Up
DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. said Thursday that its second-quarter earnings fell slightly as cost reductions and $25 million in asset sales offset sharp declines in trading and investment banking. Separately, Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., a division of Primerica Corp., reported a 24 percent gain in second-quarter earnings due to good performances in trading, investment banking and retail brokerage. The parent company's profits rose 29 percent.
DOC.HEAD: Shearson
DOC.TEXT: Shearson, which is restructuring under parent American Express Co., said it made $51 million, or 44 cents a share, in the three months ended June 30. That was down 8.6 percent from $55 million, or 54 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell 21 percent to $2.6 billion, from $3.3 billion in the corresponding 1989 quarter, reflecting slow business conditions across Wall Street. ``There certainly are indications of progress there,'' said Lawrence Eckenfelder, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in San Francisco. ``You can't turn something like this around with the snap of the fingers. It's going to take a while.'' Shearson is overhauling much of its operations since American Express stepped in to take full control of the struggling firm suffering the effects of overexpansion and management problems in the 1980s. Shearson lost $915 million in the first quarter, including a $630 million charge against earnings to pay for a restructuring that included 2,000 layoffs, consolidation of branch offices and departure from some business lines. Further reductions are expected. In the second quarter, Shearson said revenue from investment banking plummeted 42 percent to $154 million from $264 million, reflecting the slack environment for underwriting, merchant banking, and mergers and acquisitions. Trading commission revenue dropped 17.6 percent to $439 million from $533 million a year earlier. Also down was investment advisory revenue, off 10.9 percent to $156 million from $175 million. Shearson made up ground in a cost-cutting program instituted by new chief executive Howard L. Clark Jr., a former American Express executive who replaced the ousted Peter Cohen. The program is designed to save $400 million a year. The firm said total expenses fell 22 percent in the second quarter to $2.5 billion from $3.2 billion. Shearson also gained from a sharp rise in interest and dividend income, to $80 million from $23 million. In addition, Shearson reported a $16 million pretax gain from the sales of the mutual fund and individual investor services businesses of the Lehman Management Co. division to a subsidiary of Salomon Inc., and a $9 million gain from the sale of a 50 percent interest in PanAgora Asset Management Inc. to Nippon Life Insurance Co. Shearson last month announced it was splitting into two divisions, dropping the Hutton name _ which it added after the 1988 acquisition of retail brokerage E.F. Hutton & Co. _ and emphasizing the old Lehman Brothers investment banking name. American Express, which has pumped more than $1 billion in new capital into the firm, is buying the remaining Shearson shares it does not own. For the first six months of 1990, Shearson reported losses of $692 million, or $10.08 a share, compared with a $70 million profit, or 31 cents a share, for the first half of 1989. Revenue fell to $5.2 billion in the first half of the year from $6.3 billion a year earlier.
DOC.HEAD: Primerica
DOC.TEXT: Smith Barney reported earnings of $16.6 million on revenue of $392 million in the second quarter, up from $13.4 million on revenue of $389 million. The brokerage said its retail operations benefited from the acquitision of 16 offices in May 1989 from the now-collapsed firm Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Primerica, a diversified financial services company, reported net income of $96.9 million, or 84 cents a share, in the period ended June 30. That was up from earnings of $63.4 million, or 65 cents a share, in the same 1989 period. Quarterly revenue rose 10.7 percent to $1.55 billion from $1.4 billion a year earlier. For the first six months of 1990, Primerica said it earned $180 million, or $1.56 a share, on $3 billion in revenue. That was up from profit of $115 million, or $1.18 a share, on revenue of $2.64 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Western Banks' Claims on Eastern Europe, Soviet Union Rose in 1989
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For Release at 6 p.m. EDT, Time set by Source
DOC.TEXT: Claims by Western commercial banks expanded by 9.8 percent on Eastern Europe last year and by 18.4 percent on the Soviet Union, according to a new survey released Thursday. The Bank of International Settlements survey said the banks' claims _ including loans plus accrued interest _ on Eastern Europe went up by $3.3 billion during the July-December period to $96 billion following a $5.3 billion increase in the first half. Claims on the Soviet Union stood at $43.2 billion at the end of the year, rising by $1.9 billion in the second half after increasing by $4.8 billion in the first half. Undisbursed credit commitments also continued to expand. At the same time, the Soviet Union drew down its deposits with the reporting Western banks by $1.3 billion, according to the survey. The other major Eastern European borrowers during the second half of 1989 were East Germany at $800 million and Czechoslovakia at $700 million. Claims on East Germany totaled $17 billion and on Czechoslovakia were $5.4 billion at the end of the year. Claims on Hungary totaled $11.9 billion, up $100 million, and were $10 billion on Poland, down $200 million. Lending to Third World countries _ excluding OPEC members _ dropped by $9.2 billion to $305.6 billion. Of these, claims on Latin American countries declined by $7.7 billion to $176.1 billion, including a $3.3 billion decline in claims on Brazil and a $2 billion drop in claims on Argentina. ``The declines occurred in spite of the accumulation of interest arrears by these two countries and, in the case of Argentina, an increase in claims on private non-bank entities,'' the survey said. ``The reduction in claims on Brazil appears to have resulted partly from informal buy-backs of official debt at secondary market discounts.'' Claims on Mexico fell by $1.5 billion to $59.7 billion and claims on Chile dropped $1 billion to $9.3 billion, the survey said. Colombia borrowed $300 million after signing a new lending accord with creditor banks, bringing total claims on that country to $6.3 billion. Claims on members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries went up by $1.9 billion to $101.5 billion, including a $2 billion increase for Iraq and rises of $400 million each for Algeria and Iran.

The stock market lost more ground today, weighed down by earnings disappointments at several high-technology companies. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 18.07 points on Wednesday, dropped another 16.33 to 2,965.35 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by nearly 5 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 434 up, 1,014 down and 488 unchanged. The day's most conspicuous losers were concentrated in technology issues with wide followings in the financial world. Tandem Computers, the most active NYSE issue, dropped 2{ to 19. Tandem reported profits for the fiscal quarter ended June 30 of 30 cents a share, against 31 cents in the like period a year earlier. Lotus Development was the volume leader in the over-the-counter market, down 6{ at 24}. On Wednesday the company posted strong earnings, as expected, for the second quarter, but said its third-quarter profits might fall short of comparable year-ago levels. Apple Computer dropped 2| to 42 after the company also warned that its earnings for the current quarter might show a decline. Ashton-Tate, which reported an unexpectedly wide loss for the second quarter, fell ~ to 9{. Given that kind of turbulence, analysts said it wasn't surprising that the market as a whole experienced a bumpy ride. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost 1.06 to 197.77. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 1.72 at 360.34. Volume on the Big Board came to 109.22 million shares with two hours to go.

DOC.HEAD: Fujitsu Negotiating For Control Of Britain's Top Computer Maker
DOC.TEXT: Japan's biggest computer maker, Fujitsu Ltd., is negotiating to buy a controlling stake in International Computers Ltd., Britain's leading computer manufacturer, ICL's parent said Thursday. A majority interest in ICL, likely to cost more than $1 billion, would give Fujitsu a bigger foothold in the European Community before the trade bloc dismantles its internal trade barriers in 1992. It also could offer ICL security for the future, analysts said. A tie-up has been expected for months but analysts said they were surprised that the parent company, STC PLC, might sell control of ICL to Fujitsu. ICL is a major supplier of computer hardware to the Ministry of Defense and other government departments. The idea of selling control to a foreign company has raised concerns about British jobs and national security. Lawmaker Lewis Moonie, who serves as the opposition Labor Party's spokesman on technology matters, said, ``We are deeply concerned about the implications for the British computers industry, for jobs and research.'' Larry Broke, national officer of the Manufacturing Science and Finance workers union, said on BBC Radio: ``We are probably going to witness the demise of Britain's last mainframe computer manufacturer.'' Broke said he would rather see British companies join European partners to create a strong European computer industry. STC, formerly known as Standard Telephones and Cables, confirmed the negotiations after Fujitsu President Tadashi Sekizawa said earlier Thursday in Tokyo that his company was considering purchasing an interest in ICL. No decisions have yet been made, he said. Newspapers in Britain and Japan have reported that Fujitsu is to acquire 50 to 60 percent of ICL for about 650 million pounds, or $1.2 billion at current exchange rates. ICL has a value of about $2.2 billion, analysts estimate. It employs 22,000 people and is Europe's most profitable mainframe computer maker, they said. Its operating profit increased 13 percent to about $266 million on an 18 percent gain in sales to $2.9 billion last year. But STC has warned that this year's performance might be adversely affected by launch costs of new ICL products and key customers' deferrals of capital purchases. STC's shares rose the equivalent of 44 cents to $5.11 a share on London's Stock Exchange. Fujitsu's major activity in Europe is selling semiconductor computer chips, although it makes office computers in Spain and semiconductors in Ireland. It has marketing and development arms in Britain, West Germany, the Netherlands and elsewhere. Rumors have circulated for about a year about a possible equity tie between ICL and Fujitsu, which already have technology links. Under a 10-year agreement signed in 1981, ICL uses Fujitsu's computer chips and disks. STC Chairman Alan Walsh said earlier this year that his company was looking for a partner to help carry the burden of heavy research and development costs in the rapidly changing computer industry. Given the existing ties, Fujitsu was the only company that could take control of ICL, according to one London analyst, who requested anonymity. ``Technologically, they are vital to the future of ICL,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Stotler Announces Investor Offer
DOC.TEXT: A commodities brokerage headed by Chicago Board of Trade Chairman Karsten Mahlmann may have found its financial savior, according to an announcement Thursday by the firm's parent company. Stotler Group Inc. said it had accepted an unidentified investor's ``conditional offer to purchase a substantial equity interest'' in Stotler Group. A one-page statement identifed neither the prospective investor nor the size of the stake it has offered to buy. Mahlmann is managing partner of Stotler Group's principal subsidiary _ Stotler and Co., a large, old-line trading company that recently ran afoul of the federal government's minimum capital requirements. Chicago-based Stotler Group, a publicly traded company, confirmed in the announcement that Stotler and Co. had brought itself into compliance with the capital requirements. The developments mean Stotler could avert a cash-flow crisis and will avoid restrictions on its brokerage operations while sparing Mahlmann further embarrassment. The statement said the offer announced Thursday was subject to approval by the investor's board of directors. The deal will die if such approval is not granted by 11 a.m. EDT Monday, Stotler Group said. Stotler Group confirmed Wednesday's Board of Trade announcement that it had brought itself into compliance with a Commodity Futures Trading Commission rule requiring futures brokerages to maintain in a separate account liquid assets equal to 4 percent of customer funds. On Wednesday, after a deadline set by the Board of Trade had passed, the exchange released a statement saying it ``believes the firm has achieved the requisite capital requirements.'' The exchange had ordered Stotler to boost its capital or face restrictions on its trading activities. The exchange can force a brokerage out of the business of trading for customers if its capital level falls below 4 percent of customer funds. Stotler's plan for bringing its capital level into compliance included trimming it customer base and finding an investor. Stotler Group had said that without new capital from an outside source, it might have trouble meeting its debt obligations. Stotler is one of the country's 10 largest commodity brokerages, with its roots in the grain business. The company also trades financial futures, which have outstripped agricultural commodities in trading volume in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices closed at session lows on London's Stock Exchange Thursday, pulled down by a poor showing on Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 23.02 points at 2,958.66 as London trading wound down. But dealers said market sentiment still was relatively buoyant, and shares were merely drifting lower after several consecutive days of rallying prices. ``The market's just taking a breather. We had strong volumes in recent days,'' one dealer said. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index fell 14.7 points to close at 2,387.3, its session low. Its high of 2,407.7 came early in the session. The Financial Times 30-share index was down 10.8 points at 1,889.8 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index was down 6.77 at 1,284.73. Volume came to 412 million shares, compared with 595.2 million shares at the same time Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Talks Open at Ford With UAW
LaserPhoto DT6
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. indicated Thursday it probably wouldn't eliminate plant overtime that the United Auto Workers claims is straining employees. Owen Bieber, president of the UAW, said after opening contract talks with the automaker that Ford was using extensive overtime so it could employ fewer hourly workers. ``Ford's practice of running some of its plants at above-rated capacity is its relentless effort to squeeze out costs,'' Bieber said at a news conference after a ceremonial opening handshake with Ford Vice President Peter Pestillo. UAW talks opened Wednesday with General Motors Corp. and begin Friday at Chrysler Corp. The three contracts expire at midnight, Sept. 14. At one point during the current three-year contract with the UAW, Ford was running as much as 20 percent over factory capacity in order to deal with surging car and truck demand. Sales since then have weakened. The union has complained that physical and psychological burdens on employees can result from such overwork. Extensive overtime also indicates the company's hourly work force is too small, Bieber said. But UAW negotiators will have to negotiate the overtime issue gingerly _ many Ford workers have become accustomed to regular overtime in their paychecks. Pestillo said Ford would like to eliminate overtime in the plants but probably won't do it. The Big Three are trying to prevent further erosion of their share of the U.S. vehicle market to Japanese companies. They also are concerned about federal government mandates for better gas mileage and safety. Ford shut no plants during its current contract, instead cutting back on overtime to reduce production. When UAW signed the current GM contract in 1987, it touted job-protection provisions allowing the automaker to close a plant only when sales of its products tumbled. But GM stopped production at four plants, saying they were ``indefinitely idled.'' Chrysler used the same contract provision to shut down two assembly plants. A total of 17,000 hourly jobs were lost. Ford last closed an assembly plant since 1983 when it shut its San Jose, Calif., car and truck plant. During the boom years of the mid-1980s, Ford paid overtime to keep the cars and trucks rolling out of existing plants. The average wage for an assembly worker at the Big Three is just less than $15 an hour before overtime or benefits. In addition to curbing overtime and protecting current jobs, the union will seek higher wage and improved pensions, more management accountability and protection of health-care benefits. The companies will be looking for more flexibility in work rules and scheduling and ways to hold down soaring health costs.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Rise, Grains Slip In Quiet Trading
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices closed mostly higher Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade while grain futures ended mostly lower, reflecting near-perfect weather for crop development and wheat harvesting. Trading activity was slow. Support for soybeans stemmed from reports that the Soviet Union bought 330,000 metric tons of soybean meal from Argentina using West German marks, said John Frazier, director of agricultural trading with Gerald Inc. in Chicago. The reported purchase quieted speculation that the Soviets would be unable to get financing for more grain purchases. A weather pattern of mild temperatures and occasional showers is expected to continue through next week in the nation's midsection. Those conditions could bring the winter wheat harvest to its abundant conclusion and help move the corn crop through its critical pollination phase without incident. ``The weather is just about perfect and the market perceives that,'' Frazier said. At the close, wheat futures were \ cent to 4\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in July at $2.97 a bushel; corn was unchanged to 4{ cents lower with July at $2.67{ a bushel; oats were } cent to 1{ cents lower with July at $1.17{ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent lower to 3 cents higher with July at $6.02{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Up This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 163,826 cars and light trucks this week, up from last week's 113,348, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is higher than the same week a year ago, in which 154,646 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 91,409 cars this week, compared with 63,044 a week ago and 83,044 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 72,417, compared with last week's 40,304 and last year's 71,602. Canadian automakers were to build 17,599 cars this week, down from 19,732 a week ago but up from last year's 12,101. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 8,130, compared with 11,118 a week ago and 5,751 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Citibank VP Gets 8 Years for $25 Million Theft
DOC.TEXT: A former Citibank vice president whose job was to safeguard assets was sentenced Thursday to eight years in prison for embezzling securities worth $25 million from the bank's vault. Of the five $5 million certificates stolen, four were recovered when the defendant, Mario Rios Pinochet, tried to negotiate them three days after the Jan. 25 theft, prosecutors said. The fifth certificate, which matured in February, was never recovered. Pinochet, 48, of Weston, Conn., claims to be a distant relative of former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet. He was convicted in May by a Manhattan federal court jury of four felony counts stemming from the embezzlement. Pinochet was fired by Citibank after his Feb. 1 arrest. He maintains his innocence and plans an appeal. ``Even if it takes me 50 years, I am going to prove I am innocent,'' he told U.S. District Judge Robert Ward. Ward's sentence of eight years fell in the middle range of the punishment allowed by federal sentencing guidelines. The judge said he considered the seriousness of the charges and Pinochet's lack of remorse. ``There is no question that his position allowed him to commit the crime,'' Ward said. Pinochet was a vice president in charge of a risk management team that investigated discrepancies in the handling of multimillion-dollar securities held by Citibank. Bank employees testified at trial that the bearer securities disappeared while Pinochet was conducting a count of commercial paper in the bank's vault under the guise of trying to improve procedures to safeguard assets. Then, in what Ward described as a ``James Bond scenario,'' he arranged the delivery of four of the certificates to the Stamford, Conn., office of Paine Webber Inc. in an envelope taped to the inside of a Chilean newspaper. According to trial evidence, Pinochet said he received the certificates from a courier in Chile on behalf of three principals, who turned out to be fictitious. He instructed a broker at Paine Webber to wire the proceeds to an account in Bermuda, but the transaction was never completed because the broker discovered that the securities had been reported missing by Citibank. Ward also imposed three years probation but ordered no fine because Pinochet, who is married with three children, has no money. The judge said Pinochet would have to pay restitution if Citibank is held responsible for the missing $5 million certificate during the years of his imprisonment and probation. Pinochet, who has been in jail since his arrest, was denied a request to be freed pending his appeal.

DOC.HEAD: UTC Reports 5 Percent Earnings Increase in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: United Technologies Corp. reported Thursday its second-quarter net income rose 5 percent on strong results from its Pratt & Whitney and Otis Elevator subsidiaries. UTC reported earnings of $207.5 million, or $1.64 a share, up from $197.3 million, or $1.50 a share, for the same period in 1989. The company reported revenue of $1.87 billion, down slightly from $1.91 billion a year earlier. The results reflected a $30 million pre-tax charge against earnings from the planned closing of a Carrier manufacturing facility in Syracuse, N.Y. Along with the strong results from Pratt & Whitney and Otis, improved earnings at the UT Automotive and Sikorsky Helicopter divisions helped offset lower results at Carrier, said Robert F. Daniell, UTC chairman and chief executive officer. For the first six months of the year, UTC reported net income of $342 million, or $2.69 a share, up 6.5 percent from last year's $321 million, or $2.45 a share. UTC's first-half revenue rose to $3.5 billion from $3.49 billion a year earlier.

A late wave of buying in blue chips helped the stock market recover from a broad early decline to finish mixed today. Analysts said disappointments in second-quarter earnings reports, notably among technology companies, weighed down the market at the outset. The day's most conspicuous losers were concentrated in technology issues with wide followings on Wall Street. But buyers took the upper hand in the afternoon, going with particular enthusiasm after energy issues as oil prices rose. Bullish traders evidently were not yet ready to give up on chances for the Dow Jones industrial average to break through the 3,000 level, which it has been challenging for the past few sessions.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Chiquita Cuts Off Talks in Honduran Strike
DOC.TEXT: Chiquita Brands Inc., the American banana company, said Thursday it was cutting off talks with a union whose strike has crippled Honduran banana exports. The 10,000 workers struck June 25 to demand the first pay increase in six years. Wages now average $15.32 a day and workers want a 57.8 percent increase. Chiquita's general manager, Karl F. Koch, said the company was cutting off talks with the union. He blamed the union for taking a ``rigid position'' that has kept discussions stalled for two weeks. Honduran President Rafael Leonardo Callejas said Thursday the strike has cost the country more than $4.5 million. Union president Rene Ayestas said the union rejected Chiquita's last offer of a 14.33 percent pay increase. He said the company ``has repeatedly offended us. Its offers are humiliating.'' Cincinnati-based Chiquita, formerly United Fruit, accounts for 60 percent of Hondura's banana exports of 50 million boxes a year. Castle & Cooke, based in San Francisco, exports the other 40 percent. Callejas earlier sent a presidential mediation team to try to solve the impasse. He called the situation ``tense and difficult.'' The walkout initially was joined by 30,000 other workers in the health, postal and industrial sectors along the Atlantic coast. But those workers returned to work after 10 days.

DOC.HEAD: PPG Industries' Earnings Increase in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: PPG Industries Inc., a maker of glass, paints and chemicals, said Thursday its second-quarter profits increased nearly 11 percent because of improved operating efficiency. PPG reported earnings of $141 million, or $1.31 a share, in the three months ended June 30, compared with $127.3 million, or $1.13 a share, in the same 1989 period. The company said the latest quarterly results included a pre-tax charge of $25 million, or 14 cents a share, in its chemical business. Sales increased 5 percent to $1.57 billion in the second quarter from $1.49 billion in the year-ago period. ``Improved operating efficiencies in all of our businesses continue to favorably influence the company's financial performance,'' PPG Chairman Vincent A. Sarni said. In the first half of 1990, earnings increased nearly 4 percent to $266.3 million, or $2.47 a share, from $257.1 million, or $2.28 per share. Sales climbed to $3.05 billion from $2.95 billion. The second-quarter special charge resulted from an agreement in which PPG will clean 53 chrome residue sites in New Jersey, pay a $2.5 million fine, drop its lawsuits against the state and reimburse the state $900,000 for administrative costs. The obligations stem from chrome chemical operations in Jersey City that PPG discontinued nearly thirty years ago, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Textron Earnings Improve 21 Percent in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Textron Inc. reported Thursday its second-quarter earnings rose 21.5 percent despite disappointing results in its helicopter division. The conglomerate said it earned $72.1 million, or 80 cents per share, up from the $59.3 million, or 67 cents per share, it earned from April through June 1989. Revenue rose to $2 billion from $1.8 billion. Earnings at Textron's Bell Helicopter subsidiary fell to $27 million from $34.7 million a year earlier, largely because the division had a ``less favorable mix of non-U.S. government sales,'' said B.F. Dolan, the conglomerate's chairman and chief executive officer. Dolan credited gains in the company's financial services subsidiaries for Textron's overall improvement. For the first six months, Textron's net income rose 12.8 percent to $138.3 million, or $1.53 per share, from earnings of $122.6 million, or $1.40 per share, a year earlier. Textron's first-half revenue rose to $3.9 billion from $3.7 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Highest Closes in Dow Jones Industrials Average
With AM-Wall Street
Corning to Sell Iwaki Glass Interest to Asahi
DOC.TEXT: Corning Inc. said Thursday it will sell most of its 33.4 percent interest in Iwaki Glass Co. of Japan to Asahi Glass Co. for an after-tax gain of $18 millio Chinese borrowers will pay interest at an internationally-agreed rate of 8.3 percent a year for seven years. The Export-Import Bank lends at subsidized rates when that is necessary to promote the sale of U.S. goods in competition with banks of other governments eager for exports. The loans will go through the private Bank of America. One loan, for $10 million, will buy equipment for the Hong Qiao International Airport at Shanghai from Aarotec-Airways Engineering Associates of Fairfax, Va. The order includes baggage handling, air conditioning and security systems. The other loan, for $4.3 million on similar terms, will be used to buy equipment for Gao Qiao Petrochemical International Trading Co., known as GITCO. the seller is Rayonier C and C Ltd of Seattle. The Shanghai firm is expanding its capacity to produce pellets of acrilonitrile-butadiene-styrene, called ABS. The material is used to make refrigerator liners and parts of other appliances.

DOC.HEAD: Say Bond Will Step Down As Chairman of Debt-Strapped Company
DOC.TEXT: Debt-plagued Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond, whose vast world holdings range from brewing to real estate, will resign as chairman of his company to appease creditors under an agreement announced Thursday. Bond's departure from Australia-based Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd, more than $6 billion in debt, could lead to important refinancing arrangements, company director Peter Lucas said in disclosing the pact after a bondholders meeting in London. No decision has been made on who will replace Bond, Lucas said. He also said the 58 percent voting power of Bond's Dallhold Investments Pty Ltd. over Bond Corp. Holdings would be restricted to 25 percent. The bondholders decided at their meeting to form a committee to improve communication between them and the company. Bondholders meet again Aug. 9. Bond's departure is contingent upon bondholder approval of the sale of Bond Corp. Holdings' brewery assets and permission to suspend interest payments on two types of bonds, Lucas said. Bond Corp. Holdings plans to sell Bond Brewing Holdings for about $1.4 billion to Bell Resources, an independently managed affiliate of Bond Corp. Holdings. Bond's decision to separate himself from his company was intended to entice bondholders to approve these steps, Lucas said. ``The proposed changes have been under consideration for some time,'' Bond said in a prepared statement to the meeting. He said the changes ``should confirm in people's minds our dedication to do everything necessary to restore full value to Bond Corp.'' Lucas said Bond recognized that stepping aside would be in the interests of bondholders generally and that ``there should be seen to be a change in the team.'' Bond, who runs his empire from Perth, Australia, is considered one of the world's most flamboyant entrepreneurs. He acquired a string of media companies, brewing concerns, natural resource companies and other properties largely through borrowed money. A combination of heavy debts, rising interest rates and bad business decisions alienated Bond's bankers and creditors, put his Australian brewing interests into receivership and has forced him to sell assets ranging from a Hong Kong office development to a coal mine. Bond's best-known U.S. business is the G. Heileman Brewing Co., a Wisconsin beer-maker burdened by heavy debt since he bought it for $1.3 billion in borrowed money three years ago. Heileman has been trying independently to restructure the debt in order to stay in business. It was not immediately clear how Bond's agreement with other creditors might affect Heileman's situation. Bond received a great deal of personal publicity for taking financial assistance from Sotheby's auction house to purchase Vincent Van Gogh's ``Irises'' from Sotheby's in 1987 for what was a then-record $53.9 million. He also won notoriety for financing the Australian sailing team's stunning triumph over the United States in the 1983 America's Cup race.

DOC.HEAD: As Expected, AT&T Reports Lower Second-Quarter Earnings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `But the market ...,' to UPDATE stock price with late change.
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Earns-Baby Bells
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: As expected, AT&T on Thursday reported lower second-quarter earnings, a 6.4 percent drop it attributed to declining equipment sales and unexpectedly high startup costs for the company's new credit card. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. warned of an expected drop in earnings in an unusual announcement three weeks ago, but it did not say how steep it would be. That announcement sent AT&T's stock price tumbling. AT&T is the nation's most widely held stock. But the market had little reaction to the actual profit decline, which was within the expectations of industry analysts. AT&T shares rose 37{ cents to close at $37.50 on the New York Stock Exchange. AT&T said it earned $657 million, or 60 cents a share, in the quarter ended June 30, down from $699 million, or 65 cents a share, in the same quarter of 1989. Revenue fell to $9.03 billion from $9.26 billion a year earlier. It was the phone company's first quarterly earnings drop since December 1988, when AT&T lost $3.34 billion. That loss _ the company's first ever _ resulted from a $6.72 billion charge it took against earnings to pay for a modernization program. For the first six months of the year, AT&T earned $1.33 billion, or $1.22 per share, up from $1.29 billion, or $1.20 a share. Revenue totaled $17.9 billion, virtually unchanged from the same period of 1989. AT&T said the disappointing results last quarter were due mostly to slower sales of corporate telephone systems, data communications gear and equipment sold to the federal government. The company also blamed unexpectedly high costs for processing applications for its Universal card, which combines a MasterCard or Visa with telephone charge privileges. The New York-based company blamed the 2 percent drop in equipment sales on a sluggish economy. It said the introduction of the Universal card in March produced twice the expected number of applications. AT&T also said its long-distance revenue was down 1.8 percent in the quarter due to less favorable access charge settlements with local phone companies and customer shifts to lower-cost AT&T services. However, the volume of long-distance calls rose 7 percent. Industry analysts said the fact long-distance volume rose while revenue declined pointed to the increasingly competitive nature of the long distance phone business. AT&T has been shifting its business customers to contracts that save them money to keep them from fleeing to competitors, ``but it has come at a price in terms of what has happened to revenue growth,'' said Charles Nichols, who follows AT&T for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Nichols said the second-quarter results also demonstrate how closely AT&T's fortunes are tied to the economy. As economic growth slumps, businesses spend less on phone systems and computers such as those sold by AT&T. In addition, he said, the pace of growth in long-distance volume has been slowing as the economy weakens. Despite the second-quarter problems, AT&T said it stood by its forecast that earnings for all of 1990 would exceed its record 1989 earnings of $2.7 billion. ``These results do not alter our confidence in our direction or our future prospects,'' Chairman Robert E. Allen said in a news release. Gregory Sawers, an analyst at the investment firm Sanford C. Bernstein & Co., said it is difficult to predict earnings for AT&T and other phone companies. ``This is really virgin territory for investors in the sense there's never been a truly competitive long distance industry in this country,'' he said. That uncertainty was demonstrated earlier this week, when United Telecommunications Inc., parent of No. 3 long distance company US Sprint, reported a 55 percent drop in its second-quarter earnings. The news took industry analysts by surprise and sent the company's stock price sliding. Also this week, No. 2 MCI Communications Corp. said its second-quarter earnings rose 20 percent from a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: UAW Launches TV Advertising Campaign
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers union commissioned three television ads that began airing Thursday, as national contract negotiations with the nation's Big Three automakers got under way. The advertisements show actors and UAW President Owen Bieber talking about such issues as quality and keeping jobs in the United States. The spots will appear in 27 major markets and are built around the theme, ``Because American jobs are worth fighting for.'' The union's contracts with General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. expire at midnight Sept. 14. The ads have an initial 10-day run and may be aired again later as negotiations continue, UAW spokesman Peter Laarman said.

DOC.HEAD: PacTel Earnings Fall, Southwest Bell Flat, Ameritech, BellSouth, Nynex Up
With AM-Earns-AT&T, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Pacific Telesis Group said Thursday its earnings fell 13.2 percent in the second quarter, Southwestern Bell said its profit was flat, and three other regional phone companies, Ameritech, Bellsouth and Nynex, said their profits rose in the period.
DOC.HEAD: Pacific Telesis
DOC.TEXT: Pacific Telesis, based in San Francisco, said it earned $287 million, or 72 cents a share, in the quarter ended June 30, down from $325 million, or 79 cents a share, in 1989's second quarter. Revenue totaled $2.43 billion, up from $2.41 billion. The company blamed the lower results on a rate reduction associated with telephone regulation restructuring in California and increased expenses for network and operating improvements. For the first six months of the year, PacTel earned $549 million, or $1.37 a share, down from $642 million, or $1.55 a share, in the 1989 period. Revenue totaled $4.81 billion, up from $4.75 billion.
DOC.HEAD: Southwestern Bell
DOC.TEXT: Southwestern Bell Corp. reported earnings of $262.5 million, or 87 cents a share, compared with $261.5 million, or 87 cents a share, for the same period a year earlier. Revenue totaled $2.17 billion, up from $2.14 billion. The St. Louis-based company said state and federal telephone rate reductions offset growth in new service. The company said earnings in 1989's second quarter were swollen by a one-time $11.8 million gain from a phone routing change. If that gain were excluded, Southwestern's profit would have risen 4.4 percent in this year's second quarter. For the first half of the year, earnings totaled $510.3 million, or $1.70 a share, up 2.4 percent from $500.3 million, or $1.66 a share, for the same period in 1989. Sales were $4.29 billion, up 2.7 percent from $4.19 billion.
DOC.HEAD: BellSouth
DOC.TEXT: Atlanta-based BellSouth Corp. said it earned $445.2 million, or 92 cents a share, up from $418.1 million, or 87 cents a share, in 1989's second quarter. Revenue totaled $3.62 billion, up from $3.47 billion. BellSouth said the earnings increase was due partly to greater contributions from its domestic cellular telephone operations. However, it said earnings growth was dampened by rate reductions in several Southeastern states. For the first six months, BellSouth earned $868.4 million, or $1.80 a share, compared with $867.7 million, or $1.83 a share, a year earlier. Revenue totaled $7.14 billion, up from $6.84 billion.
DOC.HEAD: Nynex
DOC.TEXT: Nynex said its second-quarter earnings rose 7.7 percent to $300.6 million, or $1.52 a share, compared with $279 million, or $1.42 a share, a year earlier. Revenue totaled $3.44 billion, up from $3.30 billion. The New York-based company said the results benefitted from cost-containment programs and growth in its cellular phone business. For the first six months, Nynex earned $592 million, or $2.98 a share, up from $562.6 million, or $2.86 a share. Revenue totaled $6.76 billion, compared with $6.53 billion.
DOC.HEAD: Ameritech
DOC.TEXT: Chicago-based Ameritech, which reported its results Wednesday, said it earned $352.3 million, or $1.33 a share, in the second quarter, up from $316.6 million, or $1.19 a share, a year earlier. Revenue totaled $2.68 billion, up from $2.55 billion Ameritech said earnings were boosted by a 42 percent increase in mobile phone line hookups. For the first six months, it earned $655.8 million, or $2.46 a share, compared with $617.4 million, or $1.46 million, a year earlier. Revenue totaled $5.3 billion, vs. $5.05 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Browning-Ferris Plan Allows Community Input on Siting Landfills
DOC.TEXT: A major waste disposal company Thursday unveiled a program to allow New York communities to choose whether they want landfills or recycling centers, rather than letting the state decide for them. ``We're asking that communities become our partners not just in developing a site but in locating a site,'' Browning-Ferris Industries Inc. Chairman William Ruckelshaus said. BFI, based in Houston, said its community partnership plan was limited for now to New York state. The company said New York was selected because it needs landfills and because the process of opening new landfills has stopped. Only three new landfills have opened in New York since 1986 while hundreds have closed and hundreds more are under order to close, BFI spokesman Gary Brotherton said. No landfill sites are selected in advance under BFI's plan. ``We believe it is up to the community to decide whether or not they want such a facility,'' Ruckelshaus said. ``If they decide they'd like to go forward with a site, we'd like to participate.'' Ruckelshaus, who twice headed the federal Environmental Protection Agency and was an acting director of the FBI, said if communities decide they don't want a landfill in their area BFI won't request permission from the statee's solid waste management plan to expand landfill capacity to complement recycling and incineration facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Recalls Trucks for `Park' Fix
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. said Thursday it is recalling about 110,000 1989 and 1990 E- and F-series vans and pickup trucks with automatic transmissions that might slip out of ``park.'' Ford said 103,457 of the vehicles are in the United States, 6,163 are in Canada and 297 are in other countries. Owners will be notified by mail to bring the cars to dealers, the company said. Dealers will inspect the vehicles and, if necessary, replace free a snap ring in the transmission with an improved part. A broken snap ring can prevent the ``park'' mechanism from engaging. Ford has received about 100 complaints about the problem, none involving accidents or injuries, spokesman Jim Trainor said. Trainor said about 90 percent involved the E-series vehicles, Econoline vans usually used as urban delivery trucks or shuttle vehicles. The rest involved F-series pickup trucks. The affected vehicles are two-wheel drive.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: A spirited afternoon rally in blue chips helped the stock market salvage a mixed showing Thursday from a session that began with a broad decline. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down about 20 points at its midsession low, closed with a 12.13 gain at 2,993.81. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 621 up, 858 down and 522 unchanged. Analysts said disappointments in second-quarter earnings reports, notably among technology companies, weighed down the market at the outset. The day's most conspicuous losers were concentrated in technology issues with wide followings on Wall Street. But buyers took the upper hand in the afternoon, going with particular enthusiasm after energy issues as oil prices rose. Bullish traders evidently were not yet ready to give up on chances for the Dow Jones industrial average to break through the 3,000 level, which it has been challenging for the past few sessions. In the energy sector, Exxon gained 1{ to 50; Mobil 2\ to 65}; Texaco 1} to 61{; Amoco 1| to 54, and Chevron 1{ to 76}. The story was much different in technology issues. Tandem Computers, the most active NYSE issue, dropped 1~ to 19| after the company reported profits for the fiscal quarter ended June 30 of 30 cents a share, against 31 cents in the like period a year earlier. Lotus Development was the volume leader in the over-the-counter market, down 6[ at 25[. On Wednesday Lotus posted strong earnings, as expected, for the second quarter, but said its third-quarter profits might fall short of comparable year-ago levels. Apple Computer dropped 2~ to 41} after the company also warned that its earnings for the current quarter might show a decline. Ashton-Tate, which reported an unexpectedly wide loss for the second quarter, fell ~ to 9{. Given that kind of turbulence, analysts said it wasn't surprising that the market as a whole experienced a bumpy ride. Elsewhere, U.S. Shoe tumbled 4\ to 18. The company estimated lower quarterly earnings, citing a softening of its optical retailing business. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 161.90 million shares, against 168.76 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 192.74 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $3.64 billion, or 0.10 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .55 to 199.38. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.67 to 433.20, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 1.10 at 365.32. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 2.65 to 458.18. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 361.84, down .22.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Company Buys West Virginia Ski Resort
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese leisure and recreational company has purchased West Virginia's largest ski resort for about $20 million, it was announced Thursday. The sale of the Snowshoe Ski Resort by Ski Venture Inc. marks the first U.S. acquisition by Tokyo Tower Development Co. Ltd., said Fukusabura Maeda, Tower's owner and chief executive officer. The deal also reflects growing Japanese interest in U.S. recreational industries. For example, a number of Japanese investors have ownership interests in American golf courses. Japanese business concerns also have stakes in some New England ski resorts. West Virginia Gov. Gaston Caperton, who has actively sought Japanese investment in one of the nation's poorest states, welcomed the ski-resort deal and described Tokyo Tower as a leading recreational developer. Tokyo Tower Development is an arm of the Tokyo Tower Group of Companies operated by Nippon Television City Corp. Its trademark is the Tokyo Tower, located in the center of Tokyo that serves as a tourist attraction and media transmitter. ``Tokyo Tower Group studied a number of opportunities ranging from California to Florida,'' Maeda said. ``We were very strongly impressed with the physical beauty of the nature in West Virginia.'' Hiroshi Kojima, senior director of the company's development division, said Snowshoe was chosen because it has been successfully operated for the past several years, after several bouts with bankruptcy. Kojima promised both expansion and stability. He said the current management team and employees will be retained. A group of eight thrifts bought the resort in October 1986 under the umbrella company Ski Venture Inc. for $13.4 million. They assumed $11.8 million in debt.

DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Rose $3.67 Billion in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the wek ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 513 money market mutual funds climbed $3.67 billion in the latest week to $389.91 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise in the seven-day period ended Wednesday followed a $3.50 billion increase in the funds' assets the previous week. The previous week's advance was originally reported as $3.10 billion but the Washington-based mutual fund trade group revised it. The funds' assets hit a record high $392.14 billion in the week ended March 21, 1990. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 251 general purpose funds rose $313.3 million to $134.70 billion, assets of 102 broker-dealer funds rose $361.6 million to $160.40 billion, and assets of 160 institutional funds jumped $2.99 billion to $94.81 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds rose in the week ended Tuesday to 7.66 percent from 7.65 percent the previous week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield slipped to 7.66 percent from 7.67 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 44 days, up from 43 days, Donoghue's said. Separately, the newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts held at 6.14 percent as of Wednesday, unchanged from a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, fell to 5.03 percent from 5.04 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.89 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.90 the previous week. Yields were 8.06 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 8.09 percent; 8.08 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 8.10 percent; and 8.16 percent on 5-year CDs, unchanged from the previous week.

DOC.NOTE: $adv22
For release Sunday, July 22, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Double Hulls Create Controversy
With BC-Troubled Waters. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A double hull creates a ship within a ship. It is two layers of steel, separated by a gap of air, around the sides and bottom of an oil tanker as an extra layer of protection. Environmental groups, in a letter to a congressional committee this month, said requiring double-hull tankers was ``the single most important step Congress can take to prevent oil spills.'' A compromise is pending in Congress to have two hulls on new tankers and to retrofit or phase out single-hulled tankers within 20 years. The House originally wanted a 15-year timetable while the Senate asked for more study. ``A double hull is not a be-all or end-all. But we've got to build redundancy into the system,'' said Clifton Curtis, president of the Oceanic Society. Curtis called the compromise ``a signficant victory.'' But he added: ``We are sorely displeased with the fact that the retrofit schedule is not more rapid.'' Advocates of double hulls say they would limit the impact of oil spills if a tanker runs aground, because a reef or man-made object would have to gash both layers to spill oil. A Coast Guard study of 30 tanker groundings between 1969 and 1973 said 96 percent of the spills would have been averted if the vessels had double hulls. A double hull would not have prevented the Exxon Valdez spill, but some studies say less crude oil would have fouled Prince William Sound in the nation's worst oil spill. ``Double hulls are an extra margin of safety to prevent or minimize marine accidents,'' said U.S. Coast Guard Commandant J. William Kime. But critics say double hulls also may have drawbacks. Water can rush in between layers of the steel and make a ship settle lower, thereby leaking more oil. There are also fears explosive vapors could gather between the gaps. Double hulls are also more expensive. It would have cost 10 percent to 15 percent more to build a double hull on the $125 million Exxon Valdez. Its damaged hull was repaired with 3,000 tons of new steel, but it still doesn't have a double hull. Retrofitting the 153 U.S. tankers at $30 million each would cost $4.6 billion; the same work on 900 foreign-flagged tankers could be as high as $10 billion, industry officials said. But the oil industry believes the debate is misdirected. ``If an airplane crashes into a mountain, we don't build planes that can withstand the impact. We try to find out why and prevent it from happening again,'' said Sean Connaughton of the American Petroleum Institute. ``If we have ships running into underwater mountains, we end up with people calling for ships that can withstand that type of collision,'' Connaughton said. Meanwhile, some companies aren't waiting for Congress. Houston-based Conoco Inc. ordered two double-hull tankers in April and said it would order double-hull ships in the future. Norway's Statoil, the largest producer of North Sea crude oil, said in June that it was ordering five new tankers, two with double hulls and three with double or partial double bottoms.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, July 22

DOC.HEAD: Horizontal Drilling to Make Debut in Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: A small local energy company plans to introduce horizontal oil drilling to the Soviet Union when it begins developing two oil fields in western Sibera. Anglo-Suisse, whose 10 employees specialize in international oil exploration projects, will use horizontal drilling both on existing wells and on the 400 additional wells the company plans to drill throughout the 250,000 acres that compose the Tagrinskoye and West Varyeganskoye fields. The company recently reached a development agreement with a Soviet cooperative. Gilles Labbe, company president, said the 50-50 joint venture will mark the first known Soviet foray into the popular drilling technology, already credited with reviving previously dead oil fields in Texas, Oklahoma and Wyoming, the Houston Chronicle reported Thursday. Horizontally drilled wells begin as conventional, vertical wells. Once deep underground, they are gradually turned at a 90-degree angle, enabling the drill bit to travel horizontally across hydrocarbon reserves, rather than simply piercing them from above. The development project is expected to produce as much as 800 million barrels of oil over its 25-year life, officials said. ``There are a tremendous number of prospects here,'' said Bob Bryngelson, president of MER Engineering, a Houston firm working as a subcontractor on the Anglo-Suisse venture. ``It's just like the Middle East, but it's cold.'' Anglo-Suisse will split the cost of the $100 million project with the Varyegan Oil and Gas Association, a Soviet state oil company. Varyegan is providing the energy infrastructure for the project, including electricity, pipelines and roadway systems. Anglo-Suisse will contribute the engineering work and the drilling technology. Labbe said the company will begin soliciting investors for the venture later this year. The costs and the profits will be split by the two partners. Anglo-Suisse began negotiating terms of the venture in March, after being introduced to the Soviet association through contacts in Burma. A contract was signed last month and work is scheduled to begin next January. The Anglo-Suisse venture is similar to dozens of other cooperative arrangements under negotiation between the Soviet government and U.S. energy companies. Many of those projects have been slow to materialize, bogged down by overburdened bureaucracies in both the United States and the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply: M1 Down, M2 Down, M3 Up
DOC.TEXT: One key measure of the nation's money supply rose while another fell in the week ended July 9, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 fell to a seasonally adjusted $3,274.8 billion from a revised $3,277.5 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,061.5 billion from a revised $4,058.7 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, fell to a seasonally adjusted $810.2 billion from a revised $817.7 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 3.6 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 was 1.3 percent, which is within the Fed's new target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,269.1 billion, a 1.9 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,060.4 billion, up 0.2 percent, while M1 rose 3.2 percent to an average of $807.9 billion.
