In other reports: _The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks rose $200 million. _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $415 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $369 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged $504 million in the two weeks ended July 11, down from $639 million in the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $307.7 billion in the two-week period ended July 11, down from $309.1 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Scripps to Buy Baltimore TV Station
DOC.TEXT: Scripps Howard Broadcasting Co. said Thursday it has signed a letter of intent to buy television station WMAR of Baltimore from Gillett Group Inc. for $154.7 million. Scripps, an 80 percent-owned subsidiary of The E.W. Scripps Co., said it expects the transaction to be completed before the end of next year. WMAR Channel 2 is an affiliate of NBC and recently signed a three-year contract to continue as the flagship station for the Baltimore Orioles baseball team. ``We have not made a major acquisition since 1986, preferring to wait until an attractive opportunity presented itself,'' said Lawrence A. Leser, president and chief executive officer of The E.W. Scripps Co. ``This acquisition meets that criteria.'' Scripps Howard Broadcasting operates nine television stations and radio stations in three markets. The E.W. Scripps Co. operates 19 daily newspapers and cable television systems with 576,000 basic subscribers. Gillett, which is based in Denver, acquired the station in September 1986, according to spokesman Rich Boehne of Scripps. Calls to Gillett were not immediately returned.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower In Lackluster Trading, Gold Prices Soften
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mostly lower Thursday in lackluster trading, with little news to affect the market, traders said. Gold prices softened. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $361.40 a troy ounce, off 20 cents from late Wednesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $360.40 an ounce, down 70 cents. Traders described the currency market as listless, with major dealers sidelined due to a lack of market-affecting news. ``There's no real reason to buy or sell dollars,'' said Gabriele Schmitt, a vice president in the foreign exchange department of Bank of New York. The only market activity came from small traders taking profits, she said. ``It was one of those choppy days that didn't have much reason behind it,'' she said. Traders said the market was seeking clearer signs on the direction of interest rates and inflation. Congressional testimony Wednesday by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan failed to ease confusion over U.S. interest rates, they said. Greenspan said the central bank would lower rates to prevent a recession, but only after lawmakers agreed on a deficit-reduction package. The market was further confused about inflation by a Labor Department report Wednesday that consumer prices climbed 0.5 percent in June, more than double the rate of the past two months. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 147.60 Japanese yen from 147.25 yen at Wednesday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 148.00 yen. In New York, one dollar bought 148.09 yen, up from 147.65 yen. In London, the British pound fell to $1.8155 from $1.8205 late Wednesday. In New York, one pound cost $1.8165, more expensive than $1.81525 late Wednesday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's quotes, included: 1.6408 German marks, down from 1.6480; 1.4060 Swiss francs, down from 1.41585; 5.5045 French francs, down from 5.5285; 1,201.75 Italian lire, down from 1,207.00; and 1.1524 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15425. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's levels were: 1.6430 West German marks, down from 1.6440; 1.4090 Swiss francs, up from 1.4085; 5.5100 French francs, down from 5.5160; 1.8500 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8522; 1,203.00 Italian lire, down from 1,203.75; and, 1.1535 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1530. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $362.75 a troy ounce from $360.25 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $362.20 from $359.85 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.14 to close at $362.29 an ounce. Silver prices fell domestically after rising overseas. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.851 a troy ounce, down from $4.884 late Wednesday. In London, silver bullion rose to a late bid price of $4.88 a troy ounce from $4.84 bid late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Westinghouse Joins Consumers Power-Bechtel Plant Deal
DOC.TEXT: Westinghouse Electric Corp. said Thursday it will pay $20 million for a share in a venture formed by Consumers Power Co. and Bechtel Corp. to purchase Consumers' Palisades nuclear plant. Westinghouse will become a 22 percent partner in Palisades Generating Co., a Pittsburgh, Pa.-based firm in the commercial nuclear power industry, Consumers said. Consumers, which serves nearly 6 million customers in Michigan, will hold a 44 percent equity interest in Palisades, while San Francisco-based Bechtel will have a 33 percent share. Title to the 777-megawatt plant is expected to be transferred to the partnership in early 1991, the companies said. Consumers and Bechtel proposed in October 1987 to form Palisades to help resolve disputes stemming from Consumers' discontinued Midland nuclear plant project, on which Bechtel was a contractor.

DOC.HEAD: Government Bank Lends China $14.3 Million
DOC.TEXT: The government's Export-Import Bank said Thursday it wa lending China $14.3 million to buy equipment for an airport and a plastics plant in Shanghai. Chinese borrowers will pay interest at an internationally agreed rate of 8.3 percent a year for seven years. The Export-Import Bank lends at subsidized rates when necessary to promote the sale of U.S. goods in competition with banks of other governments eager for exports. President George Bush and other leaders of industrialized nations agreed last week that loans to China should be limited to basic human needs and to reforming the Chinese economy. The limitation does not apply to the new loans because they are commercial, bank spokeswoman Ellen Schweppe said. One loan for $10 million and will buy equipment for the Hong Qiao International airport at Shanghai from Aarotec-Airways Engineering Associates of Fairfax, Va. The order includes baggage handling, air conditioning and security systems. The other loan, for $4.3 million dollars, will be used to buy equipment for Gao Qiao Petrochemical International Trading Co. The seller is Rayonier C and C Ltd of Seattle. The Shanghai firm is expanding its capacity to produce pellets used in refrigerator liners and parts of other appliances.

DOC.HEAD: Pork Bellies Limit Down For Second Day
DOC.TEXT: Frozen pork belly futures prices plummeted the 2-cents-a-pound permitted daily limit for the second straight day Thursday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting burdensome supplies and slack demand for bacon. On other commodity markets, livestock futures ended mostly lower; energy futures were mixed; grains and soybeans were mixed; and precious metals retreated. Frozen pork bellies settled 2 cents lower across the board with the contract for delivery in July at 46.50 cents a pound and the more heavily traded August contract at 44.42 cents a pound. Weak consumer demand for bacon, which is made from pork bellies, has weighed on the market for several weeks. The situation has been reflected in the narrowing gap between prices of fresh bellies on the cash market and frozen bellies on the futures market. Belly futures normally are priced about 5 cents below cash bellies in mid-summer, creating an incentive for belly slicers to take bellies out of cold storage to meet the traditional summer surge in bacon demand, said Thomas Morgan, president of Sterling Research Corp. in Arlington Heights, Ill. But so far this month, bacon demand has been so weak and supplies of fresh bellies so ample that cash prices have dropped below futures. On Thursday, fresh bellies sold for as low as 43{ cents a pound compared with the low of 44.42 cents for the August futures contract. ``The demand is slow enough that they're barely using the fresh bellies, so there's no incentive for them to pull the bellies out of the freezer,'' said Paul Georgy, president of the futures brokerage Allendale Inc. in Crystal Lake, Ill. Georgy said the market may get some direction from the monthly Agriculture Department cold storage report, which will be released after Friday's close. In livestock trading in Chicago, live cattle futures settled .13 cent lower to .05 cent higher with August at 76.15 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .35 cent lower with August at 87.32 cents a pound; live hogs were .38 cent to .92 cent lower with July at 63.57 cents a pound. Near-term energy futures rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange in reaction to plans by operators of the Alaska pipeline to reduce its output of crude oil by about 600,000 barrels per day _ a 30 percent cut _ unless the company negotiates some other agreement to address pollution concerns. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 2 cents lower to 44 cents higher with August at $18.99 a barrel; heating oil was .15 cent lower to .27 cent higher with August at 56.38 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .05 cent lower to .49 cent higher with August at 63.07 cents a gallon. Soybean futures ended mostly higher in slow trading on the Chicago Board of Trade while grain futures ended mostly lower, reflecting near-perfect weather for crop development and wheat harvesting. Support for soybeans stemmed from reports that the Soviet Union bought 330,000 metric tons of soybean meal from Argentina using West German marks, said John Frazier, director of agricultural trading with Gerald Inc. in Chicago. The reported purchase quieted speculation that the Soviets would be unable to get financing for more grain purchases. Wheat futures settled \ cent to 3} cents lower with July at $2.97\ a bushel; corn was unchanged to 3\ cents lower with July at $2.68} a bushel; oats were } cent to 1{ cents lower with July at $1.17{ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent lower to 3 cents higher with July at $6.02{ a bushel. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures finished 20 cents to 60 cents lower with August at $362.10 a troy ounce; silver was 3.3 cents to 5 cents lower with July at $4.851 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Big Second-Quarter Earnings Drop
DOC.TEXT: Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp. reported a 28 percent drop in second-quarter earnings Thursday, saying high interest rates have hurt its major markets. The supplier of construction and industrial materials said earnings for the quarter ended June 30 totaled $39 million or 92 cents per share, vs. $54 million or $1.28 per share during the year-earlier period. Second-quarter sales totaled $771 million vs. $721 million. The 1990 figures, unlike those of 1989, include results from Fiberglas Canada. ``These results reflect weakness in our major markets, including new housing construction, pleasure boats and automobiles,'' said William W. Boeschenstein, chairman and chief executive officer. ``They are all being hurt by continued high interest rates and cautious consumer buying.'' Owens-Corning said most areas of its Construction Products business were down during the quarter, thanks to declining new housing and commercial construction. But sales of insulation and roofing products for home improvements and remodeling held steady. Sales for the company's Industrial Materials Group were up slightly during the quarter because of the addition of the results from Fiberglas Canada. However, Owens-Corning said demand for industrial materials appeared to be weakening in North America and in Europe. For the first six months, Owens-Corning said earnings totaled $71 million, or $1.68 per share, compared with $89 million, or $2.10 per share, during the first six months of 1989. Sales totaled $1.5 billion vs. $1.4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 9.5 Percent Rise In 2nd Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Houghton Mifflin Co. posted a 9.5 percent rise in second quarter earnings, but the publisher said Thursday its third quarter performance will be crucial to making the year a success. Earnings for the quarter that ended June 30 were $11.5 million, or 81 cents a share, compared with $10.5 million, or 74 cents a share, a year earlier. Net sales of $122.5 million were recorded for the second quarter, a rise of 11 percent over last year's $110.4 million. Houghton Mifflin, best known as a publisher of textbooks, reported a loss for the first half of the year of $554,000, or 4 cents a share. That compared with a loss of $749,000, or 5 cents a share, for the same period in 1989. The results for the first six months of 1990 included a non-recurring net gain of $4 million, or 17 cents a share, after taxes, the company said. First-half sales rose 8 percent to $166.3 million from $154.0 million a year earlier. ``The first-half results were in line with our 1990 business plans, which call for increased revenues and income for the full year,'' Nader Darehshori, chairman and chief executive officer, said in a prepared statement. ``However, school and college textbook sales in the third quarter will be key to full-year results because a large proportion of those materials are ordered for the beginning of the new school year,'' Darehshori said. Stephen Jaeger, senior vice president and chief financial officer of the firm, said a first quarter loss was to blame for the half-year loss. ``In the first quarter of the year our seasonal loss was larger than it had been historically,'' Jaeger said in an interview. The first quarter in the publishing business is always one of little gain while fixed costs must still be paid, he said. ``That loss was right in line with our expectations for the period,'' he said. Houghton Mifflin gets about 80 percent of its income from textbooks, the rest comes from general interest books. Sales in the company's general publishing section rose 33 percent in the second quarter. Educational publishing sales rose 8 percent and sales of elementary and secondary school texts made a strong showing as well, due in large part because some states placed orders earlier than expected. Second-quarter expenses included an increase in the costs of developing new textbooks.

DOC.HEAD: Grumman Chairman O'Brien Resigns, Cites Personal Reasons
DOC.TEXT: Grumman Corp. Chairman John O'Brien has resigned and the defense contractor announced Tuesday it had elected the company's technology chief to take over. O'Brien, 60, resigned as chairman, president, chief executive officer and board member. According to a press release, O'Brien, a 35-year veteran of the company, cited personal reasons. A company spokesman would not elaborate. O'Brien will be available to help in the transition, the company said. Taking his place will be Renso Caporali, 57, the vice chairman for technology. Although the board elected him to the three posts, the board is reviewing candidates for the jobs, including Caporali, said W.B. Jones, a Grumman spokesman. ``My job will be to maintain the course we've set, which includes restructuring the company into a more efficient and cost-competitive form,'' Caporali said. Grumman reported a 22 percent drop in net income for 1989 and said it planned to cut 1,000 jobs by the end of 1990. The cuts come on top of 3,000 work force cuts in 1989 that left the defense contractor with 28,900 employees. Caporali has been with Grumman for 31 years. As vice chairman for technology, he oversaw research and development, engineering and advanced systems.

DOC.HEAD: Hasbro Earnings Down; Mattel Up
DOC.TEXT: Hasbro Inc. on Thursday reported a 52 percent drop in second-quarter earnings because of costs from a dicontinued toy while Mattel Inc. said its profits rose 22 percent.
DOC.HEAD: Hasbro
DOC.TEXT: Hasbro, based in Pawtucket, R.I., said it earned $8.7 million, or 15 cents per share, from April to June. That compared with $18.2 million, or 31 cents per share, during the same 1989 period. Revenue fell 7.8 percent to $277.3 million from $301.4 million. Hasrbo chief financial officer John T. O'Neill said costs associated with the dropped racing car toy Record Breakers hurt earnings. The company also blamed the poor performance on slow domestic sales. For the first six months of 1990, earnings fell 23.6 percent to $28.2 million, or 48 cents per share, from $36.9 million, or 63 cents per share. Half-year revenue was $578.4 million, down from $589.7 million last year. Hasbro is counting on a third-quarter rebound from the introduction of dolls based on the pop music group New Kids on the Block and on performers affiliated with the World Wrestling Federation.
DOC.HEAD: Mattel
DOC.TEXT: Hawthorne, Calif.-based Mattel profits rose on strong international sales of such products as Barbie dolls and Hot Wheels toys. Mattel said it earned $20.3 million, or 40 cents per share, in the second quarter, up from $16.6 million, or 33 cents a share, last year. Sales rose 17 percent to $318 million from $272 million. In the first half of 1990, earnings gained 37 percent to $28.7 million, or 57 cents per share, on sales of $552 million. That compared with 1989 first-half earnings of $20.9 million, or 42 cents per share, on $468 million in sales. The company benefited from increased sales of such core products as Barbie, Hot Wheels, Disney Preschool and Infant Toys, He-Man, large dolls and See'N Say, said John W. Amerman, chairman and chief executive.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: FIXES date in lede
DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Close Mostly Higher
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices closed mostly higher Thursday after a session largely dominated by technical factors. The August contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, rose 44 cents to $18.99 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract fluctuated fom a low of $18.47 to a high of $19.51 during the day as traders sought to profit on the price difference between the August and September contracts. Oil for September delivery closed at $19.86 cents a barrel, up 25 cents. Prices also got a nudge upward from word that the flow of crude through the Alaska pipeline was being reduced, but late profit-taking brought futures down to their closing levels. Greg Dreis, a trader with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures, said there also were rumors in the market for a second day about possible military action between Iraq and Kuwait. Iraq has accused Kuwait of stealing oil worth $2.4 billion from Iraqi territory near their border. Iraq has been campaigning against fellow members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries who have exceeded production limits set by the cartel, especially Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates. OPEC has scheduled a meeting on pricing and production next week. Oil traders, increasingly optimistic that the cartel will be able to curb its production problems, were reluctant to sell heavily Thursday. Prices for refined products traded on the mercantile exchange ended the day mixed. Unleaded regular gasoline for August delivery rose 0.40 cent to 63.07 cents a gallon. The August contract for home heating oil picked up 0.27 cent to close at 56.38 cents a gallon, but subsequent months closed lower. In natural gas trading, the August contract closed at $1.445 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.450 on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Oxy Pete Second Quarter Up 11 percent
DOC.TEXT: Occidental Petroleum Corp. reported an 11 percent rise in second-quarter earnings Thursday, benefiting from the impact of one-time gains that helped offset a big decline in the company's chemical business. Earnings for the three months ended June 30 totaled $89 million or 30 cents a share, up from 80 million or 29 cents a share a year earlier. The per-share figures reflected the issuance of 23 million new shares earlier this year. Sales totaled $5.1 billion, unchanged. The 1990 second-quarter results included an after-tax gain of $41 million from selling some domestic oil and gas properties. They also were helped by a net extraordinary gain of $20 million, due mainly to tax carry forwards. The second quarter of 1989 had included an extraordinary loss of $4 million resulting from paying some debt off early. ``We are pleased that the earnings from our oil and gas, natural gas transmission, agribusiness and coal operations all show improvement,'' Occidental Chairman Armand Hammer said in a statement. But he said chemical operations were suffering from industrywide softness. The unit's earnings declined by $134 million in the quarter. For the six months, earnings totaled $197 million or 67 cents a share, up from $147 million or 53 cents a share a year earlier. Sales totaled $10.28 billion vs. $10.19 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Breeden Defends CFTC Chief, Suggests Deposit Insurance Cap
DOC.TEXT: Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden wound up defending rival regulator Wendy Gramm Thursday to a Senate panel questioning White House commitment to legislation that would shift regulatory control of stock index futures. Breeden also suggested a cap on the deposit insurance system and said a tax on stock transactions could hurt the markets. But the Senate Banking Committee hearing on modernizing financial institutions shifted to pending legislation on stock index futures as several panel members expressed doubts that the administration was really behind the bill. Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., said it looked like a ``cynical political exercise'' by the administration to support the bill. ``And then when it doesn't pass _ and I think right now it's looking very shaky up here _ they can say, `We told you so.' It's just like the S&L scandal. Now it's the Congress' fault.''' Despite officials' claims that the bill must pass, there hasn't been much lobbying by top administration officials, noted Sen. Donald W. Riegle, D-Mich. ``There is not a full-court press going on,'' said Riegle, chairman of the committee. ``In terms of an all-out effort to get this accomplished, I'm not seeing that.'' The legislation would strip the Commodity Futures Trading Commission of authority over stock index futures and transfer it to the SEC. Stock index futures, often used in program trading strategies by large institutional investors such as pension funds, allow investors to trade on the movement of a basket of stocks without having to buy the underlying stocks. Breeden and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady say the SEC should have control over stock index futures to curb extreme volatility. But Wendy Gramm, the CFTC chairman, as well as futures exchanges and CFTC supporters on congressional agriculture committees claim the jurisdiction switch isn't necessary and in fact would hurt the futures markets. When Wirth questioned how Gramm _ a presidential appointee _ could be at odds with administration policy, Breeden found himself in the unusual position of defending his sometime-adversary. ``One should not undercut the ability of the head of an independent agency to express disagreement,'' Breeden said. Asked about a possible tax on securities transactions that White House budget experts have reportedly been kicking around, Breeden said: ``I think we have to be extraordinarily careful in creating taxes on capital formation.'' ``We have to be very careful that we do not take steps which drive trade from our shores,'' he said. Outside the hearing room, Breeden said he has not been privy to White House budget talks and does not know if a transaction tax is still on the table. He also declined to speculate on the fate of the stock index futures bill, although he said he was encouraged by the number of senators at the hearing who expressed a need for reform. In his testimony, Breeden outlined possible reforms of deposit insurance, which many fear could be subject to losses similar to those incurred in the multi-billion dollar savings and loan bailout. He suggested a possible cap on deposit insurance, which now guarantees deposits of up to $100,000 in every account. Breeden said the cap could limit the amount of deposits insured in each account or limit the number of accounts an individual can have insured. He also suggested a system in which consumers would determine how much deposit insurance they want and pay accordingly, much like life insurance. ``I think most taxpayers are showing signs of being irate at having to pay for the losses the savings and loans incurred. I think there will be very strong public support for trimming deposit insurance so that the thrift nightmare cannot be repeated,'' Breeden told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Earnings Up 10 Percent; Razor Sales Strong
DOC.TEXT: Gillette Co. said Thursday that second-quarter earnings rose 10 percent on a big increase in razor sales and strong performance by its European division. For the period ended June 30, the personal care giant reported profits of $379.4 million, or 70 cents per share, up from $344.6 million, or 65 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Sales rose 14 percent to $1.03 billion from $903.9 million for the first three months in 1989. Gillette spokesman David A. Fausch said an across-the-board earnings increase included a 33 percent rise in razor sales. Sales by Braun, Gillette's European division, increased 20 percent. In addition, Gillette shipped almost 17 million of the new Sensor razor since its introduction in January, well ahead of an originally projected 20 million for the year. For the first six months of 1990, Gillette reported net income of $172.8 million, or $1.45 a share, an increase of 7 percent from $162 million, also $1.45 a share, in the same 1989 period. First-half sales rose to $2.08 billion from $1.84 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Unisys Profit Drops Sharply in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Unisys Corp. reported Thursday a 78 percent drop in second quarter profit, while revenues dipped 4 percent. The nation's third-largest computer company said it earned $11.8 million in the quarter, down from $53.6 million in the second quarter of 1989. Unisys officials blamed the results partly on weak domestic sales. Revenue for the quarter totaled $2.47 billion, down from $2.57 billion for the same period last year. After paying $26.9 million in preferred stock dividends, the company lost $15.1 million in the quarter, or 9 cents per share. Analysts said Unisys officials are making slow but steady progress in turning around the company and predicted improvement. ``It was obviously a disappointment, but I think think they'll show results _ a dollar or so _ by the end of the year,'' said William H. Gorman, an analyst for Provident National Bank in Philadelphia. He said benefits from last year's reorganization and work force cuts wouldn't start to show up until the last half of the year. Standard & Poors Corp. said Thursday it had put Unisys' senior and subordinated debt and preferred stock on its Creditwatch list with negative implications. The ratings agency said it is concerned about Unisys's ability to improve profitability and revenues over the long term. Unisys said its worldwide orders posted a slight gain in the quarter as defense orders rebounded from depressed levels a year earlier. Gains in international commercial orders were offset by continued weakness in U.S. orders. ``Our U.S. business remains weak and our international business, while still growing, is not as robust as a year ago,'' said James A. Unruh, president and chief executive officer. Unisys also reduced its debt by $265 million in the quarter, and Unruh said the company made significant progress toward a goal of reducing debt by $600 million to $800 million this year.

DOC.HEAD: Housing Construction Falls to Lowest Level Since 1982
With AM-Economy Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Housing construction fell for a fifth straight month in June, hitting its lowest level since the last recession, the Commerce Department said Wednesday. Analysts said the 2.3 percent decrease in housing starts last month offered disturbing evidence of continued weakness in the overall economy, especially in the housing industry. ``There's still a stranglehold of weak growth, as demonstrated by the housing report,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co. Analysts said the housing industry had been battered by high interest rates, lower income growth and a deterioration in consumer confidence. However, they said the slump may be showing signs of bottoming out. They noted that mortgage rates, which shot up from mid-December to early May, have been falling since that time, giving hope that potential buyers will be attracted back to the market. Also, in one bit of good news in the new report, the government said applications for building permits rose in June for the first time since January. The 3.9 percent increase pushed permit applications to an annual rate of 1.11 million units. ``What has happened here is we've hit a plateau ... We've been able to hang on to a little bit of a ridge on the cliff where we were falling down,'' said Martin Regalia, chief economist for the National Council of Savings Institutions. In June, new homes and apartments were built at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.18 million units, the government said. Last month's decline followed decreases of 0.9 percent in May, 6.9 percent in April, 12.2 percent in March and 5.1 percent in February. It marked the first time housing construction has fallen for five months in a row since a string of declines from July through November in 1981. It pushed the level of building activity to its lowest point since October 1982. Analysts said they do not expect building activity to rebound significantly until a large backlog of unsold homes is worked down. The Bush administration, fearful of the adverse impact that high interest rates were having on the economy, has been pushing the Federal Reserve to loosen its grip on credit. The Fed made a small move in that direction last week. For June, construction of single-family homes edged down a slight 0.1 percent to an annual rate of 892,000 units. Construction of multi-family units fell 8.7 percent to an annual rate of 285,000 units. All geographic areas of the country except the South suffered declines. The weakness was led by a big 10.9 percent drop in the Northeast, while housing starts fell 10.1 percent in the West and 9.2 percent in the Midwest. The South had an 8.7 percent jump to an annual rate of 532,000 units.

DOC.HEAD: Apple Reports 25 Percent Jump In Third-Quarter Profits
DOC.TEXT: Apple Computer Inc., citing good demand and improved gross margins, on Wednesday reported a 25 percent increase in third fiscal quarter profits. Earnings for the three-month period that ended June 29 were $119.8 million, or 96 cents per share, on sales of $1.365 billion. For the same period a year ago, earnings were $96.1 million, or 74 cents per share, on revenues of $1.248 billion. Sales of Apple's high-end, modular Macintosh computer products were strong during the third quarter, and recent ``pricing actions'' on some compact Macintosh computers helped push up demand, John Sculley, Apple's chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement. After several years of rapid growth, Apple's sales have slowed recently, with critics blaming the company's woes on the absence of a cheap Macintosh. In February, the company cut prices on some of its products by up to 17 percent. During the first nine months of the fiscal year, earnings were $376.4 million, 28 percent more than the $293 million earned in the first three months of fiscal 1989. Revenues for the first three quarters rose 8 percent, from $3.9 billion to $4.2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Mack Reports $63 Million Loss; Navistar Expresses Interest
DOC.TEXT: Mack Trucks Inc. reported a $63 million loss in the second quarter Thursday and gained a second suitor _ Navistar International Corp. The interest from Navistar came two weeks after Renault Vehicules Industriels, which owns 44.6 percent of Mack stock, announced it wanted to acquire the Allentown-based truck maker in a buyout of $6 a share. The French automaker said it would spend $98 million for the Mack stock. Navistar spokesman Bill Greenhill said the Chicago-based truck maker has requested additional information from Mack to determine whether to make an offer and at what price. Navistar told Renault it would probably take about 10 days to complete its review and make a decision. In a letter to Mack, Navistar said it would not proceed with the offer without Mack's approval and a decision by the Renault group to sell, Greenhill said. In a statement issued by Renault, the company said it has told Mack's board it has no interest in selling its stake in the truck maker. Renault's offer is due to expire at midnight Aug. 8. Mack's net loss of $63.3 million for the second quarter, or $2.13 per common share, compared to a net loss of $19.6 million, or 66 cents per common share, for the same period last year. The company reported net sales of $400.9 million in the second quarter, down 23 percent from the same period in 1989, when net sales were $518.85 million. In a further complication of Mack's financial situation, Mack Financial Corp. has been trying to extend a $350 million revolving credit agreement with Chemical Bank that matures Friday. Company spokesman James Santanasto said Thursday no extension had been granted but negotiations were continuing. The second-quarter losses were due largely to significant drops in sales and gross margin levels, the company said. Also affecting the results was $21.7 million added to the warranty program, which the company said needed a boost in its reserves because of ``continued unfavorable experience.'' The second quarter results have caused Mack to violate the terms of a $148 million credit agreement with Citibank N.A. and the New York branch of Credit Lyonnais. The violation, if not waived, would permit the banks to accelerate payment on the outstanding principal. Mack, pointing to Renault's offer, has requested a waiver until Dec. 31. Santanasto said Thursday the discussions were continuing.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Pacific Earnings Dip, Reflecting Costs of Great Northern Takeover
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS reports from Champion, Bowater
DOC.TEXT: Georgia-Pacific Corp. reported Thursday its second-quarter earnings declined 38 percent as costs from its takeover of Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. offset strong sales. Other paper companies also reported steep drops in earnings. Bowater Inc., of Darien, Conn., reported 63 percent decline and Stamford, Conn.-based Champion International Corp.'s profit dropped 44 percent. Georgia-Pacific said its net income fell to $107 million, or $1.25 a share, from $172 million, or $1.90 a share, in the same period of 1989. The recent three-month period was the first full quarter in which the two corporations were combined. Georgia-Pacific and Connecticut-based Great Northern agreed in February to a $5 billion merger, creating the nation's largest paper and forest products company. Georgia-Pacific's sales for the quarter totaled $3.5 billion, up from $2.6 billion a year earlier, but the increase was offset by takeover-related interest expenses, the company said. Interest expenses rose to $185 million from $66 million a year ago. Georgia-Pacific Chairman T. Marshall Hahn Jr., in a statement accompanying the earnings report, stressed the sales gains. ``The company's building products business has experienced a record second quarter,'' Hahn said, noting that despite a decline in housing starts the company has benefited from an increased demand for materials used in the remodeling and repair market. Prices for the company's forestry products are up also because of a diminishing supply of timber in the Northwest, he said. The company's pulp and paper divisions have shown gains mainly because of demand for communication papers, Hahn said. For the six months ending June 30, Georgia-Pacific's net income was $208 million or $2.43 per share, down 36 percent from $326 million or $3.55 a share for the first six months of 1989. First-half sales totaled $6.2 billion, up from $5.1 billion during the same period a year earlier.
DOC.HEAD: Champion International Corp.
DOC.TEXT: Champion said its earnings drop was caused by production losses and higher taxes on a Brazilian subsidiary. Champion's after-tax profit for the second quarter was $63 million, or 60 cents per share, compared with $114 million, or $1.16 per share, for the same period last year. The company reported $81.8 million in income from operations for the second quarter, compared with $207.4 million for the second quarter of 1989. The second-quarter figures include $43 million set aside to pay for costs incurred in cutbacks at its Canton, N.C., mill. In addition, Champion had several one-time gains in the second quarter, including $11 million from the sale of a portion of its West Coast Timberlands division, $18 million from the disposal of fixed assets and divested operations and $39 million from the favorable resolution of issues related to the merger with St. Regis Corp. Income dropped at the company's Brazilian subsidiary due to an economic reform package that included higher taxes, the company said.
DOC.HEAD: Bowater Inc.
DOC.TEXT: Bowater Inc. blamed a continued slump in newsprint prices for its earnings drop. Bowater said another factor contributing to the drop was a $9 million, one-time charge to retire 12] percent interest rate bonds. For the second quarter, after-tax profit totaled $14.2 million, or 36 cents per share, on revenue of $342.3 million. That compared to earnings of $38 million, or $1.01 per share, on revenue of $363.6 million for the same period last year. A.P. Gammie, chairman and chief executive officer of Bowater, said he expected newsprint prices to rise in the second half of 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Parliament Wants Saddam to be President for Life
With AM-Kuwait-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's Parliament has proposed that President Saddam Hussein be president for life, the official Iraqi News Agency said Thursday. The 250-member assembly, which has been dominated by the governing Baath Party for the last two decades, on Wednesday ended a special three-day session to debate the new constitution. INA said the assembly proposed changing a new draft constitution that said presidential elections should be held for the first time since Iraq became a republic in 1958, with the head of state serving an eight-year term. Saddam, 54, has said he will run in the election, but so far there has been no mention of any challengers. That was part of a package of political reforms, including a multiparty system and a free press, Saddam promised following the August 1988 cease-fire in Iraq's eight-year war with Iran. These were widely seen as being little more than a nod toward democracy with Saddam staying firmly entrenched in power in this Middle East nation of 17 million people. Saddam has been in absolute control since July 1979, when he took over as president from Gen. Ahmed al Bakr. He served as vice president under Bakr for 10 years and in effect became the strongman of the Baathist regime. INA said the assembly proposed other changes in the draft constitution, but only mentioned the proposal to make Saddam president for life. Under the present constitution, the president is elected by the Revolutionary Command Council composed of senior Baath figures. It will replace the current constitution drawn up in 1968, when the Baath Party seized power in a coup. Iraq's estimated 8 million eligible voters will decide on the new constitution in a nationwide referendum later this year. If Saddam is elected president for life, presumably by the Revolutionary Command Council, it will consolidate his rule over Iraq through his vast security apparatus. The inner circle of the leadership is packed with Saddam's relatives, by blood or marriage, from his extended clan from Takrit in northern Iraq. During the Persian Gulf war, Saddam made his power absolute by imposing tight personal control of the 1 million-strong military and the Baath Party, ostensibly socialist and pan-Arab but now almost devoid of ideology beyond Saddam's policies. He has turned his hold on power into a personality cult. Photos and posters of Saddam are everywhere. It is a capital offense to insult him publicly. Iraqi dissident sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, have claimed in recent weeks that up to 40 senior military figures, including a cousin of Saddam, were arrested and probably executed in Saddam's latest purge. There has been no independent confirmation of the reports. Since the cease-fire, Saddam has revived his ambitions to become the paramount leader of the Arab world and has built up an arsenal of long-range missiles and chemical weapons that has drawn denunciations from the West and Israel. The president-for-life move was reported after Saddam earlier this week accused Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of violating their OPEC oil production quotas and threatened to retaliate with force, if necessary. He blamed them for an oil glut that drove down prices that he claimed has cost Iraq $14 billion in lost revenue in the last year.

DOC.HEAD: Silverado S&L Figure Living in Luxurious Orange County Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT amount of loans to Walters to $106 million sted $96 million. SUBS 18th graf to delete loan amount.
DOC.TEXT: A key figure in the collapse of Silverado Savings & Loan lives in a $1.9 million home despite telling a congressional committee he was broke, a newspaper reported Wednesday. Developer Bill L. Walters, 44, also is a former business associate of Neil Bush, President Bush's son and a former director of Denver-based Silverado. Investigators say Walters' default on $106 million in real estate loans extended by Silverado contributed to the thrift's collapse. A trust for Walters' wife, Jacqueline, purchased the $1.9 million estate near Newport Bay for the couple in February, according to Orange County records reviewed by the Los Angeles Times. State records also show Mrs. Walters bought a mobile home on prime oceanfront property in Laguna Beach for $250,000, the newspaper reported. Federal regulators seized Silverado in December 1988. Its failure is expected to cost taxpayers more than $1 billion. During a House Banking Committee hearing on Silverado's failure, Walters was asked last month about his financial condition. ``I have a negative net worth,'' he testified. Documents filed with the Orange County recorder's office indicate the luxurious Newport Beach home was purchased by the Walters Trust I, of which Jacqueline Walters is the beneficiary. The mobile home in the beachfront El Morro Beach Mobile Home Park also is listed in Mrs. Walters' name, the Times reported. Walters could not be reached immediately for comment Wednesday by The Associated Press. There was no public listing of Walters' residential and business telephone numbers. He moved to Orange County five months ago to begin anew in the real estate business, the Times said. But the Orange County Board of Realtors said Wednesday he was not listed with the organization. Congressmen reacted angrily at word of the home. ``The government should immediately take action to file claims against all of Mr. Walters' property so the taxpayers can get their money back,'' said Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., chairman of the Housing Financial Institutions subcommittee. ``This is what happens when the Bush administration doesn't aggressively go after those who cause the savings and loan fraud,'' said Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., chairman of a House panel overseeing the industry bailout. The Bill L. Walters Co. was one of Denver's largest development firms, employing about 1,000 people. Its holdings included office, retail and hotel buildings and athletic clubs. Neil Bush and Walters were partners in JNB Exploration, an oil exploration company. Walters testified at the hearing that he paid $150,000 in 1983 to own 6 percent of the company while Bush paid $100 to gain an 87.5 percent stake. Bush joined Silverado's board of directors two years later. Documents released last week by federal regulators indicate Bush voted to approve the in loans to Walters. Walters, one of Silverado's preferred shareholders and one of its biggest borrowers, said he would try to pay back the money. ``I have elected to spend the last year and a half working diligently with my lenders, restructuring, staying alive for another day so that I can pay every dime back if I can,'' he said.
